requirements.text:
This document defines the Product Assurance (PA) objectives, policy and rules for the establishment and implementation of a PA programme for DLR projects to ensure the required product quality for the project covering design, development, procurement, manufacturing, integration, test and operations of the contractual items. This document further provides a listing of potential supplier generated PA documents resulting from PA efforts identified in this document (Document Requirements List - DRL).
The description of the required contents of the supplier generated PA documents is provided in detail by a set of DRDs (Document Requirements Definitions) which is contained in the DLR Document ${DRD_DOCID}, Document Requirements Definitions.
The prime objective of PA is to ensure that space products accomplish their defined mission objectives in a safe, available and reliable way.

The prime objective of PA for mission operations is to assure that the space segment and the ground segment accomplish their defined mission objectives and more specifically that they are available and reliable.
Objective is to implement and coordinate an adequate, effective and efficient PA-programme in cooperation with project management and engineering.

The DLR PA policy requires a PA programme derived from a system based and preventive approach and includes:
  • protection of human life, space products and services and environment,
  • definition and maintenance of a project PA function, with appropriate autonomy with respect to other lines and project level organisations,
  • integrated applications of the PA disciplines and coordination with the associated functions of project management and project engineering,
• tailoring of the PA requirements according to project and mission criteria,

• assignment of PA requirements and their control commensurate with the project and mission criticality within the system; integrated PA participation to the overall risk management process,
  • PA contribution to proper control of the technical risks and assuring awareness by the appropriate levels of management,
  • implementation of a preventive approach, i.e. early identification of potential problems and continuous influence on the development process,
  • control of requirements implementation and verification,
  • certification activities on the end product for customer's final acceptance.

Existing and already proven processes, methods, procedures, analyses of relevant previous space projects shall be used. These are subject to be checked for compliance with the project requirements. In order to improve the effectiveness of the PA programme the use of already existing company manuals and procedures is encouraged under the following conditions:
In case of deviations or incompleteness of a company manual or procedure, deviations have to be reported and to be agreed by DLR.

The supplier shall demonstrate compliance of this document with a detailed compliance matrix providing the actual indication of compliance to each paragraph.
When deviation is identified the justification shall be provided.

The PA requirements specified in this document apply to all deliverable
  • HW items,
  • SW items,
  • combinations thereof, and
  • services
as specified by the contract (SOW or 'Leistungsbeschreibung'). During proposal preparation suppliers are encouraged to report to DLR those specific requirements that seem inappropriate, are believed excessive, or are conflicting with other contract requirements.
NOTE:
Nothing in this document shall restrict the rules of the applicable law.
The PA requirements in this document are divided into the following major disciplines:

• PA Management,
  • Quality Assurance (QA),
  • Dependability (Reliability, Availability and Maintainability Assurance),
  • Safety Assurance,

• EEE Parts (Components),
  • Materials, mechanical parts and processes (MMPP),

• SW PA,
  • GSE PA,
• Space Debris Mitigation,
• Planetary Protection,
• Mission Operations.

requirements.text: The following definitions apply to terms used in this document:

Acceptance Authority Media
Devices or media to confirm and document acceptance.
NOTE 1:
Examples of acceptance authority media are stamps, electronic signatures, passwords.
NOTE 2:
Wording adopted from EN 9100.

Analysis
The determination of the essential quality, performance and limitations of an item by cognitive or computational methods.

Boundary scan
Boundary scan is a methodology allowing complete controllability and observability of the boundary pins of a JTAG (Joint Test Action Group)-compatible device via SW control. This capability enables in-circuit testing without the need of in-circuit test equipment.

Certification
Procedure by which a party gives formal assurance that a person or an organization acts, or a product is, in compliance with specified requirements.
NOTE:
Certification can be carried out by a first, second or third party.

Configuration item
Aggregation of HW, SW, processed materials, services or any of its discrete portions, that is designated for CM and treated as a single entity in the CM process.
NOTE:
A configuration item can contain other configuration item(s).

Contract
Legally enforceable business agreement in which payment is part of the conditions.

Component
Set of materials, assembled according to defined and controlled processes, which cannot be disassembled without destroying its capability and which performs a simple function that can be evaluated against expected performance requirements.
NOTE 1:
The term "part" is synonymous.
NOTE 2:
The term "part" is preferred when referring to purely mechanical devices.
NOTE 3:
The term "component" is preferred for EEE devices.

Critical item
Potential threat to the schedule, cost, performance and quality of a project or programme that is controlled by a specific action plan in order to mitigate emanating risks and to prevent undesirable consequences.

Critical mechanical part
Mechanical part that requires specific attention or control due to fracture mechanics aspects and limited life aspects, or with which the supplier has no previous experience of using the mechanical part in the specific application and environment or that is new or non-qualified, or that has caused problems during previous use that remain unresolved.

Critical process
Process new to an individual company or non-verified for the application in question or has caused problems during previous use that remain unresolved.

Critical material
Material that is new to an individual company or non-validated for the particular application and environment, or that has caused problems during previous use that remain unresolved.

Customer
Organization or person that receives a product as part of a business agreement.
NOTE:
A customer can be internal or external to the supplier organization.

Derating
Action when designing a product to limit the component stresses to specified levels that are below their ratings in order to increase its reliability.

Destructive Physical Analysis
DPA comprises series of inspections, tests and analyses performed on a sample of components to verify that the material, design and workmanship used for its construction, as well as the construction itself, meet the requirements of the relevant specification and are suitable for the intended application.

Deviation
Formal authorization to depart from the originally specified requirements for a product, prior to its production.
NOTE:
Waiver is an a posteriori decision whereas deviation is an a priori decision with respect to the production phase.

End Item
Any item defined in the contract as deliverable to DLR.

Electrical and Functional Model (EFM)
EFMs (sometimes called also integration models) are functionally representative of the end products in both electrical and SW terms. They are used for functional and interface tests and for failure mode investigations. Some part can be simulated by SW; the rest is using commercial parts.

Engineering Model (EM)
The EM is flight representative in form, fit and function, without high reliability parts and usually without full redundancy. The EM is used for functional qualification, failure survival demonstration (and parameter drift checking if military parts are used).

Engineering Qualification Model (EQM)
The EQM fully reflects the design of the end product except for the parts standard (military grade parts can be used instead of high reliability parts, provided they are procured from the same manufacturer).

Existing SW
Any SW developed outside the agreement to which this requirements catalogue is applicable, including SW from previous developments provided by the supplier, SW from previous developments provided by the customer, COTS, OTS and MOTS SW, freeware and open source SW.

Fail Safe
Preventing the failure of an item from resulting in catastrophic or critical consequences.

Hazardous event
Mishap resulting from a hazard.

Hazard
Existing or potential condition that can result in a mishap.
NOTE 1:
This condition can be associated with the design, manufacturing, operation or environment.
NOTE 2:
Hazards are not events but potential threats to safety.

Inspectability
The ability to be inspected.

Joint Test Action Group (JTAG)
A standard specifying how to control and monitor the pins of compliant devices on a PCB. JTAG is a standard interface used for in-system testing and debugging.

Launch vehicle
See "launcher".

Launcher
Vehicle designed to transport payloads to space.
NOTE:
The term "launch vehicle" is synonymous.

Limited Life Item
Any item which deteriorates with the passage of time and thus requires periodic replacement, refurbishment, retesting, or operation to assure that its operating characteristics have not degraded beyond acceptable limits. This includes installed as well as stored items.

Material
Raw, semi-finished or finished substance (gaseous, liquid, solid) of given characteristics from which processing into a component or part is undertaken.

Milestone
Any significant event during the execution of a project, which can allow assessment of work progress.

MPCB Material, Mechanical Parts and Process Control Board
is implemented to review and approve the selection and the use of materials, mechanical parts and processes.

NC
Non-fulfilment of a requirement.
NOTE:
The term "nonconformity" is synonymous but deprecated.

Part
See "component".

Parts Control Board (PCB)
is implemented for approval of the selection and usage of EEE parts and is held between the customer and the supplier (or lower-tier subcontractor).

Process
Set of interrelated or interacting activities which transform inputs into outputs.
NOTE:
Inputs to a process are generally outputs of other processes.

Producibility
The ability to be manufactured.

Product
Result of a process.
NOTE 1:
There are four generic product categories:
  • services (e.g. transport),
  • SW (e.g. computer program, dictionary),
  • HW (e.g. engine mechanical part),
  • processed materials (e.g. lubricant).
Many products comprise elements belonging to different generic product categories. Whether the product is then called service, SW, HW or processed material depends on the dominant element. For example the offered product "automobile" consists of HW (e.g. tyres), processed materials (e.g. fuel, cooling liquid), SW (e.g. engine control SW, driver's manual), and service (e.g. operating explanations given by the salesman).
NOTE 2:
Service is the result of at least one activity necessarily performed at the interface between the supplier and customer and is generally intangible. Provision of a service can involve, for example, the following:
  • an activity performed on a customer-supplied tangible product (e.g. automobile to be repaired),
  • an activity performed on a customer-supplied intangible product (e.g. the income statement needed to prepare a tax return),
  • the delivery of an intangible product (e.g. the delivery of information in the context of knowledge transmission),
  • the creation of ambience for the customer (e.g. in hotels and restaurants).
SW consists of information and is generally intangible and can be in the form of approaches, transactions or procedures. HW is generally tangible and its amount is a countable characteristic. Processed materials are generally tangible and their amount is a continuous characteristic. HW and processed materials often are referred to as goods.
NOTE 3:
QA is mainly focused on intended product. [ISO 9000:2015]

Programme (also space programme)
Group of projects managed in a coordinated way to obtain benefits not available from managing them individually.

Protoflight model (PFM)
Flight modelon which a partial or complete protoflight qualification testcampaign is performed before flight.
NOTE:
More detailed information on the build standard and the use of this model is given in ECSS-E-HB-10-02.

Qualification Model (QM)
The QM fully reflects the end product design in all aspects.

Reliability
The ability of an item to perform a required function under given conditions for a given time interval.
NOTE 1:
It is generally assumed that the item is in a state to perform this required function at the beginning of the time interval.
NOTE 2:
Generally, reliability performance is quantified using appropriate measures.

Reliability Assessment
An evaluation of reliability of a system or portion thereof. Such assessments employ mathematical modelling, directly applicable results of tests on system HW, estimated reliability figures, and non-statistical engineering estimates to ensure that all known potential sources of unreliability have been evaluated.

Repair
Action to correct a defect of a product that leads to a configuration item change.
NOTE 1:
Unlike rework, repair affects or modifies parts of the defective product.
NOTE 2:
An NCR needs to be raised for the CI change.

Repeatability
The ability to be repeated.

Rework
Action to correct a defect of a product that does not lead to a configuration item change
NOTE 1:
Unlike repair, rework does not affect or modify parts of the defective product.
NOTE 2:
No NCR needs to be raised.

Request for Approval (RFA)
Document with which the supplier or user asks the competent body for permission to use a critical material, part or process.

Request for Waiver (RFW)
Document with which the supplier or user asks the competent body for permission to use or release a product that does not conform to specified requirements.
NOTE:
A waiver is generally limited to the delivery of a product that has nonconforming characteristics within specified limits for an agreed period of time or quantity of that product.

Shelf-Life
The total period of time beginning with the date of manufacture, date of cure (e.g. for elastomeric and rubber products), date of assembly, or date of pack, and terminated by the date by which an item must be used (expiration date) or subjected to inspection, test, restoration, or disposal action.

Single Point Failure (SPF)
Part of a product that, if it fails, will result in the unrecoverable failure of that product.

SW product
Set of computer programs, procedures, documentation and their associated data.

Space debris
Non-functional fragments of, or residue from, a space segment element, or launch segment element, in Earth orbit or re-entering the Earth's atmosphere.
NOTE:
The term "orbital debris" is synonymous, but deprecated.

Special process
Process where quality cannot be completely ensured by visual inspection of the end article only.

Supplier
Organization or person that provides a product as part of a business agreement.
NOTE:
A supplier can be internal or external to the customer organization.

Testability
The ability to be tested.

Waiver (RFW)
Formal authorization to accept products which during production, or after having been submitted to inspection or tests, are found to depart from specified requirements.
NOTE:
Deviation is an a priori decision whereas waiver is an a posteriori decision with respect to the production phase.

Zonal Analysis
Zonal analysis is the systematic inspection of the topology of a system, the evaluation of potential component to component interactions with and without failure, and the assessment of the severity of potential hazards inherent in the system installation.

Please note that for the project specifically tailored requirement catalogue the numbering of requirements and chapters might not always be continuous. There might be gaps in the continuous numeration. These gaps are intentionally and caused by requirements which are tailored out, as not applicable. It was decided to have the fixed numbering of requirements to allow for a general electronic handling of compliances in Systems as e.g. DOORs in project-independent approaches.

Please note, that the tailored requirements catalogue is based on a general catalogue, which mainly addresses the development, build-up and qualification/verification/acceptance of space segment hardware in Phase 0 - D, similar to the ECSS Standards which are referenced. In consequence, especially for Phase E & F as well as for the Ground Segment the requirements shall be applied only for the relevant aspects of the Hard- and Software of this Project Phase as well as their development, build-up and qualification/verification/acceptance.

Any requirements imposed by the certifying authority of safety, IT- & Software-Security or Space Debris Mitigation might be subject to change by the certifying authority in the course of the project. The Project is obliged to comply with the respective, currently valid requirements to be able to be certified.

The requirements shall not overrule or invalidate any national or international regulations or laws applicable. These regulations and laws, as any other applicable other applicable statutory regulations, shall remain fully applicable.
The supplier shall identify the personnel responsible for implementing and performing PA management and other PA disciplines.
The supplier shall assign a project PA manager reporting to the project manager and having unimpeded access to higher management.
The appointed project PA manager, irrespective of other responsibilities, shall have organizational authority to establish and implement a PA programme in accordance with the project PA requirements.
The project PA manager shall act as the focal point of contact within the project concerning PA matters.

All PA related communication between higher levels and the suppliers, and vice versa, shall be directed to the respective PA manager. Focal point of all PA related correspondence with DLR shall be the DLR PA manager.
The supplier shall define and document the responsibility, the authority and the interrelation of personnel who manage, perform and verify work affecting PA.
The supplier shall define and document the responsibilities and the interfaces of the PA functions, either external or internal, involved in a project.

When the supplier´s PA organization delegates PA tasks to another organization it shall be done in a documented and controlled way monitored by the PA organization.
NOTE:
The supplier PA organization retains the responsibility towards the customer.
The supplier shall identify the PA resources needed to implement the PA programme.
The supplier shall provide resources capable to perform the PA tasks identified in the PA programme.
Reviews and audits of the PA programme, of processes or of product shall be carried out by personnel not directly involved in the work being performed.
The PA manager shall interface with project management, ensuring that the contractual provision and schedule planning for the definition and phasing of PA activities are met.
The PA manager shall interface with risk management, CM, engineering, procurement and AIV for the definition and execution of tasks in which PA activities are involved.
The supplier PA manager shall interface with the customer PA manager regarding all PA matters.
The PA manager shall interface with lower-tier suppliers regarding all PA matters.
Suppliers shall impose these requirements upon their lower-tier suppliers. The requirements shall be tailored as appropriate to the procured item.
The supplier shall prepare, maintain and implement a plan of the PA activities in accordance with the customer PA requirements.
The PA plan shall be prepared in conformance with DRD-2.01.

The PA plan shall be submitted to the customer for acceptance.
NOTE 1:
The PA plan can refer to clauses of the Company Quality Manual and to in-house procedures.
NOTE 2:
Information on the schedule for delivery of PA management documents is given in para. 13, PA Document Requirement List (DRL).
Lower-tier suppliers PA plans, if any, shall be provided to DLR for review on request.
The PA manager shall ensure that PA disciplines are organized at the beginning of the project according to customer contractual requirements.
The PA manager shall ensure that the inputs used by the PA disciplines are consistent and complete, and available in line with the project schedule.
The PA manager shall ensure that the PA disciplines perform the tasks described in the PA Plan in line with the project schedule.
The PA manager shall ensure that the outputs produced by the PA disciplines are consistent and complete, and delivered in line with the project schedule.
The PA manager shall ensure the application of processes defined in applicable project plans and documents.

The PA manager shall control the quality of his supplier´s products by:
  1. ensuring that the DLR project PA requirements are tailored down to lower level suppliers,
  2. issuing PA requirements applicable to the supplier,
  3. ensuring the implementation of the PA requirements by the supplier.
The PA manager shall ensure that PA contributions to verification are defined and provided.
The PA manager shall ensure that a qualification programme is defined, approved and maintained by the relevant organization.
The PA manager shall ensure that the qualification programme is implemented and the qualification results are recorded, evaluated and documented.
The PA manager shall ensure that a Qualification Status List of the programme items is maintained in conformance with DRD-2.02.

requirements.text: The PA manager shall review and approve the achieved qualification status.

The PA manager shall approve the product acceptance during the Acceptance or Delivery Review.
NOTE:
The PA manager approval is based on the outputs of the Acceptance or Delivery Review.

For launch segment perimeter, the PA manager shall ensure that qualification certificates, identifying the qualified configuration, are issued for all ground and flight programme items in accordance with DRD-2.05.
For launch segment perimeter, the PA manager and the project manager shall sign and approve these certificates.
The supplier shall report on the status and progress of the PA program implementation according to DRD-2.03.

requirements.text:
The PA progress report may be part of the project progress report.
NOTE:
The general contents of the project progress report are detailed in ECSS-M-ST-10, Annex E.

requirements.text:
The supplier shall perform audits on his own performance to verify the implementation and effectiveness of the provisions defined in the PA plan.
NOTE 1:
Audits can be performed by sampling on various projects or by periodic audits of the supplier quality system.
NOTE 2:
The general contents of project audits are detailed in ECSS-M-ST-10 clause 5.2.3.
