requirements.text: The supplier shall ensure that packaging materials, methods, procedures and instructions provide for protection of items while at the supplier's plant, during transportation, and after their arrival at destination.
The supplier shall ensure that appropriate marking and labelling for packaging, storage, transportation and shipping of items are performed in accordance with the applicable specifications.
The identification label shall be legible with unaided eye from 0.5 m distance.
The identification label shall meet all the requirements applicable to the item.

The supplier shall ensure that the items to be shipped from his plant are inspected before release and found to be complete, adequately preserved and packaged, correctly marked and accompanied by all the required documentation.

Accompanying documentation shall include the EIDP and, attached to the outside of the shipping container, the handling and packing or unpacking procedure and any relevant safety procedures.
The supplier shall make provisions for the prevention of damage to items during transportation.

The supplier shall take into consideration all special requirements imposed by the launch authority. The supplier can either use appropriate industrial, national or international rules and procedures, or if none of the latter is suitable, he can draft his own documents.

The supplier shall take into consideration all special requirements e.g. especially language of labelling and marking for Russian flights. The supplier can either use appropriate industrial, national or international rules and procedures, or if none of the latter is suitable, he can draft his own documents.
The supplier shall establish and implement procedures for handling and storage of components in order to prevent possible degradation.

As a minimum, the following areas shall be covered:
  • control of the environment
  • prohibited materials
  • personnel access rules
  • prohibited personnel actions
  • measures and facilities to segregate and protect components during receiving inspection, storage, and delivery to maintenance.
  • control measures to ensure that electrostatic discharge susceptible components are identified and handled only by trained personnel
The objective of dependability engineering is to ensure a successful mission by optimizing the system dependability within all competing technical and financial constraints.

Dependability assurance is a continuous and iterative process throughout the project life cycle:
  • supporting design rules, dependability analyses and risk reducing actions are tailored with respect to an appropriate severity categorisation,
  • initiating risks reducing actions are implemented continuously since the early phase of a project and especially during the design phase and, if so, also for serial production activities.
NOTE:
For details on dependability analysis see para. 4.10.3.
The supplier shall coordinate, implement and integrate the dependability programme management with the PA programme management.

The supplier shall develop, maintain, and implement a dependability plan for all programme phases. The plan shall address the applicable requirements of this document.
NOTE:
The plan can be included in the PA programme plan (see para. 2.1.3).
The establishment and implementation of the dependability programme plan shall be considered in conjunction with the safety aspects of the programme.
The supplier shall ensure that any potential conflict between dependability and safety requirements are managed.
Responsibilities for carrying out all dependability tasks within each phase of the lifecycle shall be defined.

As part of the risk management process implemented on the project, the supplier shall be responsible for identifying and reporting dependability associated risks.
NOTE:
ECSS-M-ST-80C describes the risk management process.

applicableDocuments.title: ECSS-M-ST-80
applicableDocuments.description: Risk Management (31 July 2008)

requirements.text:
Dependability risk analysis reduction and control shall include the following steps:
  1. identification and classification of undesirable events according to the severity of their consequences,
  2. analysis of failure scenarios, determination of related failure modes, failure origins or causes,
  3. classification of the criticality of the functions and associated products according to the severity of relevant failure consequences,
  4. definition of actions and recommendations for detailed risk assessment, risk elimination, or risk reduction and control to an acceptable level,
  5. status of risk reduction and risk acceptance,
  6. implementation of risk reduction,
  7. verification of risk reduction and assessment of residual risks.
NOTE:
The process of risk identification and assessment implies both qualitative and quantitative approaches.
Risk reduction measures that are proposed for dependability shall be assessed at system level in order to select the optimum solution to reduce the system level risk.
Each dependability CI shall be documented in CIL (DRD-2.04).

  2. a failure mode is classified as CN greater or equal to 6 in conformance with table 4-1.

requirements.text:
Dependability CIs shall be identified by dependability analyses performed to support the risk reduction and control process performed on the project.
NOTE:
The criteria for identifying dependability CIs to be included in the CIL are given in para. 4.5.1 (Dependability CIL).
Dependability CIs, as part of the CIs List, shall be subject to risk assessment and CIs control in conformance with para. 2.2.4.

requirements.text:
The control measures shall include:
  • a review of all design, manufacturing and test documentation related to critical functions, CIs and procedures,

• dependability representation on relevant review boards to ensure that the disposition takes account of their criticality level.
    NOTE:
    It is recommended to have dependability representation also in MRR, TRR.
The dependability aspects shall be considered during the entire verification process for dependability CIs until close out.
The justification for retention of each dependability CI shall be subject o approval by the customer.

NOTE:
Potential RAMS CIs are:

• item constituting a residual single-point failure (SPF),
  • fracture CI (pressure vessel, structural item whose failure can result in catastrophic or critical consequences),
  • limited-life and limited-cycle item (item with useful life duration or operating cycles limitation; item prone to wear out, drift or degradation below minimum required performance in less than the storage and mission time),
  • item not meeting applicable derating requirements,
  • item considered critical at the conclusion of the WCA,
• item not meeting the applicable failure tolerance requirement,
• items sensitive to environmental exposure (e.g. vibration, acceleration, thermal, chemical, radiation),
• items whose failures are not readily detectable (no methods of generating a system advisory or providing a visible indicator) by the flight or ground crew during any mission phase.

The supplier shall ensure that all dependability data for a design review are presented to the customer in accordance with the project review schedule.

All dependability data submitted shall indicate the design baseline and shall be coherent with all other supporting technical documentation.

All design changes shall be assessed for their impact on dependability and a reassessment of the dependability shall be performed.

chapters.name: Integration of Dependability in the Project

requirements.text: Manufacture, assembly, integration, test and operations shall not degrade dependability attributes introduced into the design.

The dependability requirements specification shall be part of the overall project requirements.

Dependability requirements shall be apportioned, in a top-down process, to establish dependability requirements for lower level elements.

Dependability requirements shall be applied during the preparation and review of design and test specifications.

The dependability requirements shall be included into the technical specifications.
The technical specification is an engineering document and typically includes w.r.t ECSS-E-ST-10-06 (for information):

• functional, operational and environmental requirements,
  • test requirements including stress levels, test parameters, and accept/reject criteria,
  • design performance margins, derating factors, quantitative dependability requirements, and qualitative dependability requirements (identification and classification of undesirable events), under specified environmental conditions,
  • the identification of human factors and how they can influence dependability during the project lifecycle,
  • the identification of external, internal and installation factors that can influence dependability during the project lifecycle,
  • the degree of tolerance to HW failures or SW malfunctions,
  • the detection, isolation, diagnosis, and recovery of the system from failures and its restoration to an acceptable state,
  • the requirement for the prevention of failures crossing interfaces with unacceptable consequences,

• requirements for process and technology margin demonstration and qualification,
  • requirement on sampling strategy in serial production and for periodical demonstration of qualification preservation,
• definition of the maintenance concept,
• maintenance tasks and requirements for special skills,
• requirements for preventive maintenance, special tools, and special test equipment.
The dependability characteristics shall be traded off with other system attributes such as mass, size, cost and performance during the optimization of the design in all phases of the project.

The contractor shall develop and implement design criteria to improve reliability.
In establishing reliability the contractor shall use data obtained from previous programmes when appropriate data is available. The contractor shall ensure that reliability is built into the design using fault tolerance and design margins.

He shall assess the failure characteristics of systems to identify areas of design weakness and propose corrective solutions.

The contractor shall develop and implement design criteria to facilitate maintenance actions in predicted environments.

In establishing maintainability design criteria, the contractor shall use data obtained from previous programmes when appropriate data is available.
The supplier shall develop and implement specific design criteria to ensure that no failure will propagate to any interfacing HW or SW element.

A severity classification (either severity name or level) shall be assigned in accordance with table 4-2 to each identified failure mode analysed according to the failure effect (consequence).
NOTE:
The severity categories are common to dependability and safety. The table 4-2 is common to ECSS-Q-ST-30 and ECSS-Q-ST-40 (as table 6-1), which address respectively the dependability and safety types of consequences.

Severity categories shall be assigned without consideration of existing compensating provisions to provide a qualitative measure of the worst potential consequences resulting from item failure.

For analyses lower than system level, the severity due to possible failure propagation shall be identified as level 1 for dependability.

NOTE:
For example, for analysis at subsystem, and equipment level.

The number identifying the severity category shall be followed by a suffix to indicate either redundancy (R) single point failures (SP) or safety hazards (SH). An understanding to these criteria identified in table 4-2 shall be agreed between customer and supplier.

SYSTEM LEVEL FMECA

Catastrophic

Loss of an interfacing manned flight system.

Critical
2

The safety severity levels are identified in SSP 51721 DC004 for ISS payloads.
NOTE:
Additional information can be taken from NASA RISE programme results.

applicableDocuments.title: SSP 51721
applicableDocuments.description: Payload Safety Policy and Requirements for the International Space Station, DCN 004 (09-February-2016)

requirements.text: Failure tolerance requirements shall be defined in the performance specifications.

The performance specification (technical specification) of the system shall comprise the following failure tolerance requirements by word or in sense:
  • No single failure or operator error shall have critical (or catastrophic) consequences.
  • No combinations of failures, operator errors, or combinations thereof shall have catastrophic consequences.
The verification of the failure tolerance shall address all failure modes whose severity of consequence is classified as catastrophic, critical and major.
The safety failure tolerance requirements of para. 5.8.2.3.1 and para. 5.9.2 shall be considered.
A redundancy concept should be established under consideration of the performance, lifetime, weight or power constraints.
Redundancy shall be incorporated within the design to eliminate the SPFs (as defined in para. 4.8.4.3) to the extent possible, or if necessary to achieve the overall system reliability requirements.
The specified function and performance of each redundant element shall be capable of being measured during specified test phases.
Redundancies shall be provided for functional items to be in compliance with the SPF requirements (see para. 4.8.4.3).

A single failure shall not propagate outside a single reconfigurable element. Redundant functions shall be routed separately. The former provision should be met via redundant harness and physically separated connectors. Redundant functions shall be physically separated with no risk of failure propagation by thermal or other coupling and as a minimum, contained within a different package to avoid failure propagation.
NOTE:
E.g. within hybrid and integrated circuit.

For redundant functions implemented on the same PCB, a physical separation shall be provided, with no risk of thermal or other failure propagation.

NOTE:
Example of physical separation are by a minimum distance, insulation, or cut-out.

For redundant functions implemented on the same PCB, any deviation of the physical separation specified in the provision before shall be tracked in the CIL. For hybrids, redundant and protection functions shall be located in a different cavity. In case a cold redundant function is simultaneously activated together with the nominal one, by a deliberate or wrong command or due to a fault, this shall not induce permanent degradation of either of the two functions or loss of the mission before FDIR action.

NOTE:
E.g. thermal and EMC functions.

In the case of hot redundant essential functions, either latching protection shall not be used, or it shall have an autonomous periodic reset.

requirements.text:
The effectiveness of redundancy shall be supported by application of general redundancy techniques as stated below unless otherwise specified by the contract:
  • where two or more wires are provided to meet the derating requirements of para. 4.11.2.11 and the loss of a single wire would not violate the manufactures nominal rating, this may be counted as a redundancy,
  • redundant and back-up wires/cables shall be routed in different bundles and through separate connectors,
  • redundant functions shall not be supplied from the same power source as the primary function,
  • components of redundant circuits (terminals, circuit breakers, relays etc.) shall be independent (not shared) from the components used in the primary circuit.

Further techniques are given in documents ECSS-E-ST-10, and ECSS-E-ST-20.

requirements.text: The proposed design shall be evaluated, and the respective maintainability aspects shall be considered.

The maintainability design criteria such as accessibility, reparability, limited life, fault detection/isolation capability etc. shall be used during item selection, design application, trade-offs and design reviews.

Consideration shall be given to spare parts and storage time on the ground. Where special environmental conditions are required during storage, they shall be compatible with the overall project requirements and constraints.

The design of the system shall be such that any SPF shall be avoided. It is the responsibility of the supplier to select adequate analytical techniques to identify the SPFs and to make the necessary actions to reduce the SPFs as far as practicable.
All SPFs shall be identified and summarised in the CIL (DRD-2.04, see para. 2.2.4).

chapters.name: Use of Previously Designed, Fabricated or Flown Equipment

requirements.text: Where the contractor proposes to take advantage of previously designed, manufactured qualified or flown elements in his system, he shall demonstrate that the proposed elements do conform to the dependability assurance requirements of the design specification. NCs to dependability assurance requirements shall be identified and the rationale for retention of unresolved NCs shall be provided by a RFW in accordance with requirements in para. 3.5.8.

drds.deliveryDate: initial written report, latest 3 working days after detection of non-conformance; to be provided for Control Boards as affected

requirements.text:
In order to implement dependability aspects into the design, the following approaches shall apply as appropriate to system and equipment level:
  1. functional design:
    • the preferred use of SW designs or methods that have performed successfully in similar applications,
    • the implementation of failure tolerance,
    • the implementation of fault detection, isolation and recovery, allowing proper failure processing by dedicated flight and ground measures, and considering detection or reconfiguration times in relation with propagation times of events under worst case conditions,
    • the implementation of monitoring of the parameters that are essential for mission performance, considering the failure modes of the system in relation to the actual capability of the detection devices, and considering the acceptable environmental conditions to be maintained on the product.
  2. physical design:
    • the application of proven design rules,
    • the selective use of designs that have performed successfully in the same intended mission environment,
    • the selection of parts having a quality level in accordance with project specification,
    • the use of EEE parts derating and stress margins for mechanical parts,
    • the use of design techniques for optimising redundancy (while keeping system design complexity as low as possible),
    • the assurance that built-in equipment can be inspected and tested,
    • the provision of accessibility to equipment.
NOTE:
Functional design is intended to imply non-physical design which includes SW.

chapters.name: Classification of Critical Functions and Products

requirements.text:
During the preliminary design phase, the supplier shall classify functions in accordance with their criticality.

The classification of the functions, as per requirement before, shall be submitted to the customer for approval.

NOTE:
The function criticality is documented by FMEA, i.e. by the attributed severity category assigned to the consequences of the functional failure.

The criticality of functions shall be directly related to the severity of the consequences resulting from failure of the function as defined in table 4-3.

The highest identified severity of failure consequences shall determine the criticality of the function.

NOTE:
Failures can result from a function not executed or executed degraded, incorrectly, untimely, out of the specified time interval, out of sequence or inadvertently.

The function criticality shall be assigned according to the categories of table 4-3, without taking into account any compensating provisions.

NOTE:
Continuing functional decomposition into lower-level functions, to distinguish between functions that could lead to different feared events, is not considered as creating compensating provisions.

Table 4-3: Criticality of functions

Severity Function criticality Criteria to assign criticality categories to functions
Catastrophic (Level 1) I A function that if not or incorrectly performed, or whose anomalous behaviour can cause one or more feared events resulting in catastrophic consequences
Critical (Level 2) II A function that if not or incorrectly performed, or whose anomalous behaviour can cause one or more feared events resulting in critical consequences
Major (Level 3) III A function that if not or incorrectly performed, or whose anomalous behaviour can cause one or more feared events resulting in major consequences
Minor or Negligible (Level 4) IV A function that if not or incorrectly performed, or whose anomalous behaviour can cause one or more feared events resulting in minor or negligible consequences

The criticality of HW and operations shall be determined in accordance with the highest criticality of functions implemented.

NOTE:
For the criticality categorization of SW, see clause 8.6.2.2.

The criticality classification shall be used to focus efforts on the most critical areas during the project phases.

chapters.name: Identification and Classification of Undesirable Events

requirements.text:
The supplier shall identify undesirable events that lead to the loss or degradation of product performances, together with their classification into categories related to the severity of their failures consequences (see Table 4-2 of para. 4.8.2). Preliminary identification and classification of undesirable events shall be determined from analysis of criteria for mission success, during conceptual and preliminary design phases. All undesirable events, whose occurrence can jeopardize, compromise, or degrade the mission success shall be assessed at the highest product level (overall system including space and ground segments).The undesirable events, at lower levels of the product tree, shall be the product failure effects which can induce the undesirable events identified for the highest product level.
NOTE:
For example, at space segment, ground segment, subsystem, and equipment level.

Identification and classification of undesirable events shall be finalised after assessment of failure scenarios (see para. 4.10.2).

The supplier shall analyse the possible scenarios leading to the occurrence of undesirable events.

The supplier shall identify failure modes, failure origins and causes, detailed failure effects leading to undesirable events.

chapters.name: Dependability Analyses and the Project Life Cycle

requirements.text: Dependability analyses shall be performed on all space projects throughout the project life cycle to support the tasks and requirements specified in para. 4.7.
The analyses shall be performed to support the conceptual, preliminary and detailed development and optimization of the design, including the testing phase that leads to design qualification.

Dependability analyses shall be implemented in order to :
  • ensure conformance to reliability, availability and maintainability requirements, and
  • to identify all potential failure modes and technical risks with respect to functional requirements that can lead to noncompliance to the dependability requirements,
  • provide inputs to risk assessment and risk reduction and their control measures in line with the risk management process implemented on the project,
  • provide inputs to the project CI control process.

The results of dependability analyses shall be incorporated into the DJF in order to support the rationale for the selection of the design solution, and the demonstration that the design meets the dependability requirements.
The analyses shall comprise electronic equipment, as well as mechanical elements. The depth of analyses is dependent on the mission criticality and complexity of the unit functions.

The analyses shall be performed for the level(s) and project phases indicated in the Table(s) below.
The project phases in the last column of the Table are:

Reliability Analyses on Equipment Level
Task Purpose Output Project Phase

Reliability Prediction Verification of reliab. requirements. Identification of weak points in the equipment Equipment reliability report
(Part Count / Part Stress Prediction)		 BC

Reliability Prediction Verification of reliab. requirements. Identification of weak points in the equipment Equipment reliability report
(Part Count Prediction)		 BC
Parts Derating Analysis Verification of appropriate design margins (derating) versus stress levels of EEE Parts Derating analysis report/parts application review C
Worst Case Analysis (WCA) Demonstrate that the performance is within specification despite particular variations in its constituent part parameters and the imposed environment. WCA report C

FMECA Identification of SPFs and mission critical interference with other equipment or sub-systems FMECA report. List of SPFs and mission critical elements and their probability of their occurrence. Definition of remedy actions and/or control provisions BC
Common Cause Analysis Identification of the root cause of failures Report/Analysis can be accomplished as part of FMEA/FMECA or FTA C

Reliability Analyses on Sub-System Level
Task Purpose Output Project Phase
Reliability Apportionment Assignment of reliability design goals to equipment level Design goal definition in equipment specification B
Reliability Prediction Verification of reliability requirements. Identification of weak points in the sub-system design Sub-System reliability report BC

FMECA Bottom-up identification of SPFs and mission critical failure modes and compensation methods FMECA report. List of SPFs and evaluation of probability of their occurrence, assessment of failure effects. Definition of remedy actions and/or control provisions BC
Fault Tree Analysis (FTA) Top-down identification of possible mal-functions and mission critical failure propagation paths FTA report and proposed remedy actions BC
Common Cause Analysis Identification of the root cause of failures Report/Analysis can be accomplished as part of FMEA/FMECA or FTA C
Zonal Analysis Evaluation of potential subsystem-to-subsystem interactions with and without failure Analysis can be accomplished as part of FMEA/FMECA or FTA BC

Hardware Software Interaction Analysis (HSIA) To verify that SW is specified to react to HW failures as required Analysis shall be performed concurrently with the FMECA for all HW products involving SW C

Reliability Analyses on System Level
Task Purpose Output Project Phase
Reliability Apportionment Assignment of reliability design goals to system level Design goal definition to system specification B
Reliability Prediction Verification of customer design requirements. Identification of weak points in the system design System reliability report BC

FMECA Bottom-up identification of SPFs, mission critical failures and compensation methods. Identification of weak points in the system design FMECA report. List of SPFs and evaluation of probability of their occurrence, assessment of failure effects. Definition of remedy actions and/or control provisions BC
Fault Tree Analysis (FTA) Top-down identification of possible mal-functions and mission critical failure propagation paths FTA report and definition of remedy actions and/or control provisions BC
Common Cause Analysis Identification of the root cause of failures Report/Analysis can be accomplished as part of FMEA/FMECA or FTA C
Zonal Analysis Evaluation of potential subsystem-to-subsystem interactions with and without failure Analysis can be accomplished as part of FMEA/FMECA or FTA BC

Hardware Software Interaction Analysis (HSIA) To verify that SW is specified to react to HW failures as required Analysis shall be performed concurrently with the FMECA for all HW products involving SW C

Derating Analysis Summary To verify that lower level product tree items provide a derating analysis summary and all derating analysis of PCBAs within the flight system or flight sub-system are available and compliant to projects derating requirements. Derating analysis summary report C

Worst Case Analyses (WCA) Summary To verify that product tree items provide WCAs to demonstrate that their performance is within specification despite particular variations in its constituent part parameters and the imposed environment. WCA summary report C

Dependability analyses shall be conducted on all levels of the space system and be performed in respect of the level that is being assessed i.e. system, subsystem and equipment levels.
NOTE:
The main purpose of all dependability analyses is to improve the design by providing timely feedback to the designer, to reduce risks within the processes used to realize the products and to verify conformance to the specified dependability requirement.
Depending on the complexity of the system, the supplier shall use various established analytical techniques, to demonstrate the system inherent reliability, such as:
• Reliability Apportionment and Reliability Prediction (part count technique), see para. 4.11.2.1.1 and 4.11.2.1.4,
• Reliability Prediction (part stress technique), see para. 4.11.2.1.5,
• Derating Analysis, see para. 4.11.2.11,
• WCA, see para. 4.11.2.10,
• FMECA, see para. 4.11.2.5,
• FTA , see para. 4.11.2.8,
• Zonal Analysis see para. 4.11.2.12,

• HW-SW Interaction Analysis (HSIA), see para. 4.11.2.6,
    NOTE:
    HSIA can be included in the FMEA/FMECA (refer to ECSS-Q-ST-30-02).

applicableDocuments.title: ECSS-Q-ST-30-02
applicableDocuments.description: Failure modes, effects (and criticality) analysis (FMEA/FMECA) (6 March 2009)

requirements.text:
• Common-cause Analysis, see para. 4.11.2.9,
    NOTE:
    The analyses can be accomplished as part of FMEA/FMECA or FTA.
• Availability Analysis see para. 4.11.2.14.

The first step in the design process shall be to translate the overall system reliability requirement into reliability requirements for each subsystem. The reliability parameters apportioned to the subsystems are used as guidelines to determine design feasibility.

If the allocated reliability for a specific subsystem cannot be achieved at the current state of technology, then the system concept must be modified and the allocation reassigned. The reliability apportionment of the particular subsystems shall be determined regarding:
  • the complexity of the subsystem,
  • criticality of the subsystem,
  • any necessary constraints,
  • any obtainable technical possibilities,
  • survival probabilities for the intended lifetime,
  • redundancy requirements,
  • SPF and outage probabilities,
  • maturity of equipment design's.

The apportionment/allocation shall be reflected in the subsystem and equipment specifications, and the relevant reliability prediction analysis.
Numerical reliability requirements and mission success criteria for the system, subsystem and equipment shall be stated in the relevant specification.

Failure rates shall be taken from MIL-HDBK-217, revision F, +notice 2 for electronic equipment and from RADC-NPRD-91 for mechanical devices. The references for failure rates shall be stated in the reliability analysis.

Passive mechanical structures can be considered as 100% reliable if the specified stress/strength and fracture control requirements are met.

NOTE:
The information of ECSS-Q-HB-30-08A Annex B concerning applicability and information of MIL-HDBK-217, shall be considered.

applicableDocuments.title: MIL-HDBK-217
applicableDocuments.description: Reliability Prediction of Electronic Equipment (use as Guideline)

requirements.text: If other reliability handbooks, and/or manufacturer or user data will be used, the supplier shall justify the selected data sources and methods used according with ECSS Q-HB-30-08A within the relevant reliability prediction analysis.

This technique shall be used when the number of components (actual or estimated) by class or type that will be used in the system does not have enough data as to the stresses to which each part will be subjected in the final design. It involves counting the number of parts of each class or type, multiplying this number by generic failure rate for each part class or type, and adding up these products to obtain the failure rate for the equipment.

The necessary generic (average) failure rate and the quality factor are obtained e.g. from the MIL-HDBK-217, revision F, + notice 2, APPENDIX A. Reliability prediction (Parts Count) shall be carried out using computer programs to the extent possible. The required content of the analysis is given in DRD-4.01.

applicableDocuments.title: MIL-HDBK-217
applicableDocuments.description: Reliability Prediction of Electronic Equipment (use as Guideline)

drds.title: Part Count Reliability Prediction
drds.deliveryDate: PRR; SRR; PDR; CDR; QR, AR

requirements.text: The technique is based upon knowledge of the stress to which the part will be subjected, e.g. temperature, voltage, power etc., and the effect of those stresses on the parts failure rate. Therefore, the reliability prediction (parts stress) shall be performed when most of the design is completed, parts details are known, and when part stresses are available in accordance with MIL-HDBK-217, revision F, <u>+ notice 2</u>. Reliability prediction (parts stress) shall be prepared for flight HW. The reliability prediction (parts stress) has to be updated after major design changes, trade-off studies and relevant stress and thermal analyses, taking into consideration the results of derating analyses. Reliability prediction (parts stress) shall be carried out using computer programs to the extent possible. The required content of analysis is given in DRD-4.02.

applicableDocuments.title: MIL-HDBK-217
applicableDocuments.description: Reliability Prediction of Electronic Equipment (use as Guideline)

requirements.text: As an output of any reliability prediction a Reliability Prediction Report in accordance with DRD-4.03 shall be provided.

drds.title: Reliability Prediction Report
drds.deliveryDate: PRR; SRR; PDR; CDR; QR, AR

requirements.text:
Reliability prediction techniques shall be used with the following objectives:
  • to optimise the reliability of a design against competing constraints such as cost and mass,
  • to predict the in-service reliability of a product and
  • to provide failure probability data for purposes such as risk assessment.

Reliability models shall be prepared to support predictions and FMEA/FMECA.

Starting in the preliminary design stage (phase B), the supplier shall develop reliability prediction models and predictions for the system. Predictions shall be performed in close co-ordination with failure mode, effects and criticality analyses (FMEA/FMECA) on the same system elements. The scale of effort and degree of precision in each prediction shall be appropriate to the phase of project life in which the prediction is made and to the intended use of the result. Predictions are useful as a basis for:
  • comparing predicted reliability against apportioned reliability goals within the system and planning a design capable of meeting mission reliability goals,
  • timely identification of potential reliability problem areas and guiding design trade-offs and redundancy decisions,
  • mission planning, test program planning, and reliability evaluation program planning,

• support trade-offs on reliability versus availability, safety, and maintainability,
  • estimation of Mean-Time-Between-Failures (MTBF) to support maintainability analysis and logistics planning.

The data resulting from prediction shall influence the design of the system to make it as reliable as possible under the constraints of cost effectiveness. The implementation of the agreed corrective actions shall be controlled. No numerical reliability assessment is required for passive structural elements, passive thermal control elements, SW and human factors. Except for these, all elements of the analysed item shall be considered the reliability prediction, including wiring, solder points and connectors. The following assumptions shall apply:
  • the design assessed is representative for the flight design,
  • useful life of an item begins upon the satisfactory acceptance test of the item,
  • mission phases are independent: stresses experienced during one phase do not affect the failure rate of succeeding phases,
  • all inputs to the analysed item are within the specified limits,
  • individual elements or functions are mutually independent with regard to the probability of failure.
A reliability block diagram shall be provided according to DRD-4.04 and DRD-4.05.

drds.title: Reliability Block Diagram Symbols
drds.deliveryDate: PRR; SRR; PDR; CDR; QR; AR

requirements.text: Functional block diagrams (DRD-4.06) shall be prepared which illustrate the operation, interrelationships and interdependencies of the items which constitute the product. All product interfaces shall be indicated. Schematic diagrams and block diagrams to a level consistent with the depth of the analysis and with design maturity shall be provided to assist the analysis. An appropriate identification number shall be used to provide consistent identification and complete visibility of the relationship between each block and the applicable failure modes.

drds.title: Functional Block Diagram
drds.deliveryDate: PRR; SRR; PDR; CDR; QR, AR

requirements.text: Functional tree (DRD-4.07) shall be constructed to identify the elements of the analysed product, to illustrate its function, and to indicate the functional dependencies among the elements.

drds.deliveryDate: PRR; SRR; PDR; CDR; QR, AR

chapters.name: Failure Modes, Effects Analysis (FMEA)/Failure Modes, Effects and Criticality Analysis (FMECA)

requirements.text: FMEA/FMECA shall be performed on the functional and physical design (functional FMEA/FMECA and product FMEA/FMECA respectively), and the processes used to realize the final product (process FMEA/FMECA) (DRD-4.08).

drds.title: FMECA
drds.deliveryDate: PRR; SRR; PDR; CDR; QR, AR

requirements.text:
Phase A: Feasibility
The FMEA/FMECA shall assist the trade-off among the various possible design concepts by assessing their impact on the project dependability and safety requirements.
NOTE:
The analysis contributes to the overall risk evaluation of each design concept. The functional approach is generally used.

The corresponding detailed requirements of ECSS-Q-ST-30-02 shall be used.

applicableDocuments.title: ECSS-Q-ST-30-02
applicableDocuments.description: Failure modes, effects (and criticality) analysis (FMEA/FMECA) (6 March 2009)

requirements.text:
Phase B: Preliminary definition
The FMEA/FMECA shall be performed either according to the functional approach (functional FMEA/FMECA) or to the HW approach (HW FMEA/FMECA).

The corresponding detailed requirements of ECSS-Q-ST-30-02 shall be used.

applicableDocuments.title: ECSS-Q-ST-30-02
applicableDocuments.description: Failure modes, effects (and criticality) analysis (FMEA/FMECA) (6 March 2009)

requirements.text:
Phase C: Detailed definition
The FMEA/FMECA shall be performed according to the HW approach (HW FMEA/FMECA).
NOTE:
In this phase the HW can be uniquely identified from the engineering design data. In some cases the functional approach or a combination of the two approaches can be used (rationale for selection to be provided and agreed by the customer).

The corresponding detailed requirements of ECSS-Q-ST-30-02 shall be used.

applicableDocuments.title: ECSS-Q-ST-30-02
applicableDocuments.description: Failure modes, effects (and criticality) analysis (FMEA/FMECA) (6 March 2009)

requirements.text:
Phase D: Production or ground qualification testing
The FMEA/FMECA performed in phase C shall be updated with regard to design changes decided after the CDR and according to test results.
The FMEA/FMECA shall be utilized as a diagnostic tool in order to support the failure diagnosis during the qualification and the elimination of potential failures.

The corresponding detailed requirements of ECSS-Q-ST-30-02 shall be used.

applicableDocuments.title: ECSS-Q-ST-30-02
applicableDocuments.description: Failure modes, effects (and criticality) analysis (FMEA/FMECA) (6 March 2009)

requirements.text: The objectives of the FMEA/FMECA shall be:
• to identify the effects of assumed failures,
• to identify potential hazards in support of the safety analyses,
• to determine the need for redundancies or fail-safe features,
• to demonstrate compliance to the fault tolerance requirements included in the safety requirements and the technical specifications,

• to identify critical failure effects, particularly all SPF, and to make recommendations to eliminate them from the design or to provide formal rationales for retention,
  • to identify available or needed monitoring facilities for the symptoms of a failure which can be observed during flight via telemetry or on-board monitoring and during ground testing,
  • to identify potential redundant or contingency operating modes,
  • to identify failures on the interface to GSE (failures within the GSE which damage flight HW), the FMEA/FMECA for GSE shall be limited to electrical interface circuits from GSE to flight HW.

drds.title: FMECA
drds.deliveryDate: PRR; SRR; PDR; CDR; QR, AR

requirements.text: Improper commands or improper command sequences or SW errors (e.g. originating from SEU) shall not cause damage to HW and shall not result in operational conditions which cannot be restored by ground command. This is also applicable for ground testing of flight HW.

Formal issues or revisions of the FMEA/FMECA shall be provided to the customer for review within the data packages for the design reviews. Updates shall be prepared and submitted if major design changes are introduced at intermediate steps. The FMEA/FMECA shall be supported by:
• functional block diagram (see para. 4.11.2.3) according to DRD-4.06,

requirements.text: • functional tree (see para. 4.11.2.4) according to DRD-4.07,

drds.title: Functional Tree

requirements.text: • reliability block diagram according to DRD-4.04 and-4.05,

drds.title: Reliability Block Diagram Symbols
drds.deliveryDate: PRR; SRR; PDR; CDR; QR; AR

requirements.text: • functional description, schematics and/or flow diagrams shall be provided additionally to support the understanding of functions.
• SW reactions to HW failures shall be addressed by the HW-SW Interaction Analysis (HSIA) as described in para. 4.11.2.6.

All potential failure modes shall be identified and classified according to the severity of their consequences. Measures shall be proposed in the analysis and introduced in the product design and in the control of processes to render all such consequences acceptable to the project.

When any design or process changes are made, the impact with respect to the FMEA shall be analysed and if needed the working file of the FMEA shall be updated and the effects of new failure modes introduced by the changes shall be assessed.

requirements.text: Provisions for failure detection and recovery actions shall be provided as part of the FMEA.

requirements.text: The FMEA shall be used to support the verification of the reliability modelling, the reliability and safety analyses, maintainability analyses, logistic support activity, test and maintenance planning, and the Failure Detection, Isolation and Recovery (FDIR) policy.

requirements.text: The FMEA shall be performed at the assembly level according to the para. 4.10.4. The FMEA shall be performed for each block in the functional block diagram or functional tree, indicating the effect of the item failure on the performance of the next higher assembly level. A numerical reference for all items in the functional diagram or functional tree shall be provided by using a standard coding system.

drds.deliveryDate: PRR; SRR; PDR; CDR; QR, AR

requirements.text:
As a minimum the following modes shall be considered in the FMEA:
  • premature operation,
  • failure to operate at a prescribed time,
  • failure to cease operation at a prescribed time,
  • failure during operation,
  • degradation or out of tolerance operation,

drds.title: FMECA
drds.deliveryDate: PRR; SRR; PDR; CDR; QR, AR

requirements.text:
• for failure on component level for EEE components:
    1. short circuit,
    2. open circuit,
    3. incorrect function e.g. from SEU or latch-up,
  • failures of electromechanical or mechanical parts,
  • incorrect commands or incorrect sequence of commands,
  • HW/SW interaction according to para. 4.11.2.6.

Further failure modes which are unique for the analysed items shall be considered. A combination of two failures should only be addressed in the FMEA if it has been identified that it can result in hazardous failure effects acc. to para. 4.8.2 or that it could result from a common cause.

drds.title: FMECA
drds.deliveryDate: PRR; SRR; PDR; CDR; QR, AR

requirements.text:
All potential failure modes shall be identified and classified according to the criticality of their consequences.

Measures shall be proposed in the analysis and introduced in the product design and in the control of processes to render all such consequences acceptable to the project.

The supplier shall prepare the FMECA using the ECSS-Q-ST-30-02, IEC 60812:2006, or equivalent specification as a guideline and in accordance to DRD-4.08. All requirements of para. 4.11.2.5.2 and 4.11.2.5.3 shall apply. The acronym FMECA replaces FMEA.

requirements.text: The failure mode probability of occurrence shall be estimated only for consequence severity 1, 2 and 3 at system level according to para. 4.8.2 and if reliability prediction is required.

HSIA is an activity performed to ensure that the SW reacts in an acceptable way to HW failures. Particular attention is paid to each failure mode of HW used in compensatory provisions (redundancy, protection) and controlled by SW.

The HSIA shall be performed concurrently with the FMEA/FMECA to influence the HW design and the SW requirements. The HSIA shall be used to verify that the SW specifications as expressed in the requirements baseline (RB) or the technical specification (TS) cover the HW failures according to the applicable FDIR requirements.
NOTE:
For more details on RB and TS, see ECSS-E-ST-40.

Suppliers of products combining HW and SW shall perform a HSIA covering all HW failures which can interact with internal SW. In the performance of the System HSIA, the supplier shall integrate the HSIAs performed at one level lower than the level of the supplier. The HSIA shall be performed to provide the following results:

  • inputs to the list of CIs,
    NOTE:
    For example: no or nonconforming SW action and SW action having adverse effects on HW.
  • inputs for FDIR policy,
  • recommendations.
    NOTE:
    For example: HW or SW to be added or modified.

Nonconforming cases shall be identified and formally dispositioned in conformance with para. 3.5.1. The HSIA shall be documented by completing a form in conformance with the DRD-4.09. Findings and recommendations arising from the HSIA shall be recorded and tracked together with the ones coming from FMEA/FMECA.

applicableDocuments.title: ECSS-E-ST-40
applicableDocuments.description: Software general requirements (6 March 2009)

drds.title: FMECA
drds.deliveryDate: PRR; SRR; PDR; CDR; QR, AR

requirements.text: HW-SW interaction analysis shall be performed to ensure that the SW is designed to react in an acceptable way to HW failure. This shall be performed at the level of the technical specification of the SW. The HSIA can be included in the FMEA/FMECA.

drds.title: FMECA
drds.deliveryDate: PRR; SRR; PDR; CDR; QR, AR

requirements.text:
Contingency analysis shall be performed in conformance with DRD-4.10 (Contingency analysis) in order to:
  • identify the failure, identify the cause, control the effect and indicate how recovery of the mission integrity can be achieved, and
  • identify the methods of recovery of the nominal or degraded functionalities, with respect to project dependability policy.
    NOTE 1:
    For example, availability targets.
    NOTE 2:
    The contingency analysis is typically a system level task.
    NOTE 3:
    FMEA/FMECA is an input to contingency analysis.

drds.title: FMECA
drds.deliveryDate: PRR; SRR; PDR; CDR; QR, AR

requirements.text:
A FTA shall be performed to ensure that the design conforms to the failure tolerance requirements for combination of failures.
NOTE 1:
ECSS-Q-ST-40-12 and DRD-5.16 is a guideline for FTA.
NOTE 2:
The system supplier performs FTA to identify possible event combinations leading to the undesirable end event (e.g. "loss of mission"). Sub-system suppliers provides input to this activity by establishing FTA at sub-system level with respect to the top events:
  • loss of function of the sub-system, and
  • inadvertent activation of the sub-system function.

requirements.text:
Common-Cause Analyses shall be performed on reliability and safety CIs in conformance with DRD-4.11, to identify the root cause of failures that have a potential to negate failure tolerance levels (see para. 4.8.3 - Failure tolerance).
NOTE:
The analyses can be accomplished as part of FMEA/FMECA or FTA.

drds.deliveryDate: PRR; SRR; PDR; CDR; QR, AR

requirements.text: Common-cause analyses (DRD-4.11) shall be performed where redundancy is used to reduce the probability of losing a function or of inadvertently actuating a safety critical situation.
Principles, requirements and procedures to perform the analysis are described in para. 4.11.2.5 (FMEA/FMECA)

drds.title: FMECA
drds.deliveryDate: PRR; SRR; PDR; CDR; QR, AR

drds.title: FTA
drds.deliveryDate: PRR; SRR; PDR; CDR; QR; AR

requirements.text:
The check list of generic common-cause parameters of DRD-4.11 shall be used.
NOTE:
An example of check list of generic common-cause parameters is provided in DRD-4.11.

Worst Case Analysis shall be performed on electrical equipment in conformance with DRD-4.12, to demonstrate that it performs within specification despite variations in its constituent part parameters and the imposed environment. The WCA report shall contain all baseline information (assumptions, methods and techniques) used for the preparation of the analysis, the results obtained and a comparison of the specified parameters as derived from the specification of the equipment or module. If not specified in the project requirement, the supplier shall propose and justify the component aging parameter drifts within the WCA.
NOTE 1:
The document ECSS-Q-TM-30-12 shall be used as source for component aging parameter drifts, but is to be complemented with other inputs as it does not cover exhaustively the EEE parts.
NOTE 2:
ECSS-Q-HB-30-01 describes the WCA methodology.

The WCA shall include part parameter variations, temperature effects, radiation effects, part tolerances, input variations etc. The design process must ensure that the distribution or tolerances of parts/circuits cannot combine in such a way as to cause the intended function to fall outside of the range allowed by the specification. It is necessary to consider the overall effect of the expected range of manufacturing tolerances, ageing, electrical stresses and operational environment. The supplier is required to screen the application of WCA to some extent under the constraints of cost effectiveness and the usefulness of the result.
Derating to electronic, electrical and electromechanical components shall be performed by intentional reduction of electrical, thermal and mechanical stresses to levels below their specified rating.

EEE components shall be derated according to the derating requirements of ECSS-Q-ST-30-11, EEE-INST-002 or MSFC-STD-3012.
NOTE 1:
Derating standard applied has to be agreed between the project parties involved.
NOTE 2:
Detailed specifications could be found e.g. in ESCC.

requirements.text: Formal parts derating analysis shall be submitted to DLR for review according to DRD-4.13. All parts stressed in excess of the specified derating criteria shall be classified as CIs (para. 2.2.4).

If the supplier proposes to use derating policy factors other than those in ECSS-Q-ST-30-11 or other applicable requirements, or proposes that derating is not necessary, the proposed policy with appropriate justification must be submitted to DLR for acceptance through RFD.

applicableDocuments.title: ECSS-Q-ST-30-11
applicableDocuments.description: Derating - EEE components (4 October 2011)

requirements.text: For all interfaces, non-compliances to the derating requirements are subject to acceptance (RFW, para. 3.5.8.2) on a case by case basis.
All non-compliances to the derating requirements are subject to approval (RFW, para. 3.5.8.2) on a case-by-case basis.
Zonal analysis shall be performed in conformance with DRD-4.14, in order to evaluate the consequence due to potential subsystem-to-subsystem interactions inherent in the system installation.

The supplier shall develop and implement specific design criteria to facilitate maintenance or repair actions in predicted environments. In establishing maintainability design criteria, the supplier, with the assistance of the procuring activity, shall use data obtained from previous maintenance activities.
Maintainability aspects shall be considered for intravehicular activities (IVA) or extravehicular activities (EVA) required by the customer.
Design criteria shall include design for modularity, optimum accessibility, accurate fault diagnostics, standardisation and commonality.
Design criteria shall include crew handling compatibility. SSP 50005 B "International Space Station Flight Crew Integration Standards" shall be used as a guideline.

applicableDocuments.title: SSP 50005
applicableDocuments.description: Flight Crew Integration Standard (NASA−STD−3000/T) (June 2006)

requirements.text: When tools are required, the supplier shall design on-orbit replaceable units to use tools and equipment previously designed and qualified for the intended use in the EVA or IVA environment to the greatest degree practical. Any special tools designed shall be of light weight but durable construction. SSP 50005 shall be used as a guideline.

applicableDocuments.title: SSP 50005
applicableDocuments.description: Flight Crew Integration Standard (NASA−STD−3000/T) (June 2006)

requirements.text: The system design shall minimise the need for maintenance tools. Use of tools shall be standardised to minimise the number of special tools required.

The supplier shall prepare a maintenance plan (DRD-4.15) to support the maintenance concept adopted to satisfy operational requirements. The initial plan shall include the early identification of logistic items requiring long range acquisition planning and implementation by the supplier procuring activity. The plan shall identify trade-offs and decisions concerning, for example, repair by replacement, repair by remote activated or automatic command bypass or switch-off of faulty item etc. The plan shall use inputs from maintainability engineering efforts to identify personnel training and technical data requirements for each level of maintenance. As a minimum, the following shall be identified and described in the plan:
  • training programmes,
  • training facilities,
  • equipment necessary for training personnel,
  • technical data necessary to enable personnel to operate and maintain the equipment, and
  • special aids depicting tool usage, failure isolation, repair/replacement procedures and other maintenance actions for training and operational maintenance.
Maintainability requirements shall be apportioned to set maintainability requirements for lower level products to conform to the maintenance concept and maintainability requirements of the system.

Maintainability prediction shall be performed at system level in conformance with DRD-4.16, and used as a design tool to assess and compare design alternatives with respect to special maintainability quantitative requirements:
  • the time to diagnose (i.e. detect and isolate) item failures,
  • the time to remove and replace the defective item,
  • the time to return the system or subsystem to its nominal configuration and to perform the necessary checks, and
  • the item failure rates.
ECSS-Q-ST-30-09C shall be applied concerning maintainability aspects.

applicableDocuments.title: ECSS-Q-ST-30-09
applicableDocuments.description: Availability analysis (31 July 2008)

requirements.text:
Preventive maintenance analysis according to DRD-4.16 shall be performed at system level to determine the maintenance plan.
NOTE:
Each preventive maintenance action is based on the results of the application of systematic decision logic accepted by the customer.

The maintainability analysis shall identify maintainability CIs.
NOTE:
Maintainability CIs include:
  • products that cannot be checked and tested after integration,
  • limited-life products,
  • products that do not meet, or cannot be validated as compliant to the maintainability requirements.

NOTE:
The preparation of maintainability/maintenance analysis shall be supported by the analyses mentioned in para. 4.11.1.

The supplier shall prepare analysis of the time-to-restore for any restoration or repair procedures designed for sustaining mission capability in the absence of necessary spare parts. These analyses shall consider actions to recover the function.

Consistent with the maintenance concept, the supplier shall determine the quantities of spares required for each system and the total quantities required to sustain the required operational availability.

The supplier shall prepare maintainability information in conjunction with the FMEA/FMECA task effort described in para. 4.11.2.5.
The FMEA/FMECA shall be expanded to include:
  • failure trouble shooting, starting from the failure effects (failure effects summary list),
  • identification of maintenance actions to prevent failures.

The maintainability information shall be used to provide criteria for maintenance planning, preparation of logistics support analysis, test planning, inspection and checkout requirements, and to identify maintainability design deficiencies requiring redesign. Whenever the FMEA/FMECA is updated, the maintainability information shall be updated as changes occur.

drds.title: FMECA
drds.deliveryDate: PRR; SRR; PDR; CDR; QR, AR

requirements.text:
A system maintenance concept shall be developed by the supplier and provided as an end item design requirement to the customer. Inputs to the maintenance concept shall include:
  • mission profile,
  • system reliability requirements,
  • system availability requirements, and
  • overall size and weight constraints.

The concept shall be the basis for establishing maintainability design requirements that will be applied to the system, subsystem, or equipment being developed.

As a minimum, the system maintenance concept shall include a discussion of:
  • system operational availability,
  • repair vs. replacement policy,
  • skill level requirements,
  • sparing concept,
  • diagnostic principles and concepts, and
  • responsibilities for maintenance.

As a minimum, the system maintenance concept shall include a discussion of:
  • repair vs. replacement policy, and
  • diagnostic principles and concepts.

The Availability analysis shall be performed in order to
  • verify the conformance of the selected system design with the applicable availability requirements, and
  • provide inputs to estimate the life cycle cost of the system.

The above design activity leads to the optimization of the system concept definition with respect to design baseline, operations and logistics provisions. The availability analysis identifies the unavailability contributors in order to quantify their impact in supporting the

  • decision making process, and
  • risk evaluation, reduction and control (see ECSS-M-ST-80).

The availability activity is fully integrated into the development programme to ensure the correct support to the other disciplines (e.g. engineering, operations and logistics).

requirements.text: Availability-requirements, -assessment, -allocation and analytical method shall be applied according to ECSS-Q-ST-30-09.

requirements.text: For flight equipment, the availability analysis shall take into account radiation effects: for instance, upset for logic parts such as SET for opto and linear parts, and latch up.
Functional effects on flight equipment due to radiation single events shall be evaluated to provide quantified inputs for availability analysis.

Sources of numerical data shall be provided (e.g. internal database from supplier data, field return experience, or calculation from standard handbooks, such as MIL-HDBK-217, revision F, or UTE C80-810).

requirements.text:
Availability analysis report content
The supplier shall prepare availability analysis report as specified by DRD-4.17.
The availability analysis performed in each project phase shall contribute to the preparation of
  • specifications,
  • trade-off reports, and
  • availability assessment reports.

The availability assessment report shall cover the following aspects:
  • availability model description (including details of the selected mathematical approach and relevant assumptions or hypotheses),
  • inputs (e.g. reliability data, logistic times, and working hypotheses),
  • results obtained,
  • conclusions and recommendations.

For non-maintainable systems, the availability during mission lifetime requirements shall be established considering that the mission is still operational at end of life.
NOTE:
For example, no SPF is considered as an unavailability contributor.
The availability predictions/assessments shall be carried out at system level using the system reliability models.
The availability predictions/assessments shall be carried out at system level using the system maintainability models.

For the attainment of reliability objectives the supplier shall perform reliability analyses starting from early design phases to:
  • identify failure modes which reflect deficiencies in materials, workmanship, or quality control,
  • verify capability of the design,
  • evaluate the susceptibility of the design, the SW and the HW to failures either through known failure modes and mechanisms or through those which had not previously been revealed in design reviews,
  • identify unexpected interactions among components,
  • validate the ability of the HW and SW to function together to meet mission requirements.

Reliability testing and demonstration shall be performed according to the project requirements in order to:
  • validate failure modes and effects,
  • check failure tolerance, failure detection and recovery,
  • obtain statistical failure data to support predictions and risk assessment,
  • consolidate reliability assessments,
  • validate the capability of the HW to operate with SW or to be operated by a human being in accordance with the specifications,
  • demonstrate the reliability of CIs, and
  • validate or justify data bases used for theoretical demonstrations.

Maintainability demonstration shall be performed by performing the verification of the applicable maintainability requirements and by ensuring that preventive and corrective maintenance activities are successfully performed within the scope of the maintenance concept. The maintainability demonstration shall verify the ability to:
  • detect, diagnose and isolate each faulty line replaceable unit or orbit replaceable unit,
  • remove and replace each line replaceable unit or orbit replaceable unit,
  • perform mission-essential repairs on units that are not intended to be replaced,
  • check that the product is fully functional after maintenance actions have been completed,
  • demonstrate that no safety hazard is introduced as a result of maintenance actions, and
  • demonstrate that the maintenance operations can be performed within the applicable constraints, including the operations necessary to prepare a system during the launch campaign.
    NOTE 1:
    Examples of such a constraints are time and volume or accessibility.
    NOTE 2:
    Examples of such operations are "remove-before-flight" items or replacement of batteries.

Safety assurance shall:
  • ensure that space systems do not cause a hazard to, in order of priority:
    • human life,
    • the environment,
    • public and private property (including launch facilities),
    • spacecraft and launcher,
    • GSE and facilities,
  • determine and evaluate the safety risks associated with project activities,
  • minimize safety risks in a technically effective and cost effective manner,
  • ensure adequate verification of safety control measures.

Safety policy is implemented by applying a safety programme which ensures that:
  • safety is designed into the system,
  • safety controls are adequately implemented in the verification plan,
  • safety requirements including launch centre safety regulations are met,
  • hazards are identified, and eliminated or, where this is not possible, minimized, ranked and controlled in accordance with project objectives in a manner acceptable to the customer and to the safety organisations involved in the implementation of the mission.
Safety of human life shall be the overriding consideration during design, manufacture and operation of space systems, including all facilities and ground support systems.

The supplier shall establish and maintain a safety programme plan in conformance with DRD-5.01.
NOTE:
The plan can either be included as part of an overall project PA plan or as a separate safety programme plan.

The supplier shall cover, in his safety programme plan, the safety tasks for the project phases.

requirements.text: All space system programmes which utilise a national range, either for test or mission operations, shall meet the design, operations, analysis and data requirements of the national range instead of this document. The safety approvals required by each range and their design and operational requirements are identified in their range safety manuals. Compliance with the requirements of the range safety manuals is necessary to obtain range approval to conduct operations on or from range. Therefore all relevant ground safety requirements from the relevant launch organisation facility shall be applied for all launch site ground operations. The detailed requirements shall be obtained from the launch organisation via the project management.

requirements.text: Each supplier shall appoint a safety manager who has appropriate training or experience.

The safety manager shall have organisational authority and independence to:
  1. establish and maintain a safety programme in accordance with the project safety requirements,
  2. manage all safety assurance aspects of the design of the system (including SW) and its operation in accordance with the safety plan,
  3. coordinate the interfaces:
    1. with the relevant bodies involved in the project in accordance with the safety plan,
    2. with the safety launcher authority.
    NOTE:
    Depending on the project safety criticality, the safety manager can be combined with other functions (e.g. PA manager) when agreed with the customer.

The safety manager or safety relevant authority shall have the authority to:
  1. reject any project document, or to stop any project activity that does not conform to approved safety requirements or procedures,
  2. interrupt hazardous operations when it becomes clear by the safety manager that the operation does not conform to the agreed measures defined in the corresponding HR and derived approved hazard procedure.

The safety approval authority shall:
  • review and dispose the safety data submittals,
  • approve the close-out of hazards,
  • decide on deviations and waivers, and finally
  • accept the statement of safety compliance.

The safety risk identification, reduction and control shall be part of the project's risk management process as specified in ECSS-M-ST-80C.

Safety risk identification, reduction and control shall be a continuous and iterative process throughout the project life cycle, encompassing

  1. allocation of safety requirements,
  2. hazard and safety risk identification,
  3. evaluation (including categorisation) of consequence severity,
  4. hazard and safety risk reduction and control,
  5. close out and acceptance of residual risk.

chapters.name: Project Phases and Safety Review Cycle

requirements.text: Safety analysis shall support the identification of sources of safety risk as well as the performance of preliminary trade-off analyses between alternative system concepts.
The following safety programme tasks shall apply for safety critical systems:

1. analyse safety requirements and lessons-learnt associated with similar previous missions,
  2. perform preliminary hazard analysis of the proposed system and operations concept to support concept trade-offs,
  3. perform comparative safety risk assessment of the concept options,
  4. identify the relevant project safety requirements,
  5. plan safety activities for the feasibility phase,
  6. support the mission definition review.

Safety analysis shall support trade-off analyses in arriving at the concept that has acceptable safety risk considering the project and mission constraints.

The design technology selected and the operational concept to be implemented shall be selected based on the analysis data for the safest system architecture to eliminate or reduce hazards to acceptable levels.
The following safety programme tasks shall apply for safety critical systems:

1. commence hazard analyses of the design and operations concepts in order to identify applicable system level hazards, hazardous conditions, and potential hazardous events and consequences,
  2. support concept trades by identifying safety critical aspects of the concept options,
  3. apply hazard elimination and minimization and make safety recommendations,
  4. perform comparative safety risk assessments of the concept options,
  5. identify system level safety critical functions,
  6. identify system level project specific safety requirements,
  7. plan safety activities for the project definition phase,
  8. support the preliminary requirements review.

The safety analysis shall support a continued and more detailed safety optimization of the system design and operations and the identification of technical safety requirements and their applicability.

The analysis shall also provide inputs to safety risk assessment in support of safety risk evaluation, the identification of risk contributors in the design and in the operational concept.
The following safety programme tasks shall apply for safety critical systems:

1. update hazard analysis in support of design and mission concept definition activities, identify additional project specific safety requirements,
  2. update safety critical functions identification, and define the failure tolerance requirements,
  3. identify emergency, warning, and caution situations,
  4. update the system safety risk assessment as part of the contribution provided by the safety domain to the risk management process,
  5. Identify project safety requirements,
  6. ensure that project requirement documentation and activities comply with project safety requirements,
  7. support a SRR and PDR,
  8. plan verification of safety requirements implementation,
  9. prepare the safety plan for the detailed definition, production and qualification phase.
A phase 0 - SDP shall be established for the phase 0 Flight Safety Review (FSR) or for a phase 0, i.e. in manned missions the Technical Interchange Meeting, (typically in SRR timeframe).
A phase 1 - SDP shall be established for the phase 1 FSR (typically in PDR timeframe).

chapters.name: Detailed Definition, Production, Qualification, Testing - Phase C/D

requirements.text:
Safety analysis shall support detailed design, production, qualification, testing.

Safety analysis shall also support operational safety optimization, safety requirements implementation evaluation, risk reduction verification, and hazard and risk acceptance.

Analysis of operations shall also support the identification of emergency and contingency response planning and training requirements, and the development of procedures.
The following safety programme tasks shall apply for safety critical systems:

1. perform detailed system level hazard analysis,
  2. perform supporting safety analysis,
  3. update the project technical safety requirements to incorporate the results of safety analyses,
  4. ensure that the project implementation and verification programme covers identified hazard control verification activities,
    NOTE:
    For example: reviews, inspections, analyses and tests.
  5. update safety critical functions identification, failure tolerance requirements, and identify safety CIs,
  6. implement control programme for safety CIs,
  7. perform safety risk assessment in support of design improvement, project resource apportionment, control programme for safety CIs and project reviews,
  8. monitor verification of safety requirements implementation,
  9. verify and document hazard control implementation,
  10. check that all open verification items are recorded and agreed procedures are in place,
  11. support the CDR, the qualification review and the AR,
  12. perform project internal safety reviews and internal audits,
  13. identify, monitor and control project assembly, integration, testing and handling operations which are potentially hazardous to personnel or HW,
  14. review and approve hazardous and safety critical operational procedures,
  15. perform accident-incident reporting and investigation.
A phase 2 - SDP shall be established for the phase 2 FSR (typically in CDR timeframe).

A phase 3 - SDP shall be established for the phase 3 FSR (typically in AR timeframe, when all major hazard verifications are closed).

All open verifications shall be recorded in the VCD at this time.

The SVTL (control sheet) shall show no open safety relevant verifications (DRD-5.25).

Safety analysis shall evaluate all disposal operations and associated hazards.
Disposal solutions shall be identified which meet the project's safety requirements. The following safety programme tasks shall apply for safety critical systems:
  1. perform hazard analysis with respect to the disposal operations,
  2. check that the disposal operation conforms to international safety regulations by performing the necessary safety analysis,
  3. review the procedures of the disposal operations,
  4. support the mission close-out review.
Further requirements are given by para. 11 "Space Debris Mitigation" and para. 12 "Planetary Protection".
Safety programme tasks for human spaceflight programmes as defined in applicable requirements per SSP 30599 shall be implemented.

requirements.text: The supplier shall establish and maintain a safety programme to assure conformance with project safety policy and requirements.

The supplier shall provide a statement of safety compliance to demonstrate that the space and ground system elements conform to stated project specific safety requirements.

The supplier shall include in his statement of compliance a statement that open verifications are followed up in the SVTL (DRD-5.24), and do not affect further safe processing.

The project shall provide to the safety approval authority all safety-related information for their acceptance of the statement of safety compliance.

The supplier shall provide a statement of safety compliance to demonstrate that the space and ground system elements conform to stated project specific safety requirements.

The supplier shall include in his statement of compliance a statement that open verifications are followed up in the SVTL (DRD-5.25), and do not affect further safe processing.

The project shall provide to the safety approval authority all safety-related information for their acceptance of the statement of safety compliance.

The supplier shall certify the safety of the flight and ground system products as having reached an acceptable level of risk in conformance to project specific safety requirements. The certification process shall be completed before delivery to any party other than the purchaser. The certification shall include a statement that open verifications shall be closed and do not affect further safe processing at third party premises. It shall be the responsibility of the supplier to provide to the certification authority all safety related information that is required to enable the statement of safety compliance to be accepted and understood.

requirements.text:
Safety training shall be part of the overall training in accordance with para. 3.4.2.

It shall contain:

  1. general awareness briefings on safety measures to be taken at a given location or working environment,
  2. basic technical training in the required safety techniques and skills which is a prerequisite to fulfil the job function under consideration, e.g. inspection, test, maintenance or integration,
  3. product specific training that focuses on the hazards related to the specific system element.

The supplier shall report to the customer all accidents and incidents occurred during project activities under the control of the supplier or his lower-tier suppliers that affect the system element.

The supplier shall support at request - project related accident and incident investigations that occur outside of the supplier's control or facility.

The supplier shall coordinate the investigation activities in cooperation with other supplier functional departments and lower-tier suppliers.

The accident or incident investigation report shall be formally closed by the supplier upon approval by the customer.

If the conclusion of the assessment is that the accident-incident has had an effect on the project, i.e. the safety of the product or its operation, the organisations safety representative shall be informed. In such case the accident-incident report shall become part of the project's safety data and is documented in the SDP.

The supplier shall submit a SDP for each review in accordance to para. 5.3.6.
NOTE:
This may be a stand-alone package or may be integrated into the overall data package if the safety review is part of an overall project review.

The safety approval authority shall specify the content of the SDP.
If the safety authority has not defined the content of the SDP differently, the content of the data package shall be in accordance with DRD-5.07.

NOTE:
JSC-26943 is outdated and can be used as historic guideline or learning basis but does not contain current valid requirements.

requirements.text: Safety requirements that cannot be met shall be identified and a RFD or RFW shall be generated and tracked according to the requirements of para. 3.5.8, 3.5.8.1 or 3.5.8.2.

The ISS-Safety-NCR shall describe why the requirement cannot be met and provide sufficient analysis and rationale to support an exception to the requirement. It shall be shown that the design or operation is safe despite the deviation from requirements.
