chapters.name: Acceptance by the Safety Approval Authority

requirements.text: Safety deviations and waivers shall be subject to safety approval authority acceptance.

Deviations and waivers that affect project safety requirements or safety critical functions which the supplier considers acceptable shall be subject of review and disposition by the customer and the safety approval authority.

Safety lessons learned shall be collected during the project and used during the project, as far as they are relevant.
NOTE:
Safety lessons learned shall consider as a minimum:
  1. the impact of newly imposed requirements,
  2. assessment of all malfunctions, accidents, anomalies, deviations and waivers,
  3. effectiveness of safety strategies of the project,
  4. new safety tools and methods which have been developed or demonstrated,
  5. effective versus ineffective verifications which have been performed,
  6. changes proposed to safety policy, strategy or technical requirements with rationale.
The lessons-learned file shall be made available to the customer upon request at the end of a project.

Appropriate design features shall be selected to ensure inherent safety.
NOTE:
Such features are fail safe design solutions, damage control, containment and isolation of potential hazards.

Hazards and hazardous conditions shall, consistent with the project constraints and mission objectives, be eliminated from the design and operational concepts by the selection of design technology, architecture, and operational characteristics.

Where hazards and hazardous conditions are not eliminated, the severity of the associated hazardous events and consequences shall, consistent with the project constraints and mission objectives, be reduced to an accepted level through the change of the design architecture, technologies, and operational characteristics allowing the substitution of those hazards by other hazards with lower potential threat.

Failure tolerance is the basic safety requirement that shall be used to control most hazards.

The design shall tolerate a minimum number of credible failures and/or operator errors determined by the hazard consequence.

The supplier shall establish the list of failures to be considered as non-credible for customer approval as early as possible in development.

chapters.name: Design Selection - Design for Minimum Risk

requirements.text:
Hazards which cannot be controlled by compliance to failure tolerance shall be reduced to an accepted level by compliance with specific safety related properties and characteristics of the design.
NOTE:
Examples are: structures, pressures vessels, mechanisms, material compatibility, flammability.

Hazards that are not eliminated through design selection shall be reduced and made controllable through the use of automatic safety devices as part of the system, subsystem or equipment.

The safety devices shall not be dependent on human performance.

If SW is used in automatic safety devices, justification shall be provided.

When it is not practical to preclude the existence or occurrence of known hazards or to use automatic safety devices, devices shall be used for the timely detection of the condition and the generation of an appropriate warning signal.

This shall be coupled with emergency controls of corrective action for operators to safe or shut down the affected subsystem.

When it is not possible to reduce the magnitude of a hazard through the design, the use of safety devices or the use of warning devices, special procedures shall be developed to control the hazardous conditions for the enhancement of safety.
Special procedures shall be verified by test and appropriate training be provided for personnel.
Hazard detection shall be implemented if alternative means cannot be used.

The requirement for hazard detection, signalling and saving by the flight crew to control time-critical hazards shall be minimised and shall not be implemented if an alternative means of reduction or control of hazardous conditions can be used.

To permit the use of real time monitoring, hazard detection and saving systems for hazard control, the availability of sufficient response time shall be verified and corresponding saving procedures be developed and verified and the personnel trained.
NOTE:
Special procedures are the least effective of the hazard control and risk reduction measures available. They can include emergency and contingency procedures, procedural constraints, or the application of a controlled maintenance programme.

Whenever the safe operation of the system depends on externally provided services (e.g. power), the system design shall be such that critical or catastrophic consequences are not induced (at least for a certain interval of time that is to be defined for each project) after the loss of those services.

Hazards that have not been eliminated and have been subjected to hazard minimization (as defined in para. 5.8.2.2) shall be controlled through preventative or mitigation measures, associated to hazard scenarios, which are introduced into the system design and operation to avoid the events or to interrupt their propagation to consequences.

The system design shall meet the safety requirements under the worst case natural and induced environments defined for the project.

Design and performance margins shall be established and applied for worst case combinations of induced and natural environments and operating characteristics.

Loss, malfunctioning, and sudden restoration of external services shall be defined as an input to the development phase.

The system design shall be defined so that catastrophic or critical consequences are not induced by loss, malfunctioning, and sudden restoration of external services.

The following sequence of activities shall be applied to identified hazards, hazardous conditions, and functions whose failure has hazardous consequences:
  1. hazard elimination,
  2. hazard minimization,
  3. hazard control.

Safety is an integral part of all project PA and engineering activities. It shall not be a stand-alone activity.

Safety engineering consists of safety analysis, management of hazard and risk reduction processes, hazard and risk potential assessment, design assurance, hazard and risk control activities.
The presentation of personnel safety shall be the most important priority in the development and operation of DLR space projects.

chapters.name: Severity of Hazardous Event and Function Criticality

requirements.text:
The availability of the following shall not be used as rationale for the reduction of the severity:
  1. design features which reduce the probability of a hazardous event occurring, but which do not affect its severity,
  2. warning devices, crew safe haven, or crew escape capabilities.

For international programmes, a coherent set of consequence severity shall be established for joint operational phases.

These categories shall not violate the ECSS policy of priorization for the protection of human life, or the principles of categorization in accordance with the definition of consequence severity categories.

The severity of potential consequences of identified hazardous events shall be categorized as shown in table below:
Type of Consequences
name Level Dependability Safety
Catastrophic 1

Failure propagation
(Only for lower than system level analysis)
(Refer to ECSS-Q-ST-30 requirement 5.3.2.c)

 Loss of life, life-threatening or permanently disabling injury or occupational illness.
Loss of system.
Loss of an interfacing manned flight system.
Loss of launch site facilities.
Severe detrimental environmental effects.
Critical 2 Loss of mission. Temporarily disabling but not life-threatening injury, or temporary occupational illness.
Major damage to an interfacing flight system.
Major damage to ground facilities.
Major damage to public or private property.
Major detrimental environmental effects.
Major 3 Major mission degradation. NA
Minor or Negligible 4 Minor mission degradation or any other effect. NA
NOTE:
When several categories can be applied to the system or system component, the highest severity takes priority.

applicableDocuments.title: ECSS-Q-ST-30
applicableDocuments.description: Dependability (15 February 2017)

requirements.text:
The criticality of a function implemented in the space system shall be assigned in accordance with the severity of identified hazardous events it can cause, following the categories defined in table 5-1.
NOTE:
Hazardous events can result from a function not executed or executed degraded, incorrectly, untimely, out of the specified time interval, out of sequence or inadvertently.
Table 5-1: Criticality of functions
Severity of hazardous event Function criticality Criteria to assign criticality categories to functions
Catastrophic
(Level 1)		 I A function that if not or incorrectly performed, or whose anomalous behaviour can cause one or more hazardous events resulting in catastrophic consequences.
Critical
(Level 2)		 II A function that if not or incorrectly performed, or whose anomalous behaviour can cause one or more hazardous events resulting in critical consequences.

Failure tolerance shall be the basic safety requirement used to control hazards.

No single system failure or single operator error shall have critical or catastrophic consequences.

No combination of two independent system failures or operator errors shall have catastrophic consequences.

Safety inhibits shall be independent, verifiable, stable and stay in a safe position even in case of energy failure.

Multiple failures, which result from common-cause or common-mode failure mechanisms, shall be analysed as single failures for determining failure tolerance.
All hazards not controlled by conformance to failure tolerance shall be controlled by conformance to "Design to Minimum Risk" (see para. 5.9.3).

The system design shall:
  1. include the capability for on-board redundancy management of safety critical functions,

1. provide failure tolerance and redundancy status information to the flight and ground crews, including immediate crew notification in the case of failure detection, redundancy switch over, or loss of operational redundancy,
1. include failure detection, failure isolation and switching of redundant items.

The capability shall be provided to the flight crew and mission control to override automatic saving and redundancy switch over.

Alternate or redundant safety critical functions shall be physically and functionally separated or protected in such a way that any event that causes the loss of one path does not result in the loss of alternative or redundant paths.
HW failures or SW errors shall not cause additional failures with hazardous effects or propagate to cause the hazardous operation of interfacing HW.

The design of payloads with safety critical structure shall comply with SSP 52005. The payload provider shall prepare and submit a Structural Verification Plan to be approved by DLR and safety authoritybefore the Phase II FSR closure.

All fracture-critical or safety-critical components, including payload structure, support brackets and mounting HW, shall be made of materials resistant to stress corrosion cracking, i.e. table I materials per MSFC-STD-3029A, table I materials per ECSS-Q-ST-70-36, or "A"-rated materials per MAPTIS. When released, NASA-STD-6004, Selection of Metallic Materials for Stress Corrosion Cracking Resistance, may be used in place of MSFC-STD-3029A.

Materials proposed for use in fracture/safety critical HW and not listed in table I of MSFC-STD-3029A or in table I of ECSS-Q-ST-70-36 or non-"A"-rated in MAPTIS, shall pass a screening assessment per MSFC-STD-3029A or ECSS-Q-ST-70-36. Such assessment shall be referenced in the stress corrosion related Hazard Report (HR).

requirements.text:
All payloads materials shall be assessed for flammability by analysis or test according to the flammability requirements in paragraphs 4.7.1 and 4.7.1.1 of SSP 51721 and JSC 29353. When flammable materials are used in quantities larger than allowed, a method to control the flame propagation shall be agreed with DLR and ESA/NASA.

Materials flammability shall be tested in accordance to test 1 (Upward Flame Propagation) of NASA-STD-6001B Appendix A.2.4 or test 1 (Upward Propagation Test Method) of ECSS-Q-ST-70-21 or test 4 of ECSS-Q-ST-70-21.

Electrical wire insulation shall be tested for flammability in accordance to NASA-STD-6001B Test 4 or ECSS-Q-ST-70-21 test 3 (Electrical Wire Insulation Flammability test Method). Electrical wire insulation for arc tracking shall be evaluated by test or analysis with a method to be agreed by DLR and ESA/NASA.

In the case of flammable material used for a short time in the pressurized environment and permanently stowed in non-flammable containers an ESA/NASA Operational Control Agreement Database (eOCAD) entry shall be implemented.

All materials used/launched/stored in habitable flight compartment shall meet the offgassing requirements of NASA-STD-6001B or ECSS-Q-ST-70-29.

Determination of offgassing products from materials and assembled articles shall meet the offgassing acceptance criteria in paragraph 7.7.3 of NASA-STD-6001B. Seven-day Spacecraft Maximum Allowable Concentrations (SMAC) defined in SSP 30233 or MAPTIS shall be used for analysis of offgassing data.

Offgassing evaluation by analysis and/or test is required only for items with non-metallic mass greater than 20lb (9072 grams). Uncured adhesives, lubricants, cleaning wipes, marker and other items containing liquids or gels shall be evaluated for offgassing.

All materials shall be evaluated by analysis for compatibility with applicable liquids or gasses. The compatibility assessment shall be agreed by DLR and ESA/NASA.

Materials exposed to corrosive or hazardous fluids shall be evaluated by analysis or tested for compatibility and shall meet the fluid compatibility requirements of SSP 51721, paragraph 4.7.1.3 and 4.7.2.

requirements.text:
The release of the following water-soluble volatile organic compounds into the ISS habitable environment is prohibited:
  • methanol,
  • ethanol,
  • isopropyl alcohol,
  • n-propyl alcohol,
  • n-butyl alcohol,
  • acetone,
  • ethylene glycol,
  • propylene glycol.

The DLR and ESA/NASA agreement shall be requested by submitting a Volatile Organic Compound Usage Agreement (VUA) according to SSP 30233 section 3.1.5 with following exceptions:

  • the release of these compounds by normal materials offgassing,
  • the water soluble volatile organic compound is properly contained and released to the habitable environment only as a result of a single barrier failure (redundant containment not required).

Technical requirements for areas of design for minimum risk shall be identified and approved by DLR and the relevant safety approval authorities.
NOTE:
"Design for minimum risk" is a safety requirement used to control hazards by specifying safety related properties and characteristics of the design.

chapters.name: Identification and Control of Safety Critical Functions

requirements.text:
A function that, if lost or degraded, or through incorrect or inadvertent operation, can result in a catastrophic or critical hazardous consequence, shall be identified as safety-critical function.
NOTE:
This includes, but is not limited to, series of operational events which may result in a hazard if they occur inadvertently or are operated out of order.

Identification shall be done without taking into account hazards controls to be or already implemented.

Inadvertent operation of a safety critical function shall be prevented by
  1. two independent inhibits, if it induces critical consequences, or
  2. three independent inhibits, if it induces catastrophic consequences.

The system shall provide failure tolerance and redundancy status information of safety critical functions.

The system shall provide the status of at least two inhibits on functions that, if inadvertently operated, can lead to catastrophic consequences, including:

  1. notification in real time in case of failure detection,
  2. announcement of any loss of operational redundancy,
  3. notification of redundancy switch over, or
  4. changes of inhibit status.

chapters.name: Safe Shutdown and Failure Tolerance Requirements

requirements.text: The design shall either provide the capability for the safe shutdown of safety-critical functions prior to inflight maintenance operations or conform to the failure tolerance requirements during maintenance operations.
EEE components used to support safety critical functions in flight standard HW shall be selected and procured in accordance with the applicable programme requirements of chapter 6 in this document.

The payload provider shall ensure that non-hermetically sealed materials of components meet the safety requirements established for the project regarding off-gassing, flammability, toxicity and any other criteria specified for the intended use.

Wet slug tantalum capacitors are prohibited except for CLR79 construction with double seal tantalum case.

Solid tantalum capacitors shall be surge tested.

requirements.text:
Safety aspects associated with the SW function shall be an integral part of the overall system safety efforts and not be assessed in isolation.

A SW product shall be considered safety-critical if it implements or affects one or more functions of which at least one has a criticality I or II, as defined in clause 5.9.1 of this catalogue.
When SW is used to control hazards, the SSP 51721 and SSP 50038 requirements shall apply.

requirements.text:
During the project life cycle, safety analysis shall be carried out to:
  1. identify safety-critical SW and any common resources shared between safety critical and non safety-critical SW,
  2. determine where and under what conditions the system can trigger hazardous events caused by the SW,
  3. define verification methods for hazard controls involving SW,
  4. provide verification evidence of hazard control implementation.

The criticality of a SW component shall be evaluated taking into account the overall system design which can provide for, e.g. back-up or emergency procedures, HW inhibits and certain time to effect.

Safety critical SW component shall be designed, implemented, verified and operated according to the engineering and PA requirements defined in ECSS-E-ST-40 and chapter 8 of this document.

Safety critical SW shall be analysed for the identification and verification of adequate SW controls and inhibits and validated accordingly.

The level of required SW PA effort shall be determined in accordance with the criticality of the SW component.

Touch temperature requirements of SSP 50005 shall apply.

Payload's rotating parts shall be contained. The rotating parts shall not exceed 200 mm (8 inches) in diameter and 8000 revolutions per minute (rpm) speed in all conditions. Unique controls are required for rotating parts exceeding 200 mm and 8000 rpm and shall be documented in a Unique HR.

requirements.text:
Payloads using relief valves shall be designed such as a periodic re-test of the valves is possible once the payload is on board ISS.

Alternatively the payload shall:

  • use overpressure protections that do not require periodic retest, such as a burst disc,
  • use relief valve with a threaded fitting and upstream pressure isolation that can easily be replaced,
  • provide overpressure protection that can be retested in-place,
  • provide overpressure protection that can be manually verified periodically in-place (relief valve with a manually opening device).
NOTE:
Additional details may be found in the NASA Letter ES4-14-081.

requirements.text: Hazards to the humans, public and private property and the environment, resulting from launcher system operation or malfunction shall be precluded by compliance with the regulations of the launch safety authority.
Flight rules shall be prepared for each mission that outline pre-planned decisions in case of off-nominal situations and consistent with safety requirements.
eOCADs shall be prepared for each mission that outline pre-planned decisions in case of off-nominal situations and consistent with safety requirements

Hazardous commanding control shall ensure that failure modes, associated with flight and ground operation - including HW, SW and procedures - used in commanding from control centres or other ground equipment, are included in the safety assessment.

Hazardous commanding control shall ensure that the system design provides protection to avoid the erroneous acceptance of commands that can result in catastrophic or critical consequences.

Hazardous commanding control shall ensure that commands, which can result in catastrophic or critical hazardous consequences, are not performed until they are authorized and verified.

Mission operation change control shall ensure that all changes, which are desired or become necessary during mission, are reviewed for safety impact.

Mission operation change control shall ensure that the responsible safety approval authority approves all operational CRs with safety impact.

Safety requirements of para. 5.11.6 shall be applied during the following ground operations:
  1. development, qualification or acceptance testing,
  2. assembly, integration or test operations,
  3. launch site operations,
  4. servicing or turn-around operations, and
  5. transportation or handling operations.
The supplier shall establish procedures to perform safety readiness reviews and inspections prior to the performance of any applicable operation.

To verify conformance to safety requirements, readiness reviews and inspections shall include safety review and assessment of facilities, equipment, test articles, operating, test and contingency procedures, access controls, and personnel capabilities to comply with the safety requirements.

To verify conformance to safety requirements, inspections and assessment of facilities, equipment, test articles, operating, test and contingency procedures, access controls, and personnel capabilities shall be performed to comply with the safety requirements.

Hazardous operations shall be monitored for conforming to safety requirements and procedures, and for the possible development of unforeseen hazardous situations.

Where necessary, contingency and emergency plans or procedures shall be established and verified prior to the commencement of the operation.

The safety representative shall have the authority to stop any operation that does not conform to safety requirements.

Launch, landing, turn-around and mission operations shall be subject to hazard analysis.

For ground operations, the analysis shall address the:

  1. potential hazardous consequences of human error and procedural deficiencies,
  2. adequacy and maintenance of operational margins,
  3. potential for human exposure to hazards and hazardous effects,
  4. requirements for operator and flight crew training,
  5. adequacy of information and data provided by the flight HW, GSE, or test equipment, as appropriate, to support the performance of the operations in accordance with all applicable safety requirements (including all safety regulations).

Launch, landing, turn-around and mission operations shall be subject to hazard analysis.

For ground operations, the analysis shall address the:

  1. potential hazardous consequences of human error and procedural deficiencies,
  2. adequacy and maintenance of operational margins,
  3. potential for human exposure to hazards and hazardous effects,
  4. requirements for operator,
  5. adequacy of information and data provided by the flight HW, GSE, or test equipment, as appropriate, to support the performance of the operations in accordance with all applicable safety requirements (including all safety regulations).
GSE shall be subject to hazard analysis.

Any GSE used in European space projects shall conform to EC essential safety requirements of any applicable product safety regulation. EC new approach directives shall be followed and CE marking shall be applied for GSE when applicable.
NOTE:
Custom build evaluation kits desired for professionals to be used solely at research and development facilities for such purposes are exempt from EC new approach directives and shall not bear a CE marking while product safety certification is always applicable.

Responsibilities, rules and contingency procedures shall be established prior to operation for hazardous limit conditions that can occur during ground and inflight operations.

Man-machine interfaces shall be designed and the personnel tasks shall be scoped to minimize the potential for hazardous events resulting from human error to an accepted level.
The supplier shall respond to and comply with the applicable project safety requirements for the project.

The supplier shall identify additional safety requirements where applicable through:
  • use of lessons learned from previous projects, and
  • safety analyses performed during the project.
The supplier shall define the safety requirements for the various functions of the system.
The supplier shall define the safety requirements associated with the various subsystems and lower levels.
The supplier shall justify to the DLR the proposed allocation of safety requirements at the latest at the end of the detailed definition phase.
The supplier shall ensure that the function and subsystem safety requirements are included in the relevant functional and subsystem specification.

Safety analysis shall be performed in a systematic manner as a basis for all applicable phases and to ensure that hazards are identified, eliminated or minimized and controlled and safety risks are assessed and reduced.
For payloads/instruments mounted in orbit on space-stations infrastructure, the safe installation, maintenance and removal need to be analysed.

Safety analyses shall be initiated early in the design phase and shall also provide concurrent support to project engineering in the selection of the least hazardous design and operational options that are compatible with the project mission and programmatic constraints and conform to the requirements.

The results of safety analyses shall also be used to support project management in the verification of risk reduction, ranking of risk sources, project resource allocation, monitoring of risk trends, and residual risk acceptance.

Safety analysis shall always be made with reference to a defined configuration baseline.

chapters.name: Safety Analyses during the Project Life Cycle

requirements.text: Safety analyses shall be refined and updated in an iterative manner as the design process proceeds, to ensure that hazards and hazardous events are assessed, and that the relevant detailed design and operational requirements, hazard controls, and verification activities are defined and implemented (see para. 5.3.6).

Safety analyses shall be refined and updated in an iterative manner as the design process proceeds, to ensure that hazards and hazardous events are assessed, and that the relevant detailed design and operational requirements, hazard controls, and verification activities are defined and implemented.

Hazard analysis shall be performed in a systematic manner, beginning in the concept phase and continuing through the operational phase, including end-of-life and disposal.

Hazard analysis shall support the hazard reduction process.

Hazard analysis shall identify and evaluate:

  1. hazards associated with system design, its operation (both on ground and in flight) and the operation environment,
  2. the hazardous effects resulting from the physical and functional propagation of initiator events,
  3. the hazardous events resulting from the failure of system functions and functional components,
  4. time critical situations.

The following potential initiator events shall be considered:

  1. HW failure (random or time dependent),
  2. latent SW error,
  3. operator error,
  4. design inadequacies, including:
    1. inadequate margins,
    2. unintended operating modes caused by sneak-circuits,
    3. material inadequacies and incompatibilities,
    4. HW'SW interactions.
  5. natural and induced environmental effects,
  6. procedural deficiencies.

Hazard analysis includes a systematic analysis of the "system" operations and operating procedures that shall be performed in the detailed design and operational stages of a project.

NOTE:
This analysis evaluates the capability of the system to be operated safely, to determine the safest operating modes, and to evaluate the acceptability of the operating procedures.

The systematic analysis of system operation and operating procedures shall be repeated as the design and operational detail evolves, including the system's operational modes and man-machine interfaces.

Payloads or elements thereof which are previously physically flown (and therefore have an approved safety certification) must be re-certified safe and have to meet all the safety requirements of the safety certification authority defined by the launch organisation.

The supplier shall assess the previously approved safety data for validity for the new payload considering new and changed requirements and intended flight environments.

As a result, the supplier shall provide all the data required to demonstrate the safety of his product.

The following data shall be provided:

  • identification of all reflown elements to be used,
  • identification of the baseline safety analysis,
  • assessment of each reflown element to indicate that the intended use environment is the same for which the original certification was issued,
  • new or revised HRs, additional data, and identification of deleted HRs,
  • identification and assessment of changes in HW, SW and operations which have safety impact,
  • report on the completion and results of safety verifications and submissions of SVTL/control sheet as appropriate,
  • assessment of all deviations and non-compliances: the acceptance rationale from the previous flight must be re-validated. Waived conditions from the previous flight must be corrected,
  • assessment of limited life items for reflown HW. All age sensitive equipment used in hazard control applications must be refurbished or replaced to meet the new requirements,
  • description of maintenance, structural inspections and refurbishment of reflown HW and assessment of safety impact,
  • assessment of all failures and anomalies during previous usage of the control element with corrective action taken and rationale for continued use,
  • certificate of product safety compliance.

For ESA/NASA approval authority the unique data for series/reflown payloads, payload elements, and associated GSE shall be submitted as a reflight SDP, following the reflown safety assessment described in section 7 of SSP 30599.

requirements.text:
Safety risk assessment shall:
  1. comprise the identification, classification and ranking of safety risks and their contributors,
  2. be based on deterministic hazard analysis by combining the consequence severity and the likelihood of occurrence of the consequence,
  3. be used to facilitate effective and efficient safety risk reduction and control,
  4. support project risk management as defined in ECSS-M-ST-80,
  5. assess compliance with probabilistic safety targets.
    NOTE 1:
    The estimation of event likelihoods is based on the use of different sources of data i.e.:
    • previous experience on the particular system (i.e. measured or observed directly relevant test or experience data),
    • data from other systems or projects (i.e. extrapolation from generic data, similarity data, or physical models), and
    • expert judgment (i.e. direct estimation of likelihoods by domain specialists).
    NOTE 2:
    The determination of likelihood is not a mean to downgrade the criticality of function (see para. 5.9.1).

Safety risk assessment shall be started early in the design process and performed in progressive steps during the implementation of the safety programme.

applicableDocuments.title: ECSS-M-ST-80
applicableDocuments.description: Risk Management (31 July 2008)

requirements.text: Warning time analysis shall be performed during the concept definition phase and the design and development phase in order to evaluate time critical situations identified in the hazard analysis and to support the implementation of hazardous situation detection and warning devices or contingency procedures (DRD-5.14).

Caution and warning analysis according to DRD-5.15 shall be performed during the concept definition phase and the design and development phase of human space flight programmes in order to identify:
  1. emergency, warning, and caution parameters,
  2. the required saving functions and capabilities,
  3. limit sensing requirements,
  4. the applicability of the individual "caution and warning" functions to the different mission phases.

The caution and warning analysis shall utilize the results of the warning time and hazards analyses as appropriate.

Multiple failures
Multiple failures, which result from common-cause or common-mode failure mechanisms, shall be analysed as single failures for determining failure tolerance.

Identification of requirements and scope

The supplier shall identify the requirement for and the scope of dedicated common-cause and common-mode analyses by means of the review of the results of the other safety analyses, such as FTA and hazard analysis, and of the characteristic of the system and of its environment.

Identification of common-cause failures

The supplier shall identify potential common-cause failures by assessment of the effects of common-causes.

NOTE:
For example: radiation, thermal environment and fires.

The common-cause failure analysis shall be performed in coordination with the FTA and the hazard analysis.

NOTE:
The analysis of common-cause failures can require that use be made of the result of dedicated engineering analyses, e.g. thermal analyses, meteorite or debris impact analysis.

Analysis of common-mode failures

Common-mode failures shall be analysed by means of the use of checklists (to be established by the supplier) that list potential common-modes for system components during the manufacturing, integration, test, operation and maintenance phases.

The common-mode analysis shall be coordinated with the FMEA/FMECA.

Integration of results

Results of common-cause and common-mode analysis shall be integrated with the results of the system level safety analyses (FTA, Hazard Analysis).

The FTA shall be used to establish the systematic link between the system-level hazard and the contributing hazardous events and subsystem, equipment or piece part failure.

The FTA, or its equivalent, shall be performed according to ECSS-Q-ST-40-12 (Fault tree analysis - Adoption notice ECSS/IEC 61025 and also DRD-5.16) whenever it is necessary to verify the failure tolerance of the product.

requirements.text:
Whenever safety analyses identify operator errors as a cause of catastrophic or critical hazards, a dedicated analysis shall be carried out.

The human error analysis shall be used to support the safety analysis for the identification of human operator error types and their effects and for the definition of adequate countermeasures to prevent or control human operator errors.

The human error analysis shall be developed from the early phases of the project onwards in order to define recommendations for the HW and SW design, procedure development and training preparation Programme.

NOTE:
ECSS-Q-HB-30-03 is a guideline for Human Dependability Analysis.

chapters.name: Failure Modes, Effects and Criticality Analysis (FMECA)

requirements.text:
The results of failure modes and effects analysis (FMEA) or failure modes, effects and criticality analysis (FMECA) shall be used to support the hazard analysis in the evaluation of the effects of failures.
FMEA/FMECA and hazard analysis are complementary analyses.
NOTE:
Refer to para. 4.11.2.5 for further instructions on FMEA/FMECA.

drds.title: FMECA
drds.deliveryDate: PRR; SRR; PDR; CDR; QR, AR

requirements.text:
Zonal analysis (see DRD-4.14) shall be performed where redundancy is used to reduce the probability of losing a function or of inadvertently actuating a safety critical function.
NOTE:
Zonal analysis can be part of the FMECA.

The objectives of the zonal analysis shall ensure that equipment installation meets the adequate safety requirements regarding:

  1. basic installation rules and space practices,
  2. interaction between subsystems,
  3. implication of operator errors,
  4. effects of external events.
    NOTE:
    Zonal analysis is the systematic inspection of the topology of a system, the evaluation of potential component to component interactions with and without failure, and the assessment of the severity of potential hazards inherent in the system installation.

drds.deliveryDate: PRR; SRR; PDR; CDR; QR, AR

requirements.text:
Dependability analysis shall support safety analysis.

NOTE:
For details on dependability analysis see para. 4.10.

Following supporting assessment and analysis methods shall be used as necessary (tailored by project) to support hazards analysis and safety risk assessment.
NOTE 1:
Example of tailoring by project is when the supporting assessment and analysis methods are not applicable in e.g. unmanned missions.
NOTE 2:
Assessments and analyses from ECSS-Q-ST-30 can be used to support safety assessment.

Supporting analyses shall be agreed with all relevant parties.

requirements.text:
The supplier shall establish a hazard reporting system for tracking the status of all identified hazards.

The system shall be applied for all hazards with potentially catastrophic or critical consequences.

The supplier shall report, and provide evidence, that
  1. controls are defined and agreed,
  2. verification methods are defined and agreed,
  3. verification is completed.
Identified hazards are to be documented on HR forms according to DRD-5.17, DRD-5.26 and DRD-5.27 and shall be consistent with the launch authority.

requirements.text: The supplier shall request a toxicological hazard assessment from the NASA JSC Toxicology Group for all gases, liquids, solutions, gels, biological material, powder and granular solids or for metals to be processed in a furnace, using relevant form sheets (see DRD-5.21). With the provided information, NASA JSC Toxicology Group establishes the so-called HMST (Hazardous Materials Summary Table) for tracking the status of all identified related hazards and their severity ratings.

requirements.text:
The supplier shall establish an Inflight Biohazardous Materials Approval Form (see DRD-5.23) and submit to NASA/ESA Biosafety Review Board for Biohazard categorisation and approval of biohazardous materials.

In case ground processing of biological material is planned at any location outside the experimenters' standard laboratory, a bio-hazard assessment has to be established together with the external laboratory responsible following the local rules and regulations.

requirements.text: Status of hazard control and risk reduction activities shall be reviewed at safety progress meetings and project safety reviews for compliance with decisions taken and achievement of intended results.
Status of hazard control and risk reduction activities shall be reviewed at progress meetings and project reviews for compliance with decisions taken and achievement of intended results.
All hazard documentation shall be formally issued for each FSR and major project review, as specified in para. 5.7.

A system shall be in place that tracks all hazards and related risks, to relate all verifications of the corresponding hazard uniquely to unambiguous causes and controls.

For common techniques for verification of design features used to control hazards, the requirements of ECSS-E-ST-10, shall apply.

To successfully complete the safety process, positive feedback shall be provided on completion results for all verification items associated with a given hazard.

applicableDocuments.title: ECSS-E-ST-10
applicableDocuments.description: System Engineering general requirements (15 February 2017)

requirements.text:
Verification engineering shall select the verification methods consistent:
  1. with the verification requirements documented in the HR, and
  2. with the launch site safety rules.
Verification planning shall commence in an integrated manner upon selection of the control method.

Safety verification methods shall include alternatively or in combination review of design, analysis, inspection and test.

For all safety verifications traceability shall be provided.

All relevant technical safety and engineering analyses performed or updated with analysis in respect to the as built configuration shall be used for verification.

When similarity analysis is provided, for tracking purposes it shall contain a copy of (or a unique reference to) the referenced previous verification, verification procedure and requirement valid at the time of the first verification.

All pre-flight safety inspections shall be assessed for inclusion in the MIP list.
NOTE:
If included on the MIP list, close-out is feasible by MIP reporting or individual reporting as appropriate.

Launch preparation inspections shall be entered into the appropriate launch base procedure.

The close-out shall be given by the approved launch authority procedure.
Late access procedures shall be the subject of training and shall be performed by qualified personnel.
Training for mission operation teams shall be performed, including specific safety briefing, training and mission simulation.
Training for flight crew shall be performed, including specific safety briefing, training and mission simulation.
Close out shall be by safety approved procedure, documented training session and simulations.
Inflight inspections shall be entered into flight procedures and operation manuals.
Inspections which are considered as necessary in order to meet safety requirements of the system shall be identified and included in user manuals and procedures.

The supplier shall select, and propose to the safety approval authority, the safety verification methods to be used in conformance to the applicable safety requirements.

The results of safety verification shall be submitted for approval to the relevant safety approval authority.

Safety critical functions shall be verified by testing which include application of the operating procedures, the "man-in-the-loop", and the verification of the effectiveness of applicable failure tolerance requirements.

The tests shall include the demonstration of nominal, contingency and emergency operational modes.

The safety critical characteristics of all safety critical functions shall be qualified by test.

Safety critical function qualification testing shall include the determination of performance margins considering worst case combinations of induced and natural environments and operating conditions.

Qualification "by similarity" shall not be applied except after customer approval on a case-by-case basis through RFA.

drds.title: RFA
drds.deliveryDate: immediately after contractor internal approval; MPCB; respectively summary lists for CDR; MRR; QR; AR

requirements.text: Induced failure tests shall be performed when required by safety analysis for evaluating failure effects, and for demonstrating failure tolerance conformance in safety critical functions.

Where full-scale testing is not performed, equivalent safety verification method based on technically representative HW or models shall be justified, approved and performed.

For the verification of hazard controls in catastrophic hazards where nonflight equipment replaces part of the flight equipment to test a flight function the verification shall be performed independently by a third party which was not involved in the design and qualification of the FM.
If verification cannot be completed, the supplier shall establish a SVTL.

A SVTL shall be established, in conformance with the DRD-5.25, to collect all the open verification items of the different HRs from the safety analysis.

In preparation of transfer to the next stage of system integration, the safety manager shall verify that:

  1. hazard close-outs performed so far by the responsible engineer are still valid,
  2. the verifications reflect the as-built or as-modified status of the HW,
  3. all open verifications at this time are acceptable for transfer to the next stage of system integration,
  4. all open verifications are entered into the verification tracking log (SVTL),
  5. the verification tracking log is maintained to reflect the current status.

A SVTL shall be established, in conformance with the form ISS_OE_764 (SVTL, DRD-5.24), to collect all the open verification items of the different HRs from the safety analysis.

In preparation of transfer to the next stage of system integration, the safety manager shall verify that:

  1. hazard close-outs performed so far by the responsible engineer are still valid,
  2. the verifications reflect the as-built or as-modified status of the HW,
  3. all open verifications at this time are acceptable for transfer to the next stage of system integration,
  4. all open verifications are entered into the verification tracking log (SVTL),
  5. the verification tracking log is maintained to reflect the current status.

requirements.text: If the safety verification constrains any ground operations, the safety manager shall give notification to the safety review panel.

The safety manager shall assure that each hazard considered for closure has the approval by the safety approval authority, verifying that:
  1. hazards not eliminated are controlled in accordance with the applicable requirements and associated verification activities are successfully completed, or, when applicable,
  2. deviations from, or waivers of requirements, are granted by the safety approval authority,
1. deviations from, or waivers of requirements (see para. 5.7.2), are granted by the safety approval authority,
1. the safety approval authority has granted a RFD, RFW or NASA-Safety- NCR (see para. 5.7.2).

This chapter defines the safety programme and the technical safety requirements that shall be implemented in order to protect flight and ground personnel, the launch vehicle, associated payloads, GSE, general public, public and private property and the environment from hazards associated with DLR space and ground systems.

The objective of safety assurance is to ensure that all safety risks associated with the design, development, production and operations of space product are adequately identified, assessed, minimized, controlled and finally accepted through the implementation of a safety assurance programme.

The supplier shall establish and implement throughout the duration of the business agreement a component programme which ensures that the requirements of the project as defined by the customer and the supplier in the related business agreement are in compliance with this standard.

The supplier shall identify the organization responsible for the management of the component programme, and describe the organization's approaches (including the procurement system and its rationale) and capability to efficiently implement, manage, and control the component requirements.
The supplier shall prepare a CCP in conformance with DRD-6.01 for class 1 component.
The CCP may be part of the overall project PA plan.
The supplier shall submit the CCP to the customer for acceptance.

This programme shall include detailed requirements and procedures relating to the selection, application, specification, screening, qualification, and traceability of components to be used in flight equipment.
The approval of the selection and usage of EEE parts shall be implemented through PCBs held between the customer and the supplier (or lower-tier subcontractor).

At supplier's level, the PCB shall be composed as follows:
  1. chaired by a member of the supplier's PA team with designated responsibility for components management,
  2. include, as a minimum, in addition the suppliers' parts engineer, the customer's representative and the lower-tier subcontractor parts engineers.

Other pertinent experts from the customer or suppliers may also participate, on request.

Depending on the progress of the program, the main PCB activities shall be:

  1. review and approval of the supplier's EEE CCP and any associated documents,
  2. parts type reduction and standardization,
  3. parts approval including evaluation activities,
  4. problem assessment (e.g. alerts, NCs, RFD, RFW and delivery delays).
  5. assessment activities (by sampling) including:
    1. conformity of procurement conditions,
    2. conformity of procurement data,
    3. post-procurement data, and
    4. application of alerts recommendations.
NOTE:
For (a) to (c), assessment is made by comparison of procurement documentation versus approval document.

requirements.text:
EEE components used in GSE, which are physically and directly interfacing to flight HW, shall be:
  1. fit, form and function compatible,
  2. manufactured from materials identical to the flight opposite part, and
  3. ensured to be visibly clean before each connection to flight HW.

Flight HW connector interfaces to GSE shall interface to a flight compatible connector, as described before.

NOTE:
This connector can be installed on the test harness or can be a saver.

NOTE:
The supplier of each product is responsible for the selection of components, which enables the performance, lifetime, environmental, material, safety, quality and reliability requirements of the product of which they form a part, to be satisfied in all respects.
Back-up solutions shall be identified when an availability risk is anticipated.

The supplier shall establish and maintain in his own facility, and ensure that his suppliers also establish and maintain, procedures for selecting and controlling all components intended for use in deliverable products.

Components shall be selected on the basis of proven qualification, characterization, and previous space experience and data, relevant with regard to the requirements for the programme, from manufacturers or sources (preferably European) employing effective PA programmes in manufacturing and test.

Preference shall be given to components which necessitate the least evaluation or qualification effort.
When selecting items, the supplier shall check the current data, applicability of the basis of qualification, problem notifications and alerts, and adequacy of specifications.
The supplier shall implement a type reduction activity.

> Class-1 (required for) <

Starting with the design phase of the project the supplier shall ensure maximum use of preferred (see 6.2.2.3 herein) and qualified components to achieve an effective components reduction and standardization.

> Class-1, 2, 3 commercial components (required for) <

For the assessment of commercial components, the supplier shall collect the available data on the manufacturer and the component in the JD as specified in para. 6.2.4.

NOTE:
It is important to check the exhaustiveness of the manufacturer documentation & data sheet with respect to e.g. the following items:
  • component marking,
  • mechanical description,
  • electrical and thermal description.

> Class-1, 2, 3 Commercial components (required for) <

For deep sub-micronic technologies (<90nm), the detailed test definition shall identify the technology through the construction analysis and the application.

NOTE 1:
It is important to ensure that the test conditions remain as close as possible to application.
NOTE 2:
This requirement is important due to the specificities of deep sub-micronic technologies (<90nm).

For ISS internal payloads with high reliability requirements:
In case of components that do not meet one or more of the requirements of this document, justification for usage shall be included in the DCL.
Components shall be procured according to the requirements of 6.3.2.1.3 (Class 3).

requirements.text:
For ISS internal payloads with moderate reliability requirements:
Use OTS EEE components is acceptable.
OTS EEE components shall be selected according to the following specifications order of preference:
  1. Components compliant with automotive industry specifications AEC-Q100, AEC-Q101, AEC-Q200 grade 3 (operating temperature range: -40°C to +85°C).
  2. If components with specification i. are not available, components in the industrial grade temperature range.
  3. If components with specification ii. are not available, components in the commercial temperature range (0°C to +70°C).

In case of components that do not meet one or more of the requirements of this document, justification for usage shall be included in the DCL.

requirements.text: The supplier shall ensure that non-hermetically sealed materials of components meet the requirements of para. 7.5.1 regarding offgassing, out-gassing, flammability, toxicity and any other criteria specified for the intended use.
The supplier shall evaluate the robustness of selected EEE components against the stresses induced by the assembly techniques to be employed.

With respect to health and safety, beryllium oxide (except if identified in the procurement specification), cadmium, lithium, magnesium, mercury, zinc, radioactive material and all material which can cause safety hazards shall not be used.

For limited life duration, known instability, safety hazards or reliability risk reasons, the EEE components listed below shall not be used:
  • EEE components with pure tin (less than 3% Pb in case of SnPb alloy) used as a finish on the leads, terminations and external surfaces of components and packages.
  • hollow core resistors,
  • potentiometers (except for mechanism position monitoring),
  • non-metallurgically bonded diodes,
  • semiconductor dice with unglassivated active area,
  • wet slug tantalum capacitors other than capacitor construction using double seals and a tantalum case,
  • any component whose internal construction uses metallurgic bonding with a melting temperature not compatible with the end-application mounting conditions,
  • wire link fuses < 5A,
  • TO5 relays without double welding of the mechanism to the header or with any type of integrated diodes inside.

For limited life duration, known instability, safety hazards or reliability risk reasons, EEE components listed below shall not be used for new designs:
  1. RNC90 > 100 kΩ,
  2. TO3 and DO4/DO5 packages.

The use of pure tin in internal cavities may be authorized, on a case-by-case basis, based on the demonstration that there is no alternative product and there is no risk (supported by a technical justification). The justification of the use of pure tin shall be presented during a PCB for customer's approval. The use of pure tin (inside or outside the part) shall be declared in the PAD (in the JD for commercial components).

requirements.text: Usage of obsolete parts or parts where the production is scheduled to be discontinued prior to design freeze are not allowed without customer acceptance through RFD.
For interfaces, usage of obsolete parts or parts where the production is scheduled to be discontinued prior to design freeze are not allowed without customer acceptance through RFD.

PEMs older than 3 years from date of manufacture to date of installation are not allowed.

PEMs older than 3 years have to be accepted by customer through RFD.

Concerning interfaces, PEMs not allowed older than 3 years from date of manufacture to date of installation.
NOTE:
Due to moisture ingress, molding material creepage, risk of corrosion, material aging, etc., it is necessary to limit the age of PEMs.

PEMs older than 3 years have to be accepted by customer through RFD.

> Class-1, 2, 3 Commercial components (required for) <

To assess Pb free with tin finish whisker risk, the following actions shall be performed by the supplier:

  • In order to verify information from manufacturer (included in the JD), as part of the incoming inspection, check the lead finish of all procured lots as per ESCC 25500 basic specification.
  • When confirmed during incoming, assess individually each use of pure tin termination through a RFD.

applicableDocuments.title: ESCC 25500
applicableDocuments.description: Methodology for the detection of pure tin in the external surface finish of case and leads of EEE components (April 2013)

requirements.text:
> Class-1 commercial components (required for) <

To assess Pb free with tin finish whisker risk, the following actions shall be performed by the supplier:

  • submit each lot confirmed with pure tin terminations to solder dip with an SnPb solder,
  • perform the retinning operation before screening and before the LAT,
  • before retinning of flight parts, document the hot solder dip process by a procedure to be submitted to customer on request for review,
    NOTE:
    Solder dip for tin whisker mitigation differs from solder dip for solderability in that for tin whisker mitigation it is required that the termination is coated over its entire length, right up to the package surface (no standoff).
  • perform the lot acceptance of retinned components in conformance with ECSS-Q-ST-60-13, para. 8.

applicableDocuments.title: ECSS-Q-ST-60-13
applicableDocuments.description: Commercial EEE components (21 October 2013)

requirements.text:
> Class-2 + 3 commercial components (required for) <

To assess Pb free with tin finish whisker risk, the following actions shall be performed by the supplier:

  • collect and synthesize all information participating to the risk analysis in conformance with para. 6.8,
  • based on the risk analysis, elaborate a mitigation plan, submitted to the customer for review,
  • include into the mitigation plan one or a combination of the following solutions (not limited to):
    1. retinning of terminations with complementary evaluation in conformance with para. 6.2.3.5 and LAT in conformance with para. 6.2.3.5,
    2. in case of both retinning and screening, perform the screening on retinned components,
    3. tin whisker sensitivity evaluation,
    4. conformal coating,
    5. design modification.
    NOTE:
    Solder dip for tin whisker mitigation differs from solder dip for solderability in that for tin whisker mitigation, it is required that the termination is coated over its entire length, right up to the package surface (no standoff).
  • submit the mitigation plan and results for the customer approval through RFA.

requirements.text:
Safety relevant restrictions per chapter 5 have to be respected for EEE components selection.
For reliability risk reasons, the EEE components listed below shall not be used:
  1. hollow core resistors,
  2. potentiometers (except for mechanism position monitoring),
  3. non-metallurgically bonded diodes,
  4. semiconductor dies with unglassivated active area,
  5. any component whose internal construction uses metallurgic bonding with a melting temperature not compatible with the end-application mounting conditions,
  6. wire link fuses < 5 A,
  7. TO5 relays without double welding of the mechanism to the header or with any type of integrated diodes inside,
  8. RNC90 > 100 kΩ,
  9. TO3 and DO4/DO5 packages.

EEE components with pure tin (less than 3% Pb in case of SnPb alloy) used as a finish on the leads, terminations and external surfaces of components and packages can be used providing re-tinning is carried out as per ECSS-Q-ST-60-13.

NOTE:
Solder dip for tin whisker mitigation differs from solder dip for solderability in that for tin whisker mitigation it is required that the termination is coated over its entire length, right up to the package surface (no standoff).

Lead free control plan shall be provided to minimize tin whiskers to meet level 2B of ANSI GEIA-STD-0005-02.

Preference shall be given to components from sources that will necessitate the least evaluation/qualification effort.
Parts subject to export restrictions or regulations shall not be preferred.
Components selected from sources according to para. 6.2.2.3 and appropriately applied in accordance with the derating criteria (para. 4.11.2.11) are considered qualified for use.

When the application of a standard component requires performances to a parameter beyond that for which it was qualified or a non-standard component has been selected, project qualification shall be accomplished. Any changes to the approved qualification status or negotiated and initially approved project component list shall require DLR approval by RFA or PAD as described in DRD-7.01 and DRD-6.06.

requirements.text:
The qualification programme shall cover as a minimum the following elements:
  • The supplier shall assure that the selected manufacturer complies with the requirements defined in this document.
  • The supplier shall also ensure that the components are actually procured from the selected manufacturers or authorized distributor.
  • Traceability data shall be available to show that the flight components have been made according to the same technology and manufacturing processes as the evaluated components.
  • If a qualification as defined herein of a component type cannot be demonstrated, a component evaluation and approval test programme, as defined herein, shall be implemented.
  • Such programmes shall be accepted by the customer before their implementation.
The method for qualifying the component shall be identified on the relevant qualification test plan and corresponding specification.

Qualification by similarity may be acceptable, with no additional space qualification testing, when it can be demonstrated that similarity exists to a space-qualified component. Similarity is given when, as a minimum, the following criteria are verified:
  • the component technology is identical,
  • the component is of comparable complexity,
  • the component is produced with the same materials and processes,
  • the component is tested according to the same screening levels.

Qualification by test shall be accomplished when:
  • the component has never been qualified,
  • the component has to be used in an application in which the performance for which it was qualified is exceeded,
  • design, materials manufacturing processes or quality controls of a qualified component are altered, or when facilities are relocated and not confirmed by the qualifying authority.

The supplier who is responsible for the design of the piece of HW shall demonstrate the compliance of its components selection with the radiation constraints of the project.

For this demonstration, the supplier shall consider all types of radiation including cosmic (heavy ions), electromagnetic, trapped (charged particles - electrons, protons - in radiation belts) and solar (flares).

Due consideration shall be given to the mission orbit and trajectory, the duration, the associated spatial and temporal variations of the radiation environment as well as all protective factors such as shielding.

The supplier shall assess the actual radiation tolerance of the selected components for compliance with the radiation requirements in term of total dose, displacement damage and SEE.

The supplier shall identify components which are not compliant with the radiation requirements as critical radiation sensitive components.

The supplier shall implement a radiation hardness assurance programme, documented by a plan to be submitted to the customer for acceptance, for radiation sensitive components, covering the collection of all relevant information and specifying the necessary actions in terms of evaluation and procurement testing, planning and control (DRD-6.05).

The supplier shall issue an equipment radiation analysis document identifying all sensitive components w.r.t. the relevant radiation effects, possibly their impact and giving an adequate engineering solution (e.g. local shielding, design solution, specific test, and RVT) for the relevant equipment.

The equipment radiation analysis document shall be submitted to the customer for acceptance.

NOTE:
More detailed information about the above requirements is given in ECSS-E-ST-10-12 and ECSS-Q-ST-60-15.

Cosmic-ray effects as well as total-dose radiation effects must be considered in accordance with projects requirements in the selection and application of components exposed to a radiation environment. SSP 30512 shall apply.
The supplier shall issue a radiation analysis document identifying all sensitive components with respect to the relevant radiation effects, their impact and giving an adequate engineering solution.

requirements.text: The hardening of an electronic system or subsystem to total dose shall comprise both the selection of radiation hardened devices and radiation tolerant design.
For all interfaces, the hardening of electronics to total dose shall comprise both the selection of radiation hardened devices and radiation tolerant design.

The following major steps are required:
  • identification of levels of radiation for the design of the product in which the component will be used,
  • specification of radiation tolerance,
  • identification of radiation sensitive components,
  • definition and implementation of adequate measures.

A WCCA shall be performed taking the change of the device parameters due to radiation effects into account. The WCCA shall demonstrate that the circuit will operate at the maximum specified radiation level with an adequate radiation design margin taking into account the radiation shielding produced by the mechanical design configuration (PSS-01-609 >>Radiation Design Handbook<< may be used as a guideline).

Circuit hardening shall be performed considering the most cost effective approach as following:
  • circuit should be designed to maximize the use of non-sensitive components,
  • vendors with a history of providing commercial (non-hardened) components that are radiation resistant should be selected,
  • circuit design should minimize the sensitivity of critical parameters,
  • radiation hardened components should be used.

SEE hardening shall be performed to minimize or exclude the impact of SEEs on system performance. SEEs include:
  • Single Event Upsets (SEU),
  • Single Event Latch-Up (SEL),
  • Single Event Induced Burn-out (SEB),
  • Single Event Gate Rupture (SEGR),
  • Single Event Transients (SET).

The following major steps are required:

  • for each type of SEE the organization responsible for the design of the product in which each component is to be used has to specify the LET threshold value for which heavy ions induced SEE can be considered as insensitive,
  • the identification of SEE-sensitive devices,
  • selection of devices with sufficient LET value, whenever this is possible,
  • if the circuit cannot be implemented without SEE-sensitive devices, SEE circuit analysis shall be prepared determining the impact on the system performance by calculations. These calculations shall be based on the known (or estimated) event rate and the mission orbit heavy ion spectra (LET spectra),
  • if the specific application and/or the project requirements cannot tolerate the soft failures suitable HW/SW modification, e.g. error detection and correction circuits (EDAC), redundancy, watch-dog circuits etc. should be implemented.

Radiation sensitive components, as defined above, and for which applicable existing test data is insufficient shall be subjected to RVT.

RVT shall be performed in accordance with internationally recognized standards, such as ESCC Basic Specifications No. 22900 and No. 25100.

NOTE:
Additional information on test methods is given in MIL-STD-750 Test Method 1019, MIL-STD-883 Test Method 1019 and JEDEC JESD57.

In such a case, a PAD in conformance with DRD-6.06 shall be issued and processed as per para. 6.2.4.

The results of RVT shall be documented by a report.

When RVT is performed in the frame of the project, the supplier shall send the related report to the customer for information.

Parts submitted to RVT shall be screened as specified in clause 6.3.4 to be fully representative of flight parts.
The control of radiation hardness shall be supported by a Radiation Control Plan (DRD-6.05) for recording the protective action taken, for each sensitive part in the system or subsystem.

> Class-1, 2, 3 Commercial components (required for) <

For commercial components, the supplier shall assess the actual radiation tolerance of the selected components for compliance with the radiation requirements in term of total dose, displacement damages and single events effects (e.g. SEB, SEGR, SEL, SET, SEU).

requirements.text:
> Class-1, 2, 3 Commercial components (required for) <

Commercial parts shall be selected in the highest available temperature range.
A minimum 10°C margin shall be used between the maximum manufacturer temperature range and the application temperature range (including worst cases).

In case |(manufacturer max temperature range - used max temp)|< 10°C, an electrical characterisation shall be performed at used temperature with an additional margin of 10°C during the evaluation step.
NOTE 1:
Example: for a manufacturer -40°C/+85°C temperature range with an application up to +80°C, then an electrical characterisation is performed at +90°C.
NOTE 2:
Example: for a manufacturer -40°C/+85°C temperature range with an application down to -35°C, then an electrical characterisation is performed at -45°C.

The supplier shall implement derating rules for components used in his design in accordance with the requirements of para. 4.11.2.11. For wire link fuses, the current derating factor shall be 50 % with an additional derating of 0,2 %/°C for an increase in the temperature of fuse body above 25 °C.
The supplier shall implement derating rules for the used components in accordance with the requirements of ECSS-Q-ST-30-11. Evidence shall be provided in the electrical and thermal analyses.

applicableDocuments.description: Derating - EEE components (4 October 2011)

requirements.text: The components control effort shall include the identification of all critical components.

Components identified as critical shall be incorporated in the CIL acc. to para. 2.2.4.
The CIL/critical components shall be subject for DLR approval before use.

drds.title: Critical Items List
drds.deliveryDate: SRR; PDR; CDR; QR; AR; FRR; LRR

requirements.text:
The critical components are:
  • components with limited operating life, shelf life, or tolerance to environmental exposure (e.g. vibration, thermal, acceleration, chemical, radiation),
  • components stressed in excess of the specified derating criteria,
  • components these may pose a safety hazard,
  • components these may create a safety risk,
  • components these may resemble a procurement risk (LLI, pending obsolescence, export restriction),
  • components under evaluation,
  • single source components which are not from PPL,
  • special components still under development (ASICs, hybrids, MMICs),
• all Ball Grid Array and Column Grid Array packages, and its variants.

The supplier shall perform a component evaluation in absence of an approved demonstration that a component has the ability to conform to the requirements for functional performance, quality, dependability, and environmental resistance as required for the project.

For all interfaces, the supplier shall perform a component evaluation in absence of an approved demonstration that a component has the ability to conform to the requirements for functional performance, quality, dependability, and environmental resistance as required for the project.

The supplier shall plan and carry out the evaluation.

The scope and planning of the component evaluation shall be derived from the results of an assessment of the design and intended application of the component.
An evaluation plan shall be sent to the customer for acceptance, and include the following elements:

drds.number: EEE Evaluation Plan acc. to requirement
drds.title: EEE Evaluation Plan

requirements.text:
> Class-1 (required for) <

  • Component Manufacturer Assessment,
• Constructional Analysis,

> Class-1, 2 + 3 (required for) <

  • Evaluation Testing,
• Radiation Hardness.
Omission of any of these elements, or the introduction of alternative activities, shall be justified.

All tests and inspections shall be carried out on representative samples of the component type from the current production of the manufacturer selected for the component procurement for the flight HW.
For programmable devices, the representativeness shall include the programming HW tools and the compatibility of the SW.
The supplier shall review the evaluation results to determine their impact on the content of the procurement specification which shall be amended as necessary.
The supplier shall summarize the evaluation results in the evaluation report and send it to the customer for acceptance.

> Class-1 + 2 commercial components (required for) <

The supplier shall prepare a preliminary internal supplier's specification for electrical testing during evaluation tests.
The supplier specification shall as minimum include tested parameters, test conditions, acceptance criteria, drift limits.
The supplier shall update the internal supplier's specification used for screening and lot acceptance in accordance with the results of evaluation testing.
The preliminary and the final internal supplier's specification as specified by DRD-6.09 shall be submitted to the customer for acceptance.

> Class-1 (required for) <

The purpose of the manufacturer assessment is to determine its capability, to ensure the adequacy of its organisation, plant and facilities, and to ascertain its fitness to supply components to the appropriate specifications for space application.
The supplier shall perform an evaluation against the ESCC basic specification no. 20200 and the ancillary specifications for dedicated component families and shall include, but not necessarily be limited to, a survey of:

  • the overall manufacturing facility and its organization and management,
  • the manufacturer's system for inspection and manufacturing control including all relevant specifications, procedures, and internal documents,
  • the production line used for the component.

The complete manufacturer assessment, including the survey report and the associated corrective actions, shall be part of the evaluation report.

applicableDocuments.title: ESCC 20200
applicableDocuments.description: Component manufacturer evaluation

requirements.text:
Constructional analysis shall be carried out on representative components.
NOTE:
The primary aim of constructional analysis is to provide an early indication of a component's constructional suitability for meeting the specified performances of the space project application.
The findings of the analysis shall be contained within a constructional analysis report and shall be included in the evaluation report.

> Class-1, 2 + 3 (required for) <

The constructional analysis shall comprise destructive and NDIs, analyses, and testing, to identify:

  • design and construction technology,
  • materials used,
  • inherent reliability aspects,
  • quality of workmanship,
  • potential hazards.

> Class-1, 2, 3 Commercial components (required for) <

The construction analysis shall be documented by a procedure to be sent to the customer on request for review.

NOTE:
Annex H of ECSS-Q-ST-60-13 provides guidelines for such procedure.

applicableDocuments.title: ECSS-Q-ST-60-13
applicableDocuments.description: Commercial EEE components (21 October 2013)

requirements.text: The evaluation shall determine which inspections or tests are required to provide the confidence that the component type under evaluation, when assembled and tested in accordance with the procurement specification, successfully meets the project requirements.

The supplier shall review the already existing data in order to adapt and minimize the content of the evaluation testing while ensuring that there are inputs and pertinent results covering the following topics:
  1. endurance test (operating at elevated temperature and electrical stress),
  2. mechanical stress (shock, vibration, constant acceleration),
  3. environmental stress (thermal shock, temperature cycling, high and low temperature storage, humidity),
  4. assembly capability testing,
  5. radiation testing, for total dose and SEEs sensitivity.
NOTE:
For guidance refer to ESCC basic specification no. 22600 and the ancillary specifications for dedicated component families.

> Class-1, 2, 3 Commercial components (required for) <

In case of retinning of components with pure tin terminations, an evaluation and lot acceptance for these retinned parts for each class of components shall be performed as specified in the flow charts of ECSS-Q-ST-60-13C chapter 8.

requirements.text:
The supplier shall document the procedure for approval of each component type intended for use in flight products.

The approval of components shall be based on consideration of all pertinent data including both the electrical and environmental performances as well as the established quality and the dependability assurance requirements.

The supplier shall maintain a system of traceability of the acceptance and approval of each component used in flight products. The approval process by the customer shall be organized as follows:

  • all parts belonging to EPPL, NPSL or qualified according to quality levels defined in para. 6.3.2 are approved through acceptance of DCL,
  • a PAD or RFA is required for any other part (including CECC parts),
  • a PAD or RFA is also required for EPPL, NPSL or qualified parts when:
    1. additional controls are required (e.g. precap, buy-off, LAT, RVT, DPA),
    2. used outside the specified limits,
    3. specific tests are required during procurement as per tables of para. 6.3.2,
    4. pure tin is used inside or outside the part,
  • a JD is required for any commercial part, instead of PAD.

When a PAD or a JD is required, the customer's approval process shall include 2 steps:

Step 1: approval of the part type and attached action plan, through PAD or JD for the PDR.
Step 2: approval of the results of the action plan defined during step 1 through PAD or JD.

PAD to be established according to DRD-6.06, or EEE JD according to DRD-6.08, RFA to be established according to DRD-7.01.

requirements.text: The supplier shall ensure that all procured components meet the programme requirements with respect to inspection, screening and tests. The supplier shall be responsible for manufacturer surveillance and control throughout the procurement programme.

> Class-1 and Class-2 (required for) <

For non-qualified parts, the supplier shall put in place a configuration control system to ensure that any change of the product (e.g. mask, manufacturing and assembly process) affecting evaluation, performance, quality, reliability and interchangeability is communicated to him by the manufacturer (e.g. PCN). The supplier shall ensure the compatibility of the change with its application. The change shall be submitted to the customer for acceptance.

NOTE:
e.g. customer notification of product/process changes by semiconductor suppliers acc. with JEDEC Standard J-STD-046 - see para. 2.2.9.1.
