applicableDocuments.description: Customer Notification of Product/Process Changes by Semiconductor Suppliers

requirements.text: To reduce the risk of procuring counterfeit components, when parts are not directly procured from the manufacturer, the supplier shall procure parts only from distributors duly franchised by the parts manufacturer.

> Class-1, 2, 3 Commercial components (required for) <

Each procured EEE part shall be traceable to a manufacturer assigned trace code.

NOTE:
The procurement of a single trace code per delivery lot should be preferred and encouraged.

Each trace code shall be maintained as is through the entire supply chain including distributor.

NOTE:
As far as possible, commercial parts should be ordered in the manufacturer's standard packing quantities or multiples thereof to avoid distributor re-packing and handling and to preserve the traceability information usually included on the original manufacturer packaging.

To reduce the risk of procuring counterfeits, all components shall be procured directly from the manufacturer, from franchised distributors or other recognised sources which provide adequate level of confidence to ensure that the components being procured are genuine hi-rel and suitable for use in the project.
The supplier shall procure EEE components according to controlled specification.
The following information shall be included as a minimum:
  1. relevant electrical and mechanical parameters,
  2. quality grade,
  3. screening, burn-in, and acceptance requirements,
  4. documentation/data requirements,
  5. delta limits when applicable,
  6. criteria for percent detective allowable,
  7. LAT quality conformance inspection (when applicable),
  8. marking,
  9. storage requirements,
  10. requirements for lot homogeneity,
  11. serialisation (when applicable),
  12. protective packaging and handling requirements,
  13. RVT requirements (when applicable).

For OTS EEE components, the procurement specification can be a manufacturer's drawing or a datasheet.
The procurement of commercial EEE components shall be in conformance with the requirements of clause 6.3 of ECSS-Q-ST-60-13C.

applicableDocuments.title: ECSS-Q-ST-60-13
applicableDocuments.description: Commercial EEE components (21 October 2013)

requirements.text:
To reduce the risk of procuring counterfeits, all components shall be procured directly from well reputed manufacturers, from authorized distributors or from other recognised sources that provide adequate level of confidence to ensure that the components being procured are genuine and suitable for use in the project.

The supplier shall procure EEE components according to controlled specification.

For OTS EEE components, the procurement specification can be a manufacturer's drawing or a datasheet.

EEE PART FAMILY QUALITY LEVEL SUPPLEMENTARY CONDITIONS

requirements.text: The screening or quality level shall be in accordance with the following requirements.

Summary of evaluation, screening and lot acceptance of Class-1, 2 + 3 commercial components.

Details are specified in ECSS-Q-ST-60-13C.

applicableDocuments.title: ECSS-Q-ST-60-13
applicableDocuments.description: Commercial EEE components (21 October 2013)

requirements.text:
For commercial components, screening tests shall be performed in accordance with the following table.
Screening tests for Class 3 commercial components
Test Sampling Method Comments
1 PIND test 100% MIL-STD-750 method 2052 cond. A
MIL-STD-883 method 2020 cond. A		 Applicable to cavity package only.
2 Seal test 100% MIL-STD-750 method 1071 cond. H1 or H2 and C or K

MIL-STD-883 method 1014 cond. A or B and C		 Applicable to hermetic & cavity package only.
In case of retinning, test to be done after retinning.
3 Electrical test 100% Electrical test (parametrical and functional) at 3 temp. as per the datasheet (selected functional tests and parameters) To be done only in case of retinning.
4 PDA - On step 3.
Max acceptable PDA: 5%		 To be done only in case of retinning.
PDA calculation applies to room temperature measurement only.
5 External visual inspection 100% MIL-STD-750 method 2071

MIL-STD-883 method 2009		 To be done only in case of retinning.
The MIL specs are not adapted to visual inspection of plastic encapsulated components, but can be used as reference (mainly for connection corrosion and marking acceptance).
In addition, for plastic packages, inspect for the following defects:
Package deformation/ Foreign inclusions in the package, voids and cracks in the plastic/ deformed leads.

applicableDocuments.title: MIL-STD-750
applicableDocuments.description: Test Method Standard for Semiconductor Devices

requirements.text:
Based on classified functions, units and/or assemblies into criticality categories acc. para. 4.8.2, the following components class conditions shall be used:
  1. Severity level-1/2/3
    Class-1 components
    Class-1 commercial components
     
  2. Severity level-4
    Class-1/Class-2 components
    Class-1/ Class-2 commercial components
     
  3. Class-3 components are not allowed.
    Class-3 commercial components are not allowed.
NOTE:
FMECA shall be performed to identify and classify the criticality of functions, units and/or assemblies.

Based on classified functions, units and/or assemblies into criticality categories acc. para. 4.8.2, the following components class conditions shall be used:
  1. Severity level-1
    Class-1 components or
    Class-2 components if unit or assembly will be redundant
    Class-1 commercial components or
    Class-2 commercial components if unit or assembly will be redundant
     
  2. Severity level-2/3
    Class-3 components if unit or assembly will be redundant
    Class-2 commercial components or
    Class-3 commercial components if unit or assembly will be redundant
     
  3. Severity level-4
    Class-2/Class-3 components
    Class-2/Class-3 commercial components
NOTE:
FMECA shall be performed to identify and classify the criticality of functions, units and/or assemblies.

Based on classified functions, units and/or assemblies into criticality categories acc. para. 4.8.2, the following components class conditions shall be used:
  1. Severity level-1
    Class-2 components
    Class-2 commercial components
     
  2. Severity level-2
    Class-2 components or
    Class-3 components if unit or assembly will be redundant
    Class-2 commercial components or
    Class-3 commercial components if unit or assembly will be redundant
     
  3. Severity level-3 + 4
    Class-2/Class-3 or
    Class-2/Class-3 commercial components
NOTE:
  • FMECA shall be performed to identify and classify the criticality of functions, units and/or assemblies.
  • Suitability of commercial components shall be determined as defined in para. 6.2.2.4.

Based on classified functions, units and/or assemblies into criticality categories acc. para. 4.8.2, the following components class conditions shall be used:
  1. Severity level-1/2/3/4
    Class-3 components
    Class-3 commercial components
     
NOTE:
  • FMECA shall be performed to identify and classify the criticality of functions, units and/or assemblies.
  • Suitability of commercial components shall be determined as defined in para. 6.2.2.4.

Based on classified functions, units and/or assemblies into criticality categories acc. para. 4.8.2, the following components class conditions shall be used:
  1. Severity level-1/2

    Class-3 components
    Class-3 commercial components
  2. Severity level 3/4

    Class-3 components
    Class-3 commercial components
NOTE:
  • FMECA shall be performed to identify and classify the criticality of functions, units and/or assemblies.
  • Suitability of commercial components shall be determined as defined in para. 6.2.2.4.

Class-1 components shall meet the quality levels and supplementary conditions specified in para. 6.3.2.1.1.
Class-1 commercial components screening tests shall be performed in accordance with para. 6.3.2.2.

Class 2 components shall meet the quality levels and supplementary conditions specified in para. 6.3.2.1.2.
Class-2 commercial components screening tests shall be performed in accordance with para. 6.3.2.2.

Class 3 components shall meet the quality levels and supplementary conditions specified in para. 6.3.2.1.3.
Class-3 commercial components screening tests shall be performed in accordance with para. 6.3.2.2.
Commercial components which do not meet the required "Class-1-, 2- or 3-commercial" requirement have to be approved by DLR per RFA or PAD as described in DRD-7.01 and DRD-6.06.

drds.deliveryDate: immediately after contractor internal approval; PCB;  respectively summary lists for CDR; MRR; QR; AR

drds.deliveryDate: immediately after contractor internal approval; MPCB; respectively summary lists for CDR; MRR; QR; AR

requirements.text: The supplier shall procure EEE components according to controlled specifications.
The supplier shall keep each procurement specification under configuration control.

> Class-1 (required for) <

International specifications systems, recognized as suitable for space applications (e.g. ESCC, MIL), shall be used by the supplier.

> Class-2 + 3 (required for) <

International specifications systems, new specifications or manufacturer's datasheets under configuration shall be used by the supplier.

> Class-1, 2 + 3 (required for) <

Any new specification shall be prepared and designed by the supplier as per existing international specification systems (ESCC, MIL). Preference shall be given to ESCC format when agreed by the manufacturer. The content of any new specification shall be as specified in the procurement specification DRD-6.07.

The use of any new specification shall be submitted to the customer for acceptance through the PAD process (see clause 6.2.4).

Upon request, any new procurement specification prepared in the frame of the project, shall be delivered to the customer.

The supplier shall keep each procurement specification under configuration control.

drds.title: PAD
drds.deliveryDate: immediately after contractor internal approval; PCB;  respectively summary lists for CDR; MRR; QR; AR

requirements.text:
> Class-1, 2, 3 Commercial components (required for) <

It can be procurer's in-house specification, a manufacturer's drawing or a datasheet as a minimum.
If additional requirements to the manufacturer are identified by the supplier, they shall be specified in the procurement specification.

The procurement documents for commercial components shall address the following as a minimum:
  • absolute maximum ratings including operating and storage temperature range of the parts,
  • outline/package drawing, table of dimensions, pin configuration, lead finish and other,
  • mechanical parameters as applicable,
  • electrical circuit and/or functional block diagram and pin allocation,
  • electrical parameters and limits at room temperature and at temperature extremes,
  • any delta testing required to establish the parts' acceptability (as identified during the space application suitability assessment), e.g. screening, burn-in, vibration or shock testing, ... etc.,
  • drift limits for selected electrical parameters as applicable,
  • criteria for percent defective allowable (PDA) if and as agreed upon with the parts supplier,
  • marking and ordering information to address possible variants, electrical grades and tolerance options,
  • protective packaging and handling precautions,
  • ESD sensitivity,
  • radiation sensitivity if applicable.
All components to be incorporated into flight-standard HW shall be subjected to screening.
For instrument/payload-interfaces to spacecraft, all components to be incorporated into flight-standard HW shall be subjected to screening testing.
The screening test requirements shall be defined such that accumulated stress will not jeopardise component reliability.

> Class-1, 2 + 3 (required for) <

All screening tests shall be performed at the component manufacturer's premises or at a facility approved either by the qualification approval authority, where applicable (e.g. ESCC), or otherwise by the supplier.

> Class-1, 2 + 3 (required for) <

The applicable quality levels defined in para. 6.3.2 shall apply.

> Class-1, 2, 3 Commercial components (required for) <

For commercial components, screening tests shall be performed in accordance with the applicable components class screening table of para. 6.3.2.2.
When a component is available in a qualified version according to quality level specified in 6.3.2, it shall be selected.

In case a component is not available in a qualified version according to quality level specified in the table in para. 6.3.2.1.1, the screening of the component shall meet the screening flow defined by the generic specifications listed in the table in para. 6.3.2.1.1.

In case a component is not available in a qualified version according to quality level specified in the table in para. 6.3.2.1.2, the screening of the component shall meet the screening flow defined by the generic specifications listed in the table in para. 6.3.2.1.2.

In case a component is not available in a qualified version according to quality level specified in the table in para. 6.3.2.1.3, the screening of the component shall meet the screening flow defined by the generic specifications listed in the table in para. 6.3.2.1.3.
In case of X-rays inspection the total dose deposited shall be less than 1/10 of the product acceptable dose.

> Class-1 (required for) <

The procurement entity shall carry out, at the manufacturer's premises, a customer precap inspection for non-space qualified parts listed below:

  1. capacitors (ceramic, mica and plastic film),
  2. crystals,
  3. oscillators,
  4. discrete semiconductors (including diodes and transistors),
  5. filters,
  6. fuses (cermet),
  7. inductors, coils and transformers (not applicable to in-house products),
  8. monolithic microcircuits (including MMICs),
  9. hybrid circuits,
  10. relays,
  11. resistors (high precision, fixed, metal foil - RNC90),
  12. switches (including mechanical and thermal),
  13. optoelectronic devices (e.g. opto-couplers, LEDs, CCDs and sensors).

The procurement entity shall carry out, at the manufacturer's premises, a customer precap inspection on critical space qualified parts, including as a minimum relays, crystals, oscillators and hybrids.
When not covered by MIL or ESCC specifications, methods and accept/reject criteria for customer's precap inspection shall be documented by a procedure to be presented to the customer, on request, for review.

drds.number: Customer Precap Procedure acc. to requirement
drds.title: Customer Precap Procedure

requirements.text:
> Class-2 (required for) <

The procurement entity shall carry out, at the manufacturer's premises, a customer precap inspection for the following non-space qualified parts types:

  • relays,
  • crystals,
  • oscillators, and
  • hybrids.

When not covered by MIL or ESCC specifications, methods and accept/reject criteria for customer's precap inspection shall be documented by a procedure to be presented to the customer, on request, for review.

drds.number: Customer Precap Procedure acc. to requirement
drds.title: Customer Precap Procedure

requirements.text:
> Class-3 components and Commercial components (required for) <

A customer precap is not required.
The supplier shall ensure that any lot or datecode of EEE parts is submitted to a lot acceptance procedure (in line with applied normative systems) according to the following rules:

• Space qualified parts:
    1. ESCC: User's lot acceptance on the procured lot/date code is not required due to periodic lot validation testing performed by the manufacturer.
    2. MIL: QCI or TCI performed by the manufacturer is in accordance with the quality level of the MIL specification.

• Class-1, Non-space qualified parts ( required for):
    1. The content of the lot acceptance is ESCC level LAT1 or level LAT2 or LVT (subgroups 1, 2 and 3) or comparable QCI.
    2. The lot acceptance may be replaced by the review of available data less than 2 years old and provided there have been no changes to the manufacturing process and no changes to the part design and construction.
    3. In case of partial available data, any complementary lot acceptance content is defined by the supplier subject to PCB agreement.
    4. The PCB documents and justifies any reduced lot acceptance based on available data for customer approval.
    NOTE 1:
    LAT1 is required unless reliability data are available on the same package from the same manufacturer.
    NOTE 2:
    For PCB see para. 6.1.3.

• Class-2 + 3, Non-space qualified parts (required for):
    1. The content of the lot acceptance is defined according to the available data.
    2. The proposed lot acceptance is approved through the approval process (see para. 6.2.4).
The sample size for lot acceptance which may be reduced in some cases is submitted to the customer for approval through the PAD process (see para. 6.2.4).

requirements.text:
> Class-1 + 2 commercial components (required for) <

Each trace code is submitted to lot acceptance as defined in ECSS-Q-ST-60-13 "Lot Acceptance Tests for Class-1/2 Components".
The proposed lot acceptance is approved through the approval process in accordance with the clause 6.2.4.
Omission of any of these elements, or the introduction of alternative tests, is justified.
If evaluation test is performed directly on flight lot (and if in conformance with lot acceptance and screening requirements), evaluation data can be used as lot acceptance.
The lot acceptance report is sent to the customer, on request, for information.

The content of the lot acceptance is defined according to information provided by the JD.
Without any representative data, the tests specified in ECSS-Q-ST-60-13 "Lot Acceptance Tests for Class-3 Components" are performed.

The lot acceptance report is sent to the customer, on request, for information.

requirements.text:
> Class-1 + 2 (required for) <

  1. The procurement entity shall carry out, at the manufacturer's premises, a final customer source inspection for non-space qualified parts, based on inspections, tests and review activities to verify that the requirements of the purchase order are met prior to shipment of the flight parts.
  2. The buy-off shall include:
    • external visual inspection,
    • witnessing electrical measurements,
    • verifying mechanical dimensions,
    • review and verification of the data-package.
  3. The buy-off may be replaced by an incoming inspection at the procurement entities facilities.
  4. If the buy-off is replaced by an incoming inspection at the procurement entities facilities, it shall be declared in the PAD which is submitted to the customer for approval.

drds.title: PAD
drds.deliveryDate: immediately after contractor internal approval; PCB;  respectively summary lists for CDR; MRR; QR; AR

requirements.text:
> Class-3/Class-3 Commercial component (required for) <

A buy-off is not required.

> Class-1 + 2 commercial components (required for) <

For commercial parts, the buy off shall be replaced by an incoming inspection at the procurement entity's facility reported in the JD in accordance with para. 6.3.9.

chapters.name: Parts Shipment from Manufacturer to Purchaser

requirements.text:
For commercial components typically bulk packaging is used for the shipment of components to the purchaser, while for standard space level components individual packaging may be used in line with the procurement specification requirements.
Nevertheless, all components shall not suffer changes in any characteristics or loss of inherent reliability during shipment and storage. Components which are sensitive to electrostatic discharge shall be packaged in such a manner that they cannot be damaged by a discharge and the bulk or individual packages shall bear an appropriate ESD warning label.
The procurement entity shall perform incoming inspection at his premises on all components to verify conformance with the purchase order requirements.
The incoming inspection shall be documented by a procedure to be sent, on request, to the customer for review.

The incoming inspection shall include the following items:
  1. For any part:
    • marking control,
    • quantity verification,
    • packing checking,
    • review of the manufacturer delivered documentation,
    • additional tests based on the type of component, criticality and heritage with the manufacturer (e.g. solderability tests, electrical tests).
    • In case of not golden termination finish check the lead finish as per ESCC 25500 basic specification.
  2. For the non-space qualified parts, when the final customer source inspection has not been performed, the following additional items:
    • External visual inspection by sampling (AQL 0,65% level II or 20 parts min)
    • Electrical measurements at room temperature on 20 parts or 100% (if lot size < 20 parts), or a datapackage review.

applicableDocuments.title: ESCC 25500
applicableDocuments.description: Methodology for the detection of pure tin in the external surface finish of case and leads of EEE components (April 2013)

requirements.text:
The incoming inspection shall include tests based on the type of component, criticality, and heritage with the manufacturer (e.g. solderability tests, electrical tests).

The procurement entity shall perform incoming inspection at his premises on all components to verify conformance with the purchase order requirements.

applicableDocuments.title: ESA-HRE-IPL-RQ-0002
applicableDocuments.description: Product Assurance and Safety Requirements for ISS Pressurized Payloads

requirements.text:
In case the incoming inspection has been performed by a procurement agent, the incoming inspection performed by the end-user, may be reduced to the following minimum:
  • packing checking,
  • quantity verification.

> Class-1, 2 + 3 (required for) <

If the parts have passed successfully a final CSI (or buy-off), the incoming inspection may be reduced to the following minimum:

  • verification of the manufacturer's CoC,
  • packing checking,
  • quantity verification.

Radiation sensitive components for which applicable existing test data is insufficient shall be subjected to RVT.
In such a case, relevant information shall be included in the DCL.
RVT shall be performed in accordance with internationally recognized standards, such as ESCC Basic Specifications No. 22900.
NOTE:
Additional information on test methods is given in MIL-STD-750 Test Method 1019, MIL-STD-883 Test Method 1019.
Parts submitted to RVT shall be screened to be fully representative of flight parts.

applicableDocuments.description: Test Method Standard for Semiconductor Devices

applicableDocuments.description: Total Dose Steady-State Irradiation Test Method

requirements.text:
> Class-1 (required for) <

The DPA shall be performed on 3 samples per lot/date code for non-space qualified parts belonging to the following categories:

  • capacitors (glass, ceramic, tantalum and variable),
  • crystals,
  • oscillators,
  • discrete semiconductors (including diodes and transistors),
  • filters,
  • monolithic microcircuits (including MMICs),
  • hybrid circuits,
  • relays,
  • switches (including mechanical and thermal),
  • optoelectronic devices (e.g. opto-couplers, LED's, CCD's and sensors),
  • passive microwave devices (e.g. mixers, couplers, isolators, and switches).

> Class-1 (required for) <

The DPA shall be performed on 3 samples per lot/date code on critical space qualified parts, including as a minimum:

  • relays, and
  • oscillators,
  • for other space qualified parts families, DPA is not required.

> Class-2 (required for) <

The DPA shall be performed on 3 samples per lot/ date code for the following non-space qualified parts types as a minimum:

  • relays,
  • oscillators, and
  • commercial parts.

> Class-3 (required for) <

The DPA shall be performed on 3 samples per lot/date code for the following non-space qualified part types, as a minimum:

  • relays, and
  • commercial parts.

> Class-1, 2 + 3 (required for) <

The DPA sample size may be reduced in some cases which shall be submitted to customer for approval through the PAD or JD process.

requirements.text:
> Class-1, 2 + 3 (required for) <

DPA may be carried out on representative samples of the component family when the following three conditions are met:

  • procured from the same manufacturer and same package without major change in the process,
  • with a limited datecode range of 13 weeks,
  • approved by the customer through the PAD process or JD.
NOTE:
In complement of above conditions, for series of integrated circuits, series of thermal switches, series of active discrete and series of passive components (e.g. 54xxxx, 1N63xx, …), representative samples can be from the same family considering technology limit and their complexity.

> Class-1, 2, 3 Commercial components (required for) <

The DPA shall be performed on 3 samples per lot of commercial parts (during evaluation after lifetest as specified by para. 6.2.3 and after relifing as specified by para. 6.3.15).

NOTE:
Annex H of ECSS-Q-ST-60-13 provides guidelines for the construction analysis and DPA.

requirements.text:
The DPA process shall be documented by a procedure to be submitted to the customer for review.
The supplier shall verify that the outcome of the DPA is satisfactory prior to the installation of the components into flight HW.
DPA may be performed by the manufacturer if witnessed by the supplier (or approved representative).
The results of DPA shall be documented by a report sent to the customer, on request, for information.
For health and safety reasons, any test producing beryllium oxide dust shall be omitted.

In order to cover the risks related to infant mortality and counterfeit components, assembled flight units shall be subjected to burn-in.

The burn-in shall consist of 168 hours at the maximum operating temperature with the payload in operating conditions. This duration shall be in addition to the duration of all the other electrical tests performed.
Storage shall comply with the requirements of para. 3.5.6.2.

The storage responsible entity shall establish and document the following:
  • prohibited materials,
  • personnel access rules,
  • prohibited personnel actions,
  • measures and facilities to segregate and protect components during receiving, inspection, storage and delivery,
  • control measures to ensure that electrostatic discharge susceptible components are identified and handled only by trained personnel using anti-static packaging and tools.

Air
Normal air is used.

Temperature:
Temperature in the immediate vicinity of stored components shall at all times be maintained between a minimum temperature of 17°C and a maximum temperature of 27 °C.

NOTE:
This is to avoid chemical reactions catalysis when it is too high or electronic reactions on certain technologies when it is too low.

Relative humidity (RH):
RH in store cupboards shall be kept in the range defined by ESCC 24900 section 7.

NOTE:
This is to avoid, when combined with temperature, corrosion phenomena. The lower the relative humidity is the greater is the probability for ESD damage.

Package:

  1. The packages used during storage shall ensure protection against ESD as defined in para. 6.3.13.4 and against any form of corrosion or contamination.
  2. Parts shall be stored in packages such that it can be demonstrated that they offer protection against ESD, corrosion and contamination including the contamination induced by the package itself.
    NOTE:
    Their primary packages can be used as long as they meet this requirement.
  3. CCDs and opto-electronic sensors shall be stored in dry air or in neutral ambience, to prevent risks of cover glass pollution and moisture ingress.

applicableDocuments.title: ESCC 24900
applicableDocuments.description: Minimum requirements for controlling environmental contamination of components

requirements.text:
EEE parts with MSL > 1 shall be stored, before and after relifing test sequemce, in one of the following conditions.
  • nitrogen,
  • dry and ionised air in a range up to 20% RH maximum,
  • dry packs as specified in IPC/JEDEC J-STD-033D (April 2018)

applicableDocuments.title: IPC/JEDEC J-STD-033
applicableDocuments.description: Standard for Handling, Packing, Shipping and Use of Moisture/ reflow Sensitive Surface Mount Devices

requirements.text:
Rules for cleanliness efficiency shall be implemented. The working areas and the contained equipment shall be maintained as visually clean with no loose material. Access rules shall apply for personnel, materials and equipment. Storage areas shall conform to a cleanliness level as defined in ECSS-Q-ST-70-01C clause 5.3.1.4.
NOTE:
This cleanliness level is often called and known as "grey zone".

applicableDocuments.title: ECSS-Q-ST-70-01
applicableDocuments.description: Contamination and Cleanliness Control (15 November 2008)

requirements.text:
The efficiency of ESD protection measures in storage, handling and testing areas shall be demonstrated.
NOTE:
Guidelines in ECSS-Q-ST-60-14C, Annex B can be used for this demonstration.

applicableDocuments.title: ECSS-Q-ST-60-14
applicableDocuments.description: Relifing procedure - EEE (15 November 2008)

chapters.name: Processing for Storage and use of PEMs

requirements.text: PEMs not been delivered in dry packs must be baked out prior to storage in order to drive out absorbed moisture from the plastic molding material.

Plastic encapsulated devices shall be stored in one of the following conditions:
  • dry nitrogen,
  • dry and ionised air with RH in a range of 15% to 20%,
  • dry packs as specified in J-STD-033 for dry pack inspection and control.

ESCC 20600 or IPC/JEDEC J-STD-033 shall apply for packing, packaging and handling.
NOTE:
Best practice is to pay attention to ESD sensitivity as described in ECSS-Q-ST-60-14, Annex B.

applicableDocuments.title: ECSS-Q-ST-60-14
applicableDocuments.description: Relifing procedure - EEE (15 November 2008)

applicableDocuments.title: ESCC 20600
applicableDocuments.description: Preservation, Packaging and dispatch of SCC Electronic Components

applicableDocuments.title: IPC/JEDEC J-STD-033
applicableDocuments.description: Standard for Handling, Packing, Shipping and Use of Moisture/ reflow Sensitive Surface Mount Devices

requirements.text: The supplier shall establish and implement procedures for handling and storage of components in order to prevent possible degradation.

As a minimum, the following areas shall be covered:
  1. control of the environment in accordance with ESCC Basic Specification No. 24900,
  2. measures and facilities to segregate and protect components during receiving inspection, storage, and delivery to manufacturing,
  3. control measures to ensure that electrostatic discharge susceptible components are identified and handled only by trained personnel using anti-static packaging and tools,
  4. plastic encapsulated devices shall be stored in one of the following conditions:
    1. dry nitrogen,
    2. dry and ionised air with RH in a range of 15% to 20%,
    3. dry packs as specified in IPC/JEDEC J-STD-033 for dry pack inspection and control.

applicableDocuments.title: IPC/JEDEC J-STD-033
applicableDocuments.description: Standard for Handling, Packing, Shipping and Use of Moisture/ reflow Sensitive Surface Mount Devices

requirements.text: When components from a supplier's or parts procurement agent's stock are used, the following criteria shall be met:

• the parts are stored according to the minimum conditions given in para. 6.3.13,
  • the minimum overall requirements (including screening) are in accordance with the project requirements,
  • the lot/date code homogeneity and traceability can be demonstrated,
  • the EEE parts documentation is available and the content is acceptable in accordance with the project requirements (including radiation data, if necessary),
  • there are no open NCRs and no unresolved alerts with respect to their date code.
For components meeting the above criteria, the requirements of para. 6.3.15 - Relifing shall be applied.
Storage control requirements are defined in para. 6.3.13.

DPA shall be performed in cases where DPA would normally be required, and no available DPA report covers the lot. Any such DPA shall be defined on an individual PAD (DRD-6.06) including the lot sample basis.
NOTE:
Degradation of the components during storage may require failure analysis to determine lot related degradation.

requirements.text: The relifing process is a lot quality control activity. The inspections and tests defined do not constitute an up-screening or up-grading of components to a higher level of quality than procured to.

Relifing data and test results shall be appropriately documented and filed by the supplier. This data and the corresponding procurement specification(s) or documents shall be provided to DLR on request.

As part of the relifing process, a DPA shall be conducted during relifing in accordance with ECSS-Q-ST-60-13C clause 4.3.10.
Humidity test and lifetest shall be performed in accordance with para. 6.3.6 in case these tests have not been performed on the lot during the evaluation or the procurement phase.

NOTE:
Humidity test includes HAST or THB.

chapters.name: Identification of Long-Lead Items (LLI) / Critical Items

requirements.text:
Components with long lead times or long procurement delays (versus the project schedule) shall be identified before the formal subsystem PDR.

Procurement shall be thoroughly planned, documented and implemented in a timely manner to obtain reliable PA provision at CDR.

Back-up plans shall be prepared and initiated whenever there is evidence of possible delays or technical problems. Long-lead items which have adverse impact of item procurement on project schedule shall be identified as CIs and shall be included in the CIL.

drds.title: Critical Items List

requirements.text:
> Class-1, 2 + 3 (required for) <

The manufacturer's CoC shall be delivered to the parts procurer.

Any other data (i.e. LAT or LVT, QCI or TCI), defined in the applicable procurement documents, shall be available at the manufacturer's facilities or delivered to the parts' procurer in line with the purchase order, as a minimum compatible with CSV.

NOTE:
CSV is a common file format that can be used to transfer data between database or spreadsheet.

For non-qualified parts, the documentation minimum storage period shall be 10 years after delivery of components by the manufacturer.

NOTE:
For qualified parts, the documentation storage period is under the responsibility of the manufacturer and the qualifying authority.

The supplier shall establish and implement procedures for handling and storage of components in order to prevent possible degradation.

The procedures shall be applicable at any facility dealing with components for flight application.

On request, handling and storage procedures shall be sent to the customer for review.

As a minimum, the following areas shall be covered:

  1. control of the environment in accordance with ESCC Basic Specification No. 24900,
  2. measures and facilities to segregate and protect components during receiving inspection, storage, and delivery to manufacturing,
  3. control measures to ensure that electrostatic discharge susceptible components are identified and handled only by trained personnel using anti-static packaging and tools.
The supplier shall establish and maintain a NC control system in accordance with the general requirements of para. 3.5.1.

Any observed deviation of EEE components from requirements as laid down in applicable specifications, procedures and drawings shall be controlled by the NC control system as described in para. 3.5.1.
NOTE:
This includes failures, malfunctions, deficiencies and defects.

The NC control system shall handle all NCs occurring on EEE components during:
  • manufacture (if available), screening and acceptance tests,
  • incoming inspection,
  • integration and test of equipment,
  • storage and handling.
For ESCC qualified components the supplier shall apply the ESCC basic specification No. 22800.

requirements.text: Traceability requirements according para. 3.5.4 are applicable.

The traceability of individual components during manufacturing and testing shall be maintained as required by the procurement specifications.

The traceability shall be maintained through incoming, storage, and installation at the procurer and user of the component in accordance with programme PA requirements.

In any case, the traceability requirements imposed by the supplier on the EEE parts manufacturer or distributor shall allow managing the adequacy of the tests performed by the supplier (i.e. evaluation, lot validation, any additional test or inspection).

The traceability of EEE parts during installation in equipment shall be ensured by the supplier through maintaining the traceability to the manufacturer's lot/date code number of the EEE parts actually mounted.

If the as built DCL has not yet been delivered, the supplier shall be able to provide these information (part type actually installed with its relevant lot/date code number) within one working day (when the flight system is on launch pad) or within one week (in the other cases).
The traceability of EEE components shall be ensured by the supplier through maintaining the traceability to the manufacturer.
The traceability of EEE components shall be ensured by the supplier through maintaining the traceability to the manufacturer's lot/date code number of the EEE parts actually mounted.

requirements.text: Flight connectors shall be selected from PPLs (ESA, NASA) and procured from qualified sources only.
Flight connectors at payload interfaces shall be selected from PPLs (ESA, NASA) and procured from qualified sources only.

During ground processing (manufacturing, integration, test etc.) the following precautions have to be implemented:
  • Hi-Rel connectors shall always be mated to another Hi-Rel connector. Single pin or probe mating is not permitted.
  • Hi-Rel connector savers shall be used wherever feasible to reduce the mating/demating cycles for the flight connectors.
  • A comprehensive visual inspection shall be carried out just prior to each mating and after each demating.
  • A log of mates and demates shall be maintained for critical connectors e.g. coax-connectors.
  • An inspection with a magnification x3 shall be performed:
    1. for critical connectors after mating 10 times,
    2. just prior to delivery or final integration of equipment.
  • For investigations of a suspected discrepancy a magnification of x10 shall be used.
  • Damages observed during inspection shall be reported as a NC.
  • Connectors shall be protected at all times when not mated by plastic caps.
  • Connectors not used or partially used in flight have to be protected by a metallic cap.
ECSS-Q-ST-60-02 shall apply.

requirements.text:

The PAD shall allow traceability to the information related to the procurement of blank parts, the programming process and the acceptance of the programmed parts.

NOTE:
The programming process and the acceptance of the programmed parts can be addressed between the customer and the supplier if not otherwise determined in the PAD.

One time programmable components shall be submitted to a post-programming sequence.

For FPGA types without a clear and defined heritage, a post-programming burn-in shall be applied, in conformance with ESCC 9000 subclause 8.21, for a minimum duration of 160 h.

NOTE:
FPGA types with defined heritage are documented in the report: ESCC REP 010 SCSB Decisions Regarding OTP FPGA PPBI, available on https://escies.org.

The supplier shall prepare a post-programming procedure for customer's approval, depending on part types (including when necessary electrical tests, programming conditions and equipment, programming SW version qualified by the supplier, burn-in conditions, additional screening tests and specific marking after programming) as applicable as specified above.

The lot acceptance procedure, as defined in clause 6.3.5, shall be performed on devices coming from the flight lot/date code and programmed on the same kind of HW tools and compatible SW.

In case of several designs based on the same lot of blank parts, the lot acceptance procedure, as defined in clause 6.3.5, may be limited to one representative flight programmed design.

requirements.text:
This specific requirements are applicable for all Ball Grid Array and Column Grid Array packages, and its variants, e.g.:
  • PBGA (Plastic Ball Grid Array),
  • EBGA (Enhanced BGA),
  • TE-PBGA (Thermally Enhanced BGA),
  • TSBGA (Tape Super BGA),
  • CGA (Ceramic Grid Array),
  • CBGA (Ceramic Ball Grid Array,
  • CCGA (Ceramic Column Grid Array),
  • FBGA (Fine Pitch Ball Grid Array).

Design and Assembly
JTAG compatible components as defined by the IEEE Standard 1149.1 (Standard Test Access Port and Boundary Scan Architecture) shall be used and shall support in-circuit testing via the industry standard JTAG interface.

applicableDocuments.title: IEEE Standard 1149.1
applicableDocuments.description: Standard Test Access Port and Boundary Scan Architecture

requirements.text: To maximize yields and maintain a high degree of quality, industry standard IPC/JEDEC 7095, "Design and Assembly Process Implementation for BGAs" shall be applied as guideline for PCB designs and PWA (printed wiring assembly) assembly workmanship.

applicableDocuments.title: IPC/JEDEC 7095
applicableDocuments.description: Design and Assembly Process Implementation for BGAs

requirements.text: Boards materials with a high Glass Transition Temperature (Tg greater than 240°C) shall be used when using Grid-Array packages, due to their lower CTE (Coefficient of Thermal Expansion) when compared to epoxy-glass boards (e.g. pure FR4).

When using ceramic packages, column grid arrays shall be used. CCGA solder joints are more reliable than ball grid arrays, because of the increased standoff height (distance between board and package) reduces fatigue on interconnects.
Vias shall not be shared at BGA/CGA locations.

BGA/CGA Placement Clearance
Sufficient clearance shall be provided around the grid array package to facilitate rework in accordance with ECSS-Q-ST-70-38.

applicableDocuments.title: ECSS-Q-ST-70-38
applicableDocuments.description: High-reliability soldering for surface-mount and mixed technology (15 September 2017)

requirements.text:
Part mirroring
A BGA/CGA part located on one side of the board directly opposite another BGA/CGA part on the other side of the board is not allowed due to the combined effect the parts will have on the displacement behaviour of the board, at that location, which may cause solder joint failure.

Underfill
Underfill shall not be used under BGA/CGA packages.

Solder Joint Inspection
Because visual inspection of BGA/CGA solder joints is limited to the outer rows, all interconnects shall be inspected using radiographic methods to screen for workmanship defects.
X-ray equipment shall allow the operator to view the assembled BGA/CGA, such that each individual solder joints at the part and board sides can be inspected.
3D microfocus computer tomography (µCT) analysis of solder joints shall be the preferred technique.

The acceptance/rejection criteria for BGA/CGA assemblies of ECSS-Q-ST-70-38 shall be used. Concerning voids, the void size limitation respectively the void acceptance criteria of ECSS-Q-ST-70-38 are applicable.

applicableDocuments.title: ECSS-Q-ST-70-38
applicableDocuments.description: High-reliability soldering for surface-mount and mixed technology (15 September 2017)

requirements.text:
Interconnection Test
For PCB assembly test, a JTAG/Boundary-scan (IEEE Std.1149.1) is required for testing and verifying interconnections between boundary-scan pins.

Rework
A nitrogen atmosphere shall be used to prevent solder ball oxidation during rework.

New technology components are those whose technology is subject to a continuous evolution process, whose production is not sufficiently frozen and mature to assure a continuous running production, or which have poor or no previous history of high reliability application.
New technology components shall be covered by a procurement specification in accordance to para. 6.3.3.

Prior to procurement new technology components shall be subjected for approval by first-level supplier and DLR per RFA or PAD as described in DRD-7.01 and DRD-6.06.

chapters.name: Pure Tin Lead Finish - Risk Analysis

requirements.text:
Pure tin finish has a propensity to generate whiskers. A tin whisker is a conductive crystalline structure of tin growing from tin rich surfaces that can induce failures as:
  • electrical instantaneous or permanent short circuit,
  • metal vapour arc in reduced atmospheric pressure conditions and for application with high levels of current and voltage (more than 12V),
  • contamination: a free floating whisker may interfere with the movement of mechanical parts or induce contamination of optical surfaces,

Many parameters can have an impact on whisker growth. The purpose of the risk analysis is to evaluate those parameters.

A pure tin lead finish risk analysis facing whiskers shall include, as a minimum, the following:
  • lead material (e.g. alloy 42, copper),
  • underlayer material and thickness (e.g. Ni underlayer, silver underlayer),
  • plating chemistry and thickness (e.g. matte or bright tin, tin thickness),
  • heat treatment by manufacturer (e.g. 1 hour at 150 °C for Cu based lead frame),
  • SnPb dipping of the parts: partial or total (with or without standoff),
  • conformal coating presence and characteristics: material and thickness,
  • design criticality (shorter distances between 2 connections or between a connection and an area at another potential),
  • supply voltage and current,
  • tin whisker sensitivity results (as per JESD-201 and JESD22-A121A),
  • mission profile: storage, mission duration, thermal cycling,
  • previous experiences.

This section specifies the requirements and statements applicable to materials, mechanical parts and processes to satisfy the mission performance requirements.

This section also specifies the documentation requirements and the procedures relevant to obtaining approval for the use of materials, mechanical parts and processes in the fabrication of space systems and associated equipment.

This section covers the following:

  • management, including organization, reviews, acceptance status and documentation control,
  • selection criteria and rules,
  • evaluation, validation and qualification, or verification testing,
  • procurement and receiving inspection,
  • utilization criteria and rules.

The provisions of this section apply to all actors involved at all levels in the production of space systems. These can include manned and unmanned spacecraft, launchers, satellites, payloads, experiments, GSE and their corresponding organizations.

This section may be tailored for the specific characteristics and constrains of a space project in conformance with ECSS-S-ST-00.

applicableDocuments.title: ECSS-S-ST-00
applicableDocuments.description: Description, implementation and general requirements (31 July 2008)

requirements.text:
The DLR policy in the area of materials, mechanical parts and processes requires:
  • to select rigorously those items which fulfil the functional requirements during the whole lifetime by taking into account the mission duration and in the specific environmental conditions,
  • to rely on available space proven technologies whenever possible,
  • to identify and control all new products, critical materials, critical mechanical parts and critical processes,
  • to make the best use of all available research, including the technology programmes of European space agencies.

chapters.name: Materials, Mechanical Parts and Processes (MMPP) Programme

requirements.text: For the selection of space materials and processes, ECSS-Q-ST-70-71 shall be applied.

applicableDocuments.title: ECSS-Q-ST-70-71
applicableDocuments.description: Materials, processes and their data selection (15 October 2014)

requirements.text: An efficient implementation programme shall be defined, covering the selection, characterisation, evaluation, qualification and procurement of the materials, mechanical parts and processes for their intended use.

This programme shall in particular identify and validate critical applications in due time for safe utilisation and lead to cost-effective solutions through a type reduction and standardisation process.

Steps to be taken to get approval for MMPP:
Materials Mechanical Parts Processes
Phase Step Comments Step Comments Step Comments
Criticality Analysis 1 RFA for every critical material 1 RFA for every critical mechanical part 1 RFA for every critical process
Evaluation (usually by test methods defined by ECSS standards) 2 Critical materials are tested, e.g. out-gassing, CORR, SCC, flammability, offgassing, HHHT (high humidity high temperature), radiation, particles… 2 Mechanical parts are tested by, for example, vibration, thermal analysis, offgassing and life test. 2 Critical processes are qualified by testing "technology samples" including all, for example, electrical interconnection processes and painting, adhesive bonding, welding
Verification Not applicable Not applicable 3 Verification tests usually defined in ECSS standards
Validation 3 Not applicable Not applicable
Qualification Not applicable 3 Not applicable
Approval By RFA (DRD-7.01) or DML By RFA (DRD-7.01) or DMPL/DPL By RFA (DRD-7.01) or DPL
NOTE 1:
Project approval is always by means of the RFA form and the projects' DML, DMPL and DPL.
NOTE 2:
To summarize:
  • Materials are validated.
  • Mechanical parts are qualified.
  • Processes are verified.
In addition:
  • Skills training schools are ESA-certified.
  • Outside test or evaluation laboratories are certified by agency or company audits.
  • Operators and inspectors for special and critical processes are trained, certified and monitored.

requirements.text:
The MMPP manager shall organize Materials, Mechanical Parts and Processes Control Board (MPCB) at all suppliers with the task to review and approve the materials, mechanical parts and processes as specified in sections 7.5, 7.6 and 7.7.

The MPCB activity shall start not later than at PDR.

Minimum tasks of the MPCB shall be as follows:

  • coordination of the initiation and approval of RFA's in conformance with DRD 7.01 by involving the relevant technical discipline,
  • review and approval of test programme and related results,
  • review of preliminary Declared Materials, Mechanical Parts and Processes Lists and of any available evidence to support the approval, by the PDR,
  • review and approval of Declared Materials, Mechanical Parts and Processes Lists and of the evidence necessary for the approval by the CDR,
  • review and approval of any change to the approved Declared Materials, Mechanical Parts and Processes Lists.
  • Identify alternatives linked to obsolescence of materials, processes, or mechanical parts at all level of the customer-supplier chain.

NOTE:

  1. REACH legislation is an example of a source for obsolescence
  2. Guidelines for obsolescence management for materials, mechanical parts and processes are provided in ECSS-Q-HB-70-23

requirements.text:
The following constraints should apply:
  • maximum use of the materials and processes specified in approved data sources and items already approved on similar projects,
  • use of project related preferred lists, if available.

The following constraints shall be assessed:

  • requirements originating from the initial technical specification,
  • programmatic project requirements and conditions.

An analysis of the criticality of these preliminary lists shall, after checking the conformity of the MMPP, against all the project requirements, allow them to be classified into three categories:
  • CIs, subject to evaluation, validation, qualification, or verification programmes,
  • items that are not critical but which do not conform to one or more project requirements,
  • non-critical items.
NOTE:
Items, subject to evaluation, validation, qualification, or verification programmes, shall be referenced to their RFA (DRD-7.01) and items which do not conform to project requirements shall be referenced to their RFD (DRD-3.03).

applicableDocuments.description: Space Station Requirements for Materials and Processes (March 1998)

requirements.text: All materials usage must be verified in accordance with applicable requirements in the relevant ISS-specific ICDs.
Verification shall be demonstrated and documented through the implementation procedure defined in SSP 30599.

applicableDocuments.title: SSP 30599
applicableDocuments.description: Safety review process (February 2015)

requirements.text: PMP shall satisfy the mission's functional requirements and constraints.

PMP shall satisfy both ground environment and flight requirements and constraints.
NOTE:
Examples are:
  • ground environment constraints: manufacture, tests, storage, maintenance, transport and integration,
  • flight constraints: launch and orbit.

The estimated availability of the parts and products obtained from materials and processes used shall be compatible with the space system's life cycle.
NOTE:
Examples of space systems life cycle are tests, storage and mission.

The supplier shall establish and maintain a contamination and cleanliness control programme including, as a minimum:
  1. cleaning procedures, and
  2. cleanliness monitoring procedures or methods.

The risks of chemical or particle pollution generated by parts, materials or processes used shall be identified and reduced as specified in ECSS-M-ST-80C, clause 7.2, in conformance with mission requirements.

applicableDocuments.title: ECSS-M-ST-80
applicableDocuments.description: Risk Management (31 July 2008)

requirements.text: For cleanliness- or contamination-critical applications, a chemical and particle requirement specification and a specific CCP shall be established in conformance with DRD-3.05 (CCP) and DRD-3.14 (CRS).

chapters.name: Technical Criteria for Selection of Materials

requirements.text: Material design data shall be generated for the intended service conditions using test and analysis procedures accepted by the customer.

Material properties shall be compatible with the environments to which they are exposed during terrestrial testing prior to launch, and during the mission.
NOTE:
The requirements of chapter 7.5 apply when the environmental conditions of the mission require their application. The specific requirements, test methods and acceptance or rejection criteria are present in the ECSS-Q-ST-70 series of documents.

Hazardous chemical substances in materials, processes, or in the end-product may be affected by the REACH regulation imposing actions for legal compliance or the risk of obsolescence.
NOTE:
Guidelines for obsolescence management for materials, mechanical parts and processes are provided in ECSS-Q-HB-70-23.

Material properties shall be compatible with the thermal environment to which they are exposed.
NOTE:
Examples of thermal environment are also the passage through transition temperatures, e.g. phase transitions, ductile-brittle transition temperatures for metals, glass transition (Tg) for polymer materials, and environmental factors which affect these properties, such as moisture.

Materials subject to thermal cycling shall be assessed for their ability to withstand induced thermal stress.

The following materials shall be tested in conformance with requirements of ECSS-Q-ST-70-04:

  • materials susceptible to thermal vacuum effect,
  • shall be tested in conformance with a procedure accepted by the customer,
  • materials of unknown characteristics in respect to thermal vacuum,
    NOTE:
    For a non-exhaustive list of materials, see ECSS-Q-ST-70-04C clause 1.
  • materials subject to thermal cycling except the case specified in the requirement,
  • thermo optical properties shall be evaluated in conformance with requirement from clause 4 of ECSS-Q-ST-70-09C,
  • directional effects due to manufacturing or processing shall be evaluated via dedicated testing to be agreed with the customer.

applicableDocuments.title: ECSS-Q-ST-70-04
applicableDocuments.description: Thermal testing for the evaluation of space materials, processes, mechanical parts and assemblies (15 November 2008)

applicableDocuments.title: ECSS-Q-ST-70-09
applicableDocuments.description: Measurements of thermo-optical properties of thermal control materials (31 July 2008)

requirements.text:
Out-gassing screening tests shall be carried out in conformance with requirements of ECSS-Q-ST-70-02.
NOTE:
The screening process applied depends on the application.

All organic materials for use in space systems shall be evaluated to determine their out-gassing characteristics.

The need for retest out-gassing characteristics of materials used for an extended period of time at a temperature higher than 50°C should be mutually agreed with the customer.

applicableDocuments.description: Thermal Vacuum out-gassing Test for the Screening of space materials (15 November 2008)

requirements.text:
Materials used in the design and construction of HW directly interfacing the habitable area shall meet the acceptability requirements for offgassing products when tested in accordance with ECSS-Q-ST-70-29, as follows:
  • carbon monoxide (CO) < 25 μg/g of material tested,
  • total organics (TO) < 100 μg/g of material tested.

offgassing tests are not required for unknown materials used in quantities < 1 g for the total number of identical equipment used in one model.

According to MSFC-HDBK-527F, the non-metallic materials are classified for Toxicity with the following rating codes:

  • K = pass the test; maximum limit weight => 100 lbs. (45,400 grams)
  • H = maximum limit weight => 50 lbs. (22, 700 grams) < 100 lbs. (45,400 grams)
  • A = maximum limit weight => 10 lbs. (4.540 grams) < 50 lbs. (22,700 grams)
  • V = maximum limit weight => 5 lbs. (2,270 grams) < 10 lbs. (5,540 grams)
  • X = maximum limit weight < 5 lbs. (2,270 grams)

Assembled articles: Summation of T values (total concentration in mg/m3/SMAC in mg/m3) of all offgassed constituent products shall not exceed 0.5 (T is the toxic hazard index).

applicableDocuments.title: ECSS-Q-ST-70-29
applicableDocuments.description: Determination of offgassing products from materials and assembled articles to be used in a manned space vehicle crew compartment (15 November 2008)

applicableDocuments.title: MSFC-HDBK-527

requirements.text:
NOTE:
NASA has relaxed the safety verification close-out for materials offgassing within the standard HR recently. All non-metallic materials of a HW item which are less than 20 lbs (equals 9.1 kg) and the absence of lubricants, uncured adhesives liquids, wipes do not need an offgassing test or evaluation. This is true for P/L and system HW regardless of COTS or in-house-manufactured.

The materials flammability resistance shall be evaluated in conformance with requirements of ECSS-Q-ST-70-21 for the most hazardous environment envisaged for their use, and applicable to:
  • unmanned spacecraft or space segment elements launched by a manned space transportation system when powered on launch, and
  • manned spacecraft and space segment elements.
NOTE 1:
For ISS payloads see NASA-STD-6001.
NOTE 2:
Materials that are flammable may still be acceptable in the used configuration. Guidelines for H/W flammability assessment and mitigation can be found in JSC 29353 "Flammability Configuration Analysis for Spacecraft application".

applicableDocuments.title: ECSS-Q-ST-70-21
applicableDocuments.description: Flammability testing for the screening of space materials (5 February 2010)

applicableDocuments.title: NASA-STD-6001
applicableDocuments.description: Flammability, Odour and Offgassing, and Compatibility Requirements and Test Procedures for Materials in Environments that Support Combustion

requirements.text:
Materials exposed to radiation shall be assessed in conformance with requirements from clause 5 of ECSS-Q-ST-70-06 to determine their resistance to the radiation dosage expected during the mission.

Evaluation of materials resistance to radiation shall include the combined effects of particle radiation and UV radiation in the normal space environment, along with any mission-specific radiation levels.

The effect of bleaching due to vacuum or air recovery shall be evaluated, in case ex-situ measurements are performed.

In case synergistic testing is not possible it shall be proven that synergistic effects caused by radiation and temperature are not degrading the materials properties.

In case technical limits prevent the synergistic testing approach, it shall be so justified, and the justification for sequential testing shall be provided.

NOTE:
For example when different acceleration factors are required for particle and UV radiation.

External surfaces of the spacecraft shall be sufficiently conductive, interconnected and grounded to the spacecraft structure to avoid the build-up of differential charges in conformance with ECSS-E-ST-20-06.
NOTE:
Electrical grounding via metal to metal contact, galvanic corrosion compatibility shall be respected.

applicableDocuments.title: ECSS-E-ST-20
applicableDocuments.description: Electrical and electronic (31 July 2008)

requirements.text:
For all materials that come into contact with atmospheric gases, cleaning fluids or other chemicals, it shall be demonstrated that the degradation of properties during their anticipated service-life does not prevent to meet the performance and integrity requirements.

All mechanical parts, assemblies and equipment, including spares, shall be finished to provide protection from corrosion.

NOTE:
This applies equally to fasteners and other fixing devices, such as insert systems.

Materials used for structural and load-bearing applications (subject to tensile stress) shall be selected in conformance with ECSS-Q-ST-70-36.

Any material not covered by standard ECSS-Q-ST-70-36 shall be tested in conformance with ECSS-Q-ST-70-37.

applicableDocuments.title: ECSS-Q-ST-70-36
applicableDocuments.description: Material selection for controlling stress-corrosion cracking (6 March 2009)

requirements.text:
Materials within the system exposed to reactive fluids, both directly and as a result of SPFs when failure propagation effects cause hazardous operation of interfacing HW shall be compatible with that fluid in their application.
NOTE:
Example of reactive fluids are liquid oxygen (LOX) and gaseous oxygen (GOX).

The compatibility of materials which are or can come into contact with LOX or GOX shall be evaluated.

NOTE:
See NASA-STD-6001 Test No. 13 and No. 14.

In case no compatibility data are available, tests shall be performed for reactive fluids other than oxygen.

NOTE:
See NASA-STD-6001 Test No. 15.

applicableDocuments.title: NASA-STD-6001
applicableDocuments.description: Flammability, Odour and Offgassing, and Compatibility Requirements and Test Procedures for Materials in Environments that Support Combustion

requirements.text:
NOTE:
As a guide for compatibility assessment might be taken NASA/TM-2007-213740 "Guide for Oxygen Compatibility Assessments on Oxygen Components and Systems".

Materials degradation in appropriated long-term test shall be characterised by post-test analysis of the material and fluid, to determine the extent of changes in chemical and physical characteristics, including mechanical testing.
NOTE:
NASA-STD-6016 (4.2.1.3) shall be taken as support.

applicableDocuments.title: NASA-STD-6016
applicableDocuments.description: Standard materials and processes requirements for spacecraft

requirements.text:
When bimetallic contacts are used, the choice of the pair of metallic materials used shall be agreed with the customer.
NOTE:
This also includes metal-to-conductive fibre-reinforced materials contacts.

Galvanic compatibilities shall be selected in conformance with the following table (below).

NOTE:
The table below is not applicable for fluid circulated systems (wetted materials).

Materials not listed in that table shall be evaluated in a flight-simulated configuration using an accelerated environment to be agreed by the customer.

Compatible couples for bimetallic contacts

NOTE: EMF limit of dissimilar materials
The electromotoric force (EMF) limit between two dissimilar materials shall be ≤ 0.5 Volts for application in a clean atmosphere environment. For fluid circulating systems (wetted materials) the EMF limit shall be ≤ 0.25 Volts.
Corrosion Assessment might be supported by "Bimetallic compatible couples" by A. de Rooij, ESA Journal 1989 Vol 13. Link to the document: http://esmat.esa.int/Publications/Published_papers/Bimetallic.PDF

All materials considered for use on the external surface of spacecraft intended for use in Low Earth Orbit (LEO) altitudes (between 200 km and 700 km) shall be evaluated for their resistance to ATOX.
NOTE:
The flux level varies with altitude, velocity, vector and solar activity. Fluence levels vary with the duration of exposure.

Test procedures shall be subject to the accepted by the customer.

The effect of impacts by micrometeoroids and debris on materials shall be reviewed and assessed on a case by case basis.

Use of materials shall comply with safety evaluation and assessment results concerning design and application criteria or details.

Micrometeoroids and debris analysis and test procedures shall be subject to the accepted by the customer.
Moisture absorption shall be prevented during manufacture and storage of hygroscopic materials.

chapters.name: Mechanical Contact Surface Effects: Cold Welding, Fretting, Wear

requirements.text:
For all solid surfaces in moving contact with other solid surfaces, it shall be demonstrated that the degradation of surface properties over the complete mission does not prevent to meet the performance requirements.

For all solid surfaces, moving or in static contact with other solid surfaces, and intended to be separated it shall be demonstrated that the increase in separation force during the physical contact does not exceed the specific limit.
Materials shall be selected to ensure that they will meet the material performance requirements during all their specified lifetime.

Evaluation of and testing of fungus growth: Materials directly interfacing the habitable volume shall be resistant to fungus growth. Evaluation of fungus growth resistance shall be performed in accordance with
  • COL-RIBRE-TN-1332,
  • SSP 30233, paragraph 4.2.10, or
  • NASA-STD-6016 paragraph 4.2.3.8.

Testing shall be performed in accordance to procedure MIL-STD-810, test Method 508, Testing of materials susceptibility to fungal surface growth.

applicableDocuments.title: COL-RIBRE-TN-1332
applicableDocuments.description: Fungus growth implementation approach - Technical Note (December 1997)

applicableDocuments.title: MIL-STD-810

applicableDocuments.description: Standard materials and processes requirements for spacecraft

applicableDocuments.description: Space Station Requirements for Materials and Processes (March 1998)

requirements.text:
Evaluation of and testing of microbiological growth: Materials of HW shall be resistant to microbiological growth and sustainable to decontamination procedures. Evaluation of material selection and operation documentation shall be performed in accordance with
  • SSP 50260, para 7.4.4., 7.4.6

The PA manager assures that budgets are transferred to technical requirement specification of HW, as applicable from:

  • Appendix D - Environmental Health Detailed System Requirements, especially
  • Table D-5 Preflight Microbial Specifications and Monitoring Requirements of Air Surfaces,
  • Table D-6 Inflight Microbial Specifications and Monitoring Requirements of Air Surfaces,

applicableDocuments.title: SSP 50260
applicableDocuments.description: International Space Station Medical Operations Requirements Document (ISS MORD) (February 2006)

requirements.text:
Materials selected for manned or fluid systems shall:
  1. not support bacterial or fungus growth,
  2. be capable to sustain bioburden reduction.

The extent of the degradation by the reduction process shall be determined to define margins for design implementation.

The design and qualification of that reduction process for an equipment shall implement the defined margins for degradation due to that process.

The level of bacterial growth and fungus contamination shall be determined on the assembled HW; if technical requirement specification provides limits.

Evaluation of organic materials used in the pressurized environment of long-term, manned spacecraft shall be performed prior to selection and verification.

The possibility of hydrogen embrittlement occurring during component manufacture or use shall be assessed.

The material evaluation shall be performed including the assessment of a protection and control.

Based on the assessment specified in the requirements, protection and control measures shall be implemented to avoid hydrogen embrittlement during both mechanical parts manufacturing and use.

NOTE:
Hydrogen embrittlement can be introduced for example during e.g. plating, welding.

Mechanical parts subject to fatigue or sustained loading stresses, which are made of material susceptible to hydrogen embrittlement, shall be heat treated after coating.

The suppliers PA shall ensure that materials used for the flight products of structural elements are in compliance with the requirements of ECSS-E-ST-32-01.
NOTE:
For unmanned, single-mission, space vehicles and their payloads, and GSE the reduced fracture control programme according to ECSS-E-ST-32-01, clause 11 may be implemented.

applicableDocuments.title: ECSS-E-ST-32-01
applicableDocuments.description: Fracture Control (6 March 2009)

requirements.text: NDI standards and techniques shall be used to identify cracks and flaws in each potential fracture critical item (PFCI) as derived from the fracture analysis. The NDI process shall be approved and certified. Non-metallic structural items (e.g. glass components) shall be proof-tested at 1.2 times the limit load (see ECSS-E-ST-32-01).

applicableDocuments.title: ECSS-E-ST-32-01
applicableDocuments.description: Fracture Control (6 March 2009)

requirements.text:
Pure tin finish with more than 97% purity shall not be used.
NOTE 1:
This is due to the possibility of whisker growth and transformation to grey tin powder at low temperatures.
NOTE 2:
EEE components with pure tin (less than 3% Pb in case of SnPb alloy) used as a finish on the leads, terminations and external surfaces of components and packages can be used providing re-tinning is carried out as per ECSS-Q-ST-60-13.
NOTE 3:
Solder dip for tin whisker mitigation differs from solder dip for solderability in that for tin whisker mitigation it is required that the termination is coated over its entire length, right up to the package surface (no standoff). Lead free control plan shall be provided to minimize tin whiskers to meet level 2B of ANSI GEIA-STD-0005-02.

The incoming inspection of each EEE component batch shall include the verification of the termination composition to avoid assembly of pure tin finish.

Cadmium and Zinc shall not be used as raw material or surface treatment for flight HW.

Cadmium and Zinc shall not be used for GSE exposed to vacuum or when in contact with flight HW.

NOTE:
For example during thermal vacuum testing phases on ground.

The incoming inspection of each non-EEE component batch shall include the verification of the metallic surface treatment to avoid assembly of pure tin, cadmium or zinc finish.

The materials presented in the following shall not be used:

  • beryllium oxide,
  • mercury and its compounds,
  • polyvinyl chloride (PVC),
  • radioactive material.
NOTE:
This list is not exhaustive.

Beryllium shall not be used for structures.

Beryllium shall not be used in applications other than structures unless:

  • approved by customer, and
  • all safety requirements are implemented by the supplier.

applicableDocuments.title: ECSS-Q-ST-60-13
applicableDocuments.description: Commercial EEE components (21 October 2013)

applicableDocuments.title: GEIA-STD-0005-02
applicableDocuments.description: Standard for Mitigating the Effects of Tin Whiskers in Aerospace and High Performance Electronic Systems (May 2012)

requirements.text: For materials to be reflown it is necessary to verify that the function, the environment, and the operational use actually are identical to the previous flight. For materials with any change new reporting and approval is requested. If only a few changes apply, then the old materials lists with indication of changes might be sufficient, otherwise a new list shall be provided. An evaluation report and a materials inspection shall be performed.

Materials shall be chosen as follows:
  • if an identical application in other space programmes similar with respect to environment constraints and lifetime to the proposed application exist use materials used in such an application,
  • otherwise
    • if materials exist for which satisfactory evaluation results are obtained on samples representative of the application with margin above the specified ones as regards conditions of use, use such materials,
    • otherwise, use materials included in approved data sources.
NOTE:
For example: ECSS-Q-ST-70-71, ESA and NASA data banks.

applicableDocuments.title: ECSS-Q-ST-70-71
applicableDocuments.description: Materials, processes and their data selection (15 October 2014)

requirements.text:
Whether the materials are already validated or remain to be validated, their selection shall ensure that the following criteria are met:
  1. continuity of supply,
  2. reproducibility of characteristics,
  3. mechanical properties of materials processed according to a specified technique,
  4. environmental-stability properties under space conditions, together with mission- or application-specific requirements.

Each critical material shall be validated for the specific application.
NOTE:
Critical material includes the ones of approved data sources.

Space-proven materials with heritage covering the specific mission requirements shall be selected at the earliest design stage.

The supplier shall be responsible for the selection of materials that are capable of meeting the requirement of his business agreement.

The supplier shall be responsible for storing and maintain all materials data in an internal database.

The access to the data, specified before shall be granted to the customer.

To achieve high reliability and good performance, the use of a material shall be restricted to within its maximum qualified range of physical and mechanical properties.

All test methods and inspection techniques used to verify materials characteristics and final products shall conform to standards approved by the customer.

All test methods and inspection techniques specified in the requirements before shall not be used before approval by the customer.

NOTE:
For the selection of space materials and processes, ECSS-Q-ST-70-71 and NASA space materials databases (i.e. MAPTIS) shall be used and shall be compliant with the relevant EU ground regulations (e.g. RoHS). Materials and mechanical parts shall be chosen from the ones used for identical application in other successfully flown space programmes similar with respect to environment constraints and lifetime.

applicableDocuments.title: ECSS-Q-ST-70-71
applicableDocuments.description: Materials, processes and their data selection (15 October 2014)

applicableDocuments.title: ESA-HRE-IPL-RQ-0002
applicableDocuments.description: Product Assurance and Safety Requirements for ISS Pressurized Payloads

requirements.text:
ECSS-Q-ST-70-71 shall be applied for the selection of materials and processes that have safety relevance. When safety is not a concern, in case of criticality, the requirements before shall apply. As far as electronic assemblies are concerned, PCBs shall be designed, manufactured, procured, qualified, assembled and accepted according to the Class 3 as defined in the IPC standards of the Association Connecting Electronics Industries.
NOTE:
ECSS standards for electronic assemblies are considered to meet and exceed IPC standards. Detailed requirements for these pressurised ISS payload electronics materials and processes are defined in para. 7.7.6.4.

The supplier shall analyse all the materials contained in his preliminary lists with respect to criticality and in correlation with the risk analysis performed.

Any material not meeting the project requirements shall be subject to a RFD to be submitted to the next customer for acceptance.

Any critical material shall be subject to a RFA to be submitted to the customer for approval.

requirements.text:
For ISS payloads processed directly with NASA a Material Usage Agreement (MUA) shall be prepared for review and approval of all materials which do not have an "A" rating per MSFC-HDBK-527 for its planned application.
The MUA shall contain sufficient information with supporting rationale to permit the use of a none "A" rated material (for MUA see DRD-7.04).
NOTE:
MUA categories and their usage are described in NASA-STD-6016.

requirements.text:
The use of ionizing material has to be described by using the Ionizing Radiation Source datasheet (JSC-Form 44, DRD-7.05).
NOTE 1:
A username and password is required to access this link. Please contact the safety review panel for further assistance.
NOTE 2:
Electronic version of JSC-Form 44 is located at:
https://hazard.iss.nasa.gov or http://docexchange.esa.int (in folder ESA PSRP Database > ESA PSRP Payloads > Requirements).
