requirements.text:
The evaluation specified in para. 7.5.6 shall assess as a minimum the following:
  1. the limits of use,
  2. the materials physical, chemical or functional characteristics along with their values and tolerances,
  3. behavioural tendencies and degradation processes depending on environmental parameters (including sensitivity to pollution),
  4. acceptance criteria.

When evaluation is performed, the supplier shall provide:
  1. an evaluation programme (at PDR) and
  2. an evaluation report (before CDR).

drds.number: Material Evaluation Plan acc. to requirement
drds.title: Material Evaluation Plan

drds.number: Material Evaluation Report acc. to requirement
drds.title: Material Evaluation Report

requirements.text:
For all critical materials, a validation programme (available at PDR) shall be drawn up by the supplier and then implemented to check or confirm that the materials satisfy the mission requirements with the specified margins to obtain validation status.

Validation status shall be decided at CDR in view of the available results obtained written in validation report and the review of corresponding documentation.

The validation programme and report shall be accepted by the customer.

drds.number: EEE Evaluation Plan acc. to requirement
drds.title: EEE Evaluation Plan

requirements.text:
The material shall not receive an approval identification in the DML for the project unless the requirements specified before are satisfied.

If approval is not granted, the supplier in charge of the item shall either:

  1. select another material, or
  2. propose a modified evaluation programme and resubmit for approval, or
  3. if actions specified in the requirements before fail to achieve positive results, initiate a deviation procedure.

For materials not conforming to project requirements, whether at the end of criticality analysis or of evaluation and validation tests, the supplier shall submit a RFD in conformance with para. 3.5.8.

If so identified by the criticality analysis, the supplier shall perform an evaluation phase before the validation phase for all critical materials with unknown characteristics (new materials) or with major changes in the use or in the configuration.

In case of an extension of an existing application, the evaluation specified above need not be performed if so agreed with the customer.

Guarantied characteristics of materials and material supplier inspection methods, together with associated documents, shall be available for review at the supplier's premises before the start of evaluation or qualification phases.

All materials shall be procured to an internationally or nationally specification approved by the supplier quality system, or an in-house fully configured procurement specification which defines the materials properties, the materials requirements, the test methods, the acceptance criteria for the specific applications, source inspection (if any) and material supplier inspection.

Where material suppliers do not accept specifications and procurement is by means of a datasheet the supplier shall introduce internal, in-house receipt inspection to ensure that the validation status of the material is maintained during the subsequent procurements.

Materials with long lead times or long procurement delays, versus the project schedule, shall be identified before the formal subsystem PDR.

Procurement shall be planned, documented and implemented to obtain reliable PA provision at CDR.

Back-up plans shall be prepared and initiated whenever there is evidence of delays or technical problems.

The material requirements shall be accepted by the material supplier or manufacturer.

All materials shall be submitted to an incoming inspection.

An incoming inspection procedure shall define the inspections and tests to be carried out, particularly for materials that are known to be variable in their final properties.

The supplier shall verify that all critical materials are validated before being used in the manufacture of qualification or flight products.

Any modification, change of condition or configuration of application shall lead to a re-evaluation in conformance with the steps indicated in para. 7.3.
The supplier shall apply the traceability rules specified in para. 3.5.4 to all materials.

Materials shall be identified by a unique reference number, code or a lot number to provide traceability should there be an incident or NC, or a need for a technical investigation following failure or damage, to reconstruct the materials history, either individually (individual traceability) or by the manufacturing lot of which it was a part (lot traceability).
NOTE:
The traceability allow to reconstruct the materials history, either individually (individual traceability) or by the manufacturing lot of which it was a part (lot traceability) in case of an incident or NC, or a need for a technical investigation following failure or damage.

The supplier shall define provisions for packaging, storage and removal from storage for materials.

Measurements and inspections used to guarantee the material integrity and monitoring during storage and removal from storage shall be identified.

The supplier shall ensure that all materials which have limited-life characteristics have their date of manufacture or date of delivery and shelf-life expiry date identified and clearly marked on each lot or batch.

Materials which have exceeded their shelf-life expiry date shall not be re-certified until the physical and chemical characteristics are inspected and the parameters, subject to deterioration, are evaluated for continued acceptability according to the acceptance and rejection criteria in conformance with requirements from the clause 4 of ECSS-Q-ST-70-22.

applicableDocuments.title: ECSS-Q-ST-70-22
applicableDocuments.description: Control of limited shelf-life materials (31 July 2008)

requirements.text:
Materials with limited-life after implementation (such as propellant) shall be identified and controlled in conformance with para. 2.2.4.
NOTE:
Storage and mission life are criteria for the assessment and control of those materials.
The supplier shall verify that all materials and processes used in the manufacture of mechanical parts satisfy the mission technical requirements.

Mechanical parts shall be chosen from used for an identical application in other space programmes similar with respect to environment constraints and lifetime.

Type reduction actions shall be implemented at all levels of the programme.

Whether the mechanical parts are already qualified or remain to be qualified, their selection shall ensure that the following criteria are met:

  1. durability of supply,
  2. reproducibility of characteristics.

The supplier shall be responsible for storing and maintain all mechanical parts data in an internal database.

The access to the data, specified in requirements before, shall be granted to the customer.
The supplier shall establish and maintain a DMPL in conformance with DRD-7.06.

drds.title: Declared Mechanical Parts List (DMPL)
drds.action: R (if there will be no MPBC for the project, AC)

requirements.text:
The purpose of the DMPL is to have detailed record of all the mechanical parts used to produce the products of a project or programme.
The data in the DMPL make possible to assess whether the mechanical parts are suitable for a specific application, at the supplier and customer levels (in the approval status column).
The DRD-7.06 defines the content of a standardized DMPL.

The DMPL is prepared for each "configuration item" at the relevant stages (e.g. Start, PDR, CDR and QRR) as defined in para. 7.3.

The following document is linked to the DMPL: RFA mechanical parts.

requirements.text:
The evaluation shall include the following, as a minimum, for each critical part:
  1. the limits of use,
  2. the part's physical or functional characteristics, along with its values and tolerances,
  3. behavioural tendencies and degradation processes depending on environment parameters, including sensitivity to pollution, and
  4. acceptance criteria.

When evaluation is performed the supplier shall provide:
  1. an evaluation programme at PDR, and
  2. an evaluation report before CDR.

The behaviour of the parameters to be monitored which were also recorded during the evaluation programme tests, shall serve as a reference for the analysis of qualification test results.

NOTE:
Example of such behaviour is variation and change over time.

Qualification status shall be decided at CDR in view of the available results obtained, written in qualification report, and the reviews of corresponding documentation.

The qualification programme and report shall be submitted to the customer for acceptance.

requirements.text:
The mechanical parts shall not receive an approval identification in the declared mechanical parts list for the project unless the requirements in 7.6.5.1 and 7.6.5.2 are satisfied.

If approval is not granted, the supplier in charge of the item shall either:

  1. select another mechanical part, or
  2. propose a modified evaluation programme and resubmit for approval through RFA, or
  3. if the two actions above fail to achieve positive results, initiate a deviation procedure.

drds.title: RFA
drds.deliveryDate: immediately after contractor internal approval; MPCB; respectively summary lists for CDR; MRR; QR; AR

requirements.text: For mechanical parts not conforming to project requirements, whether at the end of criticality analysis or of evaluation and qualification tests, the supplier shall submit a RFD, according to para. 3.5.8.

If so identified by the criticality analysis, the supplier shall perform an evaluation phase before the qualification phase for all critical parts with unknown characteristics or with major changes in the use or in the configuration.

In case of an extension of an existing application, the evaluation need not be performed if so agreed with the customer.

Guaranteed characteristics of materials and material supplier inspection methods, together with associated documents, shall be available for review at the suppliers premises before the start of evaluation or qualification phases.
NOTE:
Refer to para. 7.3 for an explanation of the steps involved.
Mechanical parts with long lead times or procurement delays, versus the project schedule, shall be identified before the subsystem PDR.

Procurement shall be planned, documented and implemented to obtain reliable PA provision at CDR.

Back-up plans shall be prepared and initiated whenever there is evidence of possible delays or technical problems.

Each mechanical part shall be covered by a procurement specification or a standard approved by the supplier quality system.

The procurement specifications shall define the part characteristics, requirements, tests methods, acceptance criteria, lot acceptance testing, source inspection and material supplier inspection.

The procurement specifications shall be explicitly accepted by the mechanical part supplier or manufacturer.
For complex mechanical parts related to a specific project development, each supplier shall define the nature and frequency of their own source inspection points.
Source inspection shall be carried out by the customer on the premises of the supplier, mechanical parts manufacturer, in conformance with para. 3.7.3.

Each part or batch of mechanical parts shall be submitted to an incoming inspection according to para. 3.7.4.

An incoming inspection procedure shall be established defining the inspections and tests to be carried out.

The supplier shall ensure that all critical parts are qualified before being used in the manufacture of qualification or flight products.

Any modification, change in condition or configuration of application shall lead to a re-evaluation.
The supplier shall apply the traceability rules defined in para. 3.5.4 to his mechanical parts.

Parts shall be identified by an unique reference number or code and a lot number to provide traceability - where there is an incident or NC, or for the purposes of technical investigations following failure or damage - to reconstruct the mechanical parts history, either individually (individual traceability) or by the manufacturing lot it was part of (lot traceability).
The supplier shall define provisions for packaging, storage and removal from storage for parts and materials and shall be in accordance with the requirements of para. 3.5.6.

Measurements and inspections used to guarantee the part or material integrity and monitoring during storage and removal from storage shall be identified and shall be in accordance with the requirements of para. 3.5.6.

chapters.name: Limited-Life Mechanical Parts or Parts Subject to Wear Out

requirements.text:
Limited-life mechanical parts after implementation or subject to wear out shall be identified and controlled, including storage and mission life.
NOTE:
Examples of such mechanical parts are mechanisms, pyro initiators and o-rings.

Limited-life mechanical parts shall be assessed as candidates to the CIs list in conformance with para. 2.2.4.

Each process to be used in the manufacturing or assembly of a product shall be identified by a specification or procedure.

Reference shall be made to accept and reject criteria.

Processes shall be chosen from those already verified processes according to the following order of preference and priority:
  1. processes covered by space agencies or other governmental organization certification for identical conditions of use,
  2. processes for which satisfactory evaluation and verification results are obtained on samples representative of the application with a sufficient margin as regards conditions of use,
  3. processes already successfully used by the same supplier for other space programmes in the same conditions of use.

Whether the processes are already verified or remain to be verified, their selection shall ensure that the following criteria are met:
  1. reliability,
  2. inspectability,
  3. re-workability of the process item,
  4. reproducibility.
The supplier shall establish and maintain a DPL in conformance with DRD-7.07.

The supplier shall analyse all the processes contained in their preliminary lists with respect to criticality and in correlation with the risk analyses performed.

requirements.text:
Special processes shall be identified and controlled.

Process control shall be ensured by means of procedures available for customer review.

NOTE:
Best practice is to implement a statistical process control.

If so identified by the criticality analysis, the supplier shall perform an evaluation phase before the verification phase for all critical processes which are new or with major changes in the use or in the configuration.

In case of an extension of an existing application, the evaluation need not be performed if so agreed with the customer.

For confidential processes, the supplier shall prove that the process has been verified.

NOTE 1:
For example, by presenting a verification certificate from space agencies or other governmental organization responsible to check the applicability of this verification.
NOTE 2:
Refer to para. 7.3 for an explanation of the steps involved.

The evaluation shall include the following as a minimum for each critical process:
  1. the limits of use,
  2. the values, determined by test samples or technology samples, of relevant parameters and their tolerances, and
  3. acceptance criteria.

When an evaluation is performed, the supplier shall provide:
  1. an evaluation plan at PDR, and
  2. an evaluation report before CDR.

requirements.text:
For each critical process, the supplier shall implement a verification programme.

The verification programme shall be defined in conformance with ECSS-E-ST-10-02.

The supplier shall ensure that the processes satisfy the mission requirements and that the parameters needed for the product design are defined so as to obtain verification status.

Verification status shall be decided at CDR in view of the available results obtained, written in verification report, and the review of corresponding documentation.

The verification programme and report shall be approved by the customer.

requirements.text:
A process shall not receive an approval identification in the declared processes list unless requirements in para. 7.7.6.1 and para. 7.7.6.2 are satisfied.

In case approval is not granted, the supplier in charge of the item shall either:

  1. select other processes, or
  2. propose a modified evaluation programme and resubmit for approval, or
  3. if actions 1.) and 2.) fail to achieve positive results, initiate a deviation procedure.

For processes not conforming to project requirements, whether at the end of criticality analysis or of evaluation and verification tests, the supplier shall submit a RFD in conformance with para. 3.5.8.

The supplier shall confirm that all critical processes have been verified before used in the manufacture of qualification or flight products.

Any modification, change of conditions or configuration of application shall lead to a re-evaluation in conformance with the process.

When a process needs to be re-verified, a RFA: DRD-7.01) shall be established and a re-verification programme shall be implemented.
NOTE:
Any prolonged stoppage in manufacturing, any major change of the facilities or procedures or any transfer of production to another entity can invalidate partially or completely the initial verification of a process.

requirements.text: Before implementation of a process, the supplier shall ensure that personnel are trained in accordance with the training and certification programme specified in 7.7.3 and that environment, means, and documentation are adequate.

This verification shall ensure that:
  1. manufacturing and quality control tools associated with the process are adequate, calibrated and properly maintained, and are used under environmental and cleanliness conditions (see para. 3.8.4 Cleanliness/Contamination Control),
  2. personnel is trained and certified in accordance with the training and certification programme,
  3. the processes specifications, manufacturing and inspection procedures and workmanship standards including clear definition of manufacturing operations and clear acceptance criteria exist.
    NOTE 1:
    Photographically documented if possible for visual acceptance criteria at the appropriate work and inspection stations.
    NOTE 2:
    For planning of manufacturing, assembly and integration operation and inspection see ECSS-Q-ST-20.

requirements.text:
For manufacturing of electric/electronic equipment for space application workmanship standards are required. The following specifications shall be applied:
  • Verification and approval of automatic machine wave soldering,
    (ECSS-Q-ST-70-07)
  • The Manual Soldering of High Reliability Electrical Connections,
    (ECSS-Q-ST-70-08)
  • Preparation, assembly and mounting of RF Coaxial Cables,
    (ECSS-Q-ST-70-18)
  • Crimping of High Reliability Electrical Connections,
    (ECSS-Q-ST-70-26)
  • The Repair and Modification of Printed Circuit Boards Assemblies for space use,
    (ECSS-Q-ST-70-28)
  • The Wire Wrapping of High Reliability Electrical Connections,
    (ECSS-Q-ST-70-30)
  • High Reliability Soldering for Surface-Mount and Mixed-Technology Printed Circuit Boards,
    (ECSS-Q-ST-70-38)
  • Welding of metallic materials for flight HW
    (ECSS-Q-ST-70-39)
  • Qualification and procurement of printed circuit boards,
    (ECSS-Q-ST-70-60C)
NOTE:
These list of workmanship standard is not an exhaustive list.

requirements.text:
Operators performing
  • manual soldering,
  • repair of assembled PCBs,
  • manual SMD soldering,
  • assembly of RF-cables,
  • crimping,
  • wire-wrap

shall be trained and shall have a valid certification by an ESA-authorized/approved training school for the applicable process.

Rework, repair and modifications - PCBs
Rework, repair and modifications shall be performed in accordance with ECSS-Q-ST-70-28 taking into account the following requirements:
  • The total number of reworks or repairs (defined by ECSS-Q-ST-70-28) shall not exceed three soldering operations on any joint.
  • The total number of repairs involving soldering operations - including such repairs located on opposite side of the PCB - shall not exceed three within a circle region with a radius of 2.8 cm, centered on the middle of the item to be repaired.
  • The total number of modifications (defined by ECSS-Q-ST-70-28) involving soldering operations - including such modifications located on opposite side of the PCB - shall not exceed three within a circle region with a radius of 2.8 cm, centered on the middle of the item to be modified.

requirements.text:
DC Current Induced Thermal Cycling Test (IST) - Procurement of PCBs
NOTE:
The following tests are recommended but not required. IST shall be performed at least e.g. on 6 sample coupons.

IST shall include permanently monitoring of current from sense circuit and power circuit (max. 10% change of resistance) and temperature monitoring by Infra-Red sensor.

The tested coupons shall be delivered to the supplier.

Coupons are received and subjected to incoming inspection and pre-screening.

The PCB manufacturer shall produce and test associated test coupons according to the IPC approved Interconnect Stress Test (IST) method (IPC-TM650.2.6.26) to determine the multilayer PCBs ability to withstand the adverse influences of assembly, rework and the end use environment, and to evaluate the reliability of the copper plated barrel and innerlayer interconnects to the plated barrel of the PCBs.

applicableDocuments.title: IPC-TM650.2.6.26
applicableDocuments.description: DC Current Induced Thermal Cycling Test (IPC TEST METHODS MANUAL)

requirements.text:
ECSS-Q-ST-70-71 shall be applied for the selection of materials and processes that have safety relevance. When safety is not a concern, in case of criticality, following requirements shall apply for ISS internal HW.
  • ECSS-Q-ST-70-71 and NASA space materials databases (i.e. MAPTIS) shall be used and shall be compliant with the relevant EU ground regulations,
  • materials and mechanical parts shall be chosen from the ones used for identical application in other successfully flown space programmes similar with respect to environment constraints and lifetime.
As far as electronic assemblies are concerned, PCBs shall be designed, manufactured, procured, qualified, assembled and accepted according to the Class 3 as defined in the IPC standards of the Association Connecting Electronics Industries.
Note:
ECSS standards for electronic assemblies are considered to meet and exceed IPC standards.

applicableDocuments.title: ECSS-Q-ST-70-71
applicableDocuments.description: Materials, processes and their data selection (15 October 2014)

requirements.text:
The following standards shall be applied (as a minimum, the list is not exhaustive):
  • IPC-A-600 - Acceptability of Printed Boards,
  • IPC-6010 - Qualifications and Performance Specifications (document set),
  • IPC-2220 - Design and Land Patterns (document set),
  • IPC-7351 - Generic Requirements for Surface Mount Design and Land Pattern Standard,
  • IPC-4100 and 4200 - Base Materials for Printed Boards (document set),
  • IPC-4562 - Metal Foil for Printed Wiring Applications,
  • IPC-CC-830 - Qualification and Performance of Electronic Insulating Compound for Printed Board Assemblies,
  • IPC-4550 - Surface Finishes (document set),
  • IPC-2152 - Standard for Determining Current Carrying Capacity in Printed Board Design,
  • J-STD-001 - Requirements for Soldered Electrical and Electronic Assemblies,
  • J-STD-002 - Solderability Tests for Component Leads, Terminations, Lugs, terminals and Wires,
  • J-STD-003 - Solderability Tests for Printed Boards,
  • J-STD-004 - Requirements for Soldering Fluxes,
  • J-STD-005 - Requirements for Soldering Pastes,
  • J-STD-006 - Requirements for Electronic Grade Solder Alloys and Fluxed and Non-Fluxed Solid Solders for Electronic Soldering Applications,
  • IPC-TM-650 - Test Methods Manual,
  • IPC-A-610 - Acceptability of Electronic Assemblies,
  • IPC-7711/7721 - Rework, Modification and Repair of Electronic Assemblies,
  • IPC/WHMA-A-620 - Acceptability of Electronic Wire Harnesses and Cables Restrictions.

The following surface finishing shall be used:

  • ENIG,
  • Solder Coating (HASL - IPC code S or b1),
  • Electrodeposited Tin-Lead fused (IPC code T - not for ground HW);
  • others to be agreed by customer.

PCB solderability shall be tested as close to assembling as possible.

PCB manufacturers are not requested to be ECSS certified, however, as a minimum, they shall be either FprEN 9100:2016 certified (aerospace quality management system) or ISO 9001:2015 certified with preferably additional ISO/TS 16949:2009 (quality management system for automotive production and relevant service parts organizations) or ISO 13485:2012 (quality management systems for medical devices) certifications.

PCB manufacturers shall be notified to customer (in DPL).

PCBs for ground models (EM, QM, EQM) shall be procured from the same PCB manufacturer used for the FM PCBs.

NOTE 1:
No space or telecom addenda are applicable.
NOTE 2:
IPC's document sets are used to provide the total information related to a particular electronic packaging topic. A document set is identified by a four digit number that ends in zero (0) (i.e. IPC 6010). When a document set is made applicable in this document, all the standards belonging to that set shall be applicable (i.e. 6011, 6012, 6013, 6015, 6016 and 6018).
NOTE 3:
The applicable documents list contained in the IPC documents shall be considered as applicable.

chapters.name: Standard Processes for Additive Manufacturing & 3D Printing

requirements.text:
For additive manufacturing (AM) / 3D printing of components or mechanical parts for space application the following specifications shall be used as guidelines:
  • NASA Marshall Space Flight Center (MSFC):
    • Standard for Additively Manufactured Spaceflight Hardware by Laser Powder Bed Fusion in Metals, (MSFC-STD-3716)
    • Specification for Control and Qualification of Laser Powder Bed Fusion Metallurgical Processes. (MSFC-SPEC-3717)
  • ISO:
    • Additive manufacturing - General principles - Part 2: Overview of process categories and feedstock (ISO 17296-2:2015)
    • Additive manufacturing - General principles - Part 3: Main characteristics and corresponding test methods (ISO 17296-3:2014)
    • Additive manufacturing - General principles - Part 4: Overview of data processing (ISO 17296-4:2014)
    • Additive manufacturing - General principles - Terminology (ISO/ASTM 52900:2015)
    • Additive manufacturing - General principles - Requirements for purchased AM parts (ISO/ASTM 52901:2017)
    • Additive manufacturing - General principles - Requirements, guidelines and recommendations (ISO/ASTM 52910:2018)
    • Specification for additive manufacturing file format (AMF) Version 1.2 (ISO/ASTM 52915:2016)
    • Standard terminology for additive manufacturing - Coordinate systems and test methodologies (ISO/ASTM 52921:2013)
  • ASTM Additive Manufacturing Technology Standards (non-ISO):
    • Materials and Processes:
      • Standard Specification for Additive Manufacturing Titanium-6 Aluminum-4 Vanadium with Powder Bed Fusion (F2924 - 14)
      • Standard Specification for Additive Manufacturing Titanium-6 Aluminum-4 Vanadium Eli (Extra Low Interstitial) with Powder Bed Fusion (F3001 - 14)
      • Standard Guide for Characterizing Properties of Metal Powders Used for Additive Manufacturing Processes (F3049 - 14)
      • Standard Specification for Additive Manufacturing Nickel Alloy (UNS N07718) with Powder Bed Fusion (F3055- 14a)
      • Standard Specification for Additive Manufacturing Nickel Alloy (UNS N06625) with Powder Bed Fusion (F3056- 14e1)
      • Standard Specification for Powder Bed Fusion of Plastic Materials (F3091 / F3091M - 14)
      • Standard Specification for Additive Manufacturing Stainless Steel Alloy (UNS S31603) with Powder Bed Fusion (F3184 - 16)
      • Standard Guide for Directed Energy Deposition of Metals (F3187 - 16)
      • Standard for Additive Manufacturing - Finished Part Properties - Standard Specification for Cobalt-28 Chromium-6 Molybdenum via Powder Bed Fusion (F3213 - 17)
      • Standard for Additive Manufacturing - Post Processing Methods - Standard Specification for Thermal Post-Processing Metal Parts Made Via Powder Bed Fusion (F3301 - 18a)
      • Standard for Additive Manufacturing - Finished Part Properties - Standard Specification for Titanium Alloys via Powder Bed Fusion (F3302 - 18)
      • Standard for Additive Manufacturing - Process Characteristics and Performance: Practice for Metal Powder Bed Fusion Process to Meet Critical Applications (F3303 - 18)
      • Standard for Additive Manufacturing - Finished Part Properties - Specification for AlSi10Mg with Powder Bed Fusion - Laser Beam (F3318 - 18)
    • Test Methods:
      • Standard Practice for reporting data for Test Specimens Prepared by Additive Manufacturing (F2971-13)
      • Standard Guide for Evaluating Mechanical Properties of Metal Materials Made via Additive Manufacturing Processes F3122-14)
  • SAE AMS - Additive Manufacturing Technology Standards
    • Laser-Power Bed Fusion (L-PBF) Produced Parts, Nickel Alloy, Corrosion and Heat-Resistant, 62Ni - 21.5CR - 9.0Mo - 3.65Nb Stress Relieved, Hot Isostatic Pressed and Solution Annealed (AMS7000)
    • Nickel Alloy, Corrosion and Heat-Resistant, Powder for Additive Manufacturing, 62Ni - 21.5Cr - 9.0Mo - 3.65 Nb (AMS7001)
    • Process Requirements for Production of Powder Feedstock for Use in Laser Powder Bed Additive Manufacturing of Aerospace Parts (AMS7002)
    • Laser Powder Bed Fusion Process (AMS7003)
    • Titanium Alloy Direct Deposited Products 6Al - 4V Annealed (AMS4999A)
  • DIN - Additive Manufacturing Technology Standards (non-ISO):
    • Welding for aerospace applications - Acceptance inspection of powder bed based laser beam machines for additive manufacturing (DIN 35224)
    • Aerospace series - Powder for additive manufacturing with powder bed process - Technical specification (DIN 65122)
    • Welding for aerospace applications - Qualification of operators for powder bed based mashines for additive manufacturing (DIN 35225)
    • Aerospace series - Methods for inspection of metallic components, manufactured with additive powder bed fusion process (DIN 65123)
  • VDI - Richtlinienreihe VDI 3405 on additive manufacturing processes.
NOTE:
  1. These list of workmanship standards is not an exhaustive list. New standards may be published in the meantime, too.
  2. For ECSS there is currently (status 04/2019) a draft of ECSS-Q-ST-70-80C "Processing and quality assurance requirements for metallic powder bed fusion technologies for space applications" in the process of being established.
If not already covered by one of the applied guidelines the following shall be considered:

• Since the ability to produce multiple parts consistently across machines, operators, and manufacturing facilities needs to be ensured, adequate process monitoring shall be implemented and measurement tools be used.

• Variability in AM machines and/or beam source/material interactions can create inconsistency in the microstructure, presence of defects, and variability in the mechanical performance, therefore in situ process monitoring and control shall be implemented, mechanical testing/characterization performed and NDI technologies i.e. acoustic, ultrasonic, radiography, shearography (with capability for through thickness discrimination) and visual, eddy current, magnetic, penetrant and thermography (typically limited to surface operation) applied, as adequate for the AM parts/components.

• The alterations to the nominal chemical composition of the powder alloys used for AM may originate from different sources, e.g., raw material production stage, storage conditions, cleanliness requirements and cross-contamination from different feedstock. In particular, the oxygen content on the powder is reported, to affect the tensile properties of Ti-6Al-4V, therefore the oxygen content on the powder shall be measured along these stages.
Traceability of processes shall be ensured in accordance with requirements from para. 3.5.4.

The objectives of SW PA are to provide adequate confidence to the customer and to the supplier that the developed or procured/reused SW satisfies its requirements throughout the system lifetime. In particular, that the SW is developed to perform properly and safely in its operational environment, meeting the quality objectives agreed for the project.

Tailoring of SWPA activities shall be done in accordance to ECSS Q-ST-80C, para 4.3 and Annex D.
The drivers for tailoring of the activities shall be based on
  1. SW criticality categories (A-D, according to ECSS-Q-ST-80C, Annex D, Applicability Matrix D.2),
  2. life cycle (Agile or V-Model),
  3. quality objectives, as defined in 8.7.1,
  4. business objectives and needs,
  5. SW development constraints, see Annex S of ECSS-E-ST-40.

applicableDocuments.title: ECSS-Q-ST-80
applicableDocuments.description: Software product assurance (15 February 2017)

applicableDocuments.title: ECSS-E-ST-40
applicableDocuments.description: Software general requirements (6 March 2009)

requirements.text:
Explanation of philosophy:
The SW PA policy is directly derived from the general PA policy.
The main objective and principles are:
  • all SW requirements are adequately specified,
  • all SW applications are categorised according to criticality,
  • appropriate design and development methods and standards are established and applied in accordance with SW criticality categories,
  • development and maintenance processes are continually monitored and assured,
  • any SW problems are found and corrected with sufficient timeliness to minimise their impact,
  • performance requirements are demonstrated through acceptance tests,
  • verification and validation are properly achieved,
  • design, implementation and inspection allow a real capability to maintain and/or to reuse SW.

The provisions of the SW Engineering Standard ECSS-E-ST-40, complemented by the handbooks
  • ECSS-E-HB-40,
  • ECSS-E-HB-40-01,
  • ECSS-Q-HB-80-01,
  • ECSS-Q-HB-80-02,
  • ECSS-Q-HB-80-03,
  • ECSS-Q-HB-80-04

shall be used as a basis for SW engineering and SW PA.

applicableDocuments.title: ECSS-E-ST-40
applicableDocuments.description: Software general requirements (6 March 2009)

requirements.text: The supplier shall ensure that an organizational structure is defined for SW development, and that individuals have defined tasks and responsibilities.
The suppliers shall be responsible for planning and monitoring all activities associated with the SW, and shall assure adequate implementation of a SW PA programme.
The responsibilities and the interfaces of each organisation, either external or internal, involved in a project shall be defined and documented.

chapters.name: Software Product Assurance Planning and Control

requirements.text:
The supplier shall develop a SW PA plan (DRD-8.01) in response to the SW PA requirements.

The SW PA plan shall either be a standalone document or a section of the supplier overall PA plan.
The purpose of the SW PA plan is to provide information on the organizational aspects and the technical approach to the execution of the SW PA programme and shall be in conformance with DRD-8.01.
The supplier shall report on a regular basis on the status of the SW PA programme implementation,if appropriate as part of the overall PA reporting of the project in accordance with para. 2.2.2.

The SW PA report shall include:
  1. an assessment of the current quality of the product and processes, based on measured properties, with reference to the metrication as defined in the SW PA plan,
  2. verifications undertaken,
  3. problems detected,
  4. problems resolved.
The supplier shall define and implement procedures for the logging, analysis and correction of all SW problems encountered during SW development.
The procedures for SW problems shall define the interface with the NC system (i.e. the circumstances under which a problem qualifies as a NC).

The SW problem report shall contain the following information:
  1. identification of the SW item,
  2. description of the problem,
  3. recommended solution,
  4. final disposition,
  5. modifications implemented (e.g. documents, code, and tools),
  6. tests re-executed.
For SW NCs handling, para. 3.5.1 shall apply.
When dealing with SW NC, the NRB shall include, at least, a representative from the SW PA and the SW engineering organisations.
The SW PA plan (DRD-8.01) shall specify the point in the SW life cycle or SW development process from which the NC procedures apply.

The NRB shall dispose SW NCs according to the following criteria:
  1. use "as-is", when the SW is found to be usable without eliminating the NC,
  2. fix, when the SW product can be made fully in conformance with all specified requirements, by:
    1. correction of the SW,
    2. addition of SW patches, or
    3. re-design.
  3. return to supplier, for procured SW products (e.g. COTS).
Quality models shall be used to specify the SW quality requirements.

> Criticality A, B, C (required for) <
> Criticality D (relevant characteristics only) <

The following characteristics shall be used to specify the quality model:

  • functionality,
  • reliability,
  • maintainability,
  • reusability,
  • suitability for safety,
  • security,
  • usability,
  • efficiency,
  • portability,
  • SW development effectiveness.
NOTE 1:
Quality models are the basis for the identification of process metrics and product metrics.
NOTE 2:
Quality models are also addressed by ISO/IEC 25010:2011 (formerly ISO/IEC 9126) or ECSS-Q-HB-80-04.

applicableDocuments.title: ISO/IEC 25010:2011
applicableDocuments.description: Software-Engineering - Qualitätskriterien und Bewertung von Softwareprodukten (SQuaRE) - Qualitätsmodell und Leitlinien (March 2011)

requirements.text:
SW PA shall ensure that the characteristics listed above are adequately incorporated into the SW PA Programme, considering all interfaces to other PA functions.
NOTE:
The corresponding interfaces shall be documented in the PA plan.

chapters.name: Risk Management and Critical Item Control

requirements.text: Risk management for SW shall be performed by cross-reference to the project risk policy, as specified in ECSS-M-ST-80.

applicableDocuments.title: ECSS-M-ST-80
applicableDocuments.description: Risk Management (31 July 2008)

requirements.text: For CI control para. 2.2.4 is applicable.
The SW development life cycle shall be defined or referenced in the SW PA plan (DRD-8.01).

The following characteristics of the SW life cycle shall be defined:
  1. phases,
  2. input and output of each phase,
  3. status of completion of phase output,
  4. milestones,
  5. dependencies,
  6. responsibilities,
  7. role of the customer at each milestone review.
The SW life cycle shall be reviewed against the contractual SW engineering and PA requirements.

A milestone (SW TRR as defined in ECSS-E-ST-40C clause 5.3.5.1) shall be scheduled immediately before the SW validation process starts, to check that:
  1. the SW status is compatible with the commencement of validation activities,
  2. the necessary resources, SW PA plans, test and validation documentation, simulators or other technical means are available and ready for use.

applicableDocuments.title: ECSS-E-ST-40
applicableDocuments.description: Software general requirements (6 March 2009)

requirements.text:
The SWDP (SW Development Plan) shall cover the implementation of all the activities and tasks relevant to the involved SW processes, including:
  • system engineering processes related to SW,
  • SW requirement & architecture engineering process,
  • SW design and implementation engineering process,
  • SW validation process,
  • SW verification process,
  • SW delivery and acceptance,
  • SW operation process,
  • SW maintenance process and its interface with development (documents to be handed over, tools to be maintained),
  • SW management process.

chapters.name: Requirements Applicable to all Software Engineering Processes

requirements.text:
The following activities shall be covered either in SW-specific plans or in project general plans:
  1. development,
  2. specification, design and customer documents to be produced,
  3. configuration and documentation management,
  4. verification, testing and validation activities,
  5. maintenance.
All plans shall be finalized before the start of the activities.
All plans shall be updated for each milestone to reflect any changes during development, if necessary.
The SW PA plan shall identify all plans to be produced and used, the relationship between them and the time-scales for their preparation and update.
Each plan shall be reviewed against the relevant contractual requirements.
Procedures and project standards shall address all types of SW products included in the project.

The following activities shall be covered by the SW development plan and project standards:
  1. recording of development metrics,
  2. classification of SW product according to its functional criticality,
  3. use of program design language, if it is used in the detailed design,
  4. use of coding languages.

The criticality category of a SW product (A, B, C, D) shall be assigned, based on the criticality assigned to the most critical function it implements, and meet the criteria defined in Table 4-3 and requirements in para. 4.9

The criticality category of SW products shall be assigned, considering the overall system design, and in particular whether HW, SW or operational means exist, including compensating provisions, which can prevent SW-caused system failures or mitigate their consequences.
NOTE 1:
Compensating provisions include in particular inhibits, monitors, back-ups and operational procedures.
NOTE 2:
Compensating provisions can be implemented with different objectives, e.g. just making the system safe (fail safe) or keep the system operational (fail operational).

The effectiveness of the compensating provisions for the purpose of reducing the SW criticality category to a lower category than in absence of compensating provisions shall be demonstrated in all conditions, excluding failures of the compensating provisions themselves.
In all situations there shall be sufficient time for the compensating provisions to intervene in order to prevent or mitigate the subject failure.

In case the compensating provisions contain SW, this SW shall be classified at the criticality category corresponding to the highest severity of the failure consequences that they prevent or mitigate.
Probabilistic assessment of SW failures shall not be used as a criterion for SW criticality category assignment.

Any common resources shared by SW products of different criticality shall be identified and SW criticality allocation confirmed or changed accordingly.
Table 8-2: Criticality category assignment for SW products vs. function criticality
Function Criticality Criticality category to be assigned to a SW product
I Criticality category A if the SW product is the sole means to implement the function
Criticality category B if, in addition, at least one of the following compensating provisions is available, meeting the requirements defined in clause 8.6.2.2:
  • A HW implementation
  • A SW implementation; this SW implementation shall be classified as criticality A
  • An operational procedure
II Criticality category B if the SW product is the sole means to implement the function
Criticality category C if, in addition, at least one of the following compensating provisions is available, meeting the requirements defined in clause 8.6.2.2:
  • A HW implementation
  • A SW implementation; this SW implementation shall be classified as criticality B
  • An operational procedure
III Criticality category C if the SW product is the sole means to implement the function
Criticality category D if, in addition, at least one of the following compensating provisions is available, meeting the requirements defined in clause 8.6.2.2:
  • A HW implementation
  • A SW implementation; this SW implementation shall be classified as criticality C
  • An operational procedure
IV Criticality category D
NOTE:
It should be noted that a too high level/incomplete functional decomposition, poorly accounting for safety and dependability aspects, could lead to a unnecessarily conservative SW category classification.

> Criticality A, B, C (required for) <

The supplier shall perform a SW dependability analysis of the SW products according with para. 5.10.6, and using the results of system-level dependability analyses, in order to determine the criticality of the individual SW components (see para. 4.11.2.5 FMEA/FMECA; para. 4.11.2.6 HSIA).

> Criticality A, B, C (required for) <

The supplier shall perform a SW safety analysis (see para. 5.10.6) of the SW products, and using the results of system-level safety analyses, in order to determine the criticality of the individual SW components.

> Criticality A, B, C (required for) <

The supplier shall identify the methods and techniques for the SW dependability and safety analysis to be performed at technical specification and design level. Methods and techniques for SW dependability and safety analysis shall be agreed between the supplier and customer.

NOTE:
ECSS-Q-HB-80-03 provides indication on methods and techniques that can be applied such as:
  • SW FMEA (for the performing of this analysis, see also ECSS-Q-ST-30-02),
  • SW FTA,
  • SW common cause failure analysis.

applicableDocuments.title: ECSS-Q-ST-30-02
applicableDocuments.description: Failure modes, effects (and criticality) analysis (FMEA/FMECA) (6 March 2009)

requirements.text:
> Criticality A, B, C (required for) <

Based on the results of the SW criticality analysis, the supplier shall apply engineering measures to reduce the number of critical SW components and mitigate the risks associated with the critical SW.

> Criticality A, B, C (required for) <

The supplier shall update the SW dependability and safety analysis at each SW development milestone, to confirm the criticality category of SW components.

If it cannot be prevented that SW components cause failures of higher criticality components, due to failure propagation or use of shared resources, then all the involved components shall be classified at the highest criticality category among them.
NOTE:
Failures of higher-criticality SW components caused by lower-criticality components can be prevented by design measures such as separate HW platforms, isolation of SW processes or prohibition of shared memory (segregation and partitioning).
SW dependability and safety analysis report shall be provided for PDR, CDR, QR, AR.

drds.number: Software dependability and safety analysis report acc. to req.
drds.title: Software dependability and safety analysis report

requirements.text:
> Criticality A, B, C (required for) <

The supplier shall define, justify and apply measures to assure the dependability and safety of critical SW.

NOTE:
These measures can include:
  • use of SW design or methods that have performed successfully in a similar application,
  • insertion of features for failure isolation and handling (SW failure modes, effects and criticality analysis),
  • defensive programming techniques, such as input verification and consistency checks,
  • use of a "safe subset" of programming language
  • use of formal design language for formal proof,
  • 100 % code branch coverage at unit testing level,
  • full inspection of source code,
  • witnessed or independent testing,
  • gathering and analysis of failure statistics,
  • removing deactivated code or showing through a combination of analysis and testing that the means by which such code can be inadvertently executed are prevented, isolated, or eliminated.

> Criticality A, B, C (required for) <

Critical SW shall be subject to regression testing after:

  • any change of functionality (e.g. instruction set of a processor) of the underlying platform HW, and
  • any change of the tools that affect directly or indirectly the generation of the executable code.

> Criticality A, B, C (required for) <

The need for additional verification of critical SW shall be analysed after:

  • any change of functionality or performance of the underlying platform HW, and
  • any change in the environment in which the SW or the platform HW operate.

> Criticality A, B, C (required for) <

Identified unreachable code shall be removed and the need for re-verification and re-validation shall be analysed.

> Criticality A, B (required for) <

Unit and integration testing shall be (re-)executed on non-instrumented code.

> Criticality A, B, C (required for) <

Validation testing shall be (re-)executed on non-instrumented code.
All SW and SW related documents shall be subject to the CM according to para. 2.2.7 of this document.

The following documents shall be controlled:
  • procedural documents describing the quality system to be applied during the SW life cycle,
  • planning documents describing the planning and progress of the activities,
  • documents describing a particular SW product, including:
    1. development phase inputs,
    2. development phase outputs,
    3. verification and validation plans and results,
    4. test case specifications, test procedures and test reports,
    5. traceability matrices,
    6. documentation for the SW and system operators and users, and
    7. maintenance documentation.
Metrics shall be used to manage the development and to assess the quality of the development process.
The SPAP shall describe the process metrics derived from the defined quality models, the means to collect, store and analyse them, and the way they are used to manage the development processes.
Process metrics shall be collected, stored and analysed on a regular basis by applying quality models and procedures.

> Criticality A, B, C (required for) <
> Criticality D (limited to number of problems during validation) <

Process metrics shall be used within the supplier's organization and reported to the customer, including:

  1. number of problems detected during inspection,
  2. number of problems detected during integration and validation testing and use.
Metrics reports shall be included in the SW PA reports.

Activities for the verification of the quality requirements shall be specified in the definition of the verification plan (acc. ECSS-E-ST-40).
NOTE:
Verification includes various techniques such as review, inspection, testing, walk-through, cross-reading, desk-checking, and many types of analysis such as traceability analysis, formal proof or FTA.

applicableDocuments.title: ECSS-E-ST-40
applicableDocuments.description: Software general requirements (6 March 2009)

requirements.text: The outputs of each development activity shall be verified for conformance against pre-defined criteria.
Only outputs which have been subjected to planned verifications shall be used as inputs for subsequent activities.
A summary of the assurance activities concerning the verification process and their findings shall be included in SW PA reports.

> Criticality A, B, C (required for) <

SW containing deactivated code shall be verified specifically to ensure that the deactivated code cannot be activated or that its accidental activation cannot harm the operation of the system.

> Criticality A, B, C (required for) <

SW containing configurable code shall be verified specifically to ensure that any unintended configuration cannot be activated at run time or included during code generation.

The supplier shall ensure that:

  1. the planned verification activities are adequate to confirm that the products of each phase are conformant to the applicable requirements,
  2. the verification activities are performed according to the plan.
Each review and inspection shall be based on a written plan or procedure.

The review or inspection plans or procedures shall specify:
  1. the reviewed or inspected items,
  2. the person in charge,
  3. the participants,
  4. the means of review or inspection (e.g. tools or check list),
  5. the nature of the report.

Review and inspection reports shall:
  • refer to the corresponding review/inspection procedure or plan, and
  • identify the reviewed item, the author, the reviewer, the review criteria, and the findings of the review.
Traceability of verification results shall be demonstrated acc. to para. 3.5.4.

Analyses of the advantages to be obtained with the selection of existing SW instead of new development shall be carried out.
NOTE:
Existing SW is any SW developed outside the business agreement to which this standard is applicable, including SW from previous developments provided by the supplier, SW from previous developments provided by the customer, COTS, OTS and MOTS SW, freeware and open source SW.
The existing SW shall be assessed with regards to the applicable functional, performance and quality requirements.

> Criticality A, B, C (required for) <
> Criticality D (bullets 3, 4, 5 and 7 not applicable; bullet 2 limited to architectural design) <

The quality level of the existing SW shall be analysed with respect to the project requirements, according to the criticality of the system function implemented, taking into account the following aspects:

  1. SW requirements documentation,
  2. SW architectural and detailed design documentation,
  3. forward and backward traceability between system requirements, SW requirements, design and code,
  4. unit tests documentation and coverage,
  5. integration tests documentation and coverage,
  6. validation documentation and coverage,
  7. verification reports,
  8. performance,
    NOTE:
    For example: memory occupation, CPU load.
  9. operational performances,
  10. residual NCs and waivers,
  11. user operational documentation,
    NOTE:
    For example: user manual.
  12. code quality (adherence to coding standards, metrics).

The results of the reused SW analysis shall be recorded in the SW reuse file acc. DRD-8.04, together with an assessment of the possible level of reuse and a description of the assumptions and the methods applied when estimating the level of reuse.

The analysis of the suitability of existing SW for reuse shall be complemented by an assessment of the following aspects:
  • the acceptance and warranty conditions,
  • the available support documentation,
  • the conditions of installation, preparation, training and use,
  • the identification and registration by CM,
  • maintenance responsibility and conditions, including the possibilities of changes,
  • the durability and validity of methods and tools used in the initial development, that are envisaged to be used again,
  • the copyright and intellectual property rights constraints (modification rights),
  • the licensing conditions,
  • exportability constraints.

> Criticality A, B, C (required for) <
> Criticality D (limited to the extent to ensure maintainability of the SW) <

Corrective actions shall be identified, documented in the reuse file and applied to the reused SW not meeting the applicable requirements related to the aspects as specified above.
The SW reuse file shall be updated at project milestones to reflect the results of the identified corrective actions for reused SW not meeting the project requirements.
The detailed configuration status of the reused SW baseline shall be provided to the customer in the reuse file (DRD-8.04) for information.
Reflown SW assessment shall be performed in accordance with para. 5.14.2.1.

For the selection of tools for automatic code generation, the supplier shall evaluate the following aspects:
  • evolution of the tools in relation to the tools that use the generated code as an input (e.g. compilers or code management systems),
  • customization of the tools to comply with project standards,
  • portability requirements for the generated code,
  • collection of the required design and code metrics,
  • verification of SW components containing generated code,
  • configuration control of the tools including the parameters for customisation,
  • compliance with open standards.
The requirements on testing applicable to the automatically generated code shall ensure the achievement of the same objectives as those for manually generated code.

The required level of verification and validation of the automatic generation tool shall be at least the same as the one required for the generated code, if the tool is used to skip verification or testing activities on the target code.
Para. 8.7.3 shall apply to automatically generated code, unless the supplier demonstrates that the automatically generated code does not need to be manually modified.

chapters.name: Requirements Applicable to Individual Software Engineering Processes or Activities

requirements.text: The SW shall be subject to the HSIA according to para. 4.11.2.6. For the definition of the requirements baseline, all results from the safety and dependability analyses (including results from the HSIA) shall be used.
The requirements baseline shall be analysed to fully and unambiguously define the SW requirements in the technical specification.

In addition to the functional requirements, the technical specification shall include all non-functional requirements necessary to satisfy the requirements baseline, including, as a minimum, the following:
  1. performance (including numerical accuracy),
  2. safety,
  3. reliability,
  4. robustness,
  5. quality,
  6. maintainability,
  7. CM,
  8. security,
  9. privacy,
  10. metrication, and
  11. verification and validation.
NOTE:
Performance requirements include requirements on numerical accuracy.

The SW requirements shall be:
  1. correct,
  2. unambiguous,
  3. complete
  4. consistent,
  5. verifiable,
  6. traceable.

chapters.name: Software Architectural Design and Design of Software Items

requirements.text:
> Criticality A, B, C (required for) <
> Criticality D (documentation control only) <

The design definition file shall be subject to documentation control and CM.

> Criticality A, B, C (required for) <
> Criticality D (only recommended) <

Mandatory and advisory design standards shall be defined and applied (DRD-8.02).

> Criticality A, B, C (required for) <

For SW in which numerical accuracy is relevant to mission success (e.g. for an attitude and orbit control subsystem, scientific data generation components) specific rules on design and code shall be defined to ensure that the specified level of accuracy is obtained (DRD-8.02).

> Criticality A, B, C (required for) <

The supplier shall define means, criteria and tools to ensure that the complexity and modularity of the design meet the quality requirements.

> Criticality A, B, C (required for) <

The design evaluation shall be performed in parallel with the design process, in order to provide feedback to the SW design team.

> Criticality A, B, C (required for) <

Synthesis of the results obtained in the SW complexity and modularity evaluation and corrective actions implemented shall be described in the SW PA reports.
The supplier shall review the design documentation to ensure that it contains the appropriate level of information for maintenance activities.
Coding standards (including consistent naming conventions, and adequate commentary rules) shall be specified (DRD-8.02) and observed.

> Criticality A, B, C (required for) <

The tools to be used in implementing and checking conformance with coding standards shall be identified in the PA plan before coding activities start.
Use of low-level programming languages shall be justified.
The supplier shall define measurements, criteria and tools to ensure that the SW code meets the quality requirements.
The code evaluation shall be performed in parallel with the coding process, in order to provide feedback to the SW programmers.
Synthesis of the code analysis results and corrective actions implemented shall be described in the SW PA reports.

> Criticality A, B, C (required for) <
> Criticality D (the code shall be put under configuration control at the beginning of validation testing) <

The code shall be put under configuration control in accordance with para. 2.2.7. The point of configuration start shall be defined in the SW CM plan (SCMP).

> Criticality A, B, C (required for) <
> Criticality D (no formal unit testing and Integration control at the beginning of validation phase) <

Testing shall be performed in accordance with a strategy for each testing level (i.e. unit (DRD-8.05), integration (DRD-8.05), validation against the technical specification, validation against the requirements baseline, acceptance (DRD-8.03)) which includes:

  1. the types of tests to be performed, e.g. functional, boundary, performance, and usability tests,
  2. the tests to be performed in accordance with the plans and procedures, and
  3. the means and organizations to perform assurance function for testing and validation.

> Criticality A, B, C (required for) <
> Criticality D (no formal unit testing and Integration activity required) <

Based on the criticality of the SW, test coverage goals for each testing level shall be agreed between the customer and the supplier and their achievement monitored by metrics:

  1. for unit level testing,
  2. for integration level testing,
  3. for validation against the technical specification and validation against the requirements baseline.

> Criticality A, B, C (required for) <
> Criticality D (test procedures and data verified by sample) <

The supplier shall ensure through internal review that the test procedures and data are adequate, feasible and traceable and that they satisfy the requirements.

> Criticality A, B, C (required for) <
> Criticality D (applicable to validation and acceptance tests only) <

TRRs shall be held before the commencement of test activities, as defined in the SW development plan.
Test coverage shall be checked with respect to the stated goals. Feedback from the results of test coverage evaluation shall be continuously provided to the SW developers.
The supplier shall ensure that NCs and SW problem reports detected during testing are properly documented and reported to those concerned. SW NCs shall be treated as defined in para. 3.5.1.
The test coverage of configurable code shall be checked to ensure that the stated requirements are met in each tested configuration.
The completion of actions related to SW problem reports generated during testing and validation shall be verified and recorded.

> Criticality A, B, C (required for) <

Provisions shall be made to allow witnessing of tests by the customer.

The supplier shall ensure that:
  1. tests are conducted in accordance with approved test procedures and data,
  2. the configuration under test is correct,
  3. the tests are properly documented, and
  4. the test reports are up to date and valid.
The supplier shall ensure that tests are repeatable by verifying the storage and recording of tested SW, support SW, test environment, supporting documents and problems found.

> Criticality A, B, C (required for) <
> Criticality D (applicable to validation and acceptance tests only) <

Review boards looking to engineering and PA aspects shall be convened after the completion of test phases, as defined in the SW development plan.
Areas affected by any modifications shall be identified and re-tested (regression testing).
In case of re-testing, all test related documentation (test procedures, data and reports) shall be updated accordingly.
The need for regression testing and additional verification of SW shall be analysed after any change of the platform HW.
The need for regression testing and additional verification of the SW shall be analysed after a change or update of any tool used to generate it (e.g. source code or object code).

> Criticality A, B, C (required for) <

Validation shall be carried out by staff who has not taken part in the design or coding of the SW being validated.
Validation of the flight SW against the requirements baseline on the flight equipment model shall be performed on a SW version without any patch.
The supplier shall review the test documentation to ensure that it is up to date and organized to facilitate its reuse for maintenance.
The necessary resources for testing shall be identified early in the life cycle, taking into account the operating and maintenance requirements.
Test tool development or acquisition (HW and SW) shall be planned for in the overall project plan.

The supplier shall establish and review the test procedures and data before starting testing activities and also document the constraints of the tests concerning physical, performance, functional, controllability and observability limitations.

Before offering the product for delivery and customer acceptance, the supplier shall validate its operation as a complete product, under conditions similar to the application environment as specified in the requirements baseline.

When testing under the operational environment is performed, the following concerns shall be addressed:
  1. the features to be tested in the operational environment,
  2. the specific responsibilities of the supplier and customer for carrying out and evaluating the test,
  3. restoration of the previous operational environment (after test).

The validation shall include testing in the different configurations possible or in a representative set of them when it is evident that the number of possible configurations is too high to allow validation in all of them.

> Criticality A, B, C (required for) <

SW containing deactivated code shall be validated specifically to ensure that the deactivated code cannot be activated or that its accidental activation cannot harm the operation of the system.

> Criticality A, B, C (required for) <

SW containing configurable code shall be validated specifically to ensure that unintended configuration cannot be activated at run time or included during code generation.

The supplier shall perform a static verification of the SW source code considering the criteria listed below:
  • The code implements correct control and data flow,
  • Internal consistency between SW units is checked (number and types of parameters passed to functions - including function pointers in C language),
  • absence of following run-time errors:
    1. divisions by zero,
    2. square roots of a negative number,
    3. overflows and underflows,
    4. out-of-bound array and pointer accesses,
    5. illegal type conversion,
    6. reading of non-initialized data,
  • absence of non-deterministic behaviour,
  • absence of data corruption,
  • absence of security breaches.

In addition to the verification process established by the contractor this static verification of the SW code shall be performed by a qualified method, which is accepted by the customer, e.g. PolySpace Verifier. Nevertheless this required verification procedure shall not be interpreted as a transfer of responsibility for the results thereof. The result of this static verification (according to DRD-8.06 and DRD-8.07) shall be submitted to the customer for review. The supplier is responsible for ensuring that this static verification is executed for all SW source code delivered by its sub-tier supplier.
If the tool PolySpace is used, the settings for the analysis have to be agreed by DLR.

NOTE:
For optimized application, the code should be in conformity with coding standards (recognized standards as MISRA-C for C language (MISRA-C:2004 for legacy and MISRA-C:2012 (including Amendment 1 of April 2016 on additional security guidelines for MISRA-C:2012) for new developments)).
The roles, responsibilities and obligations of the supplier and customer during installation shall be established.
The supplier shall develop procedures to install (DRD-8.08) the SW product in the target environment.
The installation shall be performed in accordance with the installation procedure.

The supplier shall establish an acceptance test plan (DRD-8.03) specifying the intended acceptance tests including specific tests suited to the target environment.
NOTE 1:
The acceptance tests can be partly made up of tests used during previous test activities.
NOTE 2:
The acceptance test plan takes into account the requirement for operational demonstration, either as part of acceptance or after acceptance.
The supplier shall ensure that the acceptance tests are performed in accordance with the accepted acceptance test plan (DRD-8.03).

Before the SW is presented for customer acceptance, the supplier shall ensure that:
  1. the delivered SW complies with the contractual requirements (including any specified content of the SW ADP),
  2. the source and object code supplied correspond to each other,
  3. all agreed changes are implemented,
  4. all NCs are either resolved or declared.
The supplier shall verify that the executable code was regenerated from configuration managed source code components and installed in accordance with predefined procedures on the target environment.

Any discovered problems shall be documented in NCRs (DRD-3.01).
NOTE:
SW Problem Report (SPR) may be used instead of NCR if conform to the NCR process according to para. 3.5.1.

drds.title: Nonconformance Report (NCR)
drds.deliveryDate: initial written report, latest 3 working days after detection of non-conformance; to be provided for Control Boards as affected

requirements.text: On completion of the acceptance tests, a report shall be drawn up and be signed by the supplier´s representatives, the customer's representatives, the SW quality engineers of both parties and the representative of the organization charged with the maintenance of the SW product.
The supplier shall certify conformance to the procedures and state the conclusion concerning the test result for the SW product under test (accepted, conditionally accepted or rejected).

> Criticality A, B, C (required for) <
> Criticality D (bullet 4.a not applicable) <

In order to verify the implementation of the product quality requirements, the supplier shall define a metrication programme based on the identified quality model, specifying:

  1. the metrics to be collected and stored,
  2. the means to collect metrics (measurements),
  3. the target values, with reference to the product quality requirements,
  4. the analyses to be performed on the collected metrics, including the ones to derive:
    1. descriptive statistics (e.g. the number of units at each level of complexity),
    2. trend analysis (such as trends in SW problems).
  5. how the results of the analyses performed on the collected metrics are fed back to the development team and used to identify corrective actions,
  6. the schedule of metrics collection, storing, analysis and reporting, with reference to the whole SW life cycle.
NOTE:
Guidance for SW metrication programme implementation can be found in ECSS-Q-HB-80-04.

> Criticality A, B, C (required for) <
> Criticality D (design-relevant and fault density/failure intensity metrics not required) <

The following basic products metrics shall be used:

  1. size (code),
  2. complexity (design, code),
  3. fault density and failure intensity,
  4. test coverage,
  5. number of failures.
The results of metrics collection and analysis shall be included in the SW PA reports, in order to provide the customer with an insight into the level of quality obtained.
Detailed test and validation documentation (data, procedures and expected results) defined in the ECSS-E-ST-40C, DJF, shall be consistent with the defined test and validation strategy.

applicableDocuments.title: ECSS-E-ST-40
applicableDocuments.description: Software general requirements (6 March 2009)

requirements.text: The test documentation shall cover the test environment, tools and test SW, personnel required and associated training requirements.
The criteria for completion of each test and any contingency steps shall be specified.
Test procedures, data and expected results shall be specified.
The HW and SW configuration shall be identified and documented as part of the test documentation.
For any requirements not covered by testing a verification report shall be drawn up documenting or referring to the verification activities performed.

chapters.name: Development and Documentation of the Software User Manual (SUM)

requirements.text: The PA responsible shall verify that a SUM is developed and documented according to DRD-8.09.
The technical specification of components developed for reuse shall include requirements for maintainability, portability and verification of those components.

The CM system shall include provisions for handling specific aspects of SW developed for reuse, such as:
  1. longer lifetime of the components developed for reuse compared to the other components of the project,
  2. evolution or change of the development environment for the next project that intends to use the components,
  3. transfer of the configuration and documentation management information to the next project reusing the SW.
The supplier shall establish procedures for firmware device programming and duplication of firmware devices.
The firmware device shall be indelibly marked to allow the identification (by reference) of the HW component and of the SW component.
The supplier shall ensure that the firmware programming equipment is calibrated.
For the selection of COTS, OTS or MOTS SW components to be used for or integrated into the system, the requirements of para. 8.6.7 (Reuse of SW) are applicable.
The supplier shall ensure compliant use of FOSS to all agreements (e.g. licenses, contracts or frame contracts) made.
The supplier shall establish and apply an assessment process to verify the acceptable use of FOSS.
The Assessment shall be based on objective criteria and aligned with industry practice.
The assessment shall reflect technical, quality, legal (compliance, contract) and financial (liability) constraints (e.g. confidentiality, integrity or export regulations).
The assessment results shall be recorded and retrievable for providing evidence, in particular in case of an audit or contractual obligation.
The assessment shall be provided by competent staff that is capable to determine noncompliant use.
The supplier shall establish and apply a decision making process to ensure the acceptable use of FOSS.
The decision shall be recorded and retrievable, in particular in case of an audit or contractual obligation.
The PA manager shall report use of FOSS to the customer.
Contributions towards open source communities shall be made with commitment from the suppliers' customer.

SW that implements or controls safety-critical functions shall be subject to safety analysis (see para. 8.7.2). The SW safety analysis may be performed as a stand-alone SW safety analysis or as part of other safety analyses depending on the application.

The scope and level of depth of the SW safety analysis, identified by means of the functional failure analysis and the preliminary system level safety analyses and its performance, shall be coordinated with system FTA, hazard analysis, FMECA, as appropriate.

This chapter is applicable in case an agile lifecycle is contractually agreed.
NOTE:
Guidance for agile SW development can be found in ECSS-E-HB-40-01.

The supplier shall take into account the specific characteristics of agile development for the QA role.
NOTE:
The QA role is often combined with the role of the Scrum Master. This ensures continuous SW QA with automated ongoing quality gates.
The supplier shall reflect the iterative nature of development in the plans.
The QA role shall ensure that agile values and principles are properly reflected in the SDP.

The metrication process has to be adapted to an iterative model, including using Agile metrics as defined in the SW PA plan.
Metrics shall be collected automatically, if possible.

The point in time for reporting shall be adopted to support the agile lifecycle.
NOTE:
Iteration review or retrospective meetings can be a good point in time to provide QA reporting.
The supplier shall verify the compliance with respect to quality requirements in the sprint reviews.
The criticality assessment shall be re-assessed at each major architectural and functional change.
All activities identified for critical components shall be performed within the iteration.
The supplier shall establish the SW problem management process and tool from the beginning of the SW development.
The supplier shall establish SW problem reviews at the planning meeting at the beginning of each iteration.
The supplier shall assign SPRs the same priority as for requirements.
The supplier shall integrate tools for automated static code checks in the development environment.
The supplier shall integrate tools for continuous dynamic code checks in the development environment.
The supplier shall integrate tools for automated reporting in the development environment.
The supplier shall create automated SW tests in every iteration for implemented requirements and SW problems. This covers unit, integration, and acceptance tests.
The testing level shall be compliant with 8.7.4.

> Criticality A, B (required for) <

Independent SW verification shall be performed by a third party.

> Criticality A, B (required for) <

ISVV shall be a combination of reviews, inspections, analyses, simulations, testing, and auditing.

> Criticality A, B (required for) <

The proper ISVV method shall be agreed between customer and supplier.

NOTE:
Guidance for ISVV can be found in the "ESA Guide for Independent Software Verification and Validation".
SW problem reviews at the planning meeting at the beginning of each iteration.

> Criticality A, B (required for) <

ISVV shall be performed for critical SW.

> Criticality A, B (required for) <

SW criticality shall be defined as per SW criticality category definition in ECSS-Q-ST-80, Annex D.1.

> Criticality A, B (required for) <

The supplier shall together with the customer determine the ISVV level for the SW, based on the identified criticality category and the provisions of "ESA Guide for Independent Software Verification and Validation", Annex E.

In case for SW engineering the application of ECSS-E-ST-40 is supplemented by ESSB-ST-E-008 requirements and/or ESSB-HB-E-007 on SW security, also the corresponding quality requirements listed in ESSB-ST-E-008 (sections 6 - 8) shall be applied and adhered to.

applicableDocuments.title: ESSB-ST-E-008
applicableDocuments.description: Secure Software Engineering Standard (04 July 2016)

requirements.text: Any software application provided with equipment intended for use on the ISS shall be compliant to ESA-ISS-COL-SEC-RS-0002 (Security Requirements for LAN Connected Payloads) and SSP 50989 (ISS IT Security Policy for onboard Systems).

applicableDocuments.title: ESA-ISS-COL-SEC-RS-0002
applicableDocuments.description: Security Requirements for LAN Connected Payloads

applicableDocuments.title: SSP 50989
applicableDocuments.description: ISS IT Security Policy for onboard Systems

requirements.text:
For any software application provided with equipment or a spacecraft or ground controll system security maintenance shall be foreseen on ground. This maintenance shall foresee at least the implementation of:
