The following definitions apply to terms used in this section.

Break-up
An event that generates fragments which are released into the space environment, either as a result of an explosion caused by the release of stored energy, such as chemical or thermal energy from propellants and pyrotechnics, or a rupture caused by an increase in internal pressure, or a collision with another object.
NOTE:
The following are excluded from this definition: a break-up caused by aerodynamics forces during the re-entry phase; the release of mission-related objects and mission-associated objects.

Casualty risk (Space Debris)
The probability of serious injury to or death of a single person due to the re-entry of a space system.

Controlled re-entry
A controlled re-entry is defined as the atmospheric re-entry of a space structure where the point of re-entry, and thus also the time and point of impact on ground are predetermined.

De-orbiting
Deliberate or forced re-entry of a space system into the earth's atmosphere by applying a retarding force, usually via a propulsion system.

Direct re-entry
The space system performs the manoeuvres to complete its re-entry phase within a single orbit revolution.

Disposal
The actions performed by a space system after the end of its mission to achieve permanent passivation and the required long-term clearance of the protected regions.

Disposal manoeuvre
The action of moving a spacecraft or launch vehicle orbital stage to a different orbit as part of its disposal.

Disposal orbit
Synonym: Graveyard orbit
Earth orbit remaining outside the protected outer space regions even under the influence of perturbations.

Disposal phase
Begins at the end of the operational phase of a space system, and ends when either the space system has performed a direct re-entry or completed activities to enable it to reach its disposal orbit and has been passivated.

End-of-life
End of the disposal phase.

End of mission
Completion of the scheduled mission of the space system, or mission stop due to a space system failure or to a voluntary decision.

Geostationary orbit
Earth orbit having zero inclination and zero eccentricity, whose orbital period is equal to the earth's sidereal period; the altitude of this unique circular orbit is close to 35 786 km.

Geostationary transfer orbit
An earth orbit which is or can be used to transfer space systems from lower orbits to the geosynchronous region; such orbits typically have perigees within LEO region and apogees near or above GEO.

Geosynchronous region (GEO region)
The space region close to and including the earth orbit with an orbital period equal to one sidereal day.

Graveyard orbit
see Disposal orbit

Launch phase
Begins when the launch vehicle is no longer in physical contact with equipment and ground installations that made its preparation and ignition possible (or when the launch vehicle is dropped from the carrier-aircraft, if any), and continues up to the end of the mission assigned to the launch vehicle. The launch phase ends when the launch vehicle has achieved an earth orbit or an interplanetary trajectory or, if not, when it is in physical contact with the ground again.

Launching state
UN liability convention definition
  1. a state which launches or procures the launching of a space object,
  2. a state from whose territory or facility a space object is launched.

Low Earth Orbit
Orbit with apogee altitude lower than 2 000 km.

Low Earth Orbit region (LEO region)
The spherical region that extends from the earth's surface up to an altitude of 2 000 km.

Mission extension
postponement of the previously defined end of mission

Mission-related object
Any component associated with the normal operations or functions of a space system that could be released into the space environment.
NOTE:
Mission-related objects include items such as adaptor structures, antenna retention devices, apogee boost motor heat shields, attachments for electrical wiring, belts, explosive bolts, fasteners, lower fairings, mechanisms required for the deployment of one or more spacecraft into orbit, observation instrument covers, propulsion systems, protection structures, solid rocket thruster nozzle blankets, springs, and tethers.

normal operations
execution of the planned tasks or functions for which a spacecraft or launch vehicle orbital stage was designed

Operational phase
Part of the orbital phase of a space system starting as the orbital phase and ceasing at the end of mission.

Operator
Any citizen of a nation in which he is performing space activities, or any organisation existing under the laws of a nation or under an international governmental agreement in order to perform space activities or any worker of such an organisation when he is duly authorised by that organisation.

Orbital lifetime
The length of time a space object remains in earth orbit.

Orbital phase
Starts when a space system is in orbit separated from the launch vehicle and ends when it re-enters the earth's atmosphere.

Passivation
The elimination of all stored energy on a space system to reduce the chance of break-up. Typical passivation measures include venting or burning excess propellant, discharging batteries and relieving pressure vessels.

Prevention measure
Any measure which decreases the potential for generating space debris, or reduces the associated risk.

Protected region
A region in space that is protected with regard to the generation of space debris to ensure the future safe and sustainable use of that region.

Protection measure
Any measure reducing the effective damage caused by space debris.

Re-entry
Process in which atmospheric drag cascades deceleration of a spacecraft or launch vehicle orbital stage (or any part thereof), leading to its destruction or return to earth.

Re-entry phase
Begins when the space object comes into the earth's atmosphere, and continues until either the intact object or its surviving parts come to rest on the earth's surface or when the object and all of its parts have disintegrated.

Re-orbiting
Intentional changing of a space system's orbit.

Space object
Any man-made space system and any of its components or fragments.

Space system
Spacecraft, launch vehicle, and launch vehicle orbital stage are defined as space systems within this document.
Spacecraft: an orbiting object designed to perform a specific function or mission (e.g. communications, navigation or earth observation). A spacecraft that can no longer fulfil its intended mission is considered non-functional. (Spacecraft in reserve or standby modes awaiting possible reactivation are considered functional.)
Launch vehicle: any vehicle constructed for ascent to outer space, and for placing one or more objects in outer space, and any suborbital rocket.
Launch vehicle orbital stage: any stage of a launch vehicle left in earth orbit.

Suborbital
Not completing one full orbital revolution.

The space debris mitigation requirements stated here are consistent with the "European Code of Conduct for Space Debris Mitigation", with the "Inter-Agency Space Debris Coordination Committee (IADC) Space Debris Mitigation Guidelines" and with the "UN-Space Debris Mitigation Guidelines". The objective of space debris mitigation shall be to limit the creation of new orbital debris and, therefore, to limit the risk to other current and future space missions and to limit the risk to human life due to generated orbital debris through prevention and analyses.

The supplier and the user/owner of the space product are responsible for the implementation of space debris mitigation measures as required by this chapter. The supplier shall deal with these requirements using the same engineering methodology as for all other contractually applicable agency requirements.

The major mitigation measures requested by DLR are the following items:
  • limiting the generation of debris associated with space operations,
  • limiting the consequences of impact by existing orbital debris or meteoroids,
  • depleting on-board energy sources after completion of mission,
  • protection of human health and life due to generated space debris,

• limiting orbital lifetime of space systems after mission completion in or passing through LEO protected region,
  • limiting the probability of impact with other objects in orbit,
  • limiting the debris hazard posed by tether systems,
  • limiting the human casualty risk from space system components surviving re-entry,
  • transferring a space system that has completed its mission in geostationary earth orbit (GEO) into higher orbit in order to preserve the GEO protected region,
  • reducing the time during which the orbital stage left in geostationary transfer orbit (GTO) can interfere with GEO, in order to preserve GEO protected region.

Any human activity which takes place in outer space should be performed while recognising the unique nature of the LEO protected region and the GEO protected region of outer space (see Figure 11-1), to ensure their future safe and sustainable use. These regions are considered as protected regions with regard to space debris. They are defined below.
  • The low earth orbit region (LEO protected region) is the spherical shell region that extends from the earth's surface up to an altitude (Z) of 2,000 km.
  • The geosynchronous region (GEO protected region) is a segment of spherical shell defined by:
    1. lower altitude = geostationary altitude minus 200 km,
    2. upper altitude = geostationary altitude plus 200 km,
    3. -15 degrees = latitude = +15 degrees,
    4. geostationary altitude (ZGEO) = 35,786 km (the altitude of the geostationary orbit).
Figure 11-1: Protected Regions
Each program or project shall conduct a formal assessment for the potential to generate orbital debris.

Space Debris Mitigation Assessment Reports (SDMARs)
  • The assessments shall be documented in form of (SDMARs).
  • Each SDMAR shall follow the format specified by para. 11.11 and include the content indicated at requirements.
  • The SDMARs are considered as design documents and are basically final when FRR carried out.

Space Debris Mitigation Declaration (SDMD)
  • The SDMD (DRD-11.01) shall provide a brief summary of all design measures and operational procedures applicable to limit the creation of orbital debris and, therefore, to limit the risk to other current and future space missions and to limit the risk to human life due to generated orbital debris.
  • The SDMD are considered as design document and are basically final when FRR carried out.

End of Mission Plan (EOMP)
NOTE:
  • The EOMP is a living document that grows with the program as it operates.
  • For missions disposing of spacecraft beyond GEO disposal orbits that are not (or will not be) in orbit about another solar system body, the EOMP is not required.
  • An EOMP shall be developed for limiting debris generation and limiting risk to the public and other active spacecraft during decommissioning, and disposal of all space objects.
  • The EOMP is considered as an operational document and will need to be updated periodically until it is implemented at EOM.
  • The EOMP shall address how the spacecraft will be decommissioned and disposed of. This includes: Passivation of all sources of stored energy.
  • The EOMP identifies milestones in the operational life of the mission which affect the EOM processing. After those milestones, the EOMP and the health of the CIs defined in the EOMP shall be evaluated and updated so that DLR management understands the constraints and options available at EOM for limiting orbital debris.

If a requirement cannot be met because of an overriding conflict with mission requirements, technical capabilities, or prohibitive cost impact, then a waiver (RFD/RFW) shall be requested with the SDMAR containing the appropriate rationale and justification.
The SDMAR shall demonstrate:
• that space system operations will be carried out in compliance with the measures specified in para. 11.13 (Passivation),
• that the space system complies with the design measures specified in para. 11.12 (Design Measures) and 11.13.1 (Design for Passivation),
• the verification and validation means to assess compliance with the applicable space debris mitigation requirements

• that the potential of the space system products for generating space debris during nominal operation and degraded modes (for example, malfunction) is reduced to the extent possible (part of SDMAR-1),
• that the potential of the space system products for generating space debris due to an accidental explosion or destruction is reduced to the extent possible (part of SDMAR-2),

drds.title: SDMAR-2  ''Accidental breakups and potential for explosions''

requirements.text: • that the potential of the space system products for generating space debris after an orbital collision with manmade or natural objects is reduced to the extent possible (part of SDMAR-3),
• the limitation of orbital lifetime in LEO/GEO protected regions after mission completion or manoeuvring to a disposal orbit (part of SDMAR-4),
• the evolution of the space system product during the disposal phase (part of SDMAR-4),
• the potential harm at the earth's surface or damage to the environment caused by the re-entry of the space system product (part of SDMAR-5).

chapters.name: SDMAR-1 Assessment of Spacecraft Debris Released during Normal Operations

requirements.text:
SDMAR-1 shall identify any object expected intentional to be released from the spacecraft any time after launch, including object dimensions, mass, and material:
  • rationale/necessity for release of each object,
  • time of release of each object, relative to launch time,
  • release velocity of each object with respect to spacecraft,
  • expected orbital parameters (apogee, perigee, and inclination) of each object after release,
  • calculated orbital lifetime of each object, including time spent in LEO protected region,
  • assessment of compliance with requirements of para. 11.12.1 (Mission Related Objects), para. 11.12.2 (Solid Propellants and Pyrotechnics) and para. 11.12.3 (Materials and Technologies).

chapters.name: SDMAR-2 Assessment of Spacecraft Accidental Breakups and Potential for Explosions

requirements.text:
SDMAR-2 shall identify all potential causes of spacecraft breakup during deployment and mission operations:
  • summary of failure modes and effects analyses of all credible failure modes which may lead to an accidental explosion,
  • list of components which shall be passivated at EOM,
  • list shall include method of passivation and amount which cannot be passivated,
  • rationale for all items which are required to be passivated, but cannot be due to their design,
  • assessment of compliance with requirements of para. 11.12.4 (Fragmentation), para. 11.12.5 (Malfunction) and para. 11.13 (Passivation).

drds.title: SDMAR-2  ''Accidental breakups and potential for explosions''

chapters.name: SDMAR-3 Assessment of Spacecraft Potential for On-Orbit Collisions

requirements.text:
SDMAR-3 shall provide:
  • calculation of spacecraft probability of collision with large space objects (larger than 10 cm in diameter) during the orbital lifetime of the spacecraft,
  • calculation of spacecraft probability of collision with small space objects (smaller than 10 cm in diameter), including orbital debris and meteoroids, of sufficient size to prevent postmission disposal,
  • assessment of compliance with requirements of para. 11.12.6 (On-Orbit Collision).

chapters.name: SDMAR-4 Assessment of Spacecraft Postmission Disposal Plans and Procedures

requirements.text:
SDMAR-4 shall provide description of spacecraft disposal option selected:
  • plan for any spacecraft manoeuvres required to accomplish postmission disposal,
  • calculation of area-to-mass ratio after postmission disposal, if the controlled re-entry option is not selected,
  • identification of all systems or components required to accomplish any postmission disposal operation, including passivation and manoeuvring,
  • assessment of compliance with requirements of para. 11.14 (Disposal Manoeuvres).

chapters.name: SDMAR-5 Assessment of Spacecraft Re-entry Hazards

requirements.text:
SDMAR-5 shall provide detailed description of spacecraft components by size, mass, material, shape, and original location on the space vehicle, if the atmospheric re-entry option is selected:
  • summary of objects expected to survive an controlled or uncontrolled re-entry,
  • calculation of probability of human casualty for the expected year of controlled or uncontrolled re-entry and the spacecraft orbital inclination,
  • if appropriate, preliminary plan for spacecraft controlled re-entry,
  • assessment of compliance with requirement of para. 11.15 (Re-Entry Safety Measures).

For missions leaving debris in orbits passing through LEO protected region, all mission related objects intentionally released during the deployment, operation, and disposal phases with diameter of 1 mm or larger shall be limited to a maximum orbital lifetime of 25 years from date of release.

Debris passing near GEO:
For missions leaving debris in orbits with the potential of traversing GEO protected regions, mission related objects intentionally released with diameters of 5 cm or greater shall be left in orbits which will ensure that within 25 years after release the apogee will no longer exceed ZGEO - 200 km.

The total number of launch vehicle orbital stages and space debris objects left in Earth orbit by a launch vehicle during normal operations, other than space debris from pyrotechnics and solid rocket motors, shall be limited to one for the launch of a single spacecraft and two for the launch of multiple spacecraft.
NOTE:
Separated upper stages and adapters are to be considered as debris objects, the launched spacecraft's are not considered as debris objects within this constraint.

Spacecraft and payloads shall be designed so as not to release space debris into Earth orbit during normal operations, other than space debris from pyrotechnics and solid rocket motors.
NOTE:
  1. For payloads, mission related components (for example, attachments of electrical wiring, devices retaining antennas, apogee boost motor heat shields, solid propellant thruster nozzle blanks, observation instruments protections, explosive bolts, springs, belts) shall be designed so that released parts are retained.
  2. Devices, which by design release objects other than payloads into orbit, shall be avoided (for example, 'yo-yo' device).

When the release of objects into orbit cannot be avoided, potential space debris shall be identified (number, size, orbit parameters, orbit evolution, orbital lifetime, etc.) and included in the SDMAR.
Any suborbital space object (for example, launch vehicle stage, adaptation structure for a launch of multiple payloads) shall not generate long-lived space debris.
The condition of a spacecraft shall be monitored periodically during its operation to detect any anomalies that could lead to an accidental break-up.
During the operation of a spacecraft, if an anomaly is detected which could lead to an accidental break-up then a contingency plan shall be developed and implemented to mitigate this risk.
Solid rocket motors shall be designed and operated so as not to release space debris larger than 1 mm in their largest dimension into Earth orbit.
Pyrotechnic devices shall be designed so as not to release space debris larger than 1 mm in their largest dimension into Earth orbit.

The materials, their application, and the design (thermal insulation, surface materials, external equipment, etc.) shall be selected to avoid the generation of space debris larger than 1 mm during the orbital phase of any space system.
NOTE:
Depending upon the materials or technologies used, the influence of the environment on objects in space can generate a large amount of additional debris. Where the generation of space debris due to the materials and basic technologies cannot be avoided, the number, size, and lifetime of debris generated shall be minimized. The materials and basic technologies selected for space systems shall be qualified accordingly (for example, qualification plans shall include tests - radiation, shock, etc. - demonstrating minimal space debris production).

Intentional destruction of a space system or any of its parts in orbit is prohibited. The accidental destruction/breakup probability of a space system due to an internal origin of any stored energy element (AOCS, propulsion, pressurised parts, energy storage elements - batteries, fuel cells, etc.) shall be lower than or equal to 0,001 (1:1000) until EOM of the space system.

The determination of accidental break-up probability shall quantitatively consider all known failure modes for the release of stored energy, capable of causing an accidental break-up, excluding those from external sources such as impacts with space debris and meteoroids.

Elements of a space system whose malfunction can lead to a hazardous event likely to generate space debris (AOCS, propulsion, pressurised parts, energy storage elements - batteries, fuel cells, etc.) shall be designed to reduce the corresponding risk. Such measures shall be included in the SDMAR.
A spacecraft that will operate in the GEO protected region shall have a recurrent manoeuvre capability.
A spacecraft that will operate in Earth orbit with a recurrent manoeuvre capability shall be designed and operated to actively manage collision risk until the end of life.

In developing the design and mission profile of a spacecraft or orbital stage, the program or project shall estimate and limit the probability of accidental collision with known objects during the systems orbital lifetime.
If reliable orbital data is available, avoidance manoeuvres for spacecraft and co-ordination of launch windows may be considered if the collision risk is not negligible.

Limiting debris generated by collisions with large objects
For each space system in or passing through LEO, the program or project shall demonstrate that, during the orbital lifetime, the probability of accidental collision with space objects larger than 10 cm in diameter is less than 0.001 (1:1000).

Limiting debris generated by collisions with small objects
Space system design shall consider and, consistent with cost effectiveness, limit the probability to less than 0.01 (1:100) that collisions with debris smaller than 10 cm diameter will cause loss of control to prevent postmission disposal. For this requirement, only subsystems which are vital to completing postmission disposal need to be addressed.

For a spacecraft with the capability to actively manage collision risk, if the risk of collision with another space object is assessed to be above the corresponding risk threshold set, collision avoidance manoeuvres shall be conducted to reduce the risk of collision below the threshold.
NOTE:
A space object in Earth orbit which is not linked with an operator and not detectable by a space surveillance and tracking facility is of concern for managing collision risk.

Intentional spacecraft destruction shall consider measures of design-for-demise.
NOTE 1:
Spacecraft design-for-demise (D4D) entails the intentional design of spacecraft HW such that the spacecraft will completely ablate (demise) upon uncontrolled re-entry into the Earth atmosphere.

Demisability is necessary to reduce the risk of human casualty and damage to property on Earth, hence guarantee safety from satellite atmospheric re-entries.
NOTE 2:
If intentional destruction prior to re-entry is planned in order to minimize the possibility of ground casualties, the destruction altitude should be not only low enough to prevent the break-up fragments from becoming orbital debris, but also high enough to eliminate undesirable effects on the ground.

The specific methods as described below shall be applied for designing spacecraft parts to demise, after they have been established to be critical.

The methods are utilized in an iterative process involving re-entry analysis SW tools and they can be used singly or in multiple combination:

  1. Material Type
    • Different materials
      Re-designing a part by replacing materials that can withstand high heat - and could therefore survive re-entry - with low-melting-temperature materials that will burn up on re-entry (e.g. aluminium instead of titanium, beryllium stainless steel, tungsten).
    • Multiple materials
      Replacing a non-demisable material with multiple demisable materials that will result in demisability and still maintain structural integrity.
  2. Mass Removal
    Reduction of the mass of individual components to decrease their likelihood of re-entry survival, but only if each component still meets structural requirements.
    • Change wall thickness
      Changing the wall thickness implies altering the mass of the object without necessarily changing the dimensions. This action has a similar effect of increasing the surface area-to-mass ratio (see d) and the object is more likely to demise.
    • Perforate material structure
      Perforating an object without compromising the structural integrity reduces the object's mass. Therefore, with a relatively decreased mass and increased surface area to mass ratio, the object is more likely to demise.
  3. Layering
    Convert single components - such as plates - into layers, which will more easily burn up on re-entry. It has to be noted, that the challenge is to build components that are designed for demise yet can absorb launch stresses.
  4. Shape Considerations
    Demisability is a function of surface area-to-mass ratio. Changing the shape of an object to attain a relatively higher surface area to mass ratio enhances its demisability.
  5. Containment
    Design a single container that can contain multiple surviving components. This way, although a number of components may survive re-entry, the overall risk is reduced to the single container.
  6. Part structural location
    A part located in close proximity to the spacecraft configuration structural boundary is exposed to the ablation environment relatively earlier than an inwardly located part. Consequently, it possesses an elevated demise likelihood compared to a part structurally located towards the middle or inner sections of the spacecraft which is exposed to the ablative environment after the parts around it demise or structural break-up occurs.

NOTE:
References on D4D are
  • N. Johnson: Chapter 9.6. "Design for Re-Entry Demise" in "Safety Design for Space Operation" F. A. Allahdadi (ed.)
  • P.M.B. Waswa, J.A. Hoffman: Int. J. Design Engineering, Vol. 5, No. 1, 201, p 21-39
  • S. Heinrich, F. Leglise et al. "Trade-off Atmospheric Re-Entry" in "Space Safety is No Accident" T. Sgobba, I. Rongier (eds.)

This list is not exhaustive.
For constellations of more than 3 satellites in LEO-orbits the following shall be considered in the design and/or discussed in detail in design trade-offs (and presented in the design reviews):
• Any satellite in LEO flying above the ISS (around 400km) or in MEO shall be capable of signalizing its position to within 500 meters of accuracy.
• Any satellite in LEO/MEO shall carry on-board propulsion to perform collision-avoidance manoeuvres throughout the full estimated operational design life, including a factor of margin of 1.5.
• Once retired, any satellite in the LEO/MEO-Constellation shall be deorbited within 5 years or one times its operational design life, whichever is less.
• Any new satellite design in the LEO/MEO-Constellation shall be designed to completely disintegrate on atmospheric re-entry (see also section on "Prevention: Design for Demise" 11.12.7)

NOTE 1:
It is recommended that any satellite in the LEO/MEO-Constellation shall carry sensors to enable them to perform space situation awareness and to detect when they are hit by small pieces of debris.

NOTE 2:
It is recommended that any satellite of a LEO/MEO constellation shall carry a small adapter device that will allow those spacecraft, in case of it dying on its way to deorbiting, to be grabbed by a small chase vehicle and pulled out of orbit.

The following design measures are to be considered together with the:
  • passivation requirements of para. 11.13,
• and the disposal requirements of para. 11.14.

Design of the space system shall include the ability to deplete all on-board sources of stored energy and disconnect all energy generation sources when they are no longer required for mission operations or postmission disposal, or control to a level which cannot cause an explosion or deflagration large enough to release orbital debris or break up the space system.

Documentation of the EOM sources or potential sources of stored energy that require passivation, and a plan for passivating these sources at EOM shall be included in the SDMAR-2.
Passivation procedures to be implemented might include:

drds.title: SDMAR-2  ''Accidental breakups and potential for explosions''

requirements.text:
• burning residual propellants to depletion,
  • venting propellant lines and tanks,
  • venting pressurized systems,
  • de-energizing control moment gyroscopes,

• discharging batteries, other energy storage systems, and preventing recharging,
  • depressurizing/discharging pressurized gas filled batteries,
  • deactivating explosives associated with range safety systems.

NOTE:
  • Residual propellants and other fluids, such as pressurants, should be depleted as thoroughly as possible, by either depletion burns or venting, to prevent accidental breakups by over pressurization or chemical reaction.
  • Sealed heat pipes and passive nutation dampers need not be depressurized at EOM.

Batteries shall be discharged to the allowed reduction level of stored energy in the batteries and shall be disconnected from their charging circuits.
Electrical loads left connected to a battery can fail, leading to battery recharging if the charging circuit is not disconnected.
NOTE:
Paragraph 5.2.1(2) of the IADC Space Debris Mitigation Guidelines provides the additional direction for batteries: "At the end of operations battery charging lines should be de-activated."

The removal of electrical energy inputs from rotational energy devices, such as a gyro, is usually sufficient to ensure the timely passivation of these units.

All space systems shall be passivated as a part of EOM disposal/decommissioning to a level where the remaining internal stored energy is insufficient to cause breakup. EOM passivation includes all of the actions needed to prevent a breakup, either by explosion or disassembly from internally stored energy, of the space system from the point in time where EOM actions are begun and re-entry of the space system occurs. The timing, order, procedures, and verification methods for performing all depletions shall have been developed prior to launch.

The passivation process shall be completed within 1 year (2 months shall be the goal) after the end of the disposal phase, and its probability of success shall be higher than 0.9.

A spacecraft or launch vehicle orbital stage shall limit its continuous or periodic presence in the LEO protected region so that its orbit lifetime does not exceed 25 years, starting from:
  1. the orbit injection epoch if the spacecraft or launch vehicle orbital stage has no capability to perform collision avoidance manoeuvres, or
  2. the end of life epoch if the spacecraft or launch vehicle orbital stage has the capability to perform collision avoidance manoeuvres.
The removal of a spacecraft or launch vehicle orbital stage from the LEO protected region shall be accomplished by one or more of the following means (in order of preference):

1. Direct retrieval:
Retrieve the space system and remove it from orbit within 10 years after EOM.
NOTE:
  • Retrieval means the return to the earth, without damage to the space system or other space HW, by another space system capable of atmospheric entry.
  • 10 years is allowed for planned retrieval after completion of the mission, which is shorter than the 25 years for orbital decay and atmospheric re-entry. Retrieval may leave the space system in a higher altitude orbit where, in general, there is a higher probability per unit time that the system will be involved in a collision fragmentation, whereas transfer to an orbit with reduced lifetime lowers the perigee of the final orbit and reduces the probability per unit time that the system will be a source of collision fragments. To balance the risk of the system creating collision debris, the allowed period of time is therefore less for a system waiting to be retrieved.

2. Controlled re-entry:
Manoeuvring the space system into a controlled de-orbit trajectory as soon as practicable after EOM. Re-entry manoeuvring may be supported by another space system if compliant with para. 11.15.1 (Controlled re-entry).

3. Uncontrolled re-entry:
Leave the space system in their operational orbit if natural forces will lead to atmospheric re-entry within 25 years after EOM, or manoeuvre the space system to an orbit in which natural forces will lead to atmospheric re-entry within 25 years after EOM.

4. Storage orbit:
Manoeuvring the space system to a storage orbit between LEO and GEO:
Manoeuvre to an orbit with perigee altitude above 2,500 km and apogee altitude below 35,288 km (500 km below GEO altitude).

chapters.name: Disposal of Space Systems in or passing through GEO Protected Region:

requirements.text:
A space system operating in or passing through GEO protected region at his EOM shall be disposed of in a controlled manner by one of the following methods in decreasing order of preference:
  • manoeuvring to a storage orbit above GEO altitude in accordance to 11.14.5,
  • manoeuvring to a an orbit that has a perigee sufficiently above the geostationary altitude that ensures that long-term perturbation forces do not cause the space system to enter the GEO protected region within 100 years,
  • manoeuvring to a storage orbit between LEO and GEO:
    manoeuvre to an orbit with perigee altitude above 2,500 km and apogee altitude below 35,288 km (500 km below GEO altitude).

The destination orbits of disposals shall avoid crossing the 12h circular MEO altitude, (the near circular, semi-synchronous orbits of approximately 12h periods, with inclinations of 55° to 65° (hereafter denoted as "12h circular MEO"), which are used, or will be used by the navigation satellite constellations like GPS, GLONASS, and Galileo.

NOTE:
ISO-26872 "Disposal of satellites operating at geosynchronous altitude" shall be used for planning and executing manoeuvres and operations to remove an operating satellite from geosynchronous orbit at the end of its mission and place it in an orbit for final disposal where it will not pose a future hazard to satellites operating in the geosynchronous ring.

chapters.name: Disposal of Space Systems in MEO

requirements.text:
For the post-mission disposal of spacecraft and upper stages which service MEO, a lifetime reduction according to the 25 year rule, a de-orbit, or a re-orbit is requested. In the latter two cases the disposal orbits may not interfere with other protected regions (LEO or GEO), nor with the MEO region itself.

It is recommended to re-orbit 12h circular MEOs so that either:

  • Hpe>2,500 km and Hap<19,900 km, or
  • Hpe>20,500 km and Hap<35,288 km.

NOTE:
Special disposal manoeuvres are normally not required in MEO, although efforts should be made to avoid potential interference with known operational satellite constellations, like GPS, GLONASS or Galileo.

chapters.name: Disposal of Space Systems in Lagrange Points

requirements.text: Satellites going to Lagrange points should also perform an end-of-life manoeuvre to clear the region for other spacecraft, as well as to ensure that the satellite will not come back to Earth in an uncontrolled way, i.e. by injecting them into orbits around the Sun after their missions were completed, in order to avoid creating a collision threat or re-entry hazard.

Storage orbits (see Figure 11-2) in the disposal regions may be used to dispose of space systems at end of mission. At the end of its operational phase a space system in the GEO stationary orbit shall be re-orbited into a disposal orbit with initial eccentricity less than 0.003 and a minimum perigee altitude DH above the GEO stationary altitude according to the following formula:

DH = 235 + 1,000 x Cr x A/m

where:

  • DH in km,
  • Cr = solar radiation pressure coefficient of the space system at the beginning of its life (beginning of orbital phase),
    - 0 for completely transparent material,
    - 1 for completely absorbing material,
    - 2 for totally reflecting material.
  • A/m = ratio of cross-section area (in m2) to dry mass (in kg) of the space system.

Recommendation:
An additional margin in DH shall be considered to take into account uncertainties in fuel estimate, effective delta-V and orbit determination.
Figure 11-2: Disposal regions and storage orbits for post-mission disposals

To dispose of a space system actively from a protected region at EOM, there usually has to be enough propellant for the necessary manoeuvres. Because of fuel gauging uncertainties near the EOM, a manoeuvre strategy shall be implemented that reduces the risk of leaving the structure near an operational orbit. In order to perform space system disposal as planned, the estimation of available propellant mass shall be calculated.

When disposal manoeuvres of a space system are performed using allocated propellants, the following measures shall apply:
  • The remaining propellant shall be estimated.
  • This quantity shall be assessed according to a method defined during the space system design, using design data (characteristics of propellants, structure and architecture of tanks, etc.) and operational data (careful monitoring of the condition of the space system in orbit, etc.).

ISO-23339 "Estimating the mass of remaining usable propellant" shall be applied for estimating the mass of remaining usable propellant to
  1. ensure the successful disposal of the spacecraft from its operational protected region, and
  2. drain the propellant system in order to remove a potential source of energy for creating additional secondary debris caused by any primary debris impact.

applicableDocuments.title: ISO 23339:2010-12
applicableDocuments.description: Space systems - Unmanned spacecraft - Estimating the mass of remaining usable propellant

requirements.text: For postmission disposal operations leading to a natural decay within 25 years or to a long-term storage orbit, the probability of success shall be no less than 0.9.

In case of mission extension, the probability of successful disposal of a spacecraft shall be reassessed considering the status of the spacecraft at the beginning of the mission extension and demonstrated to be at least 0.9 at the time of the end of the extended mission.

If necessary, postmission disposal manoeuvres shall be performed at EOM to limit the permanent or periodic presence of the space system in the protected regions (see para. 11.7). Outside the LEO and GEO protected regions, orbit disposal shall consider operational orbit regions of known operational satellite constellations, e.g. the Galileo or GPS orbit, to avoid long-term interference of such orbits. The operational phase of the space system shall be terminated at such a time point that the quantity of propellants necessary to perform disposal manoeuvres is compliant with the requirements of para. 11.14.6 (propellant for disposal). The orbital lifetime of LEO-crossing mission-related objects shall be estimated using the processes specified in ISO-27852 "Estimation of orbit lifetime". A general plan for performing all postmission disposal manoeuvres shall be included in the EOMP.

Specific criteria for initiating the disposal of a spacecraft or launch vehicle orbital stage shall be developed, included in the EOMP, evaluated throughout the mission and, if met, consequent actions executed.
The condition of a spacecraft shall be monitored periodically during its operation to detect any anomalies that could affect its successful disposal.
During the operation of a spacecraft, if an anomaly is detected which could affect its successful disposal then a contingency plan shall be developed and implemented to mitigate this risk.

If the re-entry of a space system causes a risk of human casualty from surviving debris that exceeds 0.0001 (1:10000) per re-entry event, or the space system contains hazardous objects that could result in harmful contamination of the earth environment (for example, ionising radiation, hazardous biological or chemical products), a controlled re-entry or direct retrieval shall be performed. The time of re-entry shall be controlled and the impact footprint on ground shall be predetermined. The performance of a controlled re-entry shall ensure that the impact foot-print will be over uninhabited ocean area, with sufficient clearance of landmasses and traffic routes. The selected trajectory shall ensure that no surviving debris impact with a kinetic energy greater than 15 joules is closer than 370 km (200 nautical miles) from landmasses.
NOTE:
A kinetic energy threshold criterion of 15 joules is widely accepted as the level for casualty to an unprotected person.

For controlled re-entry, the product of the probability of failure of the re-entry burn and the risk of human casualty assuming uncontrolled re-entry shall not exceed 0.0001 (1:10000) per re-entry event.

If the re-entry of a space system causes a risk of human casualty from surviving debris that exceeds 0.0001 (1:10000) per re-entry event, or the space system contains hazardous objects that could result in harmful contamination of the earth environment (for example, ionising radiation, hazardous biological or chemical products), uncontrolled re-entry is not allowed.

Due to the complexity of satellite re-entry physics and material responses, projects shall employ standard re-entry analysis SW tools for:
  • the re-entry survivability assessment of decaying space systems,
  • the determination of the re-entry risk posed to the earth's population,
  • the calculation of the final debris casualty area caused by the surviving objects/fragments.

For controlled re-entry, procedures defined by international civil aviation and maritime organizations shall be followed. The predicted final trajectory, target impact zone, potential hazards after impact, and all useful information shall be provided to any nation or organization that could potentially be affected by the ground impact of the fragments of space system or launch vehicle orbital stages after re-entry on aircraft, ships or land. For both uncontrolled re-entry, and controlled re-entry, if the re-entering vehicle contains radioactive or other hazardous material, nations that might be affected by the re-entry shall be notified of the hazard and shall be provided information on the nature of the hazard and how it should be mitigated.

The re-entry phase of a space system, if any, shall not result in harmful contamination of the Earth environment (for example, ionising radiation, hazardous biological or chemical products):
  • A space project shall limit the risk from re-entering space debris to a safe level.
  • The end of life operations shall take into account the applicable on ground safety rules, which depend on the launching state.
  • The casualty risk on ground shall not exceed 0.0001 (1:10000) per re-entry.

During space project reviews, the contents and the status of the SDMAR and SDMD shall be presented.
NOTE:
  • The purpose of preparing the report early in the design and development process shall be to ensure that orbital debris issues are identified early when resolutions are least costly to implement.
  • Any orbital debris mitigation compliance issues should be addressed and resolved no later than the CDR or equivalent program/project development milestone.

The delivery of "PDR Draft SDMAR and SDMD" shall be prior to the program or project PDR for the spacecraft or equivalent program/project development milestone. The delivery of the "CDR SDMAR and SDMD" shall be prior to the program or project CDR for the spacecraft or equivalent program/project development milestone.
The purpose of the CDR SDMAR and SDMD shall be to update and clarify the issues and changes to the PDR Draft for any NCs which remain prior to beginning the launch approval. The final issues of the SDMARs, SDMD and EOMP shall be presented during the FAR of the space project and shall be part of the EIDP.

drds.title: SDMAR-2  ''Accidental breakups and potential for explosions''

requirements.text: For any rendezvous and proximity operation and/or on-orbit servicing the involved parties shall comply with all appropriate licensing and regulations, including especially those on export control, of all cognizant national jurisdictions of the involved parties.

Any operations shall be conducted in full compliance with the Treaty on Principles Governing the Activities of States in the Exploration and Use of Outer Space, including the Moon and Other Celestial Bodies (the "Outer Space Treaty").

Any operations shall be conducted in full compliance with relevant internationally-recognized guidelines and standards for the long-term sustainability of space activities, including those developed by the Inter-Agency Space Debris Coordination Committee (IADC), United Nations Committee on the Peaceful Uses of Outer Space (UN COPUOS), International Organization for Standardization (ISO), and the Consultative Committee for Space Data Systems (CCSDS).

reference.text: CONFERS Recommended Design and Operation Practices

requirements.text:
The following documents shall be used by suppliers and sub-suppliers as applicable.
For undated references the latest edition of the publication referred to applies:
• ESA Technical Note "Safe Close Proximity Operations" ESATECSYE-TN-010228
• SSP 50235 Interface Definition Document (IDD) for International Space Station (ISS) Visiting Vehicles (VVs).

• International Rendezvous System Interoperability Standards (IRSIS) Draft C, Feb 2018,
  • CONFERS Recommended Design and Operation Practices, Feb 2019,
  • CONFERS Satellite Servicing Safety Framework - Technical and Operational Guidance Document, Draft, April 2018.

The Visiting Vehicle (VV) provider is responsible for the performance of verification activities as specified in applicable specifications and IRD/ICDs and shall produce verification evidence for compliance with all VV applicable requirements.

The VV verification shall consist of, but not be limited to:
  1. Data for the reliability analysis collected and recorded during qualification.
  2. Engineering (development) evaluation and tests required for analysing design approaches to ensure that requirements encompassing material selection, tolerances, and operational characteristics are satisfied. If development test data is intended to be used to qualify hardware, its intent shall be previously declared.
  3. A qualification program encompass the entire range of activity to verify that the design conforms to requirements when subjected to environmental life cycle conditions including those required for environmental workmanship screening during the acceptance phase. Flight fidelity dedicated qualification test articles shall be used for the qualification program.
    Environmental models shall be used to represent environments that cannot be achieved under the conditions of ground testing. Simulators, used for verifying requirements, shall be validated such that the item undergoing qualification cannot distinguish between the simulator and actual operation hardware/software.
  4. Integration testing and checkout shall be conducted during VV build-up. Activities such as continuity checking and interface mating shall be performed. Activities such as major component operation in the installed environment, support equipment compatibility, and documentation verification shall be proven during qualification.
  5. Validation of VV ground facilities shall be performed in support of analyses, ground testing and other verification activities. Validation of facilities can be performed by comparison to realworld results or to another validated facility.

Formal verification of performance characteristics for the full range of performance requirements shall be accomplished during qualification.

The basic objectives of the ground tests shall include, but not be limited to:
  • strength verification (static, dynamic, acoustic, impact, and vibration tests),
  • validation of hardware layout modelling, installation, and assembly,
  • joint operation of the VV systems and assemblies, including the required interaction with partner systems and facilities,
  • thermal conditions of systems and structures, including those in a flight-like environment,
  • testing VV communications systems (including RF blockage and multipath characterization),
  • mating/demating of involved parties;
  • firing tests (engine burns) and gas dynamics tasks,
  • testing and verification of the operability of the emergency rescue system (for manned vehicles),
  • integrated electrical tests, including avionics tests,
  • integrated software tests,
  • integrated guidance, navigation, and control tests,
  • test and calibration of all sensors involved in the proximity operation.

The VV testing program phase shall conclude with an integrated phase where testing of the entire VV system, including the vehicle itself, ground and support elements, will be performed under conditions as close to the flight conditions as possible.

VV integrated tests shall be performed using full scale items or their simulators, including flight versions of components and systems an flight-qualified software.

Test objectives shall include, but not be limited to:

  • compatibility of on-board systems of involved parties,
  • software in terms of control of systems, assemblies, and mechanisms located on the VV and the partner system, but connected via the main electrical and data interfaces,
  • joint functionality of systems, assemblies, sensors and mechanisms of the orbital complex in nominal and off-nominal situations,
  • compatibility of the systems of the involved parties that work together during rendezvous, proximity operations, and separation,
  • compatibility of the electromagnetic environment and assessment of electromagnetic interferences of the involved parties, also wrt. to reliable ground communication.
The VV provider shall perform an analysis to confirm the performance of VV approach, mating, demating, and separation operations with the partner system.
The VV provider shall perform analyses to confirm the compliance to those design principles and requirements, which will not be verified or demonstrated by test.
The VV provider shall perform a FMEA for mission critical subsystems.
The VV provider shall evaluate and mitigate the risk of ESD between the VV and the partner system.
The VV provider shall perform a probabilistic risk assessment and a risk analysis for all mission phases.

The VV provider shall identify potential hazards to the mission, both from internal and external sources. The consequences resulting from the hazard scenarios shall be identified and considered for during the risk analysis.
The VV provider shall perform manoeuvre dispersion analysis.
The VV provider shall define keep out zones, not-to-exceed speed (relative velocity) limits, free flight trajectory paths relative to keep out zones to ensure mission safety.
The VV provider shall define guidelines, constraints, and limitations associated with the overall mission and specific phases of the mission to ensure mission safety.
The VV provider shall perform analyses to confirm VV performance during approach and mating abort failures.
The VV provider shall perform analyses for the autonomous fault detection and response tree taking into account the FMEA of the VV system.
Verification shall be conducted in compliance with SSP 50235.

The VV flight test program shall demonstrate and verify readiness of the VV and its flightsupport facilities to perform the functions needed to perform VV mission to the partner system.

The VV demonstration flight program shall be documented in the flight operations plan developed jointly by a VV developer and the partner providing the mating location.

All safety-critical functions shall be flight demonstrated in a region that is not hazardous to the partner system.

There are two approaches to the demonstration flight scenario:

  • to mate a VV with an independent spacecraft with identical mechanisms as the partner system,
  • to perform demonstration during an actual approach to the partner system, provided each step of the demonstration flight will lead to increasing capabilities and confidence that safety is assured for the partner system.

The technique used by the VV shall be defined and approved by the involved parties depending on a spectrum of different considerations, such as:

  • experience of VV personnel,
  • adequate ground-based verification of the VV functionality,
  • availability and fidelity of an independent spacecraft,
  • and financial impacts to the programme.

The functions that shall be demonstrated, as a minimum, during demonstration flight include:
  • the VV approach to the partner system or the partner-simulating system, including maintaining the required approach corridor and station keeping,
  • testing of all sensors involved in the proximity operation.
  • rendezvous and mating within predetermined kinematic parameters,
  • mechanical capture and establishment of required functional interfaces between the VV and the partner system or the partner-simulating system,
  • unmating and back off from the partner system or the partnersimulating system,
  • verification of VV Guidance Navigation and Control systems functionality by ground personnel,
  • verification of autonomous fault detection and response of the VV system to put the VV and the partner system in a "safe" configuration, when a fault is detected to prevent damage,
  • testing of the emergency termination of the VV approach to demonstrate functional capabilities in an off-nominal situation including collision avoidance and abort capability,
  • check of the VV autonomous and remote control mode,
  • command/data telemetry transfer,
  • establishment of the communications link,
  • collision avoidance manoeuvre,
  • efficiency and reliability of the VV control centre ground support personnel and equipment.

All VV requirements shall be verified on the ground prior to VV launch.

However, there are some functions and conditions that are extremely difficult to simulate on the ground. To increase the level of confidence of a VV to perform its mission safely and successfully, a demonstration flight shall be included in the VV program.

Rendezvous, proximity operation and on-orbit servicing operators are critical to flight safety and enabling mission success. These spacecraft operators should be able to detect anomalous navigation and control conditions, system health, and mission performance, as well as manually intervene, if necessary, to limit material safety risks and hazards.
This shall be ensured by adequate training and certification plans.

reference.text: CONFERS Recommended Design and Operation Practices

requirements.text:
The UN Outer Space Treaty of 1967 sets up the general principles applicable to the exploration and use of outer space. Article IX of the Outer Space Treaty constitutes the primary statement of international law:
"States parties shall pursue studies of outer space, including the Moon and other celestial bodies, and conduct exploration of them so as to avoid their harmful contamination and also adverse changes in the environment of the Earth resulting from the introduction of extra-terrestrial matter and, when necessary, adopt appropriate measures for this purpose."

Harmful contamination in that sense is defined as biological contamination, including organic-constituents, to protect the environment in order to allow future exobiology research.

NOTE:
It is recommended that:
In addition any other contamination causing sustainable environmental disturbances shall be also understood as harmful contamination. It is acknowledged that
  • life, including extraterrestrial life, has special ethical status and deserves appropriate respect because it has both intrinsic and instrumental values, and
  • non-living things, including extraterrestrial things, likewise have value and deserve respect appropriate to their instrumental, aesthetic, or other value to human or extraterrestrial life.

The COSPAR has established some planetary protection guidelines, based on the Outer Space Treaty. These guidelines impose requirements on spaceflight missions according to target body/mission type combinations undertaken for scientific, exploration or other purposes by any entity to control contamination.

The conduct of scientific investigations of possible extra-terrestrial life forms, precursors, and remnants must not be jeopardized.
In addition, the earth must be protected from the potential hazard posed by extra-terrestrial matter carried by a spacecraft returning from an interplanetary mission.
NOTE:
It is recommended to consider that:
Inherent in the conduct of scientific, exploration, and other activities - whether by robotic or human missions - is the need to consider and appropriately protect the Moon and other celestial bodies as well as potential extraterrestrial life.

Therefore, for certain space mission/target planet combinations, controls on contamination and environmental disturbance shall be imposed in accordance with issuances implementing this policy.
The objectives of DLR's planetary protection policy, which is consistent with the policy and guidelines of the COSPAR, shall be met at all times.

Deviations from the specific implementation approaches described herewith may be requested, as detailed in section 12.6 of this document.
NOTE:
Such requests will be reviewed and approved by the PPO (Planetary Protection Officer of the lead agency of the mission).

The following documents shall be used by the suppliers and subsuppliers as applicable to the extend specified herein. For undated references the latest edition of the publication referred to applies:
  • COSPAR's Planetary Protection Policy
  • NASA NPR 8020.12 Planetary Protection Provision for Robotic Extraterrestrial Missions
  • CNES RNC-CNES-R-14 Sécurité des Systems Planetary Protection Requirements
  • ISO 14644-14: Cleanrooms and associated controlled environments - Part 1: Classification of air cleanliness by particle concentration.ISO
  • ISO 14698: Cleanrooms and associated controlled environments - Biocontamination control.ISO

• NASA NID 8020.109: Planetary Prootection Provision for Robotic Extratesstrial Missions
  • Federal Standard 209E: Airborne Particulate Cleanliness Classes in Clean Rooms and Clean Zones
  • National Academy of Science: Exploration of Antarcitc Subglacial Aquaric Environments: Environmental and Scientific Stewardship; Chapter 4 "Drilling and Sampling Technologies and Potential for Contamination", THE NATIONAL ACADEMIES PRESS, 2007 (NAP2007)
  • National Academy of Science: Planetary Protection Classification of Sample-return Missions from the Matian Moons, THE NATIONAL ACADEMIES PRESS, 2007 (NAP2019)
  • ATCM34_ip033_e: Science Committee on Antarctic Research (SCAR) code of conduct for the exploration and research of subglacial aquaric environments
  • Cockell, C.S., Interstellar planetary Protection, Advances in Space research 42 (2008), 1161 (Cockell 2008)
  • Rummel J.D. et al. Mai 2012 Report: COSPAR Workshop on Ethical Considerations for Planetary Protection in Space Exploration
  • ECSS-U-ST-20C DIR1 (16 January 2018): Space Sustainability - Planetary Protection
For Non-NASA flight projects (e.g. ESA projects) the supplier shall certify compliance to the PP categorization and compliance for the spacecraft.
The documentation of compliance with the PP requirements shall be provided according to the agreement.

For NASA missions, requests for PP categorization of missions and associated mission requirements shall be submitted to the NASA-PPO by the mission project manager or principal Investigator before the end of phase A and, preferably, early during mission design.
NASA flight projects shall comply with planetary protection requirements appropriate to the mission PP category provided to them by the NASA-PPO.
Specific planetary protection requirements for each planned mission are determined by the NASA-PPO.

For ESA missions, requests for PP categorization of missions and associated mission requirements shall be submitted to the ESA-PPO by the mission project manager or principal investigator before the end of Phase A and, preferably, early during mission design.
ESA flight projects shall comply with planetary protection requirements appropriate to the mission PP category provided to them by the ESA-PPO.
Specific planetary protection requirements for each planned mission are determined by the ESA-PPO.

Each planetary mission shall be assigned one or more PP categories based on the planetary protection priorities of each extra-terrestrial solar system body and the mission plan.
Planetary protection priorities and corresponding mission PP categories are given in Table 12-1.
Each PP category has different planetary protection requirements, as described of this document.

Missions are categorised as such:
  • Category I includes any mission to a target body which is not of direct interest for understanding the process of chemical evolution or the origin of life. No protection of such bodies is warranted and no planetary protection requirements are imposed by this policy.
  • Category II missions comprise all types of missions to those target bodies where there is significant interest relative to the process of chemical evolution and the origin of life, but where there is only a remote (1) chance that contamination carried by a spacecraft could compromise future investigations. The requirements are for simple documentation only. Preparation of a short planetary protection plan is required for these flight projects primarily to outline intended or potential impact targets, brief pre- and post-launch analyses detailing impact strategies, and a post encounter and End-of-Mission Report which will provide the location of impact if such an event occurs.
  • Category III missions comprise certain types of missions (mostly flyby and orbiter) to a target body of chemical evolution and/or origin of life interest and for which scientific opinion provides a significant (2) chance of contamination which could compromise future investigations. Requirements will consist of documentation (more involved than category II) and some implementing procedures, including trajectory biasing, the use of cleanrooms during spacecraft assembly and testing, and possibly bioburden reduction. Although no impact is intended for category III missions, an inventory of bulk constituent organics is required if the probability of impact is significant.
  • Category IV missions comprise certain types of missions (mostly probe and lander) to a target body of chemical evolution and/or origin of life interest and for which scientific opinion provides a significant (2) chance of contamination which could compromise future investigations. Requirements imposed include rather detailed documentation (more involved than category III), including a bioassay to enumerate the bioburden, a probability of contamination analysis, an inventory of the bulk constituent organics and an increased number of implementing procedures. The implementing procedures required may include trajectory biasing, cleanrooms, bioburden reduction, possible partial sterilization of the direct contact HW and a bioshield for that HW. Generally, the requirements and compliance are similar to Viking, with the exception of complete lander/probe sterilization.
  • Category V missions comprise all earth-return missions. The concern for these missions is the protection of the terrestrial system, the earth and the moon. (The moon must be protected from back contamination to retain freedom from planetary protection requirements on earth-moon travel.) For solar system bodies deemed by scientific opinion to have no indigenous life forms, a subcategory "unrestricted earth return" is defined. Missions in this subcategory have planetary protection requirements on the outbound phase only, corresponding to the category of that phase (typically category I or II). For all other category V missions, in a subcategory defined as "restricted earth return", the highest degree of concern is expressed by the absolute prohibition of destructive impact upon return, the need for containment throughout the return phase of all returned HW which directly contacted the target body or unsterilized material from the body, and the need for containment of any unsterilized sample collected and returned to earth. Postmission, there is a need to conduct timely analyses of any unsterilized sample collected and returned to earth, under strict containment, and using the most sensitive techniques. If any sign of the existence of a non-terrestrial replicating entity is found, the returned sample must remain contained unless treated by an effective sterilizing procedure. Category V concerns are reflected in requirements that encompass those of category IV plus a continuing monitoring of project activities, studies and research (i.e., in sterilization procedures and containment techniques).
NOTE:
  • "Remote" here implies the absence of environments where terrestrial organisms could survive and replicate, or a very low likelihood of transfer to environments where terrestrial organisms could survive and replicate.
  • "Significant" here implies the presence of environments where terrestrial organisms could survive and replicate, and some likelihood of transfer to those places by a plausible mechanism.

Table 12-1: Mission Planetary Protection Categories
Planetary Target Priority Mission Type Mission PP Category
Not of direct interest for understanding the process of chemical evolution or where exploration will not be jeopardized by terrestrial contamination. No protection of such planets is warranted, and no requirements are imposed. Any I
Of significant interest relative to the process of chemical evolution but only a remote chance that contamination by spacecraft could compromise future investigations. Any II
Of significant interest relative to the process of chemical evolution and/or the origin of life and for which scientific opinion provides a significant chance that contamination by spacecraft could compromise future investigations. Flyby, Orbiter III
Of significant interest relative to the process of chemical evolution and/or the origin of life and for which scientific opinion provides a significant chance that contamination by spacecraft could compromise future investigations. Lander, Probe IV
Any Solar System Mission All Earth Return V
Unrestricted Earth Return
Restricted Earth Return

NOTE:

  • For missions that target or encounter multiple planets, more than one PP category may be specified for planets targeted or encountered.
  • For missions utilizing gravity assist by means of a flyby of another planet, requirements will typically be those for the target requiring the higher degree of protection.

Category-specific listing of target body/ mission types

Category I: Flyby, Orbiter, Lander: Undifferentiated, metamorphosed asteroids; Io; others to-be-defined (TBD)

Category II: Flyby, Orbiter, Lander: Venus; Moon (with organic inventory); Comets; Carbonaceous Chondrite Asteroids; Jupiter; Saturn; Uranus; Neptune; Ganymede*; Callisto; Titan*; Triton*; Pluto/Charon*; Ceres; KuiperBelt Objects > 1/2 the size of Pluto*; KuiperBelt Objects < 1/2 the size of Pluto; others TBD

Category III: Flyby, Orbiters: Mars; Europa; Enceladus; others TBD

Category IV: Lander Missions: Mars; Europa; Enceladus; others TBD

Category V: Any Earth-return mission

"Restricted Earth return": Mars; Europa; others TBD

"Unrestricted Earth return": Venus, Moon; others TBD

*The mission-specific assignment of these bodies to Category II must be supported by an analysis of the "remote" potential for contamination of the liquid-water environments that may exist beneath their surfaces (a probability of introducing a single viable terrestrial organism of < 1 x 10-4), addressing both the existence of such environments and the prospects of accessing them.

Planetary protection documents shall be prepared and the formal documentation for the project and be submitted to the PPO for approval. The Planetary Protection Implementation Plan (PPIP) shall describe all plans for compliance with applicable PP requirements. The PPIP is the primary document describing how a planetary flight project will meet its planetary protection requirements.

The PPIP should include, but not be limited to, the following information:
  • in detail, the processes, procedures, analyses, and facilities how the project will incorporate for the required planetary protection,
  • the estimated bioburden at launch, the methods used to obtain the estimate (e.g., assay techniques applied to spacecraft or a proxy), and the statistical uncertainty in the estimate,
  • the probable composition (identification) of the bioburden for Category IV missions, and for Category V "restricted earth return" missions,
  • methods used to control the bioburden, decontaminate and/or sterilize the space flight HW,
  • the organic inventory of all impacting or landed spacecraft or spacecraft-components, for quantities exceeding 1 kg,
  • intended minimum distance from the surface of the target body for launched components, for those vehicles not intended to land on the body,
  • approximate orbital parameters, expected or realized, for any vehicle which is intended to be placed in orbit around a solar system body,
  • for the end-of-mission, the disposition of the spacecraft and all of its major components, either in space or for landed components by position (or estimated position) on a planetary surface,
  • compliance with requirements of chapter 12 (Planetary Protection).
Flight projects shall comply with planetary protection requirements appropriate to the mission PP category. A summary of implementation requirements is provided in Table 12-2.

Missions with bioburden constraints shall ensure that proper procedures for reducing the microbiological contamination on flight HW are in place to meet the planetary protection constraints. ECSS-Q-ST-70-57 defines procedures for the reduction of microbiological contamination of flight HW using heat and shall be used.
NOTE:
See also ECSS-U-ST-20C, para. 5.4.

applicableDocuments.title: ECSS-Q-ST-70-57
applicableDocuments.description: Dry heat bioburden reduction for flight hardware (30 August 2013)

requirements.text:
A series of ECSS standards describe the processes and procedures to implement the bioburden control requirements and shall be applied:
  • ECSS-Q-ST-70-01 describes the cleanliness and contamination control.
  • ECSS-Q-ST-70-53 describes how to evaluate the material compatibility with different bioburden reduction processes.
  • ECSS-Q-ST-70-56 describes the currently approved bioburden reduction processes, i.e. vapour hydrogen peroxide and dry heat, respectively.
  • ECSS-Q-ST-70-55 describes how to measure the biological contamination on flight HW and in bioburden controlled environments.
  • ECSS-Q-ST-70-57 describes the reduction of microbiological contamination of flight HW.
  • ECSS-Q-ST-70-58 describes how to operate a bioburden controlled environment, like a cleanroom, for the assembly and testing of bioburden controlled flight HW.
NOTE:
Each organisation defines the way those documents are used for planetary protection.

requirements.text:
Table 12-2. Summary of Planetary Protection Implementation Requirements by Mission PP Category
Mission PP Category Implementation Requirements
I (Any) Documentation only
II (Any) Documentation only
III (Flyby, Orbiter) Impact avoidance and/or contamination control including: cleanroom assembly, microbial reduction, and trajectory biasing.
IV (Lander, Probe) Impact avoidance and contamination control including: cleanroom assembly, microbial reduction, trajectory biasing, organics archiving.
V "Unrestricted Earth Return" As appropriate for the specified PP category of the outbound mission. No inbound PP requirements.
V "Restricted Earth Return" Impact avoidance and contamination control including: clean room assembly, microbial containment of sample, breaking chain of contact with target planet, sample containment and biohazard testing in receiving laboratory (continuing monitoring of project activities, pre-project advanced studies and research, as needed).

chapters.name: Numerical Implementation Limits for Forward Contamination Calculations not Otherwise Specified

requirements.text: To the degree that numerical limits are required to support the overall policy objectives of this document, and except where numerical requirements are otherwise specified, the limit to be used is that the probability that a planetary body will be contaminated during the period of biological exploration shall be no more than 1x10<sup>-3</sup>. No specific format for probability of contamination calculations is specified.

The period of biological exploration shall extend at least 50 years after a Category III or IV mission arrives at its protected target and no longer than the time point after which no organisms remain viable on the spacecraft.

For all launch vehicle elements leaving Earth's orbit, the probability of impacting Mars shall be less than 1x10<sup>-4</sup>for a period of 50 years. The probability of impact assessment should be provided in the PPIP.

For all spacecraft crossing Mars orbit en route to other targets, the probability of impacting Mars shall be less than 1x10<sup>-2</sup>for a period of 50 years. The probability of impact assessment should be provided in the PPIP.
In the context of missions to icy satellites, "contamination" is defined as the introduction of a single viable terrestrial microorganism into a liquid-water environment.
A probability of impact analysis on protected Solar system bodies shall be performed and a report delivered.

The probability of impact analysis shall include:
  1. single and multiple pass analysis,
  2. spacecraft reliability,
  3. meteoroid impacts,
    • meteoroid fluxes from the Grün model at 1 AU, scaled to the duration of the cruise phase, with an additional safety margin factor of 3,
    • meteoroid density of 2,5 g/cm3,
    • meteoroid velocity of 20 km/s and average impact angle of 45 degrees from the surface normal,
    • damage equations in IADC protection manual for the damage assessment.
  4. spacecraft state including location, and velocity vector,
  5. manoeuvre and planet and satellite ephemeris uncertainty,
  6. stochastic variability of the atmospheric density with the amplitude of the Solar cycle estimated for the mission and sun epoch as variable.
NOTE:
  1. The "Grün model" is described in 'Collisional balance of the meteoritic complex, Icarus, 62, 244-272, 1985 Grün, E., Zook, H.A., Fechting, H. and Giese, R.H.'.
  2. The "Damage equations" are contained in IADC protection manual, see 'IADC-WD-00-03, Inter Agency Debris Committee Protection Manual Version 3.3, 2004' (www.iadc-online.org/).
  3. Different meteoroid models are used depending on the mission profile; dedicated models are currently developed for the Jovian system.

If not specified otherwise, all flight hardware subject to planetary protection constraints shall be assembled and maintained until and including launch in ISO class 8 cleanrooms "in operation", or better, as specified in ECSS-Q-ST-70-01.

applicableDocuments.title: ECSS-Q-ST-70-01
applicableDocuments.description: Contamination and Cleanliness Control (15 November 2008)

requirements.text: The elements of contamination control and planetary protection that are critical to mission planning, science, and HW design must be a fundamental part of the systems engineering and must be addressed at the earliest stages of the mission to ensure proper flow-down of requirements and cost-effective mission planning. An adequate approved materials/parts list that can accommodate both contamination control and planetary protection considerations should be developed. Integrated modelling tools should be developed to aid systems engineers and designers for future work, particularly in the form of risk assessments for forward- and back-contamination. Also, planetary protection implementers should define and engage systems engineering approaches to determine traceable requirements that can be flowed down within projects early in the process. Cost estimating tools should be developed.

Implementation guidelines for Category V missions

If during the course of a Category V mission there is a change in the circumstances that led to its classification, or a mission failure, e.g.:

  • New data or scientific opinion arise that would lead to the reclassification of a mission classified as "Unrestricted Earth return" to "Restricted Earth return," and safe return of the sample cannot be assured, or
  • The sample containment system of a mission classified as "Restricted Earth return"is thought to be compromised, and sample sterilization is impossible,

then the sample to be returned shall be abandoned, and if already collected the spacecraft carrying the sample must not be allowed to return to the Earth or the Moon.

Deviations from the requirements in this document may be permitted only after review and written acceptance by DLR and the PPO. Deviations from implementation procedures may be granted when an alternative implementation approach is demonstrated to meet planetary protection policy and objectives and is consistent with effective mission design and operations. Deviations requested prior to the acceptance of the Planetary Protection Plan (PPIP) shall be proposed by describing alternative implementation approach(es) in distinct and separately identified part(s) of the PPIP or other applicable subsidiary plan. Acceptance of the PPIP by DLR and the PPO will constitute written approval of proposed deviations so incorporated. Requests must describe the need for a deviation and the justification to support the request, and include the impact of the requested change on the original analyses, as well as address possible changes in the PP category of the mission.
All deviations related to planetary protection shall be specified as major.

The probability to release a particle having a size greater than 0.2 µm into Earth biosphere shall be less than 10-6. This probability is named Probability of Earth Contamination (PEC)

This probability covers all operations performed during all the time concerned by the risk, meaning from beginning with the back-cruise and sample containment conditions until the sample release conditions, after quarantine analyses, to laboratories. This probability PECmust be shared in allocations for all missions or analysis conditions events.
