Sterilization of hardware in contact with extraterrestrial atmosphere or material, or of extraterrestrial matter, is not allowed as far as no extraterrestrial (and consequently unknown) living microorganisms have been found and on which the efficiency of a sterilization process could be validated, and as far as no reliable scientific consideration could allow to do it.

The mission and the spacecraft design shall provide a method to "break the chain of contact" with body it returns from. No uncontained hardware that contacted body, directly or indirectly, shall be returned to Earth. Isolation of such hardware from the body environment shall be provided during sample container loading into the containment system, launch from body, and any in-flight transfer operations required by the mission.
If the mission cannot be safely returned on Earth, it must be abandoned avoiding any collision with the Earth and the Moon.

chapters.name: Requirements for Earth Return and Landing System

requirements.text: Concerning navigation back to Earth, each ERS (Earth return system - probe, spacecraft, module, etc.) shall firstly be injected on a trajectory which does not impact Earth.

Sample containers shall be hermetically closed or sealed. In order to comply with the present WHO 'Guidelines for the safe transport of infectious substances ' on Earth, the sample containment system shall include 3 biological barriers.

Before performing any manoeuvre in order to put an ERS (Earth Return System) on an Earth impact trajectory, it shall be demonstrated that
  • parts of the EEV (Earth Entry Vehicule) surfaces have not been in contact with the explored body (contact chain breaking),
  • the sample container is hermetically closed. A redundant, fail-safe containment with a method for verification of its operation before Earth return shall be required.

If the ERS has been in contact with the explored body, implementation shall be defined in order to avoid contamination transfer to the EEV.

Before the release of the EEV into Earth atmosphere, it shall be verified that the sample container remains hermetic and that all systems are able to ensure a nominal EEV Earth atmosphere entry and landing.
The UN General Secretary must be informed of this release according UN treaty signed by Germany.
The design of sample containers shall comply with a major failure of the Earth Entry vehicle (EEV) landing system in order to keep its hermeticity in case of crash.

The EEV shall be located with TBC accuracy after landing or unfortunate crash.
In order to comply with an unfortunate landing on water, the EEV shall include floating capabilities.

After the EEV release, the ERS shall be handled as following described:
  • ERS or parts of ERS which have been in contact with extraterrestrial material do not enter into Earth atmosphere. A deflexion maneuver must be performed in order to avoid any crash on Earth, meeting a crash probability specification 10-6at any time in the future.
  • It can be allowed, after demonstration, to crash on Earth ERS or parts of ERS which have not been in contact with extraterrestrial material (TBC). Is this case, the impact location does not present any risk for Earth population, according to the related safety regulations.

chapters.name: Requirements for Sample Handling and Analysis

requirements.text: Just after recovery and landing, the EEV including the sample container shall be hermetically packaged for transportation in order to prevent any contamination in case of lack of hermeticity.
After the EEV recovery, the EEV package shall be transported to a specific receiving facility according to WHO regulations 'Guidelines for the safe transport of infectious substances'.
The sample container shall be extracted out of the EEV and opened in a specific high security facility.

The extraterrestrial samples shall be analysed in specific high security laboratories in order to confine the samples and to avoid Earth environment contamination.

Implementations for environment protection shall be equivalent to BSL (Biosafety Level 4) / P4 standards.
The extraterrestrial samples shall be maintained in quarantine conditions until it is demonstrated that they do not present any hazard.

Any facility used for sample storage and analysis shall be first perfectly defined through a functional analysis, and then subject to a risk analysis.

After building and before using it, the facility must be certified by an independent entity.

The high security laboratories shall be handled according to all procedures linked to the related standard.

Crisis situation (e.g. unfortunate external contamination, fire, etc.) shall be foreseen and specific procedures shall be built and tested in order to handle such situation.

All equipment, facilities, instrumentation in contact with extraterrestrial samples are considered to be contaminated and must be placed in quarantine condition until it is demonstrated that the concerned samples do not present any hazard.
Sterilization means shall be foreseen in the view of possibility to sterilize extraterrestrial material.

Analysis protocols shall be built and applied in order to detect eventual life and/or biohazard. Before using the defined protocols, they may be firstly proposed to the PPO advice.

The decision to release the samples out the quarantine conditions may be submitted only if no hazard (particularly biohazard) is detected.

If life or traces of life are detected in absence of any biohazard, additional biohazard testing protocols must be defined and performed
If absence of biohazard is not proven, the only way to release samples is to sterilize them if it has been demonstrated that the sterilization process is efficient.

After finishing all investigations and sample analysis, the eventual decision to release extraterrestrial samples out of quarantine conditions belongs to the Program Directory Committee, advised by the PPO.

The UN General Secretary shall be informed of this release according UN treaty signed by Germany.

Earth safety analysis plan:

This document shall be the primary planning document covering the Earth-return portion of the mission to demonstrate to the PPO responsible that the project is meeting its planetary protection requirements.

This plan should include, but not be limited to, the subjects given in the following outline:

  • potential contaminating sources (sample containment approach, contact chain breaking approach, Earth entry plan),
  • probability of contamination model (mission probability of contamination equation, critical parameters),
  • contamination sources analysis (analytical techniques, assumptions, substantiation of parameter values,
  • Probability of contamination allocation model (level of risk, system allocations),
  • analysis documentation.

Earth return preparation report:

It shall be the document used by a flight project to provide verification to the PPO Responsible that planetary protection requirements outlined in the Earth Safety Analysis Plan have been met and that the project can continue to satisfy them throughout the Earth-return portion of the mission.

Sample receiving and analysis facilities certification:

Before using a facility in which the samples will be stored and analysed, it shall be checked and tested in order to verify if it complies with safety. The facility can be used only if it is certified by an independent entity.

Sample pre-release report:

Before an extraterrestrial sample is released to the general scientific community for investigation, a 'sample pre-release report' shall be issued to provide verification that the sample will not harm the Earth's biosphere.
According to COSPAR last recommendations, missions on, flying-by or around Mercury are category 1 mission. There is no special requirement.

Sample Return Missions from Mercury

Statement of Mercury is not defined at this time, and as conservative approach, requirements defined for Mars sample return missions shall be applied, i.e.:

The Earth return mission is classified, "Restricted Earth return".

  • Unless specifically exempted, the outbound leg of the mission shall meet Category Ivb requirements. This provision is intended to avoid "false positive" indications in a life-detection and hazard-determination protocol, or in the search for life in the sample after it is returned. A "false positive" could prevent distribution of the sample from containment and could lead to unnecessary increased rigor in the requirements for all later Mars missions.
  • Unless the samples to be returned from Mercury are subjected to an accepted and approved sterilization process, the canister(s) holding the samples returned from Mercury shall be closed, with an appropriate verification process, and the samples shall remain contained during all mission phases through transport to a receiving facility where it (they) can be opened under containment.
  • The mission and the spacecraft design must provide a method to "break the chain of contact" with Mercury. No uncontained hardware that contacted Mercury, directly or indirectly, shall be returned to Earth. Isolation of such hardware from the Mercury environment shall be provided during sample container loading into the containment system, launch from Mercury, and any inflight transfer operations required by the mission.
  • Reviews and approval of the continuation of the flight mission shall be required at three stages:
    1. prior to launch from Earth,
    2. prior to leaving Mercury for return to Earth, and
    3. prior to commitment to Earth re-entry.
  • For unsterilized samples returned to Earth, a program of life detection and biohazard testing, or a proven sterilization process, shall be undertaken as an absolute precondition for the controlled distribution of any portion of the sample.>/li>
  • The probability that a single unsterilized particle of ≥ 0,01 μm in diameter is released into the terrestrial biosphere shall be ≤1x10-6.

According to COSPAR last recommendation, taking into account that extreme conditions of the surface of Venus will not only destroy Earth life, but most organics as well.
Consequently, missions on, flying-by or around Venus are category 2 missions. There is no special requirement.

Sample Return Missions from Venus

Statement of Venus is not defined at this time, and as conservative approach, requirements defined for unrestricted earth return missions shall be applied.

Category III:

Mars orbiters or fly-by spacecrafts will not be required to meet orbital lifetime requirements* if they achieve total (surface, mated, and encapsulated) bioburden levels of = 5 x 105spores.
(*Defined as 20 years after launch at greater than or equal to 99% probability, and 50 years after launch at greater than or equal to 95% probability.)

Category III:

The spacecraft must be assembled and tested (AIT) in ISO 8 / class 100 000 cleanroom or better, according to ISO 14644-1 and ISO 14698 or FED-STD-209 or standard.
In case of cleanroom dys-functionment, at technical level (filtration problems, unexpected overcontamination, overpressure system failure, ... etc.) or at procedural level (non respect of cleanroom access procedures, non respect of the cleaning frequencies, ... etc.), all free surfaces of the orbiter must be controlled and eventually cleaned in order to meet a surface biocontamination compliant with the used cleanliness class after cleaning. This case of failure must be managed according the PA regulations.

Category III & IV:

A list of all organic constituents must be performed. The list should be a part of the DML provided according QA space standards. In addition, for missions around or flying-by Mars, 50g minimum sample of each material exceeding 25kg must be stored during minimum 50 years after the launch.

Category IV:

Equipment able to disseminate life on Mars (large surface equipment like parachutes or airbags, wheels, etc.) have to be sterilized (typical level of sterility assurance level (SAL) 10-3).

Category IV for Mars is subdivided into IVa, IVb, and IVc:

Category IVa. Lander systems not carrying instruments for the investigations of extant martian life are restricted to a surface bioburden level of = 3 x 105spores, and an average of = 300 spores per square meter.

Category IVb. For lander systems designed to investigate extant martian life, all of the requirements of Category IVa apply, along with the following requirement:

  • The entire landed system is restricted to a surface bioburden level of = 30* spores, or to levels of bioburden reduction driven by the nature and sensitivity of the particular lifedetection experiments, or
  • The subsystems which are involved in the acquisition, delivery, and analysis of samples used for life detection must be sterilized to these levels, and a method of preventing recontamination of the sterilized subsystems and the contamination of the material to be analysed is in place.

Category IVc. For missions which investigate martian special regions (see definition below), even if they do not include life detection experiments, all of the requirements of Category Iva apply, along with the following requirement:

  • Case 1. If the landing site is within the special region, the entire landed system is restricted to a surface bioburden level of = 30* spores.
  • Case 2. If the special region is accessed through horizontal or vertical mobility, either the entire landed system is restricted to a surface bioburden level of = 30* spores, OR the subsystems which directly contact the special region shall be sterilized to these levels, and a method of preventing their recontamination prior to accessing the special region shall be provided.

If an off-nominal condition (such as a hard landing) would cause a high probability of inadvertent biological contamination of the special region by the spacecraft, the entire landed system must be sterilized to a surface bioburden level of = 30* spores and a total (surface, mated, and encapsulated) bioburden level of = 30 + (2 x 105)* spores.

*This figure takes into account the occurrence of hardy organisms with respect to the sterilization modality. This specification assumes attainment of Category Iva surface cleanliness, followed by at least a four order-of-magnitude reduction in viable organisms.
Verification of bioburden level is based on pre-sterilization bioburden assessment and knowledge of reduction factor of the sterilization modality.

Category IV

Planned 3-sigma pre-launch landing ellipses must be evaluated on a case-by-case basis as part of the (landing) site selection process, to determine whether the mission would land or come within contamination range of areas or volumes meeting the parameter definition for Mars Special Regions or would impinge on already described features that must be treated as Mars Special Regions. The evaluation must be based on the latest scientific evidence and in particular include an assessment of the extent to which the temperature and water activity values specified for Mars Special Regions are separated in time.

The evaluation must be updated during the mission whenever new evidence indicates that the landing ellipse and/or the operational environment contain or are in contamination range of areas or volumes meeting the parameter definition for Mars Special Regions or already described features that must be treated as Mars Special Regions.

Category IV

Definition of "Special Region"

A Special Region is defined as a region within which terrestrial organisms are likely to replicate. Any region which is interpreted to have a high potential for the existence of extant martian life forms is also defined as a Special Region.

Given current understanding of terrestrial organisms, Special Regions are defined as areas or volumes within which sufficient water activity AND sufficiently warm temperatures to permit replication of Earth organisms may exist. The physical parameters delineating applicable water activity and temperature thresholds are given below:

  • Lower limit for water activity: 0.5; Upper limit: 1.0,
  • Lower limit for temperature: -28°C; No Upper limit defined,
  • Timescale within which limits can be identified: 500 years.

Spacecraft-induced special regions are to be evaluated, consistent with these limits and features, on a case-by-case basis.

Observed features to be treated as Special Regions until demonstrated otherwise:

  • Gullies (taxon 2-4) †, and bright streaks associated with gullies,
  • Subsurface cavities,
  • Subsurface below 5 meters,
  • Confirmed and partially confirmed Recurrent Slope Lineae (RSL) ‡.

Features, if found, to be treated as a Special Region until demonstrated otherwise:

  • Groundwater,
  • Source of methane,
  • Geothermal activity,
  • Modern outflow channel.

Observed features that require a case-by-case evaluation before being classified as a Special Region:

  • Dark streaks,
  • Pasted-on terrain,
  • Candidate RSL‡.

† Description for Gully taxon in Rummel, J.D, et al., A new Analysis of Mars "Special Regions": Findings of the Second MEPAG Special Regions Science Analysis Group (SR-SAG2), Astrobiology 14, 887-968, 2014.
‡ Observational evidence for Recurrent Slope Lineae (RSL), adapted from McEwen, A.S., et al., Recurrent slope lineae in equatorial regions of Mars, Nature Geosciences, 7, 53-58, 2014.

  • Confirmed: observed simultaneous incremental growth of flows on a warm slope, fading, and recurrence of this sequence in multiple Mars years,
  • Partially confirmed: observed either incremental growth or recurrence,
  • Candidate: slope lineae that resemble RSL but where observations needed for partial confirmation are currently lacking.

Spacecraft-induced special regions are to be evaluated, consistent with these limits and features, on a case-by-case basis.

In the absence of specific information, no Special Regions are currently identified on the basis of possible martian life forms. If and when information becomes available on this subject, Special Regions will be further defined on that basis.

Sample Return Missions from Mars

Category V. The Earth return mission is classified, "Restricted Earth return".

  • Unless specifically exempted, the outbound leg of the mission shall meet Category Ivb requirements. This provision is intended to avoid "false positive" indications in a life-detection and hazard-determination protocol, or in the search for life in the sample after it is returned. A "false positive" could prevent distribution of the sample from containment and could lead to unnecessary increased rigor in the requirements for all later Mars missions.
  • Unless the samples to be returned from Mars are subjected to an accepted and approved sterilization process, the canister(s) holding the samples returned from Mars shall be closed, with an appropriate verification process, and the samples shall remain contained during all mission phases through transport to a receiving facility where it (they) can be opened under containment.
  • The mission and the spacecraft design must provide a method to "break the chain of contact" with Mars. No uncontained hardware that contacted Mars, directly or indirectly, shall be returned to Earth. Isolation of such hardware from the Mars environment shall be provided during sample container loading into the containment system, launch from Mars, and any inflight transfer operations required by the mission.
  • Reviews and approval of the continuation of the flight mission shall be required at three stages:
    1. prior to launch from Earth,
    2. prior to leaving Mars for return to Earth, and
    3. prior to commitment to Earth re-entry.
  • For unsterilized samples returned to Earth, a program of life detection and biohazard testing, or a proven sterilization process, shall be undertaken as an absolute precondition for the controlled distribution of any portion of the sample.
  • The probability that a single unsterilized particle of ≥ 0,01 μm in diameter is released into the terrestrial biosphere shall be ≤1×10-6.

Principles and Guidelines for Human Missions to Mars

The intent of this planetary protection policy is the same whether a mission to Mars is conducted robotically or with human explorers. Accordingly, planetary protection goals should not be relaxed to accommodate a human mission to Mars. Rather, they become even more directly relevant to such missions-even if specific implementation requirements must differ. General principles include:

  • Safeguarding the Earth from potential back contamination is the highest planetary protection priority in Mars exploration.
  • The greater capability of human explorers can contribute to the astrobiological exploration of Mars only if human-associated contamination is controlled and understood.
  • For a landed mission conducting surface operations, it will not be possible for all human-associated processes and mission operations to be conducted within entirely closed systems.
  • Crewmembers exploring Mars, or their support systems, will inevitably be exposed to martian materials.

In accordance with these principles, specific implementation guidelines for human missions to Mars include:

  • Human missions will carry microbial populations that will vary in both kind and quantity, and it will not be practicable to specify all aspects of an allowable microbial population or potential contaminants at launch. Once any baseline conditions for launch are established and met, continued monitoring and evaluation of microbes carried by human missions will be required to address both forward and backward contamination concerns.
  • A quarantine capability for both the entire crew and for individual crewmembers shall be provided during and after the mission, in case potential contact with a martian life-form occurs.
  • A comprehensive planetary protection protocol for human missions should be developed that encompasses both forward and backward contamination concerns, and addresses the combined human and robotic aspects of the mission, including subsurface exploration, sample handling, and the return of the samples and crew to Earth.
  • Neither robotic systems nor human activities should contaminate "Special Regions" on Mars, as defined by the COSPAR policy.
  • Any uncharacterized martian site should be evaluated by robotic precursors prior to crew access. Information may be obtained by either precursor robotic missions or a robotic component on a human mission.
  • Any pristine samples or sampling components from any uncharacterized sites or Special Regions on Mars should be treated according to current planetary protection category V, restricted Earth return, with the proper handling and testing protocols.
  • An onboard crewmember should be given primary responsibility for the implementation of planetary protection provisions affecting the crew during the mission.
  • Planetary protection requirements for initial human missions should be based on a conservative approach consistent with a lack of knowledge of martian environments and possible life, as well as the performance of human support systems in those environments. Planetary protection requirements for later missions should not be relaxed without scientific review, justification, and consensus.

Sample Return Missions from the Martian Moons Phobos and Deimos

Category V. The Earth return mission is classified, "un-restricted Earth return".

Phobos and Deimos shall not currently be treated differently in their Planetary Protection Requirements.

The probability of impact on Marsby any element not assembled and maintained in at least ISO class 8 conditions shall be ≤ 1×10-4for the first 50 years after launch for nominal and off-nominal flight conditions.
NOTE:
Examples are upper stages

One of the following conditions shall be met:
  1. The probability of impact on Mars by any part of a spacecraft assembled and maintained in ISO class 8 conditions, or better, is ≤ 1×10-2for the first 20 years after launch, and ≤ 5×10-2for the time period from 20 to 50 years after launch for nominal and off-nominal flight conditions.
  2. The total bioburden of the spacecraft on Mars, including surface, mated, and encapsulated bioburden, is ≤ 5×105 bacterial spores.
  3. NOTE:
    This requirement is also applicable for fly-by and gravity assist manoeuvres.

Category III and IV. Requirements for Europa flybys, orbiters and landers, including bioburden reduction, shall be applied in order to reduce the probability of inadvertent contamination of an Europan ocean to less than 1x10-4per mission.

The probability of inadvertent contamination of an Europan ocean of 1x10-4applies to all mission phases including the duration that spacecraft introduced terrestrial organisms remain viable and could reach a sub-surface liquid water environment.

These requirements will be refined in future years, but the calculation of this probability should include a conservative estimate of poorly known parameters, and address the following factors, at a minimum:

  • Bioburden at launch,
  • Cruise survival for contaminating organisms,
  • Organism survival in the radiation environment adjacent to Europa,
  • Probability of landing on Europa,
  • The mechanisms and timescales of transport to a Europan subsurface liquid water environment,
  • Organism survival and proliferation before, during, and after subsurface transfer.

Preliminary calculations of the probability of contamination suggest that bioburden reduction will likely be necessary even for Europa orbiters (Category III) as well as for landers, requiring the use of cleanroom technology and the cleanliness of all parts before assembly, and the monitoring of spacecraft assembly facilities to understand the bioburden and its microbial diversity, including specific problematic species.

Specific methods should be developed to eradicate problematic species. Methods of bioburden reduction should reflect the type of environments found on Europa, focusing on Earth extremophiles most likely to survive on Europa, such as cold and radiation tolerant organisms.

Sample Return Missions from Europa

Category V. The Earth return mission is classified, "Restricted Earth return".

  • Unless specifically exempted, the outbound leg of the mission shall meet the contamination control requirements given above. This provision should avoid "false positive" indications in a life-detection and hazard-determination protocol, or in the search for life in the sample after it is returned. A "false positive" could prevent distribution of the sample from containment and could lead to unnecessary increased rigor in the requirements for all later Europa missions.
  • Unless the samples to be returned from Europa are subjected to an accepted and approved sterilization process, the canister(s) holding the samples returned from Europa shall be closed, with an appropriate verification process, and the samples shall remain contained during all mission phases through transport to a receiving facility where it (they) can be opened under containment.
  • The mission and the spacecraft design must provide a method to "break the chain of contact" with Europa. No uncontained hardware that contacted material from Europa or their plumes, shall be returned to the Earth's biosphere or the Moon.
    Isolation of such hardware from the Europan environment shall be provided during sample container loading into the containment system, launch from Europa, and any in-flight transfer operations required by the mission.
  • Reviews and approval of the continuation of the flight mission shall be required at three stages:
    1. prior to launch from Earth,
    2. prior to leaving Europa for return to Earth, and
    3. prior to commitment to Earth re-entry.
  • For unsterilized samples returned to Earth, a program of life detection and biohazard testing, or a proven sterilization process, shall be undertaken as an absolute precondition for the controlled distribution of any portion of the sample.
  • The probability that a single unsterilized particle of ≥ 0,01 μm in diameter is released into the terrestrial biosphere shall be ≤ 1×10-6.

Subglacial Missions on Europa

Exploration protocols should also assume that the subglacial medium environments contain living organisms, and precautions should be adopted to prevent any permanent alteration of the biology (including introduction of alien species) or habitat properties of these environments.

Subglacial medium pressures and partial pressures of gases in lakes should be estimated prior to drilling in order to avoid down flow contamination or destabilization of gas hydrates respectively. Preparatory steps should also be taken for prevention of potential blow-out situations.

Sampling plans and protocols should be optimized to ensure that one type of investigation does not accidentally impact other investigations adversely, that sampling regimes plan for the maximum interdisciplinary use of samples, and that all information is shared to promote greater understanding.

Protocols should be designed to minimize disrupting the chemical and physical structure and properties of subglacial environments during the exploration and sampling of subglacial medium and sediments.

Subglacial Missions Contamination Prevention

Combined Microbial and Chemical Contamination

Drilling fluids can be heavily contaminated not only with microorganisms but also with the substrates that they use for growth. The release of this inoculum plus growth medium into the conditions of a subglacial lake could result in a short-term phase of increased metabolism and growth and shall be avoided therefore by design.

Isotopic Contamination

The relatively small transfer of unusual isotopes during lake access (e.g., from drilling fluids) or by release of deep water and sediments into the upper water column could potentially compromise the geochemical interpretation of some isotopic signatures and shall be avoided therefore by design and mission planning.

Intrasystem Contamination

Releases of e.g. fluids during sample removal could enrich or inhibit communities in the subglacial medium column or overlying ice. Therefore the change of conditions due to sample extraction or the transfer of material from one sample region to another sampling region during sampling shall be avoided therefore by design and / or adequate sterilization measures.

Similarly the potential transfer of material from the surface to the subglacial medium and vice versa shall be avoided at any time of the mission therefore by design and / or adequate sterilization measures.

Therefore it is required to:

  1. clean hardware and drilling fluids (quantification of bacterial levels and bacterial diversity present) prior to penetration,
  2. maintain hardware cleanliness as much as possible during penetration,
  3. design research techniques that minimize the possibility of cell transfer between different levels in the ice and the lake bed itself.

Specific decontamination techniques shall to be developed for any instruments specific decontamination techniques need to be developed for any instruments deployed in a subglacial aquatic environment.

According to COSPAR present recommendations, the statement is the following:
  • missions on, flying-by or around Jupiter are category 2 missions,
  • all types of Europa missions are category 4 missions,
  • all types of Ganymede or Callisto missions are category 2 missions,
  • for all other jovian satellites, the statement is not defined at this time, but classification into category 2 missions should be appropriate presently, waiting on formal statement. In this case, requirements are similar to those applicable to Jupiter missions.
For landers or landing systems, or spacecrafts intended to crash, a list of all organic constituents shall be performed. The list should be a part of the DML provided according QA space standards.
For landers or landing systems, or spacecrafts intended to crash, planned impact probability shall be determined and recorded.

Category III and IV. Requirements for Enceladus flybys, orbiters and landers, including bioburden reduction, shall be applied in order to reduce the probability of inadvertent contamination of an Enceladan ocean to less than 1x10-4per mission.

The probability of inadvertent contamination of an Enceladan ocean of 1x10-4applies to all mission phases including the duration that spacecraft introduced terrestrial organisms remain viable and could reach a sub-surface liquid water environment.

These requirements will be refined in future years, but the calculation of this probability should include a conservative estimate of poorly known parameters, and address the following factors, at a minimum:

  • bioburden at launch,
  • cruise survival for contaminating organisms,
  • organism survival in the radiation environment adjacent to Enceladus,
  • probability of landing on Enceladus,
  • the mechanisms and timescales of transport to a Enceladan subsurface liquid water environment,
  • organism survival and proliferation before, during, and after subsurface transfer.

Preliminary calculations of the probability of contamination suggest that bioburden reduction will likely be necessary even for Enceladus orbiters (Category III) as well as for landers, requiring the use of cleanroom technology and the cleanliness of all parts before assembly, and the monitoring of spacecraft assembly facilities to understand the bioburden and its microbial diversity, including specific problematic species.

Specific methods should be developed to eradicate problematic species. Methods of bioburden reduction should reflect the type of environments found on Enceladus, focusing on Earth extremophiles most likely to survive on Enceladus, such as cold and radiation tolerant organisms.

Sample Return Missions from Enceladus

Category V. The Earth return mission is classified, "Restricted Earth return".

  • Unless specifically exempted, the outbound leg of the mission shall meet the contamination control requirements given above. This provision should avoid "false positive" indications in a life-detection and hazard-determination protocol, or in the search for life in the sample after it is returned. A "false positive" could prevent distribution of the sample from containment and could lead to unnecessary increased rigor in the requirements for all later Enceladus missions.
  • Unless the samples to be returned from Enceladus are subjected to an accepted and approved sterilization process, the canister(s) holding the samples returned from Enceladus shall be closed, with an appropriate verification process, and the samples shall remain contained during all mission phases,
  • through transport to a receiving facility where it (they) can be opened under containment.
  • The mission and the spacecraft design must provide a method to "break the chain of contact" with Enceladus. No uncontained hardware that contacted material from Enceladus or their plumes, shall be returned to the Earth's biosphere or the Moon. Isolation of such hardware from the Enceladus environment shall be provided during sample container loading into the containment system, launch from Enceladus, and any in-flight transfer perations required by the mission.
  • Reviews and approval of the continuation of the flight mission shall be required at three stages:
    1. prior to launch from Earth,
    2. prior to leaving Enceladus for return to Earth, and
    3. prior to commitment to Earth re-entry.
  • For unsterilized samples returned to Earth, a program of life detection and biohazard testing, or a proven sterilization process, shall be undertaken as an absolute precondition for the controlled distribution of any portion of the sample.
  • The probability that a single unsterilized particle of ≥ 0,01 μm in diameter is released into the terrestrial biosphere shall be ≤ 1×10-6.

Subglacial Missions on Enceladus

Exploration protocols should also assume that the subglacial medium environments contain living organisms, and precautions should be adopted to prevent any permanent alteration of the biology (including introduction of alien species) or habitat properties of these environments.

Subglacial medium pressures and partial pressures of gases in lakes should be estimated prior to drilling in order to avoid down flow contamination or destabilization of gas hydrates respectively. Preparatory steps should also be taken for prevention of potential blow-out situations.

Sampling plans and protocols should be optimized to ensure that one type of investigation does not accidentally impact other investigations adversely, that sampling regimes plan for the maximum interdisciplinary use of samples, and that all information is shared to promote greater understanding.

Protocols should be designed to minimize disrupting the chemical and physical structure and properties of subglacial environments during the exploration and sampling of subglacial medium and sediments.

Subglacial Missions Contamination Prevention

Combined Microbial and Chemical Contamination

Drilling fluids can be heavily contaminated not only with microorganisms but also with the substrates that they use for growth. The release of this inoculum plus growth medium into the conditions of a subglacial lake could result in a short-term phase of increased metabolism and growth and shall be avoided therefore by design.

Isotopic Contamination

The relatively small transfer of unusual isotopes during lake access (e.g., from drilling fluids) or by release of deep water and sediments into the upper water column could potentially compromise the geochemical interpretation of some isotopic signatures and shall be avoided therefore by design and mission planning.

Intrasystem Contamination

Releases of e.g. fluids during sample removal could enrich or inhibit communities in the subglacial medium column or overlying ice. Therefore the change of conditions due to sample extraction or the transfer of material from one sample region to another sampling region during sampling shall be avoided therefore by design and / or adequate sterilization measures.

Similarly the potential transfer of material from the surface to the subglacial medium and vice versa shall be avoided at any time of the mission therefore by design and / or adequate sterilization measures Therefore it is required to:

  1. clean hardware and drilling fluids (quantification of bacterial levels and bacterial diversity present) prior to penetration,
  2. maintain hardware cleanliness as much as possible during penetration,
  3. design research techniques that minimize the possibility of cell transfer between different levels in the ice and the lake bed itself.

Specific decontamination techniques shall to be developed for any instruments specific decontamination techniques need to be developed for any instruments deployed in a subglacial aquatic environment.

According to COSPAR present recommendations, the statement is the following:
  • missions on, flying-by or around Saturn are category 2 missions,
  • all types of Enceladus missions are category 4 missions,
  • all types of Titan missions are category 2 missions,
  • for all other Saturn satellites, the statement is not defined at this time, but classification into category 2 missions should be appropriate presently, waiting on formal statement. In this case, requirements are similar to those applicable to Saturn missions.
For landers or landing systems, or spacecrafts intended to crash, a list of all organic constituents shall be performed. The list should be a part of the DML provided according QA space standards.
For landers or landing systems, or spacecrafts intended to crash, planned impact probability shall be determined and recorded.

According to COSPAR present recommendations, the statement is the following:
  • missions on, flying-by or around Uranus are category 2 missions,
  • for all Uranus satellites, the statement is not defined at this time, but classification into category 2 missions should be appropriate presently, waiting on formal statement. In this case, requirements are similar to those applicable to Uranus missions.
For landers or landing systems, or spacecrafts intended to crash, a list of all organic constituents shall be performed. The list should be a part of the DML provided according QA space standards.
For landers or landing systems, or spacecrafts intended to crash, planned impact probability shall be determined and recorded.

According to COSPAR present recommendations, the statement is the following:
  • missions on, flying-by or around Neptune are category 2 missions,
  • all types of Triton missions are category 2 missions,
  • for all other Neptune satellites, the statement is not defined at this time, but classification into category 2 missions should be appropriate presently, waiting on formal statement. In this case, requirements are similar to those applicable to Neptune missions.
For landers or landing systems, or spacecrafts intended to crash, a list of all organic constituents shall be performed. The list should be a part of the DML provided according QA space standards.
For landers or landing systems, or spacecrafts intended to crash, planned impact probability shall be determined and recorded.

According to COSPAR present recommendations, the statement is the following:
  • missions on, flying-by or around Pluto are category 2 missions,
  • all types of Charon missions are category 2 missions,
  • for all other Pluto satellites, the statement is not defined at this time, but classification into category 2 missions should be appropriate presently, waiting on formal statement. In this case, requirements are similar to those applicable to Pluto missions.
For landers or landing systems, or spacecrafts intended to crash, a list of all organic constituents shall be performed. The list should be a part of the DML provided according QA space standards.
For landers or landing systems, or spacecrafts intended to crash, planned impact probability shall be determined and recorded.

According to COSPAR present recommendations, the statement is the following:
  • missions on, flying-by or around the Moon are category 2 missions.
For landers or landing systems, or spacecrafts intended to crash, a list of all organic constituents shall be performed. The list should be a part of the DML provided according QA space standards.
For landers or landing systems, or spacecrafts intended to crash, planned impact probability shall be determined and recorded.

According to COSPAR present recommendations, the statement is the following:
  • missions on, flying-by or around undifferentiated and metamorphosed asteroids are category 1,
  • missions on, flying-by or around carbonaceous chondrite asteroids and Kuiper belt objects are category 2 missions,
  • there is no requirements for differentiated and metamorphosed asteroids missions,
  • carbonaceous chondrite asteroids and Kuiper belt objects shall comply with the same requirements than the Moon.
Imposing forward contamination controls on these missions is not warranted except on a case-by-case basis.

Sample Return Missions from Asteroid Missions or other Small Solar System bodies

Category V. Determination as to whether a mission is classified "Restricted Earth return" or not shall be undertaken with respect to the best multidisciplinary scientific advice, using the framework presented in the 1998 report of the US National Research Council’s Space Studies Board entitled, Evaluating the Biological Potential in Samples Returned from Planetary Satellites and Small Solar System Bodies: Framework for Decision Making.

Specifically, such a determination shall address the following six questions for each body intended to be sampled:

  1. Does the preponderance of scientific evidence indicate that there was never liquid water in or on the target body?
  2. Does the preponderance of scientific evidence indicate that metabolically useful energy sources were never present?
  3. Does the preponderance of scientific evidence indicate that there was never sufficient organic matter (or CO2 or carbonates and an appropriate source of reducing equivalents) in or on the target body to support life?
  4. Does the preponderance of scientific evidence indicate that subsequent to the disappearance of liquid water, the target body has been subjected to extreme temperatures (i.e., >160°C)?
  5. Does the preponderance of scientific evidence indicate that there is or was sufficient radiation for biological sterilization of terrestrial life forms?
  6. Does the preponderance of scientific evidence indicate that there has been a natural influx to Earth, e.g., via meteorites, of material equivalent to a sample returned from the target body?

For containment procedures to be necessary ("Restricted Earth return"), an answer of "no" or "uncertain" needs to be returned to all six questions.

For missions determined to be Category V, "Restricted Earth return", the following requirements shall be met:

  • Unless specifically exempted, the outbound leg of the mission shall meet contamination control requirements to avoid "false positive" indications in a life-detection and hazard- determination protocol, or in any search for life in the sample after it is returned. A "false positive" could prevent distribution of the sample from containment and could lead to unnecessary increased rigor in the requirements for all later missions to that body.
  • Unless the samples to be returned are subjected to an accepted and approved sterilization process, the canister(s) holding the samples shall be closed, with an appropriate verification process, and the samples shall remain contained during all mission phases through transport to a receiving facility where it (they) can be opened under containment.
  • The mission and the spacecraft design must provide a method to "break the chain of contact" with the small body. No uncontained hardware that contacted the body, directly or indirectly, shall be returned to Earth. Isolation of such hardware from the body’s environment shall be provided during sample container loading into the containment system, launch from the body, and any in-flight transfer operations required by the mission.
  • Reviews and approval of the continuation of the flight mission shall be required at three stages:
    1. prior to launch from Earth,
    2. prior to leaving the body or its environment for return to Earth, and
    3. prior to commitment to Earth re-entry.
  • For unsterilized samples returned to Earth, a program of life detection and biohazard testing, or a proven sterilization process, shall be undertaken as an absolute precondition for the controlled distribution of any portion of the sample.
  • The probability that a single unsterilized particle of ≥ 0,01 μm in diameter is released into the terrestrial biosphere shall be ≤ 1×10-6.

According to COSPAR present recommendations, the statement is the following:
  • missions on, flying-by or around comets are category 2 missions.
For landers or landing systems, or spacecrafts intended to crash, a list of all organic constituents shall be performed. The list should be a part of the DML provided according QA space standards.
For landers or landing systems, or spacecrafts intended to crash, planned impact probability shall be determined and recorded.

Sample Return Missions from Comet Missions

The same requirements as applicable to Asteroid and small solar system bodies shall be applied.

Category V. Determination as to whether a mission is classified "Restricted Earth return" or not shall be undertaken with respect to the best multidisciplinary scientific advice, using the framework presented in the 1998 report of the US National Research Council's Space Studies Board entitled, Evaluating the Biological Potential in Samples Returned from Planetary Satellites and Small Solar System Bodies: Framework for Decision Making.

Specifically, such a determination shall address the following six questions for each body intended to be sampled:

  1. Does the preponderance of scientific evidence indicate that there was never liquid water in or on the target body?
  2. Does the preponderance of scientific evidence indicate that metabolically useful energy sources were never present?
  3. Does the preponderance of scientific evidence indicate that there was never sufficient organic matter (or CO2or carbonates and an appropriate source of reducing equivalents) in or on the target body to support life?
  4. Does the preponderance of scientific evidence indicate that subsequent to the disappearance of liquid water, the target body has been subjected to extreme temperatures (i.e., >160°C)?
  5. Does the preponderance of scientific evidence indicate that there is or was sufficient radiation for biological sterilization of terrestrial life forms?
  6. Does the preponderance of scientific evidence indicate that there has been a natural influx to Earth, e.g., via meteorites, of material equivalent to a sample returned from the target body?

For containment procedures to be necessary ("Restricted Earth return"), an answer of "no" or "uncertain" needs to be returned to all six questions.

For missions determined to be Category V, "Restricted Earth return", the following requirements shall be met:

  • Unless specifically exempted, the outbound leg of the mission shall meet contamination control requirements to avoid "false positive" indications in a life-detection and hazard- determination protocol, or in any search for life in the sample after it is returned. A "false positive" could prevent distribution of the sample from containment and could lead to unnecessary increased rigor in the requirements for all later missions to that body.
  • Unless the samples to be returned are subjected to an accepted and approved sterilization process, the canister(s) holding the samples shall be closed, with an appropriate verification process, and the samples shall remain contained during all mission phases through transport to a receiving facility where it (they) can be opened under containment.
  • The mission and the spacecraft design must provide a method to "break the chain of contact" with the small body. No uncontained hardware that contacted the body, directly or indirectly, shall be returned to Earth. Isolation of such hardware from the body's environment shall be provided during sample container loading into the containment system, launch from the body, and any in-flight transfer operations required by the mission.
  • Reviews and approval of the continuation of the flight mission shall be required at three stages:
    1. prior to launch from Earth,
    2. prior to leaving the body or its environment for return to Earth, and
    3. prior to commitment to Earth re-entry.
  • For unsterilized samples returned to Earth, a program of life detection and biohazard testing, or a proven sterilization process, shall be undertaken as an absolute precondition for the controlled distribution of any portion of the sample.
According to COSPAR last recommendations, all solar missions are category 1 mission. There are no specific requirements.

chapters.name: Interstellar Missions, especially to Extrasolar Systems & Planets

requirements.text:
The continuing discovery of extrasolar planets is likely to encourage design studies for spacecrafts to visit targets that might be habitable.

Also spacecrafts exiting the solar system may pass near or encounter with members of extrasolar systems.

Given the uncertainties in the surface conditions of a destination extrasolar planet, particularly at microscopic scales, the potential for unknown biochemistries and biologies elsewhere, or the possible inoculation of a lifeless planet that is habitable, it is required that the entire spacecraft of an interstellar mission is sterilized prior to arrival at the target system from a position of prudence, which is both scientifically and ethically motivated.

For long voyages spacecraft may be self-sterilizing, but as propulsion systems improve and interstellar missions become possible with decadal and centennial time scales, active sterilization procedures are required.

Any interstellar mission shall fulfil the requirements imposed to a mission investigating the "special regions" of Mars (Category IVc), which implies that entire system must be sterilized to a surface bioburden level of = 30* spores and a total (surface and encapsulated) bioburden level of = 30 + (2 x 105)* spores.

*This figure takes into account the occurrence of hardy organisms with respect to the sterilization modality.

This specification assumes attainment of Category Iva surface cleanliness, followed by at least a four order-of-magnitude reduction in viable organisms. Verification of bioburden level is based on pre-sterilization bioburden assessment and knowledge of reduction factor of the sterilization modality.

NOTE:
All bioburden constraints are defined with respect to the number of aerobic microorganisms that survive a heat shock of 80°C for 15 minutes (hereinafter "spores") and are cultured on (Tryptic-Soy-Agar) TSA at 32°C for 72 hours.

The purpose of a security controls framework is to provide a hierarchical grouping of related security concerns to guide the system owner in setting policy and aid in decomposing policy into more specific architectural and procedural requirements for implementation. It shall allow assessing whether and how the system meets its security objectives.
The frameworks recommend more controls based upon the predetermined criticality and sensitivity (with respect to confidentiality, availability, and integrity) of the data types the system processes.

The ISO/IEC 27001standard identifies a security controls framework encompassing management, operational, and technical capabilities. The framework addresses the most common aspects of protecting the confidentiality, integrity, and availability of information and information systems. There are dozens of individual controls available in the ISO framework, which are organized according to the high-level groupings listed in table A-1 of annex A.

An overview of information security management may be
found in ISO/IEC 27000.

The companion ISO/IEC documents numbered 27002-27005 provide accompanying implementation guidance.

In addition to ISO/IEC standards (and national standards derived from ISO/IEC, e.g. BSI-Standards 200-1, 200-2, 200-3 and 100-4), there are several widely used security controls frameworks. Among these are:
  1. the National Institute for Standards and Technology (NIST) framework, used by United States civilian government agencies and defined in NIST Special Publications 800-30, 800-53, 800-60,
  2. Committee on National Security Systems (CNSSI) No 1200, 1253.

Civilian space mission are supported by a large system of inter-connected resources and assets both in space and on the ground (e.g., computer systems, communication devices, processors, etc.). Each of these entities potentially has vulnerabilities that could be exploited by a threat agent. A successful attack may result in mission impact. Mission impacts can range from insignificant (such as software crash) to catastrophic (loss of mission). Successful attacks may result in a loss of mission confidentiality, integrity, or availability.

This section is written with the main objective of creating awareness and establishing initial requirements for implementing vulnerability assessments, threat limitation, security restrictions and control.

For this the following areas will be addressed and shall be looked at:

  • Space Segment:
    • Hardware with:
      • Ports for Communication,
      • Firmware.
    • Software with: (also in chapter 13 and 8)
      • access points,
      • data bases/storage,
      • uploads.
    • Network
  • Ground Segment (also in chapter 14):
    • Operation Centers / Manufacturing / AIT/AIV:
      • Facilities,
      • Personnel,
      • Hardware within the facilities.
  • Space Link:
    • Coding / Encrypting,
    • Checks,
    • Timings.
The section will follow the logic and philosophy as shown in the diagram below:
The following documents shall be used by suppliers and subsuppliers as applicable to the extent specified herein. For undated references the latest edition of the publication referred to applies:

• BSI-Standard 200-1: Managementsysteme für Informationssicherheit,
  • BSI-Standard 200-2: IT-Grundschutz-Methodik,
  • BSI-Standard 200-3: Risikomanagement,
  • BSI-Standard 100-4: Notfallmanagement,
  • CCSDS 350.1-G-2 Security Threats against Space Missions. Issue 2. (Green Book); Washington, D.C.: CCSDS, December 2015,
  • ISO/IEC 27000 Information Security Management Systems - Overview and Vocabulary. Geneva: ISO, 2009,
  • ISO/IEC 27001 Information Security Management Systems - Requirements. Geneva: ISO, 2013,
  • ISO/IEC 27002 Code of Practice for Information Security Management. Geneva: ISO, 2013,
  • ISO/IEC 27003 Information Security Management System Implementation Guidance. Geneva: ISO, 2017,
  • ISO/IEC 27004 Information Security Management - Measurement. Geneva: ISO, 2016,
  • ISO/IEC 27005 Information Security Risk Management. Geneva: ISO, 2011

• CCSDS 350.0-G-2 The Application of CCSDS Protocols to Secure Systems. (Green Book) Issue 2. Washington, D.C.: CCSDS, January 2006
  • CCSDS 350.8-G-1 Information Security Glossary of Terms. Issue 1. (Green Book); Washington, D.C.: CCSDS, November 2012.
  • CCSDS 350.4-G-1 CCSDS Guide for Secure System Interconnection. Issue 1. (Green Book); Washington, D.C.: CCSDS, November 2007.
  • CNSSI 1200 National Information Assurance Instruction for Space Systems used to Support National Security Missions, Committee on National Security Systems, 2014
  • CNSSI 1253 Security Categorisation and Control Selection for National Security Systems, Committee on National Security Systems, 2014; especially Annex F
  • ISO 7498-2 Information Processing Systems - Open Systems Interconnection - Basic Reference Model - Part 2: Security Architecture. Geneva: ISO, 1989
  • Jabbour K., Muccio S., The Science of Mission Assurance, Journal of Strategic Security Vol 4, No 2, 61-74, 2011
  • Lane D.C., Leon E.S., Tacliad F.C. et al., High-Assurance Cyber Space System (HACSS) for Small Satellite Mission Integrity Presentation
  • Takamura E., Mangum K., Wasiak F., Gomez-Rosa C., Information Security Considerations for Protecting NASA Mission Operation Centers, NASA Maven Project.
  • Gesetz zum Schutz vor Gefährdung der Sicherheit der Bundes-republik Deutschland durch das Verbreiten von hochwertigen Erdfernerkundungsdaten (Satellitendatensicherheitsgesetz - SatDSIG)
  • NIST Special Publication 800-30: Guide for Conducting Risk Assessments, Revision 1. National Institute of Standards and Technology, Gaithersburg, Maryland: NIST, September 2012,
  • NIST Special Publication 800-37: Risk Management Framework for Information Systems and Organizations: A System Life Cycle Approach for Security and Privacy, Revision 2. National Institute of Standards and Technology, Gaithersburg, Maryland: NIST, December 2018,
  • NIST Special Publication 800-53: Recommended Security Controls for Federal Information Systems and Organizations, Revision 3. National Institute of Standards and Technology, Gaithersburg, Maryland: NIST, August 2009,
  • NIST Special Publication 800-60: Kevin Stine, et al., Guide for Mapping Types of Information and Information Systems to Security Categories, Revision 1. National Institute of Standards and Technology, Gaithersburg, Maryland: NIST, August 2008,
  • NIST Special Publication 800-82: Guide to Industrial Control Systems Security, Revision 2. National Institute of Standards and Technology, Gaithersburg, Maryland: NIST, May 2015,
  • NIST Internal Report 8228: Considerations for Managing Internet of Things (IoT) Cybersecurity and Privacy Risks. National Institute of Standards and Technology, Gaithersburg, Maryland: NIST, June 2019.

The term ‘threat’ is central in these requirements and thus a common understanding is established here. The terms ‘threat’ and ‘risk’ are often used interchangeably or misused.
  • ISO 27005 defines ‘threat’ as ‘A potential cause of an incident that may result in harm of systems and organization’.
  • ISO 7498-2 defines ‘threat’ as ‘A potential violation of security’.
  • CCSDS 350.8-G-1 defines ‘risk’ as ‘Possibility that a particular threat will adversely impact an information system by exploiting a particular vulnerability’.

A ‘threat’ is a function of a threat agent's capability and intent to do harm whereas ‘risk’ is a function of the probability that an organization will be targeted and the harm that might be caused. To further distinguish the difference:

  • Threat = Capability× Intent,
  • Risk= Probability× Harm.

A threat agent (or threat source) can be human or non-human and can be intentional or unintentional. All threat agents attempt to do harm against a physical or logical resource/asset. In case that the resource has one or more vulnerabilities, it can potentially be exploited by a threat agent resulting in a compromise of system confidentiality, integrity, or availability (C-I-A).

Loss of confidentiality will result in unauthorized disclosure of information. Loss of integrity will result in unauthorized modification or destruction of information. Loss of availability will result in a loss of access to critical resources. Overall, the loss of C-I-A might result in harm to an Agency's operations, assets, or individuals.

Figure 13-1 illustrates the interactions between C-I-A and the various aspects of the overall system.

Figure 13-1: Confidentiality, Integrity, and Availability Interaction

chapters.name: Common Threats Applicable to Space Missions

requirements.text:
General:

There is a wide variety of possible threats against missions. The following nonexhaustive list contains the most relevant threats for space missions.

An exhaustive list can be found in NIST Special Publication 800-30, appendix E.

Data Corruption / Modification

Applicable to: Space Segment, Ground Segment, Space-Link Communication

Description: Data Corruption/Modification refers to the intentional or non-intentional alteration of data, whether being communicated or at rest. Data corruption/modification always implies a breach of integrity. Data could be corrupted at its source, in transit to the ground system, or at the ground system. It could also be corrupted in transmission to/from or onboard a spacecraft.

Possible Mission Impact: Corruption might be a result of software failures or bugs, hardware failures, use of unauthorized software, or active attempts to change/modify data to deny its use. A corrupted spacecraft command could result in catastrophic loss if either no action occurred (e.g., command is discarded) or the wrong action was taken onboard a spacecraft. For example, if a navigation manoeuvre burn command were corrupted, the spacecraft might end up in an unusable orbit, miss an encounter with a comet/planet/asteroid, or be destroyed.

Ground System Loss

Applicable to: Ground Segment

Description: The loss of a ground system might result in the loss of data, loss of access to data in a timely manner, or loss of the entire mission.

Possible Mission Impact: A successful exploitation of a vulnerability through a physical attack might disable the ground facility and directly affect the operation of the mission and the services provided. It might also aim to overtake the facility in order to take control of the spacecraft without technically attacking the systems. Environmental factors might also result in the loss of a ground facility. Tornados, hurricanes, tsunamis, or other weather related factors could result in physical damage to the facilities or the loss of electrical power to the ground station.

Interception of Data

Applicable to: Space Segment, Ground Segment, Space-Link Communication

Description: Data transmitted to and received from spacecraft are sent over Radio Frequency (RF) communications links. All RF communications are subject to interception by listening to the specific allocated frequencies. However, RF used for spacecraft communication are potentially less susceptible to interception than common radio because of the large ground antennas and narrow beam widths used to communicate between the ground and space and, conversely, the low power and narrow beam widths used from space to ground. But this is mission dependent since all missions are different.
For example, Geo Transitory Orbit (GTO) and Geostationary Earth Orbit (GEO) would have a relatively large downlink beam width resulting in a much more easily intercepted signal. For a low-Earth orbiter, smaller dishes and power are needed, but because of short passes, tracking creates an obstacle for an interceptor. As spacecraft move towards optical communications, data interception will become more difficult, but not impossible. Someone trying to intercept optical communication would have to be very close to the narrow optical beam width.
If ground system communications are operating over public networks (e.g., the Internet) they are susceptible to interception since the data is routed through many uncontrolled resources which could be tapped.

Possible Mission Impact: Interception of data may result in the loss of data confidentiality and data privacy if the data is not encrypted. In addition to those entities authorized for the data, non-authorized entities may also gain access. The interception of data could also result in masquerade or replay attacks.

Jamming

Applicable to: Space Segment, Ground Segment, Space-Link Communications

Description: Denial of communications to and from spacecraft could be accomplished by interfering with the RF signal. This can be done by injecting noise, by transmitting on the same frequency from another source, or by simply overpowering the original source. The interference can result in link loss and loss of mission control.

Possible Mission Impact: Spacecraft commanding as well as the ability to receive science or engineering data from the spacecraft could be blocked. In addition, authorized access to system resources can be blocked, possibly delaying time-critical operations on both the ground and in space.

Denial-of-Service

Applicable to: Space Segment, Ground Segment

Description: Denial-of-service attacks would prevent authorized access to resources. Denial-of-service attacks could occur in several ways: consumption of resources (e.g., communication bandwidth, processor bandwidth, disk space, memory), disruption of system/network configurations (e.g., routing changes), disruption of state information (e.g., persistent network connection resets), disruption of network components (e.g., router or switch crashes), or obstruction/destruction of communications paths.

Possible Mission Impact: Ground systems and their networks could be greatly affected by loss of system availability which could result in an inability to control a mission or obtain data from a mission.

Masquerade

Applicable to: Space Segment, Ground Segment

Description: Authentication of an entity’s true identity is crucial for applying access control policies. When access control policies are being enforced, certain entities are allowed to perform specific actions while other entities may be denied. However, the access controls can be rendered useless if entities can lie about their true identity or can assume the identity of another entity.

Possible Mission Impact: If an instrument operator masquerades as a spacecraft operator, incorrect spacecraft bus health and status actions might result in a loss of the mission. Likewise, if an external entity can masquerade as a spacecraft operator; unauthorized commands could be transmitted to the spacecraft resulting in damage, data loss, or loss of a mission.

Replay

Applicable to: Space Segment, Ground Segment, Space-Link Communications

Description: Transmissions to or from a spacecraft or between ground system computers can be intercepted, recorded, and played back at a later time.

Possible Mission Impact: If the recorded data were a command set from the ground to the spacecraft and they are re-transmitted to their originally intended destination, they might be acted upon, potentially for a second time. If the replayed commands are not rejected, they could result in a duplicate spacecraft operation such as a maneuver burn or a spacecraft reorientation with the result that a spacecraft is in an unintended orientation (e.g., tumbling, antenna pointed in the wrong direction, solar arrays pointed away from the sun).

Software Threats

Applicable to: Space Segment, Ground Segment

Description: Users, system operators, and programmers often make mistakes that can result in security problems. Users or administrators can install unauthorized or un-vetted software, which might contain bugs, viruses, spyware, or which might simply result in system instability. System operators might configure a system incorrectly resulting in security weaknesses. Programmers may introduce logic or implementation errors which could result in system vulnerabilities or instability. External threat agents might attempt to exploit a vulnerability to inject software or configuration changes.

Possible Mission Impact: Any such software could result in loss of data, loss of spacecraft control, unauthorized spacecraft control, or loss of mission.

Unauthorized Access

Applicable to: Space Segment, Ground Segment

Description: Strong access control policies based on strong authentication provide a means by which only those entities that are authorized to perform actions are allowed to do so while all others are prevented. With no or weak access controls in place, the result might be unauthorized access to systems. Likewise, interception of data could also result in unauthorized access because identities and/or passwords might be obtained.

Possible Mission Impact: An access control breech would allow an unauthorized entity the ability to take control of a ground system or a ground system network, shut down a ground system, upload unauthorized commands to a spacecraft, obtain unauthorized data, contaminate archived data, or completely shut down a mission.

Threat Summary
Applicable Threats Security Mechanisms to Counter Threat Threat Mitigations Threat Contingencies
Data corruption - Data integrity schemes (hashing, check values, digital signatures)
- Resilient hardware		 - Secure data backups - Verify integrity of backups
Ground facility physical attack - Guards
- Gates
- Access control		 - Alternate ground facilities - Failover or hot standby to alternate site
Interception - Protection of traffic via encryption, frequency hopping, spread spectrum
- Protection of archive & distribution systems via encryption		 - Use secure transmission - Use hardened transmission facilities
Jamming - Multiple uplink paths
- Multiple access points
- Frequency hopping, spread spectrum		 - Legislation
- Monitoring
- Interdiction
- Reporting		 - Have alternate frequencies or transmission facilities available
Denial-of-Service - Loss of access to resources - Access control lists
- Rate limiting
- ‘expect’ scripting
- Service screening		 - Firewalls
- Routers
- Switches
- Intrusion Prevention Systems
- Private, segregated networks
- Encryption & authentication
- ISP ‘edge’ support
Masquerade - Strong authentication
- Access control scheme
- Vetting of staff
- No use of open networks		 - Strong authentication
- Session tokens
- Behaviour
- Timestamps		 - Intrusion Detection Systems
- Intrusion Prevention Systems
Replay - Data integrity schemes (e.g., authenticated command counter, timestamps) - Sequence numbers
- One-time passwords
- Session tokens (nonces)
- Timestamps
- Challenge-response		 - Intrusion Detection Systems
- Intrusion Prevention Systems
Software Threats - Acceptance testing
- System evaluation (e.g., IVV, code analysis)
- COTS product use
- Continuous threat Monitoring, continuous risk management
- Run-time security monitoring
- Auditing
- Software partitioning (trusted computing base)
- Supply chain confidence
 - Secure software development methodologies - Develop multiple, independent implementations from the same specification for higher assurance platforms
Unauthorized Access - Encryption of TT&C and mission data
- Authentication of commands
- No use of open networks
- Access control in control center
- Access control in cross support network
- Access control in control and dissemination systems
- Multiple access paths
- Auditing		 - Strong authentication - Session tokens (nonces)
- One-time passwords
- Multi-factor authentication		 - Intrusion Detection Systems
- Intrusion Prevention Systems
Tainted Hardware Components - Supply chain confidence
- Authenticity of hardware
- Vetted hardware suppliers
- Vetted hardware production
- Analysis of hardware functionality
- Multi-vendor hardware components		 - Diverse hardware purchasing
- Blind buy purchasing
- Random IVV testing		 - Resource utilization monitoring
- Intrusion detection
- Intrusion prevention
- Vetted back-up hardware stocks

The threat assessment needs to consider the type of the mission and what the information security threats are to that mission. It is important to consider all parts of the mission architecture during all phases of the mission as the threat profile to the mission will change as the mission progresses.

Threat Assessment shall be performed along CCSDS 350.1-G-2.

NOTE:
The threat assessment will use the outputs of the Security Policy and Security Interconnection documents (see CCSDS 350.4-G-1) to help identify attack vectors and the value of the data and assets to be protected.

chapters.name: Operation Center, Manufacturing and AIT/AIV Facilities Security, Cloud Computing

requirements.text:
The command sequences for
  1. commanding of the spacecraft,
  2. control of its sensor or sensors,
  3. control of the transmission of the data by the spacecraft to a ground segment of the operator or a person authorized by the operator,
  4. controlling the dissemination of the data directly through spacecraft,

shall be set-up, verified, transmitted in encrypted format, checked and authorized by adequate authentications using suitably declared procedures to protect them against modification by third parties.

The transmission of security relevant data by the spacecraft to a ground segment of the operator or a person authorized by the operator, the transmission of security relevant data between different locations of the operator’s ground segment and the transmission of the security relevant data from the operator to a person authorized by the operator shall be encrypted by adequate measures to up-to-date security levels to protect them against unauthorized knowledge or modification by third parties.

The operator shall take technical and organizational measures that prevent unauthorized persons access to the installations of the commanding of the spacecraft as well as to the equipment for receiving, processing and storing the security relevant data or access to the corresponding operating rooms.

The operator shall ensure adequate security screening and clearance of persons who have access to the facilities of commanding a spacecraft or to the facilities for receiving, processing and storing the security relevant data of a spacecraft.
The operator shall maintain documentation of the all applied encryption algorithms as well as authentications keys used during the mission.
The measures and procedures that will ensure the implementation of these requirements shall be part of the security policy.

To ensure protection of a mission, and security during manufacturing (especially in industry 4.0 environment) and AIT/AIV, the operations center as well as the manufacturing and AIT/AIV facilities shall maintain information security.
Information security shall be achieved by implementation of security controls.

These security controls shall include (but are not limited to):
Access Control
  • Asset Protection
  • Infrastructure Protection
  • Connection Protection
  • Physical Access Control & Monitoring
  • Access Restriction and Surveillance
  • Access Restriction to Dedicated Zones
  • Perimeter Protection and Control
  • Encrypted Local Area Networks & Isolated Systems for Mission Control
  • Access Restrictions & Role-Based Right Restriction within the Area Network
Configuration Management
  • Change Control
  • Security Hardening of Systems
  • System Cloning and Licensing
Maintenance and Monitoring
  • Redundancy Policy
  • Software & Operating Systems & Security Library Updates / Patches (Installations in Compliance to the 4-eye Principle)
  • Use of checked and regularly updated hardware and software
  • Unauthorized Change Prevention, Detection and Deterrence
  • Firewalls
  • Anti-Malware Protection
  • Incident Handling
  • Continuous Monitoring and Logging
  • Use of up to date Secure Protocol Versions & Encryptions Algorithms
  • Security Key Maintenance
  • Password Security Policies and Maintenance i.e. against Public Password Lists
  • Optional Temporary blockages of user access or permissions
Management and Support
  • Information Technology and Information Security Leadership
  • Personnel Screening
  • Personnel Training
  • Screening of Suppliers
  • Screening and quality inspections of security relevant components and systems
  • Management Awareness
  • Policies, Procedures, Instructions
  • Scheduling Restrictions
  • IT Security Metrics
  • Security Checks and Verifications
  • Mobile Device Management
  • IoT Device Management
  • Control and monitoring of service providers, suppliers, visitors/externals
  • Identification, training and application of emergency measures
Security control implementation shall consider NIST SP 800-53, NIST SP 800-82 and / or ISO/IEC 27001 controls as guideli
The security control approach shall be part of the security policy.
Any Cloud Computing or Cloud application or Cloud Data storage shall be compliant to the requirements given in BSI Cloud Computing Compliance Controls Catalogue (C5) or ISO/IEC 27017.

Every mission should define a security policy as an element of its overall mission concept definition.The system's security policy is its ‘concept of operations’ with respect to security. It outlines how the system (which may be either considered broadly as a combination of infrastructure, multiple hardware and software components, and the individuals operating and maintaining them, or considered narrowly as a particular component in isolation) is intended to operate, and what action is to be taken when it operates outside its intended parameters.

The mission security policy must be observant of any higher-level organization security policies but must clearly state:

  1. the classification and therefore level of protection of all the information (e.g., telemetry, telecommand, software, and ground systems data) associated with the mission, both live and archive,
  2. the roles of those who have access to the system,
  3. the integrity requirements of the system, and
  4. the availability requirements of the system.

In order to select appropriate security controls, organizations shall categorize the criticality and sensitivity of the information that will be handled by the system according to the criteria of confidentiality, availability, and integrity.

Information criticality and sensitivity categories shall be defined in line with NIST SP 800-30.
