National security classification regulations as well as other laws (e.g., export and copyright restrictions) controlling the handling of specific information types override organizational discretion in categorizing information.

Organizations must adopt a set of security controls and a process to implement and manage those controls in order to protect their information and information systems.

The controls selected or planned must be documented in system requirements documentation.

Security requirements derive from security policy as well as functional system requirements with implications to security. Most security controls may be classed as belonging to one of three basic types: protective, detective, or reactive.

Protective controls are measures designed to prevent a negative event from occurring, while detective controls aim to inform the organization about an event, and reactive controls are 'after the fact' measures to restore the system to nominal operation and/or collect forensic information about the nature and extent of the event.

Organizations shall also maintain a mission system's security controls throughout the lifetime of the mission.

Each organization should develop, document, and implement an organization-wide program to provide information security for the information and information systems that support the operations and assets of that organization.

ISO/IEC 27000, which provides a broad overview of information security management, calls this program an Information Security Management System (ISMS).

Each organization should develop a system security plan that references or provides a summary of the system security requirements, describes the security controls in place or planned for meeting those requirements, and describes the risk assessment of the system. The plan also describes organizational decisions for what is to be done about any discrepancies (including whether to accept risk and proceed as-is).

drds.title: System Security Plan
drds.deliveryDate: SRR; PDR; CDR; AR; ORR; FRR; LRR; GS Upgrades (if affected)

requirements.text: The system security plan also shall delineate responsibilities and expected behaviour of all individuals who access the system.

A security plan may have multiple subsystems or subordinate systems that inherit their policies and/or controls. The mission planner shall include both space and ground elements in defining security for the early stages of planning, although each shall have its own security plan as development progresses toward implementation.

A security plan shall generally describe resources under the same direct management control.

Where a complex system includes interacting elements under different management control (e.g., spacecraft and ground systems), those elements shall be described separately and interactions between them shall be documented.

Additionally, it must be assured that any shared resources (e.g., organizational processes, networks, and physical facilities), are adequate for the highest criticality and sensitivity handled.

The security plan shall follow the functional organization of the system. The process of uniquely assigning information resources to an information system defines the security boundary for that system. The security boundary shall take into account regulatory authority, trust relationships, and line management authority.
The red team shall replicate the potential adversarial threat to a given mission to assess vulnerability and to detect weaknesses.
The red team shall be fully independent of the team developing, testing or operating the system.

The red team shall apply the following methods (but is not limited to):

Hardware

  • firmware extraction via open interface (i.e. Ethernet, JTAG, serial, UART, microUSB, etc.),
  • firmware modification and injection (i.e. interrupt boot process, inject malicious code),
  • kernel privileges via targeted bit flips (i.e. repeated memory accesses in DRAM).

Software

  • static and dynamic analysis of target source code to identify undefined behaviour,
  • penetration tests (during development and in final flight configuration),
  • analyse encrypted data at rest for weak encryption implementations.

Network

  • analyse system for vulnerable access points, misconfigured firewall policies, and permissive routing policies,
  • fuzz target for undefined behaviour and undocumented features in protocol implementation,
  • analyse traffic for vulnerabilities in protocol and encryption implementation.

As part of the risk assessment Mission Essential Functions (MEFs) shall be identified, documented and prioritized by:
  • Defining explicitly the scope of the program or project by enumerating the MEFs of interest.
  • Specifying the interfaces of the MEFs to their surroundings and the external world.
  • Prioritizing the MEFs as an initial assessment of acceptable risk.
  • Understanding the priorities of the mission commander permits the cyber engineer to estimate the granularity of the cyber mapping as a function of MEF criticality.

chapters.name: Mission Mapping of Mission Essential Functions

requirements.text:
Each critical MEF shall be mapped into a number of layers that represent sub-functions, relationships, responsibilities, and systems, culminating in a logical representation of the atomic cyber processes that enable the MEF.

Mission mapping shall include the following steps:

  • Decompose the mission into its constituent components.
  • Identify all the stored-program processors in an MEF in the atomic cyber processes.
  • Identify the make and model of each processor, the fabrication technology, clock speed, storage architecture, amount of cache and primary storage, and input/output devices.
  • Define the function of each processor-sensing, computing, storing, or transmitting data.
  • Identify all data storage components within an MEF.
  • Identify all data communication among cyber processes, and between the MEF and the outside world.
  • List all the architectural layers that each processor implements.
  • List all the programs that the processor executes at each layer.
  • Characterize non-volatile storage in terms of pedigree, technology, and capacity.
  • Document the data format, speed, and protocol for each data communication process.

Vulnerability assessment shall include the following steps:
  • For each sensor, assess its potential malicious use as an entry vector into the system.
  • For each processing unit, estimate the risk based on the software it executes and the documented vulnerabilities and threats.
  • For each storage unit, estimate the vulnerabilities and threats.
  • For each data communication channel, estimate the threats to protocol and implementation vulnerabilities.
  • For each vulnerability, define its temporal and spatial properties and estimate their effects.
  • Where feasible, combine into a larger cyber process those adjacent atomic cyber processes that share storage or communication resources.
  • Compute an overall mission assurance metric as a measure of MEF susceptibility to cyber threats and as an input to the risk assessment and risk management.

To mitigate the vulnerabilities identified in the vulnerability assessment mitigation strategies shall be identified, defined and implemented.

Mitigation strategies shall focus on those atomic cyber processes, sensors, storage units, and inter-process communications that present the largest vulnerability surface for unintended cyber incidents and malicious cyber-attacks. Mitigation strategies include measures to reduce the exposure to, and impact of, a cyber compromise, such as:

  • defensive posture realignment from intrusion detection to threat denial,
  • physical and logical system isolation,
  • virtualization and MEF recomposition,
  • static threat avoidance by moving vulnerabilities out of band through system redesign,
  • domain modification through protocol flattening, just-in-time implementation, and hardware-software tradeoffs,
  • polymorphism through protocol and implementation modification,
  • agility for real-time dynamic threat avoidance,
  • hardening of the information assurance attribute of confidentiality through encryption (see CCSDS 350.0-G-2),
  • application of authentication measures,
  • redundancy and artificial diversity to protect against monoculture vulnerability,
  • compilation into hardware-critical software segments to protect against modification,
  • selective insertion of Government Off The Shelf (GOTS) technology into Commercial Off The Shelf (COTS) systems to harden against common threats.

The risk assessment shall use the output of the threat assessment to assess the likelihood of any potential impact occurring. Risk assessment shall involve assessing what vulnerabilities exist in the system that also correspond to identified threats. It shall also consider what vulnerabilities exist along all stages of the component (HW, SW, Firmware) supply chain and/or development.
NOTE:
  1. In the early stages of development, vulnerabilities may be theoretical in nature; in later stages, they will be highly dependent upon implementation details.
  2. Vulnerability along the component supply chain may enable gateways for future threats or they may cause "residuals" that may develop under certain circumstances into threats.

Risk is a function of the impact of an occurrence and the likelihood of that impact's occurrence. Impact may be considered qualitatively (e.g., low/medium/high) or quantitatively (e.g., lost revenue due to outages) according to organizational needs.
The risk assessment shall also identify, for each risk found, a mitigation strategy (to be prioritized and scheduled) or a recommendation simply to accept the risk in agreement with the customer.
Risk management implementation shall consider NIST SP 800-37 as guidelines.

Organizational policy should clearly define who is responsible for approving the system security plan.
NOTE:
By authorizing the system to operate, the associated risks will be accepted.

The applicability and usefulness of the security controls originally implemented shall be periodically re-evaluated as threats to the system change over time, and especially as system components are replaced or upgraded during normal maintenance.
Security controls shall be changed as appropriate to adapt to changes in their associated threats and specific vulnerabilities in system components.

Security controls and policies shall be adapted or updated on a regular basis based on any security issue that is recognized, becomes known or is publically announced.

Hereby, the current state of the art shall be considered and implemented.
The system security plan shall be subject to review during the major project review milestones.

The introduction of digital technology throughout the lifecycle of a space project has brought about fundamental changes in handling of product data.

These changes affect on the one hand the data and information handling in general but also it affects the long-term archiving of digital product data in particular.
Any Cloud Computing or Cloud application or Cloud Data storage shall be compliant to the requirements given in BSI Cloud Computing Compliance Controls Catalogue (C5) or ISO/IEC 27017.
Cloud Computing or Cloud application or Cloud Data storage shall not be used for any security relevant information.
For data and information access, transfer and storage up-to-date secure protocol versions and encryptions algorithms shall be applied.
Any security relevant data and information shall be stored encrypted using up-to-date encryptions algorithms and access authentication.

• ISO 15489-1 Information and documentation - Records management. Part 1: General; Geneva, ISO, 2016
  • ISO/TR 15489-2 Information and documentation-Records management. Part 2: Guidelines; Geneva, ISO, 2001

• ISO 23081-1 Information and documentation - Records management processes - Metadata for records - Part 1: Principles; Geneva ISO, 2017
  • ISO/TS 23081-2 Information and documentation - Records management processes - Metadata for records - Part 2: Conceptual and implementation issues; Geneva, ISO, 2009
  • BSI-Standard 200-1: Managementsysteme für Informationssicherheit
  • BSI-Standard 200-2: IT-GrundschutzMethodik
  • BSI-Standard 200-3: Risikomanagement
  • BSI-Standard 100-4: Notfallmanagement
  • ISO 14721 / CCSDS 650.0-M-2 Space data and information transfer systems - Open archival information system (OAIS) - Reference model. Issue 2. (Magenta Book); Washington, D.C.: CCSDS, June 2012.
  • ISO/IEC 27000 Information Security Management Systems-Overview and Vocabulary. Geneva: ISO, 2009.
  • ISO/IEC 27001 Information Security Management Systems-Requirements. Geneva: ISO, 2013.
  • ISO/IEC 27002 Code of Practice for Information Security Management. Geneva: ISO, 2013.
  • ISO/IEC 27003 Information Security Management System Implementation Guidance. Geneva: ISO, 2017.
  • ISO/IEC 27004 Information Security Management - Measurement. Geneva: ISO, 2016.
  • ISO/IEC 27005 Information Security Risk Management. Geneva: ISO, 2011.
  • VDA Recommendations 4958 T 3, Long term archiving of digital product data which are not based on technical drawings Part 3: Data model, September 2006.
  • Verband Organisations- und Informationssysteme e. V, zehn Merksätze zur revisionssicheren elektronischen Archivierung(VOI-Merksätze).

Up until recently, the long-term archiving of product data involved the creation and storage of printed documents, reports, 2D drawings etc. Without paper copies, the digital archives shall fulfil the same requirements for long-term archiving.

Key-requirements on long-term data archiving:
  1. Each document shall be properly stored in accordance with legal and organizational requirements.
  2. Archiving shall be done completely - no document shall be lost on the way to the archive or in the archive itself.
  3. Every document shall be archived at the earliest possible organizational point.
  4. Each document shall match its original and be archived unchangeable.
  5. Each document shall only be viewed by authorized users.
  6. Each document shall be retrievable and reproducible in a reasonable amount of time.
  7. Each document shall be destroyed at the earliest after expiration of its retention period, i.e. it shall be deleted from the archive.
  8. Every changing action in the electronic archive system shall be logically traced for authorized persons.
  9. The entire organizational and technical process of archiving shall be reviewable by an expert third party at any time.
  10. All migrations and changes to the archive system shall ensure compliance with all the principles listed above.
To ensure these key-requirements archival system shall be implemented in line with ISO 15489-1 & ISO/TR 15489-2.

The archival system, its maintenance, its protection against environmental as well as hacker attacks or other security threats and the long-term data mitigation shall be planned and documented in a dedicated section of the project management plan or a dedicated plan.
Suppliers of systems shall ensure that all records from their sub-tiers will be available in the system archive.

chapters.name: Security of Data & Information during Project

requirements.text: Process as well as project data and information shall be handled in compliance with the international and/ or national applicable Security Controls Frameworks standards (see 13.1).

If personal data are processed, used or stored, the obligations of the Federal Data Protection Act (Bundesdatenschutzgesetz - BDSG) as well as the Data Protection Ordinance (Datenschutzgrundverordnung DSGVO) shall be observed.
Software Security shall be handled in compliance with section 8.15.

Artificial intelligence (AI) refers to systems that display intelligent behaviour by analysing their environment and taking actions - with some degree of autonomy - to achieve specific goals.

AI-based systems can be purely software-based, acting in the virtual world (e.g. voice assistants, image analysis software, search engines, speech and face recognition systems) or AI can be embedded in hardware devices (e.g. advanced robots, autonomous cars, drones or Internet of Things applications).

In the following we will use the term AI system to mean any AI-based component, software and/or hardware. Indeed, usually AI systems are embedded as components of larger systems, rather than stand-alone systems.
Machine learning comes in several flavors. The most wide-spread approaches are supervised learning, unsupervised learning, and reinforcement learning.
Any AI shall comply to the guidelines set out by the European Commission in the framework for achieving trustworthy AI.

Develop, deploy and use of AI systems shall be in a way that adheres to the ethical principles of: respect for human autonomy, prevention of harm, fairness and explicability. Acknowledge and address the potential tensions between these principles.

Particular attention shall be payed to situations involving more vulnerable groups such as children, persons with disabilities and others that have historically been disadvantaged or are at risk of exclusion, and to situations which are characterized by asymmetries of power or information, such as between employers and workers, or between businesses and consumers.

It shall be acknowledged that, while bringing substantial benefits to individuals and society, AI systems also pose certain risks and may have a negative impact, including impacts which may be difficult to anticipate, identify or measure (e.g. on democracy, the rule of law and distributive justice, or on the human mind itself.) Therefore adequate measures to mitigate these risks shall be adoped when appropriate, and proportionately to the magnitude of the risk.

Therefore it shall be ensured that the development, deployment and use of AI systems meet the seven key requirements for Trustworthy AI:
  1. human agency and oversight,
  2. technical robustness and safety,
  3. privacy and data governance,
  4. transparency,
  5. diversity, non-discrimination and fairness,
  6. environmental and societal well-being and
  7. accountability.
NOTE:
To assess the trustworthiness of a given AI the assessment list of the the High-Level Expert Group on Artificial Intelligence (AI HLEG) may be used https://ec.europa.eu/futurium/en/ai-alliance-consultation/guidelines .

The AI Testing Lifecycle shall contain as a minimum:
  1. Analysis of Requirements
  2. TEACHING Phase
    1. Training data extraction
    2. Model Training
  3. TEST Phase
    1. Model scoring and evaluation
    2. Continuous monitoring & evaluation
Any dataset collected, stared and used shall be compliant with the requirements of the EU’s General Data Protection Regulation.
Whenever feasible, to enhance privacy wrt. to potentially sensitive or personal data, encryption, anonymization and aggregation shall be applied.
Training data and test data shall be two independent subsets of the complete dataset that will be used in the course of AI development and verification.
Any dataset or sub-dataset used for training shall be adequate for the application, accurate, sufficient (no underfitting or overfitting data) and complete for the application.

Training data shall be unbiased, wrt. to experimental and sampling bias as well as social, cultural or historical bias. This shall be ensured by application and demonstration of value equivalence (all discrete features have equal representation) and proportional equivalence (all discrete features have equal proportion compared to dependent variable).
Processes shall be implemented and documented to ensure the quality and integrity of the data (e.g. to prevent data poisoning).

To avoid algorithm bias for the AI application metaphoric testing shall be applied.
NOTE:
Metamorphic testing is a software testing technique that attempts to alleviate the test oracle problem. A test oracle is the mechanism by which a tester can determine whether a system reacts correctly. A test oracle problem occurs when it is difficult to determine the expected outcomes of selected test cases or to determine whether the actual outputs accord with the expected outcomes.

Testing of performance shall also include tests considering attribute variation (check on AI model performance on synthetic and yet real-life possible inputs) and adversarial inputs (check on adversarial inputs, i.e. those that may not occur naturally but can be mis-used by a malicious party). This testing shall demonstrate robustness, discrimination and interpretability of the AI.
Based on the testing results the accuracy of the AI model, the percentage of correct answers / outputs, shall be determines to at least statistically relevant level.
Security and privacy vulnerability shall be assessed and tested indicated in chapter 13.2.
Security testing shall demonstrate that data remains untouched and the AI system can combat any attempts by hackers.

A machine learning solution has much fewer lines of code than the classical solutions. Nevertheless there is source code. This code shall be handled and comply to the requirements imposed to any software development as given in chapter 8.
Programming of AI hardware shall always be done by apply the corresponding toolkits and guidelines of the AI manufacturer.

The GS shall be capable of supporting at least the following single functions or combination of functions:
  • Space - Ground Communications,
  • Command Generation and Telemetry Data Processing,
  • Raw (instrument) Data Processing to Level 0,
  • Mission Operations to include real-time console operations, offline engineering and trending, bus and instrument health and safety monitoring, anomaly detection and resolution and procedure development,
  • Signal, instrument, satellite and bus monitoring,
  • Instrument and satellite controlling,
  • Mission scheduling and planning,
  • Flight dynamics planning,
  • Orbit determination and manoeuvre planning,
  • Orbit propagation and determination of orbital events (e.g. eclipses, sensor blindings),
  • Routine instrument / satellite calibration support and product monitoring,
  • Satellite and instrument validation,
  • Satellite and instrument system maintenance,
  • Life of mission storage (e.g., telemetry, Enterprise Management (EM), event messages) ,
  • EM to include system control and monitoring, security management, and service desk,
  • Uplink,
  • Antenna Monitor, Control, and Test,
  • Configuration Control Maintenance,
  • General Monitoring.

NOTE:
Any ground segment activities shall comply with the applicable laws and legal regulations.
The GS shall be designed to utilize the International System of Units (SI, metric measurement system).
The GS shall have the capability to retrieve stored and on-line data, files, messages, and information.
The GS shall time stamp data and products with Universal Time Coordinated (UTC) to a resolution of 1 millisecond.
The GS shall time stamp data and products with UTC to an accuracy of 0.5 millisecond.
Each GS HW, SW and firmware configuration item shall generate status and performance data.
The GS shall assure HW, SW and firmware configuration item reaction to configuration and control commands.

The GS shall extract the telemetry parameters from the satellite telemetry channel and perform the following functions:
  • Parameter monitoring,
  • Parameter calibration,
  • Parameter integrity and validity check,
  • State interpretation,
  • Second order parameter calculations.

The SCC shall support the following telecommand functions:
  • Command generation and automation,
  • Command pre-transmission validation,
  • Command transmission,
  • Post-execution verification.
The GS shall be designed to accommodate technology upgrades and functional enhancements on a five year cycle to support a minimum system life of 25 years.
The GS shall be designed for a minimum 10 year life for signal processing equipment.
The GS shall be designed for a minimum 5 year life for all operational ground equipment except signal processing equipment.
The GS shall accommodate testing of both nominal operations and failure scenarios, including automated responses to out-of-limit conditions.
The GS shall include automated tests for validating and verifying GS functional capabilities and performance after repairs or modifications.
The GS shall allow validation of resources in the operational environment prior to use in service support.
The GS shall permit an operator to monitor and control built-in tests.
The GS shall include monitoring test points and indicators to support function verification, performance analysis, and fault isolation.
The GS shall be designed such that it is modular, extensible, extendable and open.
The GS shall allow the addition and removal of homogeneous components to the ground segment without any application SW changes.
The GS shall use modular HW (Line Replaceable Units) and SW that allows changes and enhancements to be performed without interfering with GS operations.
GS HW shall use functional modules that allow replacement to improve performance, reliability or for other reasons.
The GS shall be able to scale up by using new generations of components, even from different vendors.

The GS shall be modular/plug-and-play such that it will accommodate individual algorithm changes, as well as the deletion of existing and the addition of new algorithms, without the need for recompilation of other SW modules.
The GS shall provide the capability for increased automation of GS operations throughout the life of the program.
The GS shall be implemented such that all elements can be independently scalable by at least 300% to accommodate any future growth.
Individual GS computer processor CPU utilization shall not exceed 70%, averaged daily.
Individual GS computer processor memory utilization shall not exceed 50%, averaged daily.
The GS shall be able to accommodate heavier or lighter loads (up to 100% variation) for all functionalities and interfaces supporting product generation and distribution.
The GS design shall enable HW, SW and firmware maintenance of the GS while maintaining compliance with the functional and performance requirements of the system.
The GS shall include diagnostic tools to support maintenance of all internal GS interfaces.
The GS shall include diagnostic tools to support maintenance of all external GS interfaces.
All elements of the GS shall make all locally collected performance and status measurements available to EM.
All elements of the GS shall make all locally detected HW and SW event messages available to EM.

All elements of the GS shall make resource operational status and performance data available to EM, including: resource utilization (processing, storage, network and communications status), processing throughput, equipment configuration and availability, data accounting, data processing status, transfer status, and product status, to support operations, trending, and performance analyses.
The GS shall have the capability to export any operator designated file to removable media (e.g., thumb drive, compact disk, tape, etc.).
The GS shall have the capability to store any operator designated file to removable media (e.g., thumb drive, compact disk, tape, etc.).
The GS shall provide information and diagnostic tools, to include an online knowledge base, to isolate faults internal to the GS.
The GS shall be designed such that a failure in any function of the system does not impact the ability if redundant, back-up, or contingency instances of the functionality to perform the function.
The GS shall isolate anomalies by function and by site.
The GS shall provide components and interfaces for the maintenance of operational functions.
The GS shall ensure that future enhancements can be easily and quickly implemented.
The GS shall remain operational during all planned maintenance activities.
The GS shall operate continuously, 24 hours per day, 7 days per week throughout its operational lifetime.
The GS mean time between failures shall be greater than 1 month.
The GS mean time to restore functionality shall be less than 2 hours.

The GS design shall prevent disruption to the operational system from activities such as upgrades, routine and preventive maintenance, internal integration and testing, and external interface testing.
The GS shall perform all functions, including those occurring simultaneously, with no interference with or performance degradation of any other functionality within the GS.
The GS fault management functions shall cover automatic alarm recovery/healing functions.
The GS shall allow fallback mechanisms in case of failure system upgrade procedure.
The GS shall perform fault detection and isolation, i.e. identify when a fault has occurred, and pinpointing the type of fault and its location.
The GS shall continue to operate without interruptions upon the failure of one of its components.
The GS shall prevent propagation of failures from one component to the rest of the system.
The GS shall enable the operator to specify criteria for anomalies.
The GS shall enable the operator to create contingency procedures.
The GS shall manage contingency operations procedures.
The GS shall execute contingency operations procedures.
The GS shall correlate detected anomalies with an applicable contingency procedure for the operator to activate.
The GS shall store contingency operations procedures for the life of the mission.
The GS shall enable the reporting of anomaly investigation results.
The GS shall store anomaly investigation results for the life of the mission.
The GS shall provide complete reports of data associated with all detected anomalies for all GS components (HW, SW and firmware).
Any major or mission critical anomaly of GS shall be handled in agreement with the handling of major NCRs (see 3.5.1).
The GS shall allow commanding of the spacecraft "in the blind" when the spacecraft is not in an attitude that provides downlink.

The GS shall provide integrated configuration management of all system HW, SW and firmware elements, interfaces, interconnections, and documentation, including effective change control of processes and procedures.
The GS shall capture, archive, manage, and update the baseline configuration of the GS HW, SW and firmware in the EM.
The GS archive shall ensure long-term storage and availability in line with the requirements given in chapter 13.
The GS shall record and report configuration item descriptions and all departures from the baseline in the EM.
The GS configuration management system shall include maintenance history accounting that enables tracking, and reporting at the component, subsystem, element and GS levels.
The GS shall be able to restore past system configurations.

The GS configuration management system shall enable sharing/linking anomaly reporting and status, SW build, and history information such that configuration management system information may be queried and reported by information (data fields) contained in each of those functions.

The GS configuration management system shall enable reporting and tracking of data by, at a minimum:
  • Anomaly/Incident Report Identifier,
  • HW/SW CI Identifier,
  • HW component identifier,
  • Subsystem identifier,
  • Element identifier,
  • SW Build Identifier,
  • SW Version Number,
  • COTS identifier/nomenclature,
  • Operator,
  • Date range,
  • Problem type,
  • Verification event.
The GS configuration management system's anomaly tracking capability shall include, at a minimum, the capabilities of the existing anomaly tracking systems.
The GS shall maintain configuration controlled digital images of all operational flight code.
The GS shall maintain configuration controlled digital images of all flight code patches.
The GS shall allow ingest of flight code images from external sources.
The GS shall manage HW, SW, firmware and facility resource maintenance.
The GS shall integrate maintenance management with configuration management.
The EM shall provide for an operator retrieval of stored and online EM data from a specified time interval.
The EM shall export at operator request, selected EM data, EM logs, and software on removable physical media.
The EM shall retrieve, display, export, store for the life of the mission, and print operator-selected EM logs, EM reports, and EM data associated with all GS and satellite events.
The EM shall generate reports of operator-selected EM data for an operator-selected time-span.
The EM shall have the capability to retrieve, display, trend, export (reports), store for the life of the mission, and print (reports) of performance measurements.
The EM shall maintain established access privileges for different categories of GS operators and users.
The EM shall provide operator notification of any monitored non-nominal condition within three seconds of detection of the condition.
The EM shall retrieve and display within 10 seconds operator selected EM data and logs created within the last 90 days.

The EM shall monitor and display GS resource operational status and performance, including; resource utilization (processing, storage, network and communications status), processing throughput, equipment configuration and availability, data accounting, data processing status, and product status, to support operations, trending, and performance analyses.
The EM shall allow retrieval and analysis of archive data without impact to operational performance.
The EM shall allow automated data retrieval and analytical processing based on events or schedule.
The EM shall monitor the environmental status of facilities housing and operational ground equipment.
The EM shall monitor ground segment time delays.
The EM shall capture and record all ground segment messages.
The EM shall correlate data from GS specific host-based and network-based intrusion prevention and detection system and firewalls.
The EM shall monitor report and store the end-to-end status and performance of all GS system elements (HW, SW and firmware), networks, and communication links and antennae operations.
The EM shall log all telemetry from assets.
The EM shall provide real time textual and graphical display of system performance and status.
The EM shall supervise all GS networks and interfaces to external systems.
The EM shall provide support to network and system performance metering.
The EM shall provide the means to conduct post-maintenance operational validation testing to ensure operational readiness of a signal processing path after maintenance.
The EM shall provide an integrated Alarm, Warning & Event function that manages and logs all GS alarm, warning and event alerts.
The EM shall provide links to technical information for command constraint violations, alarms, warnings, and events.

The EM performance metrics shall derive in:
  • Notifications/warnings/alarms displayed to the satellite/instrument operators,
  • Automatic execution of satellite/instrument recovery procedures,
  • Historical archiving of satellite and communications payload performance metrics.

All alarms received from GS managed network elements shall be displayed by the EM showing:
  1. Network element identified,
  2. Network element sub-system identified,
  3. Occurrence time and date,
  4. Alarm criticality and severity level,
  5. Description,
  6. Probable cause.
The EM shall check SN telemetry against pre-defined constraints.
The EM shall allow association of system response actions with any operational constraint check or class of operational constraint check.
The EM shall store event messages of all GS and satellite events for the life of the mission.
The EM shall record and store Mission Planning, Mission Engineering, and Flight Dynamics analysis products.

The EM shall include a satellite/instrument database consisting of at least:
  1. Orbital parameter database,
  2. Satellite specific information including configuration, mass property, fuel information, sensor information, thrusters information, etc.,
  3. Instrument specific date including configuration, sensor information, etc.,
  4. Command script files required for nominal and contingent operations,
  5. Telemetry display files including conversion coefficients, derived telemetry parameters and formulas, ranging parameters, etc..
The GS shall manage access to spacecraft flight SW.
The EM shall maintain knowledge of the current state of onboard satellite (spacecraft and instrument) memory contents.
The GS shall manage spacecraft flight SW.
The GS shall manage instrument flight SW.
The GS shall provide for operator-initiated memory dumps from satellite processors.
The GS shall process memory dumps from satellite processors for the purpose of memory verification.
The EM shall maintain a current copy of each flight SW image.
The EM shall maintain current copies of all satellite tables.
The GS shall manage general satellite operations tables.
The EM shall allow the operator to retrieve and utilize all stored copies of satellite flight SW.
The GS shall generate flight SW loads for uplink to the satellite.
The GS shall verify flight SW and table loads.
The GS shall import flight SW for upload to the satellite.
The GS shall maintain synchronization of the spacecraft clock.
The GS shall be capable of decommutating flight SW log and memory file downloads from the satellite.
The GS shall verify by default all commands and check them against the restricted command list prior to being uplinked to the satellite.
The GS shall verify stored command and memory (table) loads.
The GS shall verify that all SW, stored command, and table loads transmitted to the satellite have been properly stored on board.
The GS shall have the capability to compare and confirm all flight SW, stored command and table loads transmitted to the satellite.
The GS shall verify from telemetry, command acceptance or rejection status of each command transmitted to the satellite.
The GS shall verify via available telemetry that a command transmitted to the satellite produces a change in state consistent with successful command execution.

For all real-time commands and potential operator errors in commanding, the GS shall incorporate the necessary safeguards to prevent potentially catastrophic commands from being processed by direct input into the command system, and develop detailed operational procedures to ensure all real-time commands receive analysis, verification, and proper approval before command transmission to the satellite.
The GS shall provide command constraint checking consistent with the satellite telemetry and command database.
The GS shall provide for a two-step commanding mode.
The GS shall route all commands through the designated primary command path.
The GS shall interpret the value and quality flag of a telemetry point.
The GS shall enable the operator to define and maintain in a database mission-critical parameter telemetry items (safety monitors).
The GS shall monitor operator-defined mission critical parameter telemetry items (safety monitors).
The GS shall display operator-defined mission critical parameter telemetry items (safety monitors).
The GS shall activate a distinct audible and visual alarm based on an operator-defined set of monitored mission-critical parameter telemetry items (safety monitors).
The GS shall alarm telemetry values that violate predefined database values (limit sets) as received.

In case of "automated" operation, the GS shall alarm telemetry values of mission-critical parameter that violate predefined database values (limit sets) as received by alarming the operator, who is in stand-by duty.
NOTE:
Mission-critical parameters might as well be e.g. life support parameter for ISS experiments.
The EM shall maintain an image of the current on-board status of each discrete commandable telemetered parameter.
The GS shall compare the status of discrete commandable telemetry with the ground image to determine if an uncommanded change in state has occurred.
The GS shall flag and report any uncommanded change in discrete telemetry in comparison with the ground image.
The GS shall assess, maintain and report space ground communications status, including data quality summary for all received data.
The GS shall receive, process, and route all satellite data in real-time in accordance with Consultative Committee for Space Data System (CCSDS) data standards defined in the applicable documents.
The GS shall process all downlinks from a satellite concurrently.
The GS shall receive engineering telemetry from the satellite in the form of CCSDS Transfer Frames.
The GS shall quality-check telemetry according to error detection decoding.
The GS shall plan orbit station management activities and station relocation manoeuvers.
The GS shall plan and execute satellite orbit maintenance activities.
The GS shall plan and execute orbit relocation activities to change the orbit of a satellite.
The GS shall plan post-operational mission orbit disposal activities.
The GS shall execute post-operational mission orbit disposal activities.

The GS shall determine the orbit of each satellite for all on-station mission phases, from completion of launch and orbit-raising through verification of the final post-mission orbit-raising manoeuver.
The GS shall model orbital manoeuvers with an absolute accuracy of 5% deviation relative to the predicted and actual post-manoeuver delta-V.
The GS shall determine spacecraft orbit within 120 meters.
The GS shall perform spacecraft thruster calibration for the purpose of manoeuver planning and propellant management.
The GS shall provide an alert if a secondary object comes within an operator-configurable distance from the satellite.
A catalogue of space debris ephemeris must be available at the GS for collision avoidance risk assessments and manoeuvre plannings.
The GS shall plan manoeuvres to avoid other objects in space.
The EM shall store each copy of the satellite flight SW (spacecraft and instrument) for the life of the mission.
The EM shall have the capability to retrieve, display, export, and store for the life of the mission operator-selected data.
The GS shall provide the capabilities to manage and plan propellant usage.
The GS shall provide the capabilities to predict the remaining propellant quantity on board of the satellite.
The GS shall provide the capabilities to predict the status of the on-board memory based on the planned activities.
The GS shall provide the capabilities to predict the status of the on-board batteries based on the planned activities.
The GS shall provide the capabilities to predict the end of mission.
The GS shall allow creation of plans for decommissioning.
The GS shall provide a development environment for GS SW development and checkout for all GS elements.
The GS development and Integration and Test environments shall be independently and simultaneously fully functional from the IF Switch through the GS.
The GS development environment shall provide the selectable capability to capture and store logs, configurations, performance data, and other artifacts associated with development activities.
The GS development environment shall provide tools to enable the change, recompilation, and execution of any segment/module of the source code from any GS element.
The GS development environment shall provide the capability to develop, modify and checkout the integrated operation of all GS databases, tables and configuration files.
The GS development environment shall have access to engineering telemetry data as it becomes available to the GS.
The GS shall provide an off-line training environment identical in HW and SW to the operations environment.
The GS shall enable instructors to induce anomalies in the training environment.
The GS shall replicate the operations control center environment and interfaces in the training environment.
The GS shall enable HW and SW maintenance training in the training environment.
The GS shall enable operations training in the training environment.
The GS shall enable ingest of operational data in real-time or recorded modes into the training, test, simulation, and development environments.
The GS shall conduct a training programme for its operators, simulating nominal operation, critical events and anomalies.
The GS shall have multi-layered secur
The GS shall provide the capability for physical network isolation of the full capability to command and control the satellite, process telemetry and EM.
The GS shall validate the unique identity and then authenticate operators and Users attempting to access the system.
The GS shall implement automated enforcement of password requirements.
The GS shall prevent external access into GS's internal networks except as appropriately mediated.
The GS shall restrict access to privileged functions based on user authorization levels.
The GS shall restrict access to security-related information and functions to explicitly authorized users.

The GS shall be designed to enforce the principle of "least privilege" so that authenticated users are limited to accessing only those system objects required for the normal performance of their duties.
The GS shall employ multi-factor identification and authentication that is separate from the administrative network.
The GS shall limit the number of failed user account access attempts prior to locking out the account.
The GS shall have the capability to limit the number of concurrent sessions any one user can establish at any one given time.
The GS shall monitor and control all methods of remote access to the GS.
The GS shall scan for vulnerabilities in the GS.
The GS shall scan networks to detect new devices without disrupting normal operations.
The GS shall manage operational networks consistent with all security and access control requirements.
The GS shall include anti-virus, anti-malware and Host based Intrusion Prevention System (HIPS) functions within the development, integration and test, and operations environments.
The GS shall allow automatic updates of security configuration information.
The GS shall allow SN operators to update security configuration information.
The GS shall allow separate security domains on a per application basis.
The GS shall isolate security functions from non-security functions.
The GS shall prevent unauthorized and unintended residual information transfer.
The GS shall protect against or limit the effects of denial of service (DoS) and distributed denial of service (DDoS) attacks.
The GS shall provide data integrity, maintaining and assuring the accuracy and consistency of data over its entire life cycle.
The GS shall ensure authenticity, i.e. that its data, transactions, communications or documents are genuine.
The GS shall protect the integrity of transmitted information.
The GS shall protect the confidentiality of transmitted information and prevent the disclosure of information to unauthorized individuals or systems.
The GS shall implement cryptographic mechanisms conform to state of the art.
The GS shall maintain duplicate synchronized datasets.

The GS shall maintain a current, accurate inventory of all IoT devices, which shall include their relevant characteristics throughout the devices’ lifecycles in order to use that information for cybersecurity and privacy risk management purposes.
The GS shall Identify and eliminate known vulnerabilities in IoT device software and firmware in order to reduce the likelihood and ease of exploitation and compromise.
The GS shall prevent unauthorized and improper physical and logical access to, usage of, and administration of IoT devices by people, processes, and other computing devices.
The GS shall monitor and analyse IoT device activity for signs of incidents involving device security.
The GS shall prevent access to and tampering with data at rest or in transit that might expose sensitive information or allow manipulation or disruption of IoT device operations.
The GS terrestrial digital communications shall conform to state of the art internet protocol standards.
The GS shall encrypt communications when required by security policy.
The GS shall process commands by satellite ID.
The GS shall supervise applications communications status between external elements and the GS.
The GS shall supervise network communications status between external elements and the GS.
The GS shall continuously monitor telecommunications traffic for security incidents and anomalies.
The GS shall continuously monitor GS communication and computer components for security incidents or anomalies.
The GS shall control the flow of information within the system and between interconnected systems.
The GS shall alert operations personnel of security incidents or anomalies.
The GS shall provide an automated reporting system that identifies all assets being protected and their status.
The GS shall allow performance of penetration testing by an approved independent entity who can do so without impact to operations.
The GS Antenna System shall have security barriers and / or fences installed around any Antenna System structures and equipment deemed mission critical.
The GS shall have door access monitoring and notification for exterior doors and doors to areas deemed mission critical.
The GS shall provide exterior doors that have non-removable hinges and high security mechanical or electronic locks.
The GS Antenna System shall have CCTV security monitoring / video surveillance capability at all external access points (gates, doors).
The GS shall have exterior lighting at entrances and exits.
The GS exterior lighting shall be adequate for night time surveillance and image recording.
The GS shall provide the ability to monitor and control the video surveillance system.
The GS shall implement adequate measures to prohibit vandalism of the facilities and equipment.
The GS shall be able to continue mission-essential SN operations during an emergency situation for a minimum of 10 days.
The GS security shall be handled in line with chapter 13. GS SW security shall be handled in line with chapter 8.

The GS indoor equipment shall be operational without service degradation under the following environmental conditions:
  • Temperature: from 10 ºC to 40 ºC,
  • Maximum humidity of 95 %.

The GS outdoor equipment shall be operational without service degradation under the following environmental conditions:
  • Temperature: from -40 ºC to 60 ºC,
  • Maximum humidity of 100 % condensing,
  • Maximum rain, fog, or mist of 30 mm/h,
  • Snow: 30mm,
  • Maximum Wind speed of 160 km/h,
  • Blowing dust, sand & liquid,
  • Solar radiation insolance: 7kWh/m2 per day,
  • Atmosphere: salt, pollutants and contaminants as encountered in coastal and industrial areas,
  • Pressure: from sea level to 3000 m altitude,
  • Seismic pressure: up to 5 (Richter scale).

The GS outdoor equipment shall survive without degradation:
  • sustained winds up to 250 km/h,
  • Snow: 30cm,
  • Ice accumulation (0.3cm /hour).
The GS outdoor equipment shall have a lightning protection system.
The GS outdoor equipment shall be corrosion protected.
The GS shall be compliant with relevant EMC regulations over the coverage area.
The GS shall be compliant with safety applicable regulations over the coverage area.
The Security and IT Security approach shall be documented in the security policy, which is part of the mission concept, and in the System Security Plan.

requirements.text: The purpose of emergency & disaster management is to establish for the project a planned response to localized emergencies to protect lives and property.
Emergencies can arise from natural disasters of from human activities that are intentional or unintentional and have the potential for creating devastating destruction.
Disasters are distinguished from emergencies by the greater level of response required.

NOTE:
To cover the required measures by e.g. activities & documentation required for ISO 9001 certification (i.e. process-oriented risk management) is possible.

An emergency plan shall be established, which, based on a dedicated risk assessment for the organisation, facilities and programmes & projects, addresses at least the following scenario:
  • Fire emergencies,
  • Emergency evacuations,
  • Power cuts,
  • Water (broken pipes, leaking roofs, blocked drains, fire extinguishing),
  • Technical disasters (e.g. machine or facility failures or down-times, power or supply media outage, backup failure, system failures and IT security planning, incl. massive hacker or virus/worm/malware/ransomware attacks against the IT systems & networks, loss of (technological) data) ,
  • Material releases:
    • Hazardous materials release
    • Biohazardous materials release
    • Chemicals spill or release
    • Toxic Gases release
    • Release of explosives
  • Contamination of facilities and / or storages,
  • Breakdown of (hazardous) technical facilities or installations,
  • Medical emergencies,
  • Safeguarding of transports (internal, external, as well as potential customs examinations),
  • Severe weather (e.g. flooding, hurricanes, lightning storms),
  • natural disasters (e.g. earthquakes),
  • Burglary, larceny, vandalism,
  • Expiration of essential certificats, obsolescence etc..
  • collision avoidance warnings
  • loss of satellite control and / or communication link
  • urgent space cyber security warnings (e.g. non-friendly close approaches)

The emergency plan shall:
  • Include preparedness and response plans and procedures for all relevant emergencies and threats (natural, biological, chemical, technical and human),
  • Addresses the needs of staff, visitors, facilities and hardware,
  • Include a substitution plan for key personnel and a verifiable plan for the backup of key personnel,
  • Specifies how to protect, evacuate, and recover structures, and hardware in the event of a disaster (i.e. emergency response procedures),
  • Includes evacuation plans and routes (also for hardware) and assembly areas for people,
  • Include emergency contact information,
  • Establish responsibilities and response action planning for disaster assistance and rescue team,
  • Establish an emergency training programme for staff, disaster assistance and rescue team,
  • Establish inspection and maintenance planning wrt. to potential hazards,
  • Establish the location, use and maintenance planning for emergency notification systems including detectors and alarms, protection equipment, emergency equipment.
In addition the emergency plan shall establish the first post-emergency actions, e.g. indication on official notification and reporting duties and protocols, and recovery operations.
All procedures laid out or referenced in the emergency plan shall be fully tested before a real-life incident and adequate, regular trainings of the personnel shall be established.

The supplier shall response within his PA-Plan with a detailed applicability/compliance matrix to each paragraph of this PA-Requirement Document. The following abbreviations shall be used for the COMPLIANCE STATUS information:
  • Y = yes, full compliant
  • N = not compliant (the reasons of noncompliance are inserted into column REMARKS)
  • P = partial compliant (all deviations are inserted into column REMARKS)
  • N/A = not applicable (the reasons for not applicability are inserted into column REMARKS)
The CROSS-REF column shall give clear cross-reference to the applicable paragraph of the PA-Plan and/or to applicable in-house documents.
